description: [NAME] was removing the bucket on a stationery JCB and the bucket swung and amputated the his middle finger on his right hand just passed the 1st knuckle , once at hospital they amputated it to the 2nd knuckle .

A site operative named <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> had his middle finger amputated and the index and fingers broken . His glove got entangled in the rotation of a drill bit . The rotation of the drill bit caused the amputation of his middle finger above the knuckle and broke his index and forefingers . This happenened when drilling a concrete pile structure with a masonry bit for installation & embedment of reinforcment in the pile .

A concrete strucure has been created in the shape of a new memorial feature and this was being clad with granite cladding in various shapes and sizes.The cladding to the vertical sections had been applied and coping stones were being lifted to the top of flank walls when the accident happened.The plant being used to lift the copings was a vaccum lift which was in turn attached to a excavator , the pieces were being lifted in sequence as shown on the drawings . Three number copings had been previoulsy lifted and when the fourth was being lifted into place the IP was not happy with the position and look of the coping the machine lifted the piece out of position to relay.The piece of granite then fell from the vaccum lift and landed on the IP left hand causing injury .The IP attended hospital where it was established he had a crush injury to his left index fingure which resulted in partial removal of the finger between the nail and first joint , the adjacent finger was crushed also and needed treatment .

Tarmaced the road ,proceeded to roll with a handheld motorised roller . The reverse leaver jammed on squashing my hand into railings resulting in the loss of the top of my right hand thumb above the knuckle . Equipment appeared to be defective . I am self employed sub contracting for [Name] , I do not work for any one else and get weekly payslips from [Name]. Although I am self employed I regard myself as employed by [Name] I am not sure if [Name]have already reported this to riddor but being self employed I feel I may be the responsible person. I do not own my own equipment or machinery . I do not know who the equipment I was using belonged to it was hired equipment.

On <NAME>  <NAME>  at approximately 15 :50 ; <NAME>   parked the all-terrain forklift truck in front of <NAME> 5 and raised the boom to at or near its full extension . There was no load on the forks at the time . <NAME> <NAME> left the cab of the forklift with the engine turned off for a number of minutes . Upon returning to the vehicle <NAME> <NAME> re-entered the cab ( it has not been confirmed if the engine was started or not ) . The forklift then began to tip to its left hand side and overturned . The vehicle came to rest with the cab door against a steel skip and the boom on the roof of plot No. 5 . <NAME> <NAME> sustained significant injuries to the little figure of his left hand . He was removed from the cab of the vehicle by other operatives on site without the need for emergency services . First aid was given on site by our first aider <NAME> <NAME> and a passing member of the public . An ambulance was called but cancelled and <NAME> <NAME> was taken by car to the local A & E department by his son <NAME> <NAME>  who also works on the site .

Injured person is a joiner ( <NAME> <NAME> 3 : <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ) and was working with his father , also a joiner ( <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ) cutting two pieces of upvc soffit using a hand held rip snorter circular saw in order to cut this to the appropriate width . His father was operating the circular saw whilst his son held the other ends of the soffits and had partially completed the cut along the length of the soffits .His son placed his hand beneath the soffits in order to grasp hold of the cut ends resulting in his left little finger and palm coming into contact with the blade of the circular saw.The injured person was taken to hospital where his left little finger was surgically amputated at the first knuckle and also sustained severed tendons to the palm of his left hand .

Machine driver was securing short lengths of gas main pipe together with fine braid rope and happened to be blocking a site road . The site telehandler required access past the area , impatiently and repeatedly sounded his horn . the machine driver , who had not knotted the rope got flustered , and keeping hold of the untied , loose end of the rope , got into the cab of his <NAME> and attempted to move . The rope caught in the machine 's wheel and , as it was wrapped round his thumb for extra grip , has removed the digit .

Using  Makita chop saw to cut mitre on a length of architrave . left hand , which was holding the architrave , slipped into the saw blade causing lacerations to the index finger on the left hand and partial amputation damaging bone tendons and nerves to the middle finger of the left hand all the injury 's were caused by the Makita chop saw .

Whilst laying a beam and block floor the operative was supplying his colleague with blocks . When moving the blocks , one had caught on a beam and the operative had not noticed so when he went to place the next block his finger was trapped between two blocks . The sub-contractors will receive a toolbox talk to warn of the dangers when handling concrete blocks .
Hoist car access hatch caught by the wind , closing down onto a hoist erector's thumb , causing amputation to a section of his left thumb .

Injured person was assisting with the dismantling of a specialist aluminium tower that supports construction hoists . Whilst receiving aluminium tower components ( legs ) into the hoist car from above him ( through the hoist hatch ) , an aluminium insert bolt was removed , allowing the insert to travel inside the tube . The injured person had positioned his finger in one of the bolt holes at the lower end of the component ( leg ) , when the insert made contact with his finger , breaking the bone . The injured person was then taken to [NAME] [NAME] , who then transferred him to [NAME] .  All inserts are now having captive pins , permanently installed in the components ( legs ) . A safety bulletin will be issued to all other employees , advising them of the incident and the remedial improvements .

The injured party was preparing to start work for the day and was attempting to unload a roller from a trailer which was positioned on a slope . On removing the trailer coupling pin , the trailer moved forward suddenly , causing the coupling mechanism to jolt and resulting in the top of <NAME> <NAME> 's right-hand little finger finger being jammed in the mechanism. <NAME> was taken to hospital immediately by a colleague , where his wound was treated before he was discharged . He has been advised that he wil need to go back on <NAME> (  <NAME> ) for surgery to remove his damaged finger cleanly back to the middle joint.All workers on the highway repairs contract have been briefed on the importance of safe unloading practice , in particular ensuring that vehicles and trailers are on a level surface before attempting any loading or unloading , and making sure that all brakes and safety mechanisms are working and are engaged appropriately during operations .
End of left hand index finger made contact with chop saw blade having completed cut to timber prior to guard fully returning to safe position ; end of finger severed .

A plywood sheet was being attached to a mechanical cable hoist at ground level by the operative . A second operative was operating the hoist from the scaffolding at roof level . The operative at ground level adjusted the cable just prior to hoisting . The third finger on his left hand became trapped as the cable tightened and was severed at the tip . First aid was administered at the scene and the injured operative was taken to hospital .

Unloading outrigger mats off wagon by use of a hiab . All trained personnel present . Chains caught between mat and hand resulting in hand injury . All staff told of the risks involved and put safety as always a priority
Helping guide a part of machinery into another part , when connected both parts dropped causing a entrapment of the finger .

Cutting/mowing maintenance of grassed area on new build site . The grass was in excess of 18 inches in height and the mower was having difficulty in cutting at the set height . Attempted to alter the cutting height of the petrol driven grass mower . Failed to confirm that the cutting blade had been immobilised . Left hand came into contact with the mower 's blade underneath the machine as it was lifted to change the height of the front wheels.A refresher toolbox talk to go out regarding isolation of machinery/moving parts when undertaking maintenance work .

Person cut his finger while cutting a deck end panel with a skill saw.  The deck end panel was on top of a kitchen base unit.  Whilst cutting it, the panel slipped and the person went to grasp the panel as it was falling and his hand slipped onto the rotating blade cutting off his left hand index finger.

He was asked to saw some timber on a machine but took it apon himself to go on another saw which he is not qualified to go on . He turned around to talk to somebody and his thumb hit the blade severing it .
piece of steel rolled over and trapped tip of ring finger on left hand

Whilst #using a graft to dig a trial pit the IP 's right hand which was gripping the handle of the graft collided with the top of the upright wooden handle of the scissor digger being held by his colleague in the trial pit , resulting in the crushing , under force , of the tip of his little finger of his right hand . The IP was taken to hospital where the tip of his right hand little finger was amputated just below the nail .

The IP was tightening a set of bolts when the clamp closed completely . IP had his little finger between the bracket plates , the force of the plates snapping together severed the top of his little finger above the top knuckle .

[NAME]and [NAME] were installing N2W2 safety barrier fencing . The works on the barrier began on the morning of the incident.They had received a site induction and read and signed the RAMS on [Date]  The barrier posts were being driven into the ground using a 5t dumper driving rig owned by [NAME] .For standard posts the operation consists of one employee positioning the post and another employee lowering the driving head into position on top of the post from the operating position of the dumper . The first employee then moves away from the operation whilst the post is driven.To install the end posts a a second top post ( known as a dolly post ) is positioned on top of the post to be driven as the profile of the post does not permit it to fit into the driving head . The dolly post is then held in place whilst the driving mechanism is operated . The dolly post being used did not fit tightly onto the first post and had to be held firmly to keep it straight . At approximately 11am , whilst holding the dolly post during driving , the dolly slipped out from under the driving head and the driving arm drove down , crushing [NAME] hand onto the bottom of the dolly post. [Name] saw this happen from the operator’s position and turned the machine off immediately . [NAME] asked [NAME] to call an ambulance so he called 999 . Almost immediately [NAME] and [NAME] ( [NAME] employees ) arrived and immediately began applying first aid to [NAME]. It was decided to drive [NAME] directly to hospital rather than wait for an ambulance as the hospital is close by . [NAME] underwent [NAME] and had his index finger amputated and breaks in three other fingers.Investigation has highlighted that this is a common procedure within [NAME] and the safety barrier industry as a whole . Dolly posts are when posts do not fit into the driving head , or when the driving head does not reach low enough . Complacency may have led to this practice not being reported as a potential risk . -The risk assessment did not highlight the use of dolly posts as a potential risk . The risk assessment controls for the driving rig state : “At no time during the driving operation will anyone be holding the post . ” “No person except the rig operator is to encroach within 5m of the driving operation .”-The employees involved deviated from the controls identified in the risk assessment and did not report their inadequacy .Preventive [NAME] rig to be replaced with alternative suitable rig -Alternatively , provide a more suitable dolly post that does not require holding in position.-RAMS to be revised to highlight the correct procedure for driving posts that do not fit into the driving head and the correct use of dolly posts if they are required. - Safety Alert to be issued

“Amendment to  Incident Reference Number  ####".  The IP was undertaking maintenance and inspection of the horizontal cable system that runs at approximately 2100mm above the platform on the wing jigs .Prior to the IP being on the jig , the hydraulic platforms had been raised and a wing had been removed ; it appears one of the sliding floor sections had caught up on the horizontal cable .The IP had spotted this and to reduce or stop damage to the cable system had attempted to free the cable . As he did so , the sliding section dropped and severed the top 30-40mm off his right hand index finger , cutting between the first and second knuckle . The IP received first aid treatment at the plant , further medical assistance was provided at the [Name] of [NAME] [NAME] . Reattachment of the finger was not possible . He remained in hospital overnight and was operated on the next morning to close and seal the wound.The incident is being thoroughly investigated by [NAME]  ( Contracted to [NAME]) .

Site operative was manoeuvring a MEWP into position to place on charge - the model was a <NAME> <NAME> 14 2012 model . When in position IP raised the entry swing down bar into the up position and proceeded to descend from the platform , as he did this he had his right hand on the vertical member of the cage , at this point the swing bar came down shut and trapped his right hand and severing the tip of his third ( ring ) finger . IP was taken to <NAME> <NAME> where the injury was treated and it was established that the finger was also fractured . IP returned to hospital on the <NAME> to undergo surgery to re-attach the finger tip . The operation went well and it is now a period on monitoring to establish if the surgery was successful . During the accident investigation it was established that there have been modifications made to the swing bar on later models to prevent this type if injury from occurring .

The injured operative was in the process of installing drainage in an excavated track using 225mm plastic pipes . He was working with his colleague in order to join two sections of pipe ; when his colleague pushed one section of the pipe in order to make the joint , the injured operative caught his finger between the pipes . The accident resulted in the operative losing the tip of his ring finger on his left hand .

The operative was cutting sheets of wood/timber , using a battery operated skilsaw , when at some point the blade made contact with his wedding ring finger & ultimately sliced the tip of the finger off ( from the nail to the tip ) .

Amendment to incident <NAME> dated <NAME> - the injured party is now to have the end of his little finger amputated.The injured party was holding a piece of wood whilst a colleague operated a hand drill into the wood ( at 1430 hours on the day ) . The hand drill slipped and injured his left little finger ( cut and ripped into finger ) . There was a misinterpretation of RIDDOR by <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> assuming a finger did not need reporting ( not realising over 7 days counted ) and hence the late submission on the original form .

<NAME> have hired a new tow behind water bowser for supressing the dust on site . A bowser was ordered by and delivered to <NAME> by there supplier.It was agreed that <NAME> and <NAME> would share the responsibility of undertaking this operation depending on the area the dust was to be suppressed . <NAME> asked <NAME> to carry out this operation on the afternoon of <NAME> 1/7.The bowser was located next to the site gate 1 . The jockey stand was not working ( it was bent and unable to be moved ) and the bowser was being left with 2 HB2 kerbs and a small piece of timber supporting under the towing hitch . The bowser was not hitched up to a vehicle , and <NAME> <NAME> was filling with water ready to carry out the operation . When approx , half full the bowser tipped up backwards pushing the towing eye in the air . <NAME> tried to pull the bowser back down to level with the towing eye back on the kerb stand but the bowser was too heavy , so <NAME> ( <NAME> operative ) put his weight on it also . At this point the water shifted in the bowser , which in turn brought the bowser crashing back down towards the kerbs . <NAME> hand was trapped between the kerb and towing eye , and when pulling his hand away , his glove and top of index finger remained trapped in situ. I was informed immediately by <NAME> staff . The ambulance was called and were there within 10 minutes . <NAME> was assessed in the ambulance and then taken to A & E <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> <NAME> went to the hospital with him , where it was found that the finger could not be saved , and that he would need an operation the following day to remove the finger to the knuckle (amputation ).The bowser has since been defected by <NAME> and put out of use .

On  <NAME>, <NAME> <NAME> were installing secant wall piles and carrying out pile attendance works as part of their role as principal contractor on the <NAME> <NAME>  project for their client <NAME> Following the morning task briefing at 0745hrs site operations commenced , secant piles were being installed using 2no <NAME> piling rigs and pile attendance operations were being carried out . As part of the pile attendance works pile mat maintenance was required so the site team had ordered 3no loads of 6F2 crushed material from the haulage department to reinstate pile platform where required . A <NAME> ( haulage sub-contractor ) lorry registration number <NAME> <NAME> delivered one of the three loads to site at approx . 1115hrs , the vehicle was banked onto site by a traffic marshall from <NAME> <NAME> site entrance and directed to where the load was to be tipped . Following the tipping of the load the lorry was then to be loaded with pile arisings using a CAT 13 ton excavator . Prior to loading with pile arisings the lorry driver asked the traffic marshall (IP) , to check the tail gate of the vehicle . The IP proceeded to walk behind the vehicle out of sight of the driver to check the tailgate and noticed that there was debris gathered in the area where the securing clamps close on to . The IP then used his hand to begin clearing the debris without communicating to the lorry driver what he was doing at which time the driver also operated the air switch thus causing the clamps to close and crush the IPs right hand index finger. Works in the area were ceased immediately , first aid was provided to the IP and emergency services were called who then arrived and took the IP to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> hospital . The IP was then given surgery and the finger was amputated to the second knuckle .

Whilst fitting side perling bars in terex high lift approximately 14 feet in the air . <NAME><NAME> was supporting the bar in position while <NAME> <NAME> was about to insert locating bolts . One end of the perling bar slipped from its position causing the bar to pivot around <NAME><NAME> 's supporting hand . This then created a scissor action bewteen the perling bar and hangar frame where <NAME> <NAME> 's hand was place . This resulted in the left index finger being amputated just below the finger nail in a clean cut . <NAME><NAME> was wearing protective gloves .

Cutting length of timber inside a site cabin whilst carrying out repairs with a hand held battery powered skillsaw - blade came into contact with his finger- of hand that was holding section of timber- cut top of index finger off . [NAME] was taken to [NAME] [NAME] hospital in [NAME] by ambulance where his severed finger tip was successfully sewn back on .

The IP our Senior site manager , decided to straighten up two steel chanels/beams that had been delivered earler that day to assist the slinger . Only two chanels on top of the low stack needed to be straightened out.The IP bent over and picked up one end of the mis-aligned chanels on the top of the low stack of stored channels to swing it over and lay it in line with the channels beneath . A lower chanel from the stack came up suddenly on the underside of the channel being held/lifted and cut in a scisssor action the tip of the IP 's finger off and broke the tip of the bone of the finger too . (his left hand middle finger ) The IP was wearing lightweight gloves as per our in house PPE policy to protect against abrasions and minor cuts but they offered no protection in this incident as the tip of the glove was cut off along with the tip of the finger.The IP attended hospital and was kept in overnight for an operation to remove the remaining tip of the injured finger and repair the damage . To prevent similar incidents the site team have been advised that two operatives must move/stack this type of material and that this accident and the circumstances leading to it are relayed to operatives that they may be aware that stored materials can move with out warning . Also that when matrials are unloaded from delivery vehicles that mechanical assistance from the delivery vehicle is used to store the items correctly and safely before it leaves site .

Our operative was in the process of dismantling a propriety cantilever loading bay gate , as he was carrying out this task he dismantled one side of the gate and then went to the dismantle the other side of the gate and the component slipped thus trapping his pinky in the component , causing injury to his pinky .

<NAME> picked up a wood splinter of approx 3mm of size from an unknown source . Infection set in , with the result of going to A & E after seeing local doctors who prescribed anti-biotics to address the infection . On admission to hospital , he was advised that he should have been there a week ago due to the extent of the infection which had set in resulting in the loss of two fingers on his left hand. Reason we have not submitted the RIDDOR report before now is due to us not knowing if this was a work related injury which still reamains uncertain . Our health and safety consultants , <NAME> <NAME> ( <NAME> ) main contact <NAME> <NAME> , reported this by telephone call to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> on the first working week of <NAME>.Due to this unusual incident and the extreme outcome , we were unable to obtain information until recently from <NAME> .

Accident unwitnessed [NAME] contractor working around the corner on his own from other contracters so no one witnessed . Contractor too shocked to explain how it happened.Paramedics on sight dealt with injury straight away and sent contractor to the hospital. Attended A+E after being seen by paramedic

Telephone report : The IP and <NAME> <NAME> were lowering the trailer onto the tow- hitch . The IP lifted the hande on the trailer to lower it down onto the ball joint , this moved slightly , caught his glove finger and the IP jammed his finger . When the IP pulled his finger away he thought he had broken his finger , when he took his glove off he noticed the tip of his finger was hanging off . <NAME> took the IP to the <NAME> <NAME> hospital in <NAME> . The IP was left at the A &E and was then referred to the <NAME> <NAME> in <NAME> .  <NAME> took the IP to the hospital and waited while the IP had an operation under local anaesthetic to remove the end of his finger . The IP was given anti-biotics and was sent home and told to return in 2 weeks time to get it checked out .

Steel road plates had been lowered onto timber bytes across a shallow trench . , The road plate in question was being lifted manually to release the timber underneath , the operative involved unfortunately trapped his finger under the road plate as it was lowered causing the removal of part of his index finger on his left hand , ( the nail section ) . We have in place a health & safety policy with specific RAMS for operations and toolbox talks , we have internally investigated the matter and will communicate to all our operatives a reminder of procedures in this particular operation .
DP was found wedged inside a vertical plastic pipe on a construction site. He had died from asphyxiation.
DP suffered poisoning by dichloromethane fumes whilst fixing bathroom floor tiles

The DP was abseiling down the side of the building to fix down conductor tape for a lightning protection system, wearing a harness and all the relevant PPE. DP got into difficulties whilst suspended by a rope
down the side of a building. He was recovered by the emergency services but subsequently died

The engineer was in the process of grinding a metal support to take a AC unit. At the time of the incident the engineer was wearing full PPE. A splinter of metal hit the engineer and penetrated his right eye causing swelling to the eye, resulting in closure.

How the injury happened and injuries sustained : Removing elastic straps to release the tarpaulium from back of vehicle to gain access to the petrol cans Bending down to release elastic bungee strap it has slipped out of gloves whipping across both eyes causing severe pain and sickness.  Follow up actions : All grounds maintenance operatives instructed immediately after the accident to wear safety eye protection whilst removing vehicle covers and removing any form of machinery from vehicles . Operatives have been advised not to use the mud guard hook

After securing wooden end of setting out string line between the end of wall and a corner flag stone , the line was tort to provide setting out of stonework . Whilst adjusting corner flag stone the wooden end of the string line dislodged and struck operative just below right eye causing a cut and swelling . Operative went to hospital where he received stitches to the wound , it was also discovered he had a chip to the socket bone and damage to the lens reducing vision and dialation of the pupil . Operative returned to work 3 days after accident but is to return to hospital for tests to see if there is any permenant damage once swelling has gone down .Following the accident we have reviewed method statement and risk assessment to include the possible dangers and caution required when using string lines , we have carried out a tool box talk and made eye protection glasses available .

Person sustained injury to the right eye after the a drill bit they were using got stuck on a piece of material and then immediately shattered , a piece of the drill bit managed to hit the eye . Action taken to prevent similar incidents occurring is firstly to take the drill out of service and re-inspect for any damage before any further use , and an accident investigation is being carried out by [NAME], recommendations from that will be submitted to the MD and site manager a toolbox talk reinforcing the site rules policy/procedures and site instructions for PPE

The IP was working on a new bungalow roof with an experienced roofer , installing felt , batten and tiles . He was in the process of cutting bands which hold a number of tiles together . Despite the IP being issued a stanley knife to cut the tile bands he decided to use a broken / sharp tile edge to cut the band . Unfortunately a piece of the broken tile he was using dislodged and went into his eye causing a laceration . The IP was taken to hospital where his injury was assessed and it deemed necessary to operate to stitch the wound . The IP left hospital the following day after a successful surgical operation . Following on from this issue all employees have been issued a tool boxTalk to use the correct tools provided to complete the task in hand ( in this case a stanley knife to cut tile bands ) .
sheeting of skip with sheet bungee cord snapped , causing eyelet of sheet coming loose and hitting eye

Two men on site were removing existing floorboards in a room in the house . One of the men removed his protective eye goggles because of sweat bothering him . During the lifting of the floorboards some debris flew up into his face and went into his eye . Advised to always wear protective goggles when doing this kind of demolition .

I am writing to you to inform you of an incident that took place on <NAME>, on a large project (value 72m ) at <NAME> <NAME> . My employer has not supported me . I am still waiting to hear back from my employer . The incident that took place caused me to be off work for over three weeks . Has this incident been reported to the HSE ? During a meeting on  <NAME> with several facade/site Managers a laser pen /Projector pointer was pointed directly into my left eye . As a direct result it caused me considerable pain on the day . I returned to work the following day as normal , however I was still experiencing some severe pain and soreness in my left eye . I contacted my opticians as the pain persisted . My opticians advised that I need to seek immediate medical attention as laser pens can cause considerable damage to the eye . My optician advised me to go straight to the closest A&E . Following this advice I went directly to A & E department . I was seen by a doctor who advised me to pick up my glasses ( my contact lens had fallen out of eye ) and go immediately to <NAME> eye hospital . An eye specialist at <NAME> eye hospital examined my eye and asked me a number of questions about the incident . The specialist asked me to return the following morning for further tests and for a full scan of my eye to determine if any damage had been caused to the retina . The specialist gave me a prescription for some eye drops to reduce the soreness . <NAME> eye hospital asked me to return on <NAME>  for a further examination of my eye and to measure the eye pressure . My eye pressure was 29 in my left eye and 26 in my right eye , and the nurse that examined me commented " this is sky high and should be 20 or lower " . This obviously concerned me and the nurse advised me to rest . I am notifying you of this as the doctor that saw me at the eye hospital commented that if this was a deliberate act , it constitutes a serious criminal offence . This obviously concerned me and I would like to bring this to your attention . Please do not hesitate to contact me if you require any further details . Regards <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> / <NAME> at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> .
<NAME> <NAME> was knocking a nail into the wall and it flew into his eye .

Individual was cutting metal flange, and a spark went inside eye protection and into left eye. Immediate action was to wash eye with eye wash. Individual was advised to attend <NAME> Hospital, but declined. At the time of the accident, the individual thought that only a spark had entered the eye; however when attending hospital on <NAME>, a small piece of metal was found in the left eye. The hospital referred the individual to an Eye Specialist in <NAME>, where half of the piece was removed; the other half of the piece was removed in hospital on <NAME>. Currently causing temporary blurring and impaired vision.

Men were working making formwork pans , [NAME]  was cutting 100mm x 50mm to length& the others were using claw hammers driving 100mm wire nails to form the frames. [NAME] had finished sawing timber to length then walked over to the group with a hammer in hand to help out , when a nail being driven by another operative flew out from under the hammer & hit  [NAME] in the eye . Toolbox talk was given to the remaining operatives on site on the use of safety glasses whilst at work .

On long term hire with <NAME> <NAME>  , highways department . Under their supervision using hand pick to prise up piece of metal , metal bolt flew up and hiot right eye . Taken to <NAME> general hospital by council employee . Had operation on <NAME> to right eye to repair iris damage .

A bundle of hoist gates and enclosure mesh had been positioned by the crane too close to other stored component parts preventing a ratchet strap from being undone and removed.  [NAME] attempted to move the gate bundle away from the other hoist component parts using a piece of timber as a lever whilst the lifting supervisor was knocking the strap away from the obstruction with another piece of timber.  [NAME] 's right foot was under the gate bundle when the bites (timber packers ) ( two bites one on top of the other ) slipped off eachother trapping  [NAME] 's foot under the load . The lifting supervisor had to lever the load up with a long piece of timber so that [NAME]  could release his foot . After investigating the accident I advised a review of the suitability of the bites used and the bites placement to ensure that they do not shift if there was a need for levering the loads in the future and to ensure that there is sufficient space between stacked materials to allow for slinging and de-slinging etc .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: [NAME] was working at [NAME] , [NAME].  [NAME]  received a daily task briefing in the morning on the incident explaining the works for the day ahead , this was following a method statement briefing for the works along with induction prior to commencing any works on site. [Name] was working installing sheets to a roof with [NAME] . [NAME] was working within a scissor lift , while [NAME] was standing on the flat roof passing the sheets to [NAME] . [NAME] was wearing a harness clipped onto a landyard securely fixed to an anchor point.The sheets had been installed along the length of the roof , after placing the second to last sheet , [NAME] slipped on the roof and fell towards his left hand side [NAME] landed on his left leg , bruising his upper thigh , and put his hand out to stop the fall , and when his hand touched the roof , the impact hurt his wrist.Bryan climbed down the ladder to see [NAME]  ( site manager ) to report the incident , [NAME] introduced [NAME] to the on-site First Aider ([NAME] ), and after looking at the wrist and speaking with [NAME] , [NAME] recommended [NAME] went to hospital. [Name] went to [NAME] hospital with [NAME]  where he received an x-ray / scan and it was confirmed [NAME] had a suspected fractured wrist. [Name] has since attended [NAME] hospital ([Date]), where he received surgery for a fractured wrist ( awaiting report from [NAME] hospital )

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Injured party is a site labourer and was walking downstairs in plot 18 when he slipped off the second from bottom tread , falling and sustaining injuries to his left hand side . [NAME] manager summoned medical assistance and because of the nature of the injury the injured party was taken to hospital by ambulance where he was diagnosed with a broken left hip . [NAME] [NAME] to carry out toolbox talks with all operatives on site regarding slips , trips and falls . Incident to be investigate by management and Health and Safety Dpt .

Expanded pilling were drilling secant wall pile 21 and spinning off the auger in theNorth direction ( piles 22 to 32 ) . A concrete lorry arrived on site to concrete pile 31 and therefore the direction of spinning off the auger had to change to South . The auger was up in the air full of clay and the rig was stationary , the IP crossed in between the auger and the rig mast trying to get to the other side to move an obstruction . While crossing , a lump of clay split from the very top of the auger and hit the IP on his head and back . A full stand down of all Expanded sites has been planned for [Date] A full review and rebrief of all Method Statements and Risk Assessments to be carried out . During our stand down we require all site management to engage with our personnel , ensuring that minimum standards are in place and works on site relate to our RAMS/VTS. There will be a review of current works against task sheets ( over the course of this week ) , so we have assurance that our works are fully covered . During the stand down managers will discuss our establishment of exclusion zones and responsibility of control of these zones with the site teams ( including all plant operators , engineers etc that work around our operations ) .

11 number of 8 x4” plaster board sheets 2 Number 8x4” MDF Sheets and 2 number 8x4” sound board sheets all with a combined weight of 450 kg were being stored within the corridor on the ground floor of the property . ( Please see Fig 1 below ) . Behind the sheets was the proposed location of 240 volt socket which two twin and earth cables had just been pulled up from the basement to feed . ( Please Fig 2 below ). At Approximately 3.30pm directly after the twin and earth cables had been pulled into position , [NAME]  was discussing the next job with his colleague [NAME] , in the middle of this discussion [NAME] started to pull the plasterboards towards him in an attempt to view the cables behind , with the total weight in excess of 450kg of sheet material the weight momentum swayed towards him pinning him against the staircase . ( [NAME] ) then helped pulled the boards off him . In the process of trying to stop the boards [NAME] has suffered a damaged wrist , which we now know is broken in three places .

The IP was applying membrane to the ceiling of the house standing on a " Safe tread " platform of approx ' 250mm high . A leg on the platform collapsed and the IP fell onto the chipboard floor injuring his right shoulder.Following the accident the platform was inspected and found to be defective . It has now been taken out of use and alternative , more robust platforms are being sourced to continue the work .

The labourer was obtaining bricks from the compound with the help of the forklift driver . Only a small amount of bricks were required from the pack , so the labourer was attempting to remove bricks from an open pack that was stacked on top of a full pack , this would enable the required bricks to be restacked on a pallet ready for the forklift to move to the work area . The open pack of bricks only had one remaining band in place to hold them together and this proceeded to give way at the time when the labourer was standing next to the stack . The materials then fell out on to the labourers leg area , which resulted in a possible fracture , strained tendon and muscle bruising .

<NAME> was working on a roof . He stepped back off the edge of the roof on to the scaffold . The scaffold boards had been pulled back by others leaving a gap of about 300mmx450mm . he fell through this gap wedging himself causing injury to his ribs ( cracked ) and bruising to his liver . he was assisted to the ground and went to hospital where xray showed the extent of the damage .site management have reiterated the need for work force to in form them of any thing they feel is unsafe so appropriate action can be carried out , they have told workforce not to alter scaffold in any way and are carrying out daily checks on scaffold in addition to the weekly checks .

He was laying loft insulation in the roof space ,had a lapse of concentration ,put his foot on the plaster board ,and fell through the ceiling . He fell one room height onto a solid floor . He fell feet first.An ambulance was called straight away .The other workers have all talked through the incident ,and we have gone through the training again .

At approximately 10.30am <NAME> <NAME> hired the 110v Diamond Core Drill  and associated equipment from <NAME> <NAME> and arrived at <NAME> <NAME> and set up all the work equipment to be used for core drilling in to the brickwork and installed the pilot drill in to the core drill and commenced drilling , The injured party did not experience any difficulty drilling in to the brickwork as the diamond drill was drilling in to the brickwork . Due to the thickness of the brickwork he then had to connect the 300mm diamond core extension bar . As he was drilling he was aware the clutch mechanism was working as the drill had snagged as he was drilling in to the brickwork . Due to the depth of the hole he had to stop a number of times to clear the drilled hole of brick work debris . He had drilled up to what appeared to be another course of brickwork and experienced resistance caused by the friction of the diameter of the drill bit against the outer layer of the brickwork , the drill snagged and as his left hand was gripping the handle of the core drill , and as his right hand was holding the trigger down with his right hand the body of the drill twisted anti clockwise causing his right hand to twist awkwardly resulting in the injured party experiencing severe pain to his right hand.The IP visited <NAME> <NAME> hospital where it was confirmed the IP had sustained a fracture to the 4th metacarpal of his right hand . Maintenance records showed before and after use that the Diamond Core Drill had no defects . Alternative methods for installing electrical fans are being considered , ie installing double glazing units designed for electrical fans .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: it started to snow so we ceased working . , <NAME> slipped in the carpark whilst taking hand tools back to the van

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: IP was carrying a cut roll of carpet from the delivery area to work area a distance of approx .10ft when the IP stepped up onto the gantry his ankle inturned/twisted . The operative dropped the roll of carpet after the incident , which was later moved by other operatives . The IP was able to walk back to the site offices and removed his safety boots when he could feel his ankle starting to swell . He changed into trainers and went to the first aid room on site , he was then accompanied by a <NAME> <NAME> manager to <NAME> <NAME> ' hospital for further treatment . The hospital confirmed that he had fractured his ankle . The doctors advised that the IP was very unfortunate as a twisted ankle would not normally result in a fracture . The access route used was clear without obstructions , there was good lighting and the IP was wearing the correct PPE incl safety boots with ankle protection steel toe and midsole . The IP will be off work for approx . 8 weeks to allow his fracture to heal .
Operative was going down a ladder on scaffold , when he slipped and landed on the boarded lift below

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: While breaking out a vent hole , using an electric drill , the operative slipped from the steps ( less than 1m ) on which he was working . He fell to the ground and broke his wrist.We have not yet been able to get a full statement from him as to the exact cause of the incident , as he has not yet returned to work , but we believe that he had pitched the steps sideways on to the hole and as the drill broke through , his momentum caused the steps to move sideways.The site manager reports the steps as being in good condition and the floor was flat and stable . For the type of work being done ( short duration ) the steps were appropriate and the injured party had attended work at height training on the  of <NAME>  at which the safe use and pitching of steps was explained .Risk assessments reviewed and believed to be suitable . To prevent this type of incident happening again , all operatives will be given a toolbox talk on the use of steps and ladders .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

As he climbed out of his car onto the tarmacked road he lost his footing and fell over sustaining 2 fractures to his foot . The IP managed to close the gates and drive to hospital . This incident was late reported to the group HSE department and was not reported in line with procedure hence the late notification . A full investigation is underway .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: A traffic management crew of three were making a temporary road traffic sign safe on the M1 hard shoulder when the frame lost traction started to fall towards the IP , the IP began to move backwards but stumbled loosing his footing fell , hitting his right cheekbone against a steel cabinet , sustaining a fracture ( Zygomatic )

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The IP was dismantling a sprinkler tank platform in the loft space ( as a different design and location was required ) and they climbed onto the joists from the access equipment to use a lever bar to remove the platform supports . It was not possible to get sufficient leverage from below the joists . The IP then slipped and fell down between the joists and landed on their feet causing the injury to their right ankle and the bruising to their arm and side.This task has never been carried out before as platforms are usually installed during the truss installation when a birdcage scaffold is in place to act as fall protection .If this activity is ever required in the future then the principal contractor will be contacted and under joist scaffold or over joist expandable mesh will be installed to offer fall protection/prevention. In addition written notification will be issued to all other contractors about this stating that under no circumstances should anyone work directly off the joists .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> and <NAME> left the <NAME> <NAME> site office and travelled in a company van to the <NAME> building where they would prefabricate partitions for the baggage reclaim project. On arrival at the location the van <NAME> <NAME> parked the van in the <NAME> building carpark .  <NAME> and <NAME> then walked from the van towards the <NAME> building. When crossing the Car park<NAME> <NAME> slipped and fell on a snow covered patch of ice . The ice could not be seen as a result of a fresh covering of snow. <NAME> fell to the ground complaining of a bad pain in his ankle which he was unable to move . In addition <NAME> hit his head on the ground when he fell . <NAME>, a trained first aider , did not attempt to treat the injury as the ankle could be broken . <NAME> carefully lifted <NAME> into the van and took him to the A and E unit at <NAME> <NAME> hospital in <NAME> for examination.The medical staff X-rayed and carried out a CT scan on the ankle to determine the extent of the injury . The examination concluded that the ankle was badly broken and would need setting and plastered . <NAME> <NAME> was given morphine at the hospital to ease the pain .

Amendment to Incident Reference Number <NAME> On the morning of <NAME>  a work party were carrying out preparation works for installing new pipe supports.The task was to drill multiple 30mm bolt holes inthe concrete plinths which would be used tosecure the pipe supports . The holes were beingdrilled in stages with initial 18mm pilot holes , then larger 22mm holes before finally drilling 30mmholes as per the drawings . While carrying out this task the operatives wereencountering reinforcing bar in the concrete .Whenre-bar was encountered , the holes would bemarked as containing re-bar and the operativeswould move onto the next hole .The IP was using a Hilti drill with a 30mm drill bitwhen his drill struck re-bar and the drill jammedand twisted . He immediately felt pain in his rightwrist.The IP was taken to hospital for a medical assessment and then to <NAME> We arecurrently awaiting the medical report.The initial medical assessment was inconclusive . A further assessment was carried out and the IP has damaged a bone in his right hand .More information to follow on completion ofincident investigation .
person on a step-ladder 5ft up , felt ladder slide so jumped off to the side . Landed awkwardly and broke leg . Was wearing a hard hat and safety boots at the time .
our staff were attacked by person unknown to them all three were taken to hospital and the police were called

Works were in progress to complete a concrete slab for a new building , outside the area of works is a chamber , two operatives were attempting to check the depth of the chamber in order to put a duct in from the chamber to the building for possible use in the future . The chamber lid could not be removed and one of the operatives went to find a suitable implement to remove it , as he walked away he heard a shout and turned to find his colleague lying on the floor . The clients HGV had reversed over the operatives leg . He had not been struck by the vehicle but had been lying on the floor ( no explanation has been given why ) . The operative did not want to go to hospital and was taken home , he later attended hospital where a fracture of the leg was diagnosed .

The works are 278 works on [Name] to crate a new roundabout at the [NAME] steelworks entrance . As part of the works new surface water system needs to be installed . The task was to complete a partially built catch pit by installing a 500mm deep 1050mm diameter chamber ring . The ring was transported by an 8t excavator using tested lifting eyes and tested 4 leg chains , note the ring has 3 lifting eyes which left one chain leg unused . The chamber ring was placed next to the catch pit on the tarmac road surface and the chains un attached from the ring but left on the machine arm . The machine arm was inside the ring with no bucket on . The drainage operative was placing the mortar bed to the ring previously laid with his back to the excavator , another works vehicle needed to get passed the excavator so the excavator driver decided to move , he lifted the arm of the excavator and as he did the ring moved and slid sideways onto the previously laid ring which trapped the foot of the drainage operative .( It is thought that the 4th leg of the chain was trapped under the ring ) . The machine driver quickly got out of his machine and lifted the side of the ring by hand to release the drainage operatives foot . A first responder paramedic attended followed by an ambulance who took the IP to [NAME] . Following this a full investigation and report are currently being formulated , the method statement and risk assessments are being reviewed , all operatives have had a tool box talk , the site will be visited week commencing [Date] by an independant safety officer who will carry out a full report on the site condition . Operatives are having further training on [Date] . The excavator driver has been removed from site , a preventative action report is currently being formulated .
The operative had finished strimming his section of banking and stepped backwards into a broken man hole cover falling and hurting his ribs . The cover has been replaced .

Telphone report ( possible duplicate report ) Although there were no witness IP was allegedly moving safety fall arrest bags from a flat roof area of a new build which was fitted with a guard rail system designed to be transportable in sections approximately 5m in lenght . The reason of such a design was to allow each individual section of the guard raill to be moved partially allowing heavy materials to be lifted onto the roof by telescopic fork lift to any area of the flat roof . The IP was asked to move some safety air bags from this flat roof area and was throwing them over the guard rail system which is provided for fall protection and over a scaffold 4 m below which was positioned on ground level that had it 's scaffold platform boards removed and access prohibited . It is assumed that IP has lost balance/tripped and his own body weight has caused the edge protection to topple resulting in it falling to the scaffold below along with the IP. Came to rest on a sigle board on the scaffolding . IP has managed to move to end of scaffolding and was seen by another person and ambulance called . Paramedics took IP to hospital . Injuries are broken ribs and internal bleeding .  Area cordoned off , photos taken and barriers made good . External investigation underway

Deflecting concrete from newly installed vehicle inspecting pit , construction worker lost his footing and fell into pit .

<NAME> <NAME> ( IP ) of <NAME> <NAME> & <NAME> Services ( <NAME> ) accessed an off hired scaffolding platform ( which had the access ladder removed by the scaffolding company ) . This was situated in the back garden of the property and was accessed by <NAME> using his own leaning ladder . He moved <NAME> dish onto property . He stepped out beyond platform transom , three boards flipped up causing IP to fall to ground . Dislocated shoulder initially suspected . Hospital later confirmed broken ribs . Scaffolding off hired  <NAME>  . IP not booked in on day of incident to carry out works to this property as scaffolding was being dropped on day of incident ( <NAME> ) <NAME> received site induction on  <NAME> .

As part of the ongoing renovation of a public house , the foreman & the injured party needed to use a couple of 18mm MDF boards that were leaning up behind some 9mm MDF boards . This required 2 people to pull forward the 9 mm boards whilst sliding out the 18mm boards from behind . Instead of waiting for assistance , as instructed to by the foreman , the injured party attempted to slide out the boards himself whilst taking the weight of the boards in front . He fell under the weight & the boards fell on top of him trapping his foot underneath . The foreman came immediately & managed to take the weight of the boards enough to free the injured party & commence first aid . He then took the injured party to <NAME> A & E where he was treated for lower limb fractures to the tibia , fibia and ankle .

IP was one of two slinger/signallers organising the movement and storage of a box shutter removed from lift shaft 4/5. One slinger/signaller ( <NAME> <NAME> ) was on the second floor of the building under construction controlling the movement of the crane and load across the second floor.The second slinger/signaller ( <NAME> <NAME> ) , the IP , was controlling the landing of the load at ground level . Once the box shutter had been landed the IP used a ladder to gain access to the top of the shutter to release the shutter lift clamp ( see fig.1) The box shutter stands 3.3 meters high and the ladder in use at the time of the accident was 6 meters long. IP unhooked the clamps from the shutter and gathered them to the centre of the box to prevent them snagging the shutter during the initial lift . The IP used his radio to instruct the crane driver to hoist slowly , once the clamps where clear of the top of the box shutter the IP gave crane driver instruction that it was clear to hoist . At this point one of the clamps ( see pic. 3 & fig.3 ) snagged the top of the ladder lifting it and the IP into the air ( see fig 4) . As the IP was holding the ladder with both hands he was unable to communicate with the crane driver to halt the lift . The second slinger/signaller ( positioned on the second floor of the building ) immediately instructed the crane to stop . It was at this point that the IP fell from the ladder striking the edge of the shutter as he fell . The IP fell to the ground landing alongside the box shutter see pic.2 . The IP did not lose conciseness at any point and was attended by the site first aiders until the arrival of an ambulance .The IP was taken to the local accident and emergency hospital where he has remained since the accident .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: On <NAME> <NAME> while walking on site and carrying scaffold components , an operative fell over some rebar that was extending from the ground . The operative got up and went to the site office to report the incident . They were in pain and believed it to be sprained ankle . They left site for the rest of the day and had the rest of the week off , self-medicating at home with ice . They returned to work on <NAME>  and continued with normal duties however during the day his foot continued to be sore . As such they left site and went to their doctor who advised the operative that he had probably damaged his metatarsal prescribing pain killers . The operative had 3 days off and returned to work on initially on light duties , but returned to full duties before 7 working days . There were no further issues with the IP and they raised no concerns with the company . However on <NAME>  they returned to their doctor as the foot was stiff . The doctor sent the IP for an x-ray were it was determined that there was a fracture to the metatarsal . It is possible that the original trip caused the injury hence the reporting of the incident now . The IP has returned to work on light duties with the situation being monitored

The injured person was replacing fluorescent tubes in a twin 6' fluorescent fitting which was approximately 2.5m from the floor . He was standing on a class 1 , heavy duty , GRP electricians step ladder approximately 1m from the floor carrying out the work in accordance with company procedures to which he is trained and competent but as he attempted to unclip the diffuser he over reached and fell ~1m to the ground onto his right elbow . We will carry out refresher training in the use of step ladders to reiterate the importance of not over reaching when using step ladders , we will also fit additional warning signage to our step ladders to alert electricians who are using step ladders to the dangers of over reaching .

<NAME> <NAME> was driving a 3 tonne forward tipping dumper , moving dry soil from excavated area to be tipped else where . <NAME> drove the dumper through the designated route multiple times before that day . <NAME> veered off the designated route- this reason is unknown to myself and calluym has no knowlage why this happend ( possibly due to lack of concerntration ) and turned left up a verge . We had a tower scaffold erected to the rear of the property to enable us to build a dormer window to the property . As a finishing touch , a upvc trim was to be fitted which needed a mastic seal to finish . There was approximately 650mm of roof on which to lay a ladder on the slates to carry out this work . The mastic gun got caught beneath the operatives belly ( he weighs approximately 22 stone ) and so he twisted to the left and lost balance and fell . We have obviously discussed this incident with all members of staff and our sub-contractors to ensure nothing like this happens again . The conclusions reached were firstly this operative should not have been carrying out this work due to his size , he should n't have been alone on the scaffold , and he maybe could have had a harness . A handrail was also discussed , but would have meant poles restricting the neighbours access .

Whilst using a 3/4 " jetting hose on the gully motor to clear a blocked drainage pipe and when reeling in the hose , [NAME] noticed the hose was reeling in unevenly and he stopped the motion of the hose whilst keeping it under pressure to realign the hose . The reel started moving again when another employee restarted the hydraulic reel as [NAME] was standing in the blind side of the vehicle . This resulted in his hand being caught between the hose and the metal rim of the reel . It was 4 - 5 seconds before the other employee saw [NAME] 's glove protruding from the reel . It was switched off and first aid given to [NAME] . We have reviewed the risk assessment and safe system of work for this task and have had one-to-one sessions regarding this task . [NAME] and a visual check has been added to the assessments . We are also looking at retro fitting an auto hose feed device to prevent any chance of reoccurrence . When trying to adjust a lower bracing frame the upper bracing frame became loose & fell on to the lower frame trapping/crushing our operatives hand between both frames . The lower frame was had been raised but to apposition that was not acceptable, it was then lowered to reposition but in doing so it appears as the lower frame was lowered down this caused the weight to be placed on the upper frame causing the upper frame to become loose on one corner & fall on to the lower frame. The action taken to prevent this from happening again is we have moved one side of the upper frame on to the top of a concrete ledge added additional anchor points on two sides .

As the glass was about one foot off the stillage & one and a half foot off the floor , the other glass , which was still on the stillage fell forward hitting the glass which was attached to the crane/sucker it hit him trapping him against another stillage and the glass which was falling trapping his leg. IP was placing and compacting sand within a parking bay utilising a small petrol driven wacker plate . On completion he lifted and placed the wacker plate within a wheelbarrow to transport to another part of site . During lifting and placement within the barrow the IP failed to place the plant centrally which resulted in the handle striking the back edge of the wheelbarrow , flipping upwards stiking the IP in the face causing injury . The IP reported the accident and was taken to hospital for a check up as his face was swollen . After examination he was advised that he had a broken bone within his cheek . The accident has been investigated by the site contracts manager for the works and the IP interviewed to discuss the accident , root causes and action required to prevent re-occurrence . . The IP admitted his failing during interview advising that he was aware of company policy with regards manual handling and advised he did not team lift or mechanical lift in this instance as he wanted to get on with his works and apologised for his failings in this matter . The contracts manager for the works has instructed all onsite that the company policy for manual handling must be strictly adherd to at all times and that the plant and machinery provided for transporting plant must be utilised in future .

The IP was involved with directing the load attached to a crane to a higher level on the building . He was a trained slinger/signaller . After attaching the load he then had to make his way up the building under construction via a series of ladders installed for access . On reaching the level where the load was to be landed , he communicated with the supervisor on that level to ask where it was to be placed . The supervisor indicated the area to the IP.  At this point the supervisor was getting other materials nearby and did not maintain eye contact with the IP. The next thing the supervisor heard was a 'crack ' noise from behind him and the IP had disappeared . The supervisor looked for the IP and it was obvious that he had fallen through a working platform being used to prepare shuttering for forming new walls . The supervisor , realising the IP had fallen went immediately to a lower level and found the IP on a lower platform 8 metres below . The IP was injured but it was n't known to what extent . The emergency services were called and the area was sealed off and remains sealed off to personnel .

Operative was positioning arms on the wagon after placing a skip when the injured person placed his elbow on the truck bed. The hydraulic arm lowered onto the injured persons elbow causing a crushing injury. The operator raised the arm immediately to release the trapped arm. All driver operators have been received further instruction to ensure that no one is in the vicinity when the skip wagon is in operation and if anyone comes near, the operator must stop the task.Accident investigation has been undertaken.Risk assessment has been reviewed.

The technician was using the pallet truck to move a pallet of insulation materials . The pallet truck needed to be removed from beneath the pallet and appeared difficult to remove . The technician decided that the pallet truck needed a harder pull in order to remove it from the pallet . He gave the pallet truck a harder pull , freeing the pallet truck , and stepped backwards in the process . He stepped backwards into the handle of the baler/compactor . We have since spoken to all our technicians who use the pallet truck and advised what has happened . An instructional memo has been issued to all employees to advise them that if the pallet truck becomes stuck and cannot be easily removed that it be reported so that a method of removal can be formulated , taking into account the surrounding environment and obstacles that may be present .

I was climbing up the ladder with a tray of paint and roller in my left hand and holding on with the right hand . Resulting in me landing on my back and fracturing my neck , bruising on my spine & bad muscle damage resulting in losing strength and feeling in my left leg and arm . I now have to have a MRI scan to see whats happened and if this will get better or not . This has caused me to take 8 weeks out of work and possibly never able to work again .

The incident took place on <NAME> the  of <NAME>  at approximately 14:45 when <NAME> <NAME> was dismounting a bandstand , that he had been plastering from , to ground level . <NAME> <NAME> stepped from the bandstand onto a class 1 industrial stepladder that was providing access to and from the working area. No other persons were working with or in proximity at the time of the incident . It is understood that the ladder moved or gave way from under <NAME> <NAME> when he stepped between the bandstand and the stepladder.As there were no witnesses and the ladder was on the floor when the site manager arrived on the scene , the exact cause remains unclear , however , it is possible that this could have been due to the ladder not being fully erected and the support struts not being locked out .

On the day in question <NAME> <NAME> was transporting a high reach excavator using a low loader from <NAME> to <NAME> . This was under a movement order as issued by the police , highway and bridge authority . To enable the oversize load to stick to the designated route as per the movement order the IP ( Also the Plant Operator ) has to access and exit the cab of the high reach excavator whilst on the low loader . This is to alter the height and or angle of the arm of the machine so as not to come into contact with traffic lights , road signs etc . Whilst undertaking this task the IP exited the machine via the safe route as per the manufactures guidance , as he placed his foot on the bottom track step he slipped falling approximately 80cm to the ground landing awkwardly on his right heel . The IP attended A & E and was given a X ray which did not identify any issues this was followed up by a CT Scan which identified a fracture to his right heel . A plaster cast was applied and the IP was instructed to return back to the Hospital on <NAME> 12th <NAME> for further assessment . He dually returned the cast was removed and an Air Walker Ankle brace was fitted . The IP has been instructed to keep the weight off of his foot and to return on the  <NAME>  for further assessment .

The IP is employed as a labourer ( through an agency ) and was in the process of moving waste bins around site ( At present whether the bin was full or empty is unclear and under investigation ) . There is a slight change in level between the concrete slab and scaffold loading deck which the bin is reported to have jarred against causing the IP to suffer pain in his right wrist . A light strapping was applied as first aid by his site manager as the IP could move his wrist and the IP continued work on light duties . Later (time not specified - under current investigation ) the IP sought medical advice and the following day contacted site managers to inform that he would be not be returning to work due to his injury . The IP had reported his absence from work would be for 4 weeks , so initially the classification for his injury was thought to be an "over 7 day injury" , but once a statement of fitness for work had been received which clarified a fracture , this changed . The investigation to establish why the IP became injured is on-going and suggestions to prevent reoccurrence will be concluded once all statements etc . are collated

During the installation of precast units to the steelframe on the new car park , the IP was working with fall arrest equipment on the 11th floor ( top floor ) when he fell 2.85m whilst installing a pc unit onto the 10th floor.The root cause of the accident was due to a gap in the planks causing a void on the 11th floor due to the planks being laid out of sequence as the missing plank that created the void was at the bottom of the delivery on the delivery vehicle . <NAME> have investigated the incident with our external H & S advisor and re-addressed the Risk Assessments / PC unit installation procedure including work / anchor point positioning. All pc units must be landed in the correct installation sequence to eliminate any voids being created and the erectors have also been given TBT on correct workplace positioning which includes anchorage points and the safe use of harnesses / inertia reels and anchorage points .

<NAME> ( <NAME> ) is a 58 year old relief special events assistant employed by the <NAME> and <NAME> of <NAME> . On <NAME> at 15 :15 <NAME> was carrying out plumbing work in the backstage area of the concert being held at <NAME> <NAME> . A truck was turning in the area and struck a stanchion that was laying near to where <NAME> was working . The contact resulted in the stanchion toppling over onto <NAME> 's right lower leg.Staff on site acted quickly in removing the stanchion and <NAME> was treated by First aider on site . <NAME> was taken directly to hospital with a suspected fracture to his lower right leg.The park had been booked by <NAME> <NAME> to facilitate a <NAME> <NAME> concert.A contract exists between the <NAME> <NAME> and the <NAME> & <NAME> of <NAME>. The special events team was working with <NAME> <NAME> on delivering the <NAME> <NAME> concert scheduled for <NAME>.  <NAME> entertainment had contracted <NAME> to deliver certain elements of the site build.The stage build and associated contractors was the responsibility of <NAME> <NAME> IP was  <NAME>, an experienced casual employee with the <NAME> & <NAME> of <NAME> Events team . ( <NAME> <NAME> )The IP had worked on this particular site on many previous occasions.All staff were wearing appropriate PPE and high visibility clothing.All staff had received an induction / tool box talk. Staff are allocated their tasks by the <NAME> site manager who on this occasion was <NAME> <NAME>. The truck was turning on the pad having delivered its load of staging equipment. Due to the space available all other trucks had been reversing out of the site and not attempting to turn .  Whilst turning the back of the truck struck a stage stanchion causing it to topple. During preparation for the laying of precast concrete kerbs ( 125mmx914x255 ) . The kerb stones were delivered palletised to site by mechanical off loader. Each palletised load 2no courses of 8 (16 no kerbs ) was contained by plastic banding on a timber pallet (1100x1200x100mm ). The kerbing squad was in the process of breaking down each pallet of kerbs to manually transfer each stone to the desired position , prior to final bedding and positioning . During the release of the one pallet it was noticed by the operative <NAME> <NAME> that the pallet /kerbs were unsteady . In order to support the kerbs and allow the continued removal of kerbs . <NAME> <NAME> placed a kerb on its end resting against the act as a temporary support to the remaining kerbs on the pallet . Later during the transfer process , <NAME> <NAME> proceeded to remove the temporary propping kerb , not realizing the function . At this time <NAME> <NAME> was walking past and unsecured kerbs colapsed one of which struck <NAME> <NAME> right foot. <NAME> reported to <NAME> health centre but was asked to report to <NAME> accident and emergency . Staff have access to a polythene wrap which is used to encase unstable pallets until such time as they can be re-banded and a controlled method of disassembly carried out .

An employee fractured a metacarpal on his right hand trying to remove a rotavator from the back of a vehicle . On the <NAME> at approximately 22:00 after attending a site briefing work started with the removal of variogard in order to allow the temporary white lines to be installed . After removal a sweeper would and was used to prepare the road surface for white lines.At 22:30 the area of works approximately 600 meters in length was being prepared for the removal of the existing temporary white lines known as stay mark . This work involves the peeling by hand and scraper of this material of the road surface and is carried out by either kneeling or sitting down by the operatives . At approximately midnight the drip van , whose job it was to lay an indicator line for the permanent spray lorries to follow was tracing the existing white line at the edge of the central reserve to create an intermittent line between the 2nd and 3rd lane . The van at a walking pace approached the team who were removing the stay mark and stopped until the workforce stood up and moved to both sides of the oncoming van . The van continued past the operative who was standing on the passenger side when he was struck on his lower leg by the spray bar that protruded approximately 1.2m from the rear at 90 degrees to the side of the vehicle . Being hit the IP fell to the ground and as he fell he outstretched his right arm to arrest his fall which resulted in the wrist injury . At the instruction of the second man within the van who was located in the rear , the vana stopped , and the driver helped the IP to his feet.At 00:15 the IP was taken to <NAME> A & E where he was bandaged and given a splint along with an appointment to attend the hospital later that day . Leaving the hospital the IP was driven back to site at 02:45 when he dictated a statement to the traffic managemnet foreman.The IP left site to return home with a colleague . Later that day the IP attended his local hospital at <NAME> where he was given an appointment time to return on the <NAME> when he was fitted with a plaster cast confirming a broken wrist and given a further appointment for <NAME> the <NAME> .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: A carpenter from <NAME> agency had started work on site  <NAME> , he was there to install shuttering for cable troughs in a new substation switch house . The trench had approx 1.5 cm of water in the bottom and his safety footwear became wet . It had been raining over night and the steel decking that had been laid was also wet . As he exited the trench and started to walk across the decking he lost his footing and fell , he tried to get back up but his foot slipped out from under him again and he came down on his knee on the steel decking . He was helped to his feet A chair was brought out for him and he sat for a while but he could n't put any weight on his right leg . The site manager took him to <NAME> hospital where he was sent for X-ray , this showed a small crack in the top of the right tibia . He was given a temporary cast and crutches and has instructions to return to the fracture clinic to have a permanent cast put on . Our investigation has concluded that in future we need to - ensure a trench where someone is working is free from water as far as is practicable , provide a more expansive walkway for access to/from the workplace when steel decking has been installed ( although there were plywood boards on the deck they were not close enough to the point of exit of the trench ) . Work with the client to identify if there is another design option other than steel decking that can be utilised in buildings of this type .
