description: The injured person ( IP ) is a <NAME> <NAME> . The IP tripped on his own feet walking across site . An ambulance was called and the IP was taken to hospital . The IP sustained a broken ankle .

The IP is a steelfixer who was installing vertical reinforcement to a new lining wall . Carpenters had installed an oversized stop-end to the end of the wall , this is done to allow the stop-end to be trimmed back accurately when fitting the front shutters but meant that neither party could see each other working . The carpenters warned the IP and his mate that they would be drilling through the stop-end to locate lacer bars that project further . The IP and his mate continued working towards the stop-end and were unsure if the drilling was complete , they did not check . The IP started to fit a reinforcement bar around 50mm from the stop-end when the drill came through the plywood and caught the back of his right hand . The IP shouted and the carpenters came around the stop-end to find the IP holding his hand . first aid was administered on site and the IP was then accompanied to hospital for further treatment . It was found that the IP had a fracture to his third metacarpal . The injury was cleaned and closed up by the hospital and the IP sent home .Since the accident , <NAME> <NAME> have reviewed their method Statements and Risk Assessements adding in the use of a lookout when drilling in similar circumstances .Daily start of shift briefings are more in depth in describing activities working near to each other and separation of works .

Person injured is employed to clean new constructed houses and that includes cleaning the outside of the windows . The person injured went to pick up a board from the ground to use on the new turf so as not to damage it whilst cleaning external windows . We are required by a duty of care by the main contractors to do this so we dont damage the turf . The board was adjacent to the main road in between completed parking bays on top of one sheet of celotex insulation . The area was open to members of the public and residents who had already moved into the estate thus giving no indication of the open cesspit . The injured person stood on the celotex whilst lifting the board up and subsequently fell through the celotex into the cesspit tank unaware the celotex and board was covering the entrance to the cesspit . In terms of preventing similar incidents again , we will continue to ensure that staff are site inducted by the main contractor and we rely upon that induction .

Injured party was carrying out plumbing work in the property and as he went to leave at the end of the day misjudged the top step on a temporary staircase , falling all the way to the bottom.All temporary staircases will be inspected to ensure that they are erected to required standards and where possible , permanent staircases will be installed in properties as early as possible .Tool box talks will also be given to all persons on site reminding them to take care on stairways .
Holding on to kit panel wind picked up and blew panel on to labourer
Cause is unknown .
Operative was using a ladder that was to small and whilst standing on top rung of stepladder leaned over to reach another area to paint when ladder toppled away from under him

The operative was taking small working equipment off the scissor lift and re setting the working platform area that extends out to store small hand tools on the sissor lift this was at ground level when an operative had pushed the plate back in and the other operative got his little finger trapped in when pushing the plate back in .

Operator was in process of cleaning external side of building using soider acccess platform . The spider access platform required relocationg for access purposes . Operative was dismounting from the spider access platform and placed his right foot on the ground board which supports the spider platform outriggers , twisting his ankle while doing so . This was witnessed by the ground person in attendance . The incident was immediately reported to site supervision . Decistion was made to take casualty to hospital where an x-ray confirmed that right ankle bone was broken

Telephone report- IP was working on a property, IP went to top of stairs to take a measurement.  He turned around, resulting in his foot and leg falling through the floorboard.  IP went to hospital where he was diagnosed small fracture on top of his foot.  Stairs have since been blocked off to stop this happening again.

Collapse of materials on to operatives foot. - revised method of storing materials & exclusion zones around part secured materials .
Drilling hole in wall. Drill bit snagged causing drill to spin , causing break to bone in hand . Drill is 2 months old and has been sent to manufacturer to see if clutch is faulty .

[NAME] was working on removing the insulation foam from the inside of the shed roof .  [NAME] was standing approximately two to three meters away from [NAME] next to some scaffolding when he heard a loud crack which made him step back turn and look upwards towards where [NAME] had been working.  [NAME] saw  [NAME] land on his back but did not actually see him fall from the step ladder he had been on, he did however notice a timber which had fallen and appeared to have struck [NAME]. The emergency services were called immediately to attend. ACTION TAKEN : All timbers have been checked to make sure they are secure and safe to work around and all employees and contractors informed .

We were carrying out flagging at the address listed and the labourer was asked at the end of the day to clear out mixer and have a general tidy up of the site . How the incident happened was that flags were leaned up against the house ready for laying and the labourer was putting a tarpaulin over the flags to keep them dry in doing so pulled the flags towards himself to tuck the sheet behind , he then lost balance and the flags fell over onto the top of his foot which has broken a bone . Flags are now to be stacked in delivery crates until they are needed for laying .

Talking with his collegues over the next few days he was in discomfort and had stated that he went to  hospital and  he has a  small fracture to his elbow the work area was clean and clear of obstruction it was purely human error.

description: <NAME> had finished at one project and was unloading and loading his company vehicle to move on to his next project that day . Whilst transporting materials from his van to the head office , <NAME> tripped on a dip in the ground and went over on his right ankle . At the time , <NAME> was sat down and told to take the weight off his ankle and put an ice pack on it . <NAME> did this for approx . 5 minutes then decided himself that the injury was only a sprain and that he felt ok to go back to work , despite advice from the office staff to get it checked out at hospital . <NAME> declined this advice and went back to work .

Whilst installing a Lane 1 closure on the M25 A carriageway , junction 29  marker post <NAME> . The crew were dropping cones onto the hard shoulder ready to build the taper . An operative has fallen from the vehicle and struck the side of his face on the metal vehicle restraint barrier .

The job was removing an asbestos flat roof from a domestic garage, the injured operative was cutting the fixings with a grinder and fell through the roof sheet and landed on his back, there was not a youngman board in place to support his weight, the fixings should have been cut from underneath. another operative called an ambulance which arrived and took him to hospital, he has fractured his vertebrae bone on his back which he informed me of today, i called the hse contact centre yesterday and they told me to report the incident within 10 days once I have confirmed the extent of his injuries. I am in the process of getting written statements from the supervisor and the other operative, I will get a satement from the injured operative within 10 days. The remaining sheets have been removed from the garage and i have taken photos of inside the garage

Another person present ( <NAME> <NAME> ) took <NAME> to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> then on to <NAME> <NAME>for medical treatment . At <NAME> we are advised by <NAME> <NAME> that he has suffered two fractures to the ankle and requires an operation but at the time of writing the ankle was too swollen to operate on . I understand he has remained in hospital since admission to the present time .

<NAME> was working alone and positioned the ladders on the stairs with the bottom rung locked into the stairwell to prevent slipping . The upper rung was leant against the top of wall  to prevent the ladder from sliding while working . A contractor requested access pass the work area of the stairs [Name] got down the ladders and moved them out of the way for contractor to pass. <NAME> replaced ladders in a new position which involved positioning ladder on landing area . <NAME> climbed the ladders at this point the ladders proceeded to slip down the wall , as this occurred he lost balance fell off the ladder down the stairs below. <NAME> got up and said he was ok . He was then in pain and <NAME> the site manager requested he goes to hospital , and took him straight there .It was placed in the accident book on siteThe ladders where taken out of use because these should not have been used as ladders where not allowed on site by the principal contractor - this work equipment did not belong to <NAME> and the operative should not have used it.Toolbox talks are being delivered across the site to highlight working off steps and working at height .

*TELEPHONE REPORT: The IP was unloading a vehicle in the depot , he lifted of a 25 litre drum of water , which he had unesitmated the weight of . The IP let go and the barrell fell against his leg . This has resulted in a fracture to the right leg . The IP was taken to hospital by a colleague .

Operative working from a ladder being footed by second operative . Operative up ladder replaced ceiling and as he began descending the footer moved and the ladder slipped . The operative on the ladder has fallen to the ground . This took place in the gym of the school . The circumstances are being investigated further . A footing device should have been in operation . Initial thoughts are that the device was not issued on site or that it was left behind as work proceeded . The gym floor has a smooth surface compared to other areas with carpet . This difference may have been underestimated.All work stopped when the accident occurred and the operative was dealt with.After the accident a tool box talk was given by a SSSTS supervisor on ladder use .The investigation in to the incident is now taking place and an action plan to learn and enforce lessons , and avoid a recurrence will be developed on  <NAME> with company Health and Safety Advisor.

Works were being completed to clear materials and equipment from the designed [Name] system, Sections  6 to 13 installed on Core B, Level 2, in preparation for climbing the system to Level 3.  This would bring it to the same Level alongside Sections 1 to 5 and 14 on Core A, climbed the previous day;Due to the windy weather conditions, all crane lifts were suspended, therefore works to complete concrete finishing of the completed core commenced whilst the climbing of the core was in abeyance;The IP was assisting with concrete finishing works and the infilling of holes formed during the concreting process on the trailing deck located at the ground floor slab level, when he was struck on the arm by a Doka Platform roller unit, which fell from the working deck above;The Doka Platform roller unit was removed from Section 13 of the designed system by a formwork operative from within the lift core and as he was placing the equipment through the lift core door opening on to the working deck, the operative dropped the equipment unintentionally through a gap between the working deck of the climbing formwork and the completed concrete core, leading to the roller unit falling and striking the IP on his lower arm;The IP was sent to hospital for an X-ray as a precaution after receiving First Aid examination, and showed a fracture in his lower left arm.
A piece of wood feel from a skip whilst being loaded by labourer . The skip was overloaded .

We are informed by [NAME] of the following statement of event : Was taking down an internal brick wall . working from right to left of the said wall knock blocks off one by one with a sledge hammer . Approximately at centre stage of wall , block was knock off and as so crack appeared down vertical of wall . To avoid fall of section of wall operative proceeded to knock section out , this resulted in a section of 3no blocks falling in one onto top of operatives left foot . Blocks hit just in joint of foot/ankle above steel toe capped section of boot . Following pain , operative was taken to sites first Aider where he was advised to go to hospital . Operative attended [NAME] [NAME] infirmary where foot was x-rayed . He was informed he had broken his Intermediate & medial cuneiform or tarsals.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Operative was about to commence backfilling operation using a machine at the top of a sloped area where he was about to start backfilling a small shuttered staircase , approx . change in level top to bottom of 1.75m over a distance of approx . 4m , operative moved a safety barrier marking the top of the bank to get into the working area , then picked up a small section of timber that was blocking his path of the machine , in course of bending down to pick this up he lost his footing and balance and rolled down the small slope and into a trench that was next to the shuttering at the base of the slope . Other operatives working in the vicinity heard the incident happen , went over to the area and assisted him out of the trench , he was immediately complaining of a pain to his wrist , was taken to local A&E , where they diagnosed a suspected broken wrist , which was later confirmed after x-ray , bones where reset and put into a cast .

As he fell forward he put out his hand / arm to protect himself . In doing so he sustained , what was later diagnose as , a fracture to the radius head of his arm at the elbow position

ACTIVITY Transferring a few stone slabs from a haulier’s delivery vehicle onto A-frame type transport frames ’ on a flat-bed trailer , which was hitched to the back of a van . A forklift with jib & lifting grab was used to perform this task . PERSONS PRESENT + TASKS 1.The Lorry driver – a.Preparing each slab for offloading , including spacing it from its neighbouring slab.b.Steadying the slab whilst the lifting grab was positioned .2.The forklift driver a.Operating the forklift , for lifting , manoeuvring and placing each slab , in turn .3.Assistant – a.Positioning the lifting grab , in readiness for lifting.b.Guiding the slab whilst it was transferred.c. Releasing the lifting grab , once the slab was placed on the ‘A-frame transport frames ’ on the trailer and guiding it ( the slab ) to its resting position.DESCRIPTION OF ACCIDENTThe lorry driver remained on his lorry throughout the process . Several slabs had already been safely transferred & stowed on the trailer.For the sixth slab:This had been safely placed on the trailer and the lifting grab released by the assistant . At this point , the assistant lost his footing and in doing so , noticed that the top edge of the slab was moving towards him ( instead of away from him , to rest against the slabs already placed ) . Realising that he could not steady the slab , the assistant jumped backwards , landing on his back on the ground , bumping his head . The slab fell , causing it to break up . It seems that a piece of the broken slab struck the assistant’s leg , causing the broken leg . The injured person was taken to hospital by private car and treated for a fractured leg. MEASURES TO BE IMPLEMENTED TO PREVENT RECURRENCE OF INCIDENTReview existing risk assessment & safe system of work for this process , and incorporate the following controls :Either :a Introduced a mechanical stop/restraint on the trailer/A-frames , to prevent the slab from moving significantly away from its intended resting position . ORb.Introduce a 2nd person , to assist in guiding the slab(s) on the ‘A-frame, as the grab is released.
While pulling a wheel barrow up over a kerb ,  [NAME] walked backwards and tripped on a corner of a pallet .

whilst operating the circular bench saw , a small piece of wood which was the shape of a 'Y' was being pushed towards the circular blade . As he was cutting one of the ' Y 's he was holding the other ' Y ' and his forward momentum after cutting the first ' Y ' led to his other finger being caught in the blade .

The temporary flooring where the operative walked through was warped therefore lifted as he walked through resulting in IP catching his foot on the flooring and falling into the scaffold handrail before he fell to the floor . IP landed on right arm/elbow .

[NAME] was working on a private build reshaping the driveway . He was standing beside a stationary roller which moved on uneven ground causing it to topple over , [NAME] slipped while moving out of the way which lead to the roller landing on the lower part of his leg . Any tools or machinery will now only be parked on solid level ground where stone has already been compacted .

Whilst engaged in grounds maintenance activities <NAME> was loading cut logs in the back of his van - he did not stack than safely and a log rolled out and caught him on the side of the foot . The incident was reported and <NAME> continued with his work for the remainder of the week . It was only on the <NAME> <NAME> that he reported in sick stating that his foot was in pain . <NAME> has since been signed off and intend to return to work on  <NAME> . The incident was investigated by his line manager on <NAME> <NAME> and it was concluded that <NAME> was working in accordance with his works method statement however he had not taken sufficient care in ensuring that he secured his load correctly . More care needs to be taken in future .

The injured operative was installing a door frame onto the balcony of plot <NAME>, <NAME> <NAME> A scaffold board was propped against the back wall of the balcony . The operative stepped onto the balcony to free trapped EPDM around the perimeter of the frame and a gust of wind simultaneously blew off his hard hat and blew over the propped scaffold board which struck the operative on the right hand side of the head resulting in swelling and bruising to the right hand side of the forehead and around the right eye . Conditions were extremely windy at the time .Subsequently all operatives have been issued chinstraps to secure helmets in windy conditions and operatives have been re-briefed on checking the safety of work areas and on working in inclement conditions .

IP was walking down a scaffold board being used as an access ramp to a building . IP slipped on the wet board , felt his leg give way under him and fell a maximum height of 0.5m to the ground below . He reached out with his hand to cushion the fall. IP felt pain in his wrist immediately . He carried on working until he visited hospital later that day where a fractured wrist was diagnosed .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Operative was stepping over a 225mm plot wall to carry out some internal drainage works. As he stepped over the wall he misjudged his footing the other side stumbled and injured himself.

On <NAME> <NAME>, <NAME> and <NAME> were breaking down the <NAME> show stand at <NAME>.The weather was sunny and dry and <NAME> was wearing appropriate clothing and footwear (Dewalt safety boots <NAME>)  <NAME> was on top of the Van securing the load to the roof frame using adjustable straps. The 2 other <NAME> staff were on the right of the vehicle on the ground (<NAME> pulled the straps to tighten them but had misjudged the amount of slack in the ropes. There was more slack than anticipated.) As <NAME> pulled the straps he stepped back to secure them, the straps were too slack and as a result caught his foot in the roof frame, he fell backwards, he managed to twist himself mid-fall so he landed on the ground(grass) on his right side with his arm under his side. <NAME> yelled as he was falling, his two colleagues came round to the side of the vehicle where <NAME> was lying on the ground badly winded. <NAME> assisted <NAME> into a position on his knees with his arms outstretched to assist with <NAME> breathing, after a couple of minutes the windedness has eased considerably, but <NAME> was badly shaken and complained of a stabbing pain in his chest. <NAME> was driven directly to <NAME> A+E department by <NAME>, <NAME> was examined, and X-rayed and given painkillers parecetamol and Ibuprofen. <NAME> was advised that he had hairline fractures to 3 of his ribs at the front of his chest by the breast bone he was advised to rest. <NAME> was then driven home by <NAME>.That evening <NAME> noticed some Blood in his Urine and contact NHS Direct he explained what had happened and was advised that his kidneys could easily be bruised from the fall, which was what the traces of blood were, most probably caused by the fall. He was advised to keep an eye on it but that it should improve by itself. But that if there was no improvement the following day he should re attend A+E. By the following day traces of blood were no longer apparent. <NAME> remained resting in bed until Friday <NAME> at which point he felt able to move slowly around his house.On Monday <NAME>, <NAME> decided to return to work as he was feeling quite a bit better and was no longer taking pain killers.A brief meeting was conducted between <NAME> and <NAME> at which point it was made clear that <NAME> was very welcome to be at work and his willingness to return to work so soon is greatly appreciated, but that until further assessment has been undertaken, he is on restricted duties with absolutely no lifting being allowedNew written procedures will be put in place prior to using the van roof racks.
<NAME> <NAME> (injured person) lifted a welded upvc cill and by doing so I knocked a block off a raised wall which then fell and injured the side of <NAME> face

description: The Injured person stepped out of the canteen cabin and in doing so he stepped into a hole, fell over and twisted his foot. The site provided a bandage for the injured person to apply. It was later when he arrived home he released how swollen and bruised his foot had become. He attended the local A&E Department where the foot was x-rayed, he was advised that he had broken the vascular bone in his foot. An open cast has been applied and he is to return to the A&E Department on the 12th December 2017.
The IP was working with the carpenter removing an up and over door . As the door mechanism was removed , the spring for the door spun around and hit the IP on the wrist and caused a laceration .

IP was carrying out a routine inspection of the working area on <NAME> <NAME> . Whilst descending a temporary scaffold staircase ( 3rd/4th step ) , the IP stumbled and landed on the ground on his arm . The IP carried on working , but attended hospital at the weekend ( <NAME> ) . Following an xray it was confirmed that the IP had sustained a fracture . Following the accident the staircase was inspected for integrity , and warning signage displayed on the staircase .

During works being carried out at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> for <NAME> , <NAME> operatives were using electric pump trucks to move landscaping materials around on the podium roof area . The IP had to off hire one of them ( <NAME> ) as the drive wheel had worn out . The IP managed to move the aforementioned electric pallet truck with the help of another operative to hoist number 3 where <NAME> were waiting to exchange the faulty pallet truck . The hoist had got down to the ground floor from the podium and the IP noticed that  <NAME> <NAME>  ( Hired in from  <NAME> ) was blocked in by other contractors materials and equipment . The IP and the other operative took it down the ramp manually rather than moving the equipment that was around the telehandler so that it could be used to lift it out . The pallet truck was taken down the ramp that was in place by another contract due to <NAME> waiting to exchange the pallet truck . The IP was in control of the pallet truck and took it down the ramp backwards ( handle end going down the ramp first ) when the pallet truck got near to the end of the ramp it bottomed out causing the truck to flip over ( forks in the air and handle on the floor ) the handle hit the IP in the middle of his right foot.The IP automatically started to limp . By this time the other operative and some other operatives from other trades up-righted the pallet truck and got it exchanged.The IP said he was fine and went up to the office , in doing this as he thought it was only a minor injury he did n't tell <NAME> the principal contractor about the incident that had occurred . Over the weekend the pain did not go away and the IP went to <NAME> <NAME> A & E first thing <NAME>  <NAME>. Where he contacted me to advise me of the current situation . Doctors at A & E told the IP that he had a hairline fracture to his metatarsal bone in his foot , and applied a cast to it.Action Plan : ( What has or should be done to prevent similar accidents , incident , injury , or illness )Ramp that others had put into place at the entrance to hoist 3 is to be removed and not used to load / unload materials into the hoistPrincipal contractor to monitor the area to ensure that no other ramp is formed/used.Any training that is undertaken by the hire company ( such as familiarisation on plant / equipment ) is to be recorded on <NAME> training form <NAME> and kept within the on-site folders .  Slight amendment to the <NAME> statement to include electric pallet trucks .Telehandler to be used , to remove and load items into the hoist for <NAME> work .Safety alert to be raised and briefed to all guys using electric pallet trucks .Operatives reminded to report near misses , incidents and accidents straight away to the principal contractor so that they are aware of it and it can go into their accident book .Tool box talk to be raised and used as training for operatives using electric pallet trucks .

The machine driver was sitting in a 5t excavator and was carrying out inverstigating works to locate a damaged service water drain . The operative was sat in the machine and was preparing to secure it to go to lunch . He was sat in the seat and the machine was switched on by the operative and deadman put in place . His PPE jacket got caught in the deadman/seat and he lifted himself up to release it . He knocked the deadman and this caused him to hit the control lever to the dipper arm . The dipper arm slewed and hit a colleague who was standing at ground level by a dumper and the bucket hit him . Safey alert has been issued to all site operatives. Review of RA for Excavators and Dumpers and PPE.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: During his pre-shift preparation before leaving the depot , the IP drove his asphalt lorry forwards into the loading area , this was parked beside a grab lorry that had been loaded and parked in this position over the weekend . The IP exited his lorry and walked to the back of the grab lorry to collect a water hose . Following this the IP walks between the same grab lorry and an adjacent skip to turn the water tap on to enable him to fill up the water bottles needed for his work . As the IP walked in between the grab lorry and the skip he appears to have tripped and fallen over debris on the ground and then immediately afterwards appears to have landed on his left hand side and back causing injury to his left leg .

At Approximately 14.45 on <NAME>  <NAME>  on the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> lifting operations where being carried out to lift a 3t 360 excavator from the low level basement up to a pile cap approximately 1m up from the basement The lift was being supervised by <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> who was the acting crane supervisor for <NAME> Homes the principal contractor for the project , <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> was being assisted during these lifting operations by <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> slinger signalling working for <NAME> <NAME> ltd the sub contractor for the project , all works being carried out in guidance with the signed <NAME> Homes lifting plan which in the absents of the appointed person was being managed by <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ,the 360 excavator was landed successfully and the chains removed from the load with <NAME> instructing the crane driver to lower the block to remove the shortening clutches , as the 4 leg chains were released the instruction was given to hoist the crane up , there are conflicting statements on who gave the instruction to hoist up with <NAME> ( crane supervisor ) saying in his statement that he gave the instruction to hoist up with both <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> the ( I.P) also stating that no hand signals where issued however <NAME> <NAME> the crane driver stating that he was following hand signals from <NAME> <NAME> the crane hoisted up in 1st then <NAME> gear and as the crane was hoisting up one of the hooks of the chain snagged on a section of reinforcement bar attached to the side of the pile cap this caused the chain to come under tension and as the chain released itself the chain capitulated up and spun round catching <NAME> <NAME> on the left cheek knocking him to the ground first aid was issued at the scene by <NAME> <NAME> first aider and a paramedic an ambulance was called by <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> was taken to hospital by ambulance Unfortunately it was not possible to interview <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> - <NAME> as he left his position within the company prior to my site investigationtAdvise lifting plan risk assessment be amended to highlight the hazard of snagging chains and active slinger signaler must have control of the chains at all times until above head height. Advise that clear and precise radio signals be primary means of communication where practicable so that an emergency stop signal can be issued immediately if a problems occurs advise that the crane supervisor supervising the lift is in a better position to give clear and precise instructions i .e at the actual working area or allow the slinger signaler a radio to allow him to give the clear and precise instructions via radio which would be better than hand signals from such a distance advise crane driver hoists up in 1st gear until above the operatives head and a clear signal given preferable by radio that it is safe to go up in a higher gear Tool box talk to be given highlighting the above a safety alert has already been issued by

<NAME> <NAME> was inserting a formwork column into a socket . He connected a lifting strap to a quick hitch device on an excavator to help raise the formwork into an upright position . As the column was being raised the strap released from the excavator . <NAME> <NAME> moved away from the column , however , as the column fell it propelled him to the ground . On picking himself up <NAME> <NAME> realised that he had struck his nose on the ground . A subsequent visit to a clinic confirmed a broken nose . It is suspected that the quick hitch either released prematurely or was not properly secured by <NAME> <NAME> . The site team have been reminded on the importance of checking that lifting slings are properly secured in order to prevent a similar incident occurring .

The installation of a false ceiling grid had been completed , the incident happened when breaking down the working platform , a guard rail broke and a fall happened while passing section of the platform down to an other operative . The platform has been removed and will not be re-used . I have notified our H & S inspector and he giving additional training to site for the erecting / dismantling of platforms , working from heights and manual lifting

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The IP was walking between the canteen and site office to collect tools . The authorised walking route was obstructed by scaffolding so the IP walked around on the corex sheeting where the IP tripped on a ripped section of the sheeting . When the IP fell , they cut their right hand open on an exposed screw . The IP then attended <NAME> <NAME> where they were diagnosed with a broken right hand .

<NAME> a sub contractor of<NAME>, was completing a painting task on a cement truck within the company workshop.The task involved climbing a ladder[ which is fixed to the cement truck]this was the method of access to the work area. <NAME> had already been completing the task on a prior  shift. The task involved painting the top area of the cement truck in particular the area where stones are kept. <NAME> was wearing coveralls, safety boots, gloves.at approximately 10.15am <NAME> tripped and fell to grade from the cement truck. It is possible that <NAME> tripped/slipped on a dust sheet which he had positioned at the work area. <NAME> fell onto his back, he was asked to stay still whilst support was sourced. <NAME>decided to kneel and after a visual inspection of his back area he stood up. he then walked to the office and he asked for some pain relief and a drink of water which he was given. he consumed his bottle of water returned to the locker area and removed his coveralls, at which time post a discussion he decided to go home, he was advised not to drive and was given a lift home at his request. the company managing director received a call at 14:15 from <NAME>'s wife saying that she had taken him to hospital., and that he would be staying in hospital [<NAME>].

The carpenter involved had uncovered the loft access hatch aperture on the flat roof in order to roll out breather membrane over the insulation on the flat roof already in situ . The site agent did request that the aperture should be blocked from underneath first . Forgetting that the hatch aperture was there , the carpenter walked over the membrane and onto the aperture , at which point the membrane ripped and the carpenter fell through the hole in the membrane and the aperture .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> was walking backwards on site pulling a shot blast machine . He slipped , fell over onto his right side and the shot blast machine fell onto his left hip .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> was inspecting a recent installation of a ventilation canopy , she was standing on a Hop-Up , she stepped down from the Hop-Up , stood back without looking behind her and tripped over a raised drain stack

The incident happened whilst one of our <NAME> squads on this project was carrying out their first fix works to one of the clusters on <NAME> <NAME> projectThe Following is as per the injured parties statement as there was no witness .Our site operative <NAME> was reaching to the top core hole in a wall ( 2350mm high ) to install a draw wire whilst holding on to a metal stud to steady himself ( there was 13no plaster boards stacked against the wall and sitting on the floor and against the wall below the core hole ) . As he put his feet back flat on the ground he felt as if one board pushed against him so he has tried to grab the stud again to steady himself but before he knew it the boards had fell against him and he was trapped beneath them all.After the incident I stopped all our works immediately and gave all our operatives a toolbox talk on the dangers/Risks of stacked boards . We have a method on site of tying back all stored boards back to the structure to prevent the above from happing whilst stored in areas . But the boards in the incident were boards that have been left on the floor and then put against the wall while being cut and fitted . We are reviewing this and are trying to eliminate the need for boards to be stacked against walls .

IP was tasked with carrying out minor repairs to woodwork in a domestic property that had become void . The IP only had to fit an archatrave to a first floor door and he would be finished . The accident happend when he was carrying a length of wood up a set of stairs . The IP tripped on an exposed carpet gripper and fell forward up the stairs , dropping the load . He then righted himself and turned to go back down the stairs where his foot caught the carpet gripper again , he fell forward down the stairs , 8 to 10 steps . Falling forward , the back of his left hand and his head hit the mule post . The impact between his hand on the mule post fractured 2 bones in his hand / wrist.An investigation is ongoing , initial recomendations to prevent recoourance are ensure , where carpet grippers are present , operatives are warned of the tripping hazard , adequate lighting is in place ensuring grippers can be seen - any grippers that are found to be loose / inappropriately positioned are to be replaced and houskeeping processes keep traffic routes adequately clean and free of tripping hazards .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured person was working as part of a floor laying team in an area excluded to others and as he was walking across the floor area he put his foot through a open service hatch in the floor , the service hatch was opened as part of the preperation for laying floor coverings . The hatch opening in the floor measured 300mm by 200mm .

Paving Slabs stacked incorrectly causing them to tumble onto victims leg/foot . Treated with ice and positioned comfortably until ambulance arrived . Resulted in a break and fracture to the leg/foot area . Landscaper has had manual handling training and toolbox talks on this area , this will be repeated next month .
lifting pipework onto a trailer one of the pipes slipped , bounced and made contact with Forearm applying weight between forearm and bed of trailor

While the operative was on labour only  hire to [NAME] contracting  he was  working  on the above site labouring around the asphalt machine that was laying the new road he went round the front of the asphalt paver to push the remainder of the material in to the  conveying tunnel from the side of the hopper  of the machine when it was coming up to the finished joint he then got his left foot caught between existing road surface  and front of the machine , to try and prevent this from happening again tool box talks will be re issued stating that all machinery should be isolated when this task is needed to be preformed

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: [NAME] tripped over his own feet and then fell down the step nearby he continued working

Accident happened as baton broke while I was working on rear of the roof near the ridge line right hand side of chimney {see picture} , I then lost footing as baton broke and tumbled down roof towards scaffold at gutter line , I was then told that due to insufficient scaffolding {see picture} it meant that I fell down onto a lower roof then onto a lower scaffold which had no safety barrier / barge board ,which meant I then fell further onto a lower tiled roof and then fell off this down onto ground level

Amendment to incident number  : [NAME] : Whilst carrying out the application of paint to steel beams by spray from a podium tower , the operative sprayed a steel beam then turned around without moving the podium to spray another beam behind him . As his weight transfered onto the other side of the podium tower from where he was working , the wheel of the podium tower gave way and the podium toppled to one side . The podium tower either belonged or was hired in by another trade contractor on the site and with one of their operatives permission , our operative built the tower and used it for his work whilst awaiting for a mobile scaffold tower to be delivered to site that was to be supplied by [NAME] [NAME] . Our operative has received training in the use of mobile scaffold towers and podiums and holds a valid PASMA certificate . The podium toppled with our operative still inside . Our operative sustained a cut above his left eyebrow receiving 7 stitches and also a break/fracture to his arm/elbow . It has been reported that the podium was found to have a loose bolt where the wheel secures to the podium tower .

painter using steps positioned steps side ways on , rather than face on . Whilst carrying out work on slight incline injured party and steps fell . Painter accepts that alternative measures which were available should have been used . Tool box talk provided to all employees reinforcing safe use of ladders and step ladders , risk assessment reviewed .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: operative working on a temporary deck within an underpin excavation . Operative stood on one end of deck that was not suitably supported causing him to fall to the side onto two horizontal acrow props on the same level as the temporary deck / platform .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: [NAME] was walking along the middle level of the scaffold at rear plots 12 – 15 he stumbled and put his hand out to stop himself resulting in an injury to his hand which became swollen

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: [NAME]  ( employee of  [NAME] ) entered the toilet block / welfare facilities in the [NAME] [NAME] . Whilst entering [NAME] slipped on a metal door threshold which caused him to stagger forward - as he tried to correct himself he fell over on to the wet floor of the toilet block ( it was wet outside as was the threshold strip as was [NAME] ' footwear ) . There was no task briefing in place for this activity but welfare was discussed at the induction which [NAME] had on [Date] ( Ind no 1637 ) . No first aid was given as he decided he would leave work for the day and see how it was the next morning . When he woke the morning of [Date] he was in severe pain in his right hand and it had become bruised from his wrist to the knuckle area . [NAME]  returned to work as normal at 7.30 am on the [Date] and informed our supervisor , [NAME], that he would need to restrict his work because of of the injury . [NAME] informed [NAME] ( [NAME] ) of the injury and it was reported in the accident book , [NAME] was advised to attend the NHS Walk in centre for medical advice . [NAME] accompanied [NAME] to the walk in centre and they advised him to have an xray - this was carried out at the A & E [NAME],but was inconclusive .  [NAME] was advised to rest and follow up with a visit to his GP , which he did on the [Date] , and the GP signed him off for one week . ( [NAME] is an experienced bricklayer and has been in the construction industry for many years , and has been at the  [NAME] for over 3 months with no previous incicdents recorded. It was a wet day outside causing slippery conditions ,[NAME] slipped / tripped on a door threshold as he entered the toilet block and fell to the ground injuring his hand as he tried to break his fall . A faulty water heater was leaking causing water to collect on the floor - it is possible that this contributed to water being on the floor in the location of the accident.To prevent a similar incident occuring the following action has been taken - anti-slip treatment threshold has been installed , a lead has been appointed from the [NAME]  team specifically to ensure the welfare facilities are inspected on a daily basis and any issues recorded and reported. Records of inspections are kept in the toliet area ( laminate sheet with time of inspection and signatures ) . The worforce are to be encouraged to report any issues with the welfare facilities directly to [NAME] site management team . A number of maintenance issues have been raised with the hire company prior to this accident and are in the process of being closed out .

Company tradesmen are carrying out some dilapidation repairs on a clients premises.A small area of glazed canopy and fire escape walkway had been removed and was being replaced by a timber flat roof with a fibre glass covering to it.This was effectively in a rear passage way behind the shop.The size of this roof was approximately 1.3 x 4.0 m and the roof deck height was 3 m. During the installation of the roof boarding , The foreman joiner was working on the roof deck . The second joiner , who was effectively working at ground floor level was waiting to be given the size to cut the final roof board .It appears that the second joiner had climbed up a pair of steps ( not the access to the roof ) , for reasons still not fully known , pending getting this.It is thought that he may have done this just to observe what was being done or to get in a better position to hear the sizes being shouted to him.The area where the steps had been placed wasnt particularly level.It is thought , at this time , that the steps have started to go over , probably because the floor wasnt level and the joiner has then grabbed hold of a brickwork paraphet in front of him to steady himself and the immediate area of brickwork has come away .The joiner has then fallen to the floor with the brickwork falling onto a low level wall adjacent to him , breaking the fall , and then coming to rest at ground level bending the steps that had toppled over. Both ladders and tower scaffold were provided to carry out the works by the company to carry out the work however due to the width restriction to the passageway the tower sent couldnt be used.The ladder was used initially but due to the restricted nature of the work the operatives decided to use their steps. Unfortunately the steps involved with the incident were n't actually being used as access or a working platform. For the main element of the works a narrower tower should have been utilised and ladders used for access to the roof instead of the steps.There doesnt appear to be any reason at this time for the joiner to be up the steps he was on .

[NAME] ascended a fixed ladder to access the first lift of scaffolding and slipped on the third or fourth rung . [Name] was carrying a broom and the ladder may have been more slippery due to a cleaning process being carried out . An investigation report has been carried out and it was agreed brooms would be left on each level , [NAME] was also reminded of the " 3 points of contact " with ladders which he had learnt on recent training .

The IP was engaged in making good works between a steel member and concrete ceiling slab . He was carrying a bucket of cement mortar which he placed on the lower step of a podium platform whilst in the process of climbing on . The exact circumstances are unclear , but it appears that whilst he tried to pick up the bucket when intending to start the work he dropped it on his foot and fell backwards . Through a third party he alerted the site 's first aider and was helped to the welfare area . He was then driven to hospital for treatment , where he also receive an x-ray .At the time of preparing the report it seems likely that the IP sustained a hairline fracture in the top of his foot , but this is not completely confirmed . He has been signed off work for six weeks .The injury occurred whilst the IP was undertaking a routine operation . However , in an effort to ensure no repeat , the company has inspected the podium step in detail and make sure it is assembled exactly in accordance with the manufacturer 's instructions .

The Injured Person was working on site as a roofer. His work area at the time of the accident was at the roof of <NAME>.Injured person was descending the scaffolding staircase on <NAME> Scaffolding. As he reached the 3rd platform lift and stepped onto the scaffolding boards and they collapsed from beneath him.The injured person fell 4m down to the next scaffold stair landing, falling on top of scaffolding battens. The alarm was raised and the first aider attended the IP, an ambulance was called. The IP was taken to <NAME> A&E Department.Upon investigation of the area of the accident, it was discovered that a transom had been dislodged from the Cuplock standard. This transom was supporting the boards that fell, when the IP stepped on the boards they gave way. At the time of the investigation the securing "cup" was observed as being lifted up from the transoms and ledgers. Also, a wing bracer tube adjacent to the dislodged transom, was bent and had been damaged. It is believed that the damage to the wing brace caused the unsecured ledger to be dislodged from the standard.A full inspection of the scaffold and all other scaffolds took place by the scaffolding contractor and the <NAME> H&S Team, to ensure that this had not been repeated elsewhere on site.A general Safety Alert has been sent out to all <NAME> to double check all <NAME>, in particular at staircase units and that all cups are secured in place.

Turning over a plastic mortar tub/bin to empty and clean the bin to be used for concrete placement works in another area on site . IP pulled the bin/tub over towards himself and it was at this point when he managed to pull the bin/tub over and on to the bridge of his left foot .

A roofing sub-contractor was in the process of providing felt and batten to a new lean-to-roof, single storey. As the roof has been recently constructed, the rafters from the eves to the external face of the existing building has been constructed. Within the rafters there is an opening for a velux window approx 4ft x 4ft. The roofer was working towards the opening and leaned back towards the opening and fell through onto the floor approximately 2.5 meters below. Action taken - All openings within the area of works will be covered with a suitable material such as timber ply board, youngmans boards / crawl boards, and secured to the rafters / roof structure, to prevent operatives falling through. Tool box talks with site personell and management meetings have discussed the events leading to the accident and the control measures that are to be implemented following the accident.

The plaster was skimming a small section of ceiling Rather than move the scaffold he plastered the small section of ceiling using a small set of steps.The plaster over reached and fell approximately to the floorThe plaster landed on a solid floor

Injured Person was climbing a ladder to access the mezzanine level, as he climbed he hit his head (hat), he was wearing a hard hat, on a fixed horizontal scaffold brace, this in turn made the operative lose his balance and fall from the ladder. IP left site without reporting the accident, our Contracts Manager rang him as he had left site, he left site due to being in shock, he has been accessed in [NAME] hospital and concluded that he had suffered a compression fracture of the L1 verterbral body

The skip lorry driver lowered the arms in preparation to lift a loaded skip . While attempting to retrieve the skip lorry chains from the top of a skip load of plasterboard a second operative operated the arms of the skip lorry and lowered them after wrongly being asked to raise them resulting in the drivers arms becoming trapped between the skip and the arms of the skip lorry

Injured party was tightening a bolt into a unistrut bracket with one hand . The spanner slipped off the 17mm bolt head and he hit his hand on the vertical upright of the bracket he was putting together . The injured party was using an open ended spanner which was not the correct tool for the job . Offset Ring Spanners to be used in similar tasks.
working outside plot <NAME> - shovelling around services and hit a rock and bent wrist .

<NAME> <NAME> ( Security supervisor ) was called to attend the maintenance workshop to look at <NAME> <NAME> ( maintenance operative ) foot as three paving slabs had toppled over onto his foot. When <NAME> arrived at the workshop <NAME> was sitting with his boot and sock off . There was signs of bruising above the toes with slight swelling . <NAME> advised <NAME> to visit the hospital for an xray . <NAME> <NAME> ( technical coordinator ) took <NAME> to hospital and an appointment was made for <NAME> to attend the fracture clinic on <NAME> 1st <NAME> . <NAME> submitted his sick note for 3 weeks taking him not fit for work until the  <NAME> and the doctors comments state right foot crushing injury . The sick note also states that the doctor does n't need to see him after the  <NAME> . <NAME> was at the time wearing issued steal toe boots and the activity at the time of injury was lifting the paving slabs onto the <NAME> <NAME> for transportation to the area of works .
Operative was using a hammer and punch . He missed the punch and the hammer hit his thumb

Whilst installing fire protection the building operative went to collect a 20mm glassroc board , which was underneath some 15mm fireline boards . The operative leaned fireline boards up while trying to get to glassroc board and the fireline boards started to fall towards him . The operative tried to catch boards but could not and could not get out of the way and his leg was broken .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: A van driver arrived at a delivery , parked and walked onto site to find somebody to sign his paperwork . Some scaffold boards were being used as a gangway from the ground to the opening of the front door , and lifted around 30cm from the floor . The driver walked up this gangway , one of the boards slipped and he fell to the floor cutting his knee and injuring his wrist. He has advised me that we has been signed off work for two weeks with a fractured wrist , however he has so far been unable to provide me with a medical certificate confirming this .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Came down the steps ,stepped back and twisted ankle in floor chasefell backwards and hurt his back, taken to hospital for check up.

[Name] lorry arrived at [NAME] construction. Galvanised steel sections on the back of the [NAME] lorry , were unstrapped by the driver [NAME] . The driver was on the bed of the lorry and said to [NAME] who was on the drivers side of the lorry , was told that no one else was allowed on the bed of the lorry . [NAME] ( a [NAME] employee ) was stood at the back right hand corner of the lorry . [NAME] passed [NAME] the driver a brace bar as [NAME] said he was going to ‘bump’ the steel to shift the galvanised sections . The [NAME] forklift had n’t even engaged in lifting the steel sections off the lorry at this point. At this point [NAME] put one foot on the lorry ( about 750mm from the ground ) on the passengers side wheel protection bars , he had n’t even touched the galvanised sections , they started to slide towards him as they fell off the lorry . The steel fell to the drivers side of the lorry. [NAME] fell onto some steel that was lying next to the lorry on our loading area , taking off some of the primed paint as he fell . He landed on his left hand side/back . [NAME] also caught his hand as he fell cutting at least two fingers . [NAME] rushed to see him lying on the steel. [NAME] managed to pick himself up and crawl into the workshop , cursing loudly that the driver moved the steel and he should n’t have . At this point [NAME] rushed into the office asking for [NAME] , who was out . I ( [NAME] ) rushed out to find [NAME] doubled up on the floor in agony , with blood all over his hand . [NAME] and [NAME] managed to help him up and get him into a seated position into the staff room where I administered first aid to his hand and his breathing . At this point [NAME] called 999 . The steel has remained on the lorry where it had slid and fell . It was not moved until such point that the lads were instructed too by [NAME] . Statement by the two parties involved  [NAME] has said that the driver used the brace bar to move the steel . This is what caused the steel to shift towards him . [NAME]  ( [NAME]). [NAME] said that he was passed the brace bar but had n’t moved the steel , they just slipped away from him . ”

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Please note this report is being submitted to retract RIDDOR report - F91A5B5B2E. The initial verbal diagnosis from the hospital that our operative sustained a hairline fracture to his right ankle was incorrect . We have now received medical documentation contradicting the original diagnosis informing us that the operative sustained a contusion to his right ankle .The injured party was walking through an internal corridor leading to the plant room after retrieving a data stick from the estates office when he tripped over used AHU filters . As a result of the trip the operative landed awkwardly on his right ankle when attempting to regain balance .
Operative was marking holes that needed drilling and a stack of plasterboard that was stored vertically came down and trapped his legs.

Whilst taking the washing machine into Plot 51 using a sack truck the wheel came off the curb after maneuvering round an obstacle sending the machine , sack truck and installer off balance . The installer put his left hand down resulting in some small bones being fractured . The installer agreed that he should of moved the obstacle out of the way instead of going round it .

Techician fell from tractor while install cab entry door . Door was in position bottom hinge and door latch secure , door supported by second person from ground technician fell when lost balance securing top hinge fixing . Technician was using tractor rock shaft as secure platform to stand on ( 1.3m from ground level ) and holding on to cab roof whilst attempting to secure top hinge with one hand . Lost balance and fell to ground

Apprentice carpenter was asked to secure some truss straps in a single storey garage roof . This task should have been completed using a ladder , but the operative pulled himself up into the roof space and used the truss to stand on whilst completing the task . When he tried to climb down he has lost his grip in the truss and fallen to the floor subsequently cutting his face and fracturing his elbow . An investigation report has been completed and tool box talks completed to the carpentry contractor on safe working at height .
[Name] The operative has sustained the following injuries Broken ShoulderBroken arm in 3 places L/ABroken ribs down L/H2 broken ribs down R/H Punctured  lung.

The IP was working as part of a 7 man team moving [NAME] pipe along the deck area . On e of the supporting A frames toppled over when the pipe was being moved and landed on the IP 's leg causing a fracture to the tibia and fibula .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Whilst carrying out a measurement survey in the roof plant area [NAME] stepped backwards tripping over a spare palletised pump sitting on the floor . He put his hand out to break his fall , later finding ou at the hospital that his wrist was fractured . His hand & forearm are in plaster but he is back at work today ( [Date] ) . Barriers have been around pump to section off from passers by .

Using step ladders to second fix a fan isolation switch above the bathroom door on the landing of the first floor of a customers house . For an unknown reason the ladders folded or collapsed resulting in me falling, hitting my elbow on the ladder then tumbling head first down the stairs, smashing a plant pot at the bottom .

Cleaning of windows at the above address , operatives cleaning windows off a wooden ladder when the ladder broke whilst climbing from ground level to a window on the first floor. Following our investigation the ladder had rotted in an area which caused the ladder to break . Ladder checks were carried out on [ Date] but no sign of external rotting could be seen at this time . Action to be taken to prevent similar incidents will be that all wooden ladders shall not be used and taken out of action following this incident .
Materials loaded onto board trolley , trolley became unstable due to overloading and led to it toppling onto operative trapping him underneath .

whilst holding a short piece of lath ( 150mm ) trying to trim off a small section using a battery operated saw . He should not have been using a saw he was not trained to use . This was his own saw we have since found out. PREVENTION We have issued a letter to all employees stating they must not use these saws they will sign and return them into their H & S File

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The individual who was injured , arrived on site and parked in the designated area . He then walked via his normal route to his place of work i.e Construction office building in the [NAME] [NAME] . As he turned direction walking past and close to existing porta-cabins he noticed running water coming from the cabin fixed guttering , to his left ( due to heavy and continued rainfall and wind conditions ) . On seeing this he moved further to his right hand side , upon which he slipped and fell to the ground . The ground is made up of flat concrete , no undulation or steps and there were no obstacles in the way creating any trip hazard . The ground was wet and had surface water and pooling due to the weather conditions at that time . The injured person shouted for assistance , which was immediate from the occupied cabin adjacent to where he fell . The injured person was comforted until an ambulance arrived .

[NAME] was unloading a pallet of flags and passing them to [NAME] [NAME] who was placing them next to his work area ( landing area in front of plot 1 front door ) . When [NAME] took a flag from the pack 2 more fell and made contact with his right leg . No equipment involved.A tool box talk has been completed following the accident covering the safe working method for unpacking palletised paving slabs .
Fell from the skip steps to avoid a falling object landing heavily on his wrist

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> was walking on an area of uneven pavement , in changing direction <NAME> 's foot landed on an uneven surface which caused his foot to go over sideways and his right ankle bone made contact with the ground .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: He was on the main roof and slipped on his right foot , slipping backwards and has done something to his left foot .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The operative was dismantling a scaffold on the gable end of ceder house , this was a non working lift which had 3 boards wide with external handrails , when walking along the boards from one side to the other he passed under a diagonal brace putting his left leg through first then bringing his right leg next , when he stepped on the board the board slipped and his right leg fell through the gap , he grabbed the handrail to stop him slipping through the boards but his left leg twisted whilst this happened and was causing him a large amount of discomfort . He then came down the ladder to the ground and works were stopped and he returned to the office to report it . The following day the scaffold was inspected by the supervisor and the remaining scaffold lifts were all completely filled with scaffold boards and all operatives were informed to make sure they inspect each lift prior to dismantling any scaffold .
The operative was helping the delivery driver offload a cable drum , when the drum of cable fell onto his left hand

The IP is a highways operative and as he was removing a lid from a gulley drain for it to be excavated , the IP stepped into the drain and fell . The IP put one of his hands out to break his fall and fractured his scaphoid bone .

The sub contractor ( <NAME> <NAME> ) was working for <NAME> Homes <NAME> undertaking plastering activity , fixing skim tape to a wall . The injured person <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> was using a pair of step ladders leaning against a wall instead of opening the step ladders against the wall and the ladders slipped and then <NAME> <NAME> fell to the floor . Scaffolding was available in plot 1 for use .All staff will be given tool box talks on the safe use of step ladders and the importance of using the scaffolding provided .

The Injured person was is employed by a Sub-Contract <NAME> company and was engaged in internal first fix joinery operations within <NAME> 18 . The works being carried out at the time involved the application of a membrane to a section of wall above unsheeted roof trusses. In order to gain access to this section , The IP used a step ladder which was positioned running parallel to the wall which he was working on . The area above the trusses contained a ventilation duct which had been installed previously and in order to achieve a position in which he could work , he had to twist and bend around the duct . On descent of the step ladder , The IP was manipulating his body around the duct when he displaced his body weight to his left . At this point the stepladders fell over to the right causing the IP to fall the remaining distance of approximately 1 (one ) meter to the floor . As he landed on the floor , most of the impact was absorbed by his left elbow. <NAME>  was taken immediately to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> by one of his work colleagues . The incident was not reported to site management until approximately 15:30 hrs by one of his work colleagues.Prior to this incident , on<NAME> the Injured Person and his colleagues received a stop order from <NAME> <NAME> 's <NAME> <NAME> for carrying out this task from metal trestles spanned by scaffold boards with no fall prevention or mitigation measures in place . The subcontractor was then instructed to provide a tower scaffold to carry out this work safely . On investigation it was established that the tower scaffold had been delivered to site on <NAME>, however parts were missing so it could not be used . This was reported to the subcontractor at the time , however the subcontractor took no action.The subcontractor was provided with podium steps on <NAME>, was instructed to revise their Risk Assessments and Method statement and to deliver training to their operatives on safe working at height and accident reporting procedures , again the subcontractor took no action .During a follow-up inspection on <NAME> the Sub-Contract joiners were observed working from the incomplete tower scaffold which was still on site . A second stop order was placed on the works , after which the subcontractor walked off site and has not returned . We have eventually been able to make contact with the injured person who has provided information relating to the exact nature of his injury , however the report is not specific and refers to a "radial head or neck fracture to the elbow" .
operative jumped onto window frame , slipped and fell

Injured party( IP ) was erecting temporary roads signs for traffic management , IP was on the grass verge whilst positioning a sign and fell down into the open chamber . The chamber is approx . 2 ft x 4 ft and was missing the metal frame and cover and was overgrown with vegetation .

Operative attended site and had been on site a month . Operative had received induction and had a current CSCS card . Operative was briefed in RAMS for work at height and had received two toolbox talks whilst on site . Work at height cannot be eliminated and due to site constraints stepladder use is unavoidable . The operatives employer operate a permit to work for stepladders.The operative was placing a 600mm square piece of OSB. He was working from a stepladder and he slipped . His leg fell through the treads during the fall and broke his leg . It was found from investigation that he was using the ladder incorrectly and had not obtained a permit to work . As a consequence operatives have been re-briefed on work at height that 1 ) stepladder is a last resort equipment - tower , podium or hop up first2 ) permit to work system re-briefed to all3 ) supervision increased4 ) those not adhering to site procedures will be disciplined .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured person <NAME> who was a <NAME> <NAME> employee and a trained vehicle marshal was banking a wide load lorry at the time of the incident . At about 7.30am on <NAME> the IP <NAME> was walking backwards banking the vehicle when he tripped over a steel lifting beam causing him to fall backwards , he put out his hands to break his fall which resulted in a broken right wrist . The following measures have now been implemented :Good housekeeping practises to be maintained at all times . Area to be checked regularly throughout the day Tool box talk to be delivered on traffic management by supervisor Two vehicle marshals are now in attendance at all times , one marshal at the front of the vehicle to give additional guidance and the second at the rear . The marshals will be in radio contact at all times .Marshals to be advised to stop the vehicle and move to a place of safety before commencing with the reversing , this is to minimise the vehicle marshal walking backwards as much as possible .A suitable racking system to be installed for all the lifting accessories i .e . spreader beams

<NAME> was dismantling safety decking on the ground floor of plot 164/165 . They should stand on floor stepping over joists , or boards should be fixed to the floor with handrails fixed if required .

description: IP was working at the rear / top of a recently completed concrete headwall at <NAME>  <NAME> He was backfilling behind the wall with limestone gravel to the top of the wall . They misjudged the level difference either side of the wall and in doing so , whilst stepping down , caught his left foot on the wall top causing his lower leg to twist . During the lower leg twisting , <NAME> heard a crack and felt pain in his lower leg and was then unable to walk without some difficulty . The team leader assisted IP to the welfare cabin , helped remove his boot and noticed no discernible swelling . <NAME> was still experiencing pain so they went to <NAME> <NAME> , an x-ray was taken confirming a fracture to the left fibula .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Our driver was collecting a triple extending ladder from client site . During loading he gained access to the back of the vehicle , a 2wd [NAME] [NAME] [NAME] Up in order to secure the load . When alighting the vehicle via the tailgate that was in the lowered position he stumbled and put out his hands to break his fall . This resulted in a fracture to his left wrist and dislocation and fracture to his right thumb . He also sustained a graze above his left eye and a small cut to his index finger of his right hand . The driver got up off the floor and one of the clients team took our driver to [NAME] hospital for initial treatment . We arranged to collect him after his treatment approximately 1 hour after his entry to hospital . Following his initial treatment we took him along to [NAME]  in [NAME]. Treatment has included resetting his thumb and dressing and strapping his left wrist . Further to his visit on the 1st he has revisited hospital today to attend a fracture clinic for further assessment. Actions taken to prevent similar incidents occurring : We have issued a briefing to all branches for all staff to be reminded of our safe loading procedure including minimising risk by loading / unloading vehicle from ground level where possible and taking care when accessing and egressing vehicles. In addition, our current policy states that gloves must be worn when loading and unloading equipment, unfortunately this was n't the case during this operation . A review will also be completed with the injured party on his return to work before normal duties are resumed. A further review of our safe system of work is to be completed during this month and any findings of this review will be communicated to all employees .

We were taking a large window out on the ground floor and it was made of wood and we needed to change the opening . I was on the outside levering the window and <NAME> <NAME> was on the inside pushing the window out . He chose to work from the inside and I 'm not sure why , how ever I did not see this being a problem as it never had been in the past . The window was loose and away from the wall on one side and I had a large bar to leaver it out so it would drop and we could clear it away . As I was leavening <NAME> said let me kick it out I said " no let me leaver it " sometimes <NAME> does n't always listen to me and in the past I have told him to pay attention and listen . He ignored my advise and said " no it 's ok I 'll kick it " as I was leavening the window ( aprox size 2mx2m ) I noticed him bracing to kick it so I jumped out the way as it may of dropped and hit me . As I moved he gave it a big kick but did not realise how loose the window was and fell forward with the window . He braced him self and put his arm out on a concrete surface and it resulted in him fracturing his left arm . It was very stupid of him and I was disappointed he had been so incompetent and ignored my instructions . Generally <NAME> is very hardworking and a good lad with good awareness and it was a shame he had taken those actions that day but I am sure it was a freak accident and a good lesson learnt to listen to his supervisors . He had taken out windows with me in the past and we have n't had any problems . After I had realised he hurt his arm I instructed <NAME> ( colleague ) to lock up and make sure the house was safe to leave . I then took <NAME> to the car sat him down made sure he was ok , he was hurt by his arm and he had no other injuries , I told him we will go to the nearest hospital because it looked like a broken wrist he was aware of what was going on . I rang his parents on the way as he is only 17 and thought they should know . When we got there the doctors confirmed it was broken and I had asked his dad to notify the collage . They asked me to fill out one of these forms .

An operative was installing electrical control panels into the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> control room. During the installation activity the IP identified that an end panel ( number 64 ) required manoeuvring for it to be secured on to a floor rail . The operative decided the best method was nudging  the panel into position . The IP decided to gain access to the rear of the panel without checking the security of a temporary plywood floor cover which was covering a cable duct ( approx 670mm depth ) . The IP stood on to the plywood cover with his right foot , and it gave way resulting in the IP's foot rapidly descended into the cable duct . This pushed and twisted the IPs foot causing a closed fracture to his right ankle . An Initial Incident Notification has been produced and circulated around the business to the highlight the incident and prevent recurrence .

Our operative <NAME> <NAME> was replacing a double glazed unit in the upper floor front bedroom . He had replaced and repacked the unit and was bending to pick up his hammer to fit the bead when he saw the unit was tipping out of the window glass enclosure , he reached up to hold it but it fell hitting his wrist. To avoid any further incidents all employees have been informed that anyone caught not wearing appropriate equipment may face disciplinary action . Regular toolbox talks shall remind employees of not wearing PPE using this incident as an example .

<NAME> <NAME> is a 59 year old plumber employed by the <NAME> & <NAME> of <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> & <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> was using a stepladder to access an intake air fan he was inspecting in a school kitchen . The MEWP operator was fitting bird spikes to the outer roof gantry area , it is believe the MEWP operator turned in the basket and stumbled against the control levers , the basket moved and trapped his hand that was resting on the handrail bar against a part of the building , the banksman lower the mewp from the working height to rescue the injured operator , sat him on the floor and called 999 , an ambulance arrived to take the operator to hospital .

Operator was preparing walls for painting from a scaffold tower when it appears that he over-reached and the tower leaned over and hit the wall being prepared . It then slid down the wall until it landed on the floor . He was too far away from the wall which he was preparing for painting and did not re-position the tower to reduce the gap . The tower which had been correctly assembled , has been dismantled to check its condition before being re-introduced . The operatives , have been re-trained on the existing safe working practice and the supervisors are being re-trained on the use of scaffold towers and on effective monitoring of usage . The painter who was injured will be receiving re-training on correct usage when he gets back .

lifted a sheet of ply of the floor and then dropped it on foot

<NAME> <NAME> was drilling the reinforced concrete in the corner of the hall using a rotary hand held core drill at roof level working from a MEWP.  Whilst drilling , the drill bit snagged which made the drill twist and caused his right arm to twist over with the drill injuring the right hand . He reported the accident to the first aider who applied a bandage as it was believed he had bruised his hand but there was no visible injury or bruising showing . He continued to work for the rest of the day carrying out drilling works as he maintained that he was not in any pain and fit to do so and could move his fingers and hand . He attended hospital later that night who informed him that he had sustained a spiral fracture to the metacarpal on the 4th finger on the right hand .Operatives have been reminded to use the drill in accordance with instructions and guidance and to carry out pre-start checks on the machine with daily drill bit checks . A toolbox talk has also been undertaken

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: As the operative was walking out from the men toilet block and down the access stairs he stepped to ground and twisted his ankle.  This could have occurred directly at the base of the steps or within 1m of the steps (actual location to be determined from the IP)The reported the incident to[NAME] (First aider and Supervisor for the Project) and returned to the site offices where he removed his boot and rested for approx 45 minutes.  ( [NAME] confirmed that he witnessed a bit of swelling).IP returned to work and continued to install batteries and cut trunking, before leaving site at the end of the shift.The IP contacted site on the [DATE] advised that he had attended hospital and his ankle was sprained and that he would not be attending work.The stairs to the mens toilet block were installed at the start of the project approximately [DATE].  The steps are supplied with the cabin installation, are constructed of metal checker plate painted black and of consist of a platform as you leave the welfare block and 3 steps each with a riser of 140mm.There is a hand rail on either side of the steps that is secure.The steps are positioned on compacted made ground.The ground below the bottom step has a slight fall, which may have been accentuated by weather erosion, resulting in a difference to the riser from left to right.  At time of the incident the IP was wearing work clothing which included lace up boots providing ankle support, even though the welfare is located in a non PPE area. Action Proposed to Prevent Recurrence. Daily briefings are always undertaken on ground conditions and they detail care is to be taken.  Review of stairs and landing areas to be undertaken on site.
