He fell 650mm fracturing his elbow . During the investigation the gate closing mechanism was in good working order.Preventitive action prior to the accident was inspection of podium steps . toolbox talks have been given on the safe use of podium steps.This is the second time I have submitted this accident on line and am doing so as I did not get a reporting Number . When it was reported on the [Date]

[NAME]was constructing a traditionally-built wooden roundhouse at the [NAME] [NAME] in [NAME] with assistance from [NAME] . The wooden roof panels were being added to the timber frame by [NAME] . A low scaffold was constructed to access the roof , incorporating a ladder , which was bolted to the scaffold and secured at the base . Whilst descending the ladder  [NAME] 's right foot slipped to the right and his left foot missed the rung as he tried to re-balance causing him to fall approximately 1 metre onto his left heel and then onto the floor .  [NAME] called to [NAME]  , who was talking to a member of the public at the time .  [NAME] quickly approached the scene , assessed the situation and used his mobile phone to call an ambulance . Whilst waiting for the ambulance ,  [NAME] made  [NAME] as comfortable as possible and followed instructions given by the emergency call centre . When the ambulance arrived the paramedics took charge of the situation and  [NAME] was taken to  [NAME] . Work on the roundhouse ceased whilst a review was undertaken and another professional timber framer is employed . The importance of being careful and concentrating at all times whilst working was re-emphasised .
Working on a Flat roof , the person stepped over a roll of felt and caught his foot which unbalanced him , and then proceeded to jump from the roof to try and land on his feet .

( Leading to the Accident)  to the day of the accident , a number of operatives where working on the flat roof . At the end of that working day , site manager [NAME] asked the operatives to cover the whole flat roof including skylight openings with DPM membrane .( Details of Actual Accident) On the day of the accident ,[NAME] and one site operative went on to the roof to inspect it . When on the roof he was reminded by the site operative about the skylights covered with [NAME] who then asked  [NAME] to be careful. At around 8.20am ,  [NAME] was standing on the roof and was giving instructions to the site operative , he then took a step back and stood on the skylight opening that was covered with DPM.  He then fell through the opening and landed on his back on the concrete floor in the room below fracturing vertebrates in thoracic - lumber spine .An ambulance was called and took [NAME] to hospital where he underwent surgery . Following surgery , the doctor stated that [NAME] should soon be mobile and make a full recovery .(Actions to prevent similar Accidents occurring ) : Work was stopped and the roof area was checked for safety : Toolbox talks issued to all operatives working on the project : competent site manager appointed to run the site

Operative had works at height to be carried out at the top of a staircase . our procedure are to use equipment on site ( Steps or Oxford system ) on this occasion the operative made the decision to step onto an oak handrail , to support himself instead of getting the correct equipment . This has resulted in the handrail ( that is supported by 4/5 spindles ) to collapse and the operative to fall head first down one flight of stairs . striking his head and left shoulder and landing at the foot of the stairs . Another operative heard and attended him and raised the alarm .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: One of our electrical operatives [NAME] had an accident on site on [Date]. [NAME] was working on the physiotherapy refurbishment project , whilst carrying out electrical installation works, [NAME] stepped back onto a piece of conduit pipe . This caused his foot and ankle to twist which resulted in a fracture .

[NAME] [NAME] , an employee of [NAME] [NAME] , ( delivery driver and hiab operator ) arrived at the [NAME] [NAME] site to deliver a wagon load of bricks . [NAME] parked up , shut off the wagon and mounted the hiab . [NAME] started to offload the packs of bricks , grounding them to the rear of the wagon . After 12 packs were unloaded [NAME] dismounted from the hiab and moved the wagon forward approximately 3 to 4 metres to create more space to the rear of the wagon . The forward manoeuvre brought the wagon alongside some [NAME] fencing and several stacks of 100mm blocks to the left side of the wagon.P.L. re-mounted the hiab and continued to offload . [NAME] commenced the unloading of the 16th pack and moved his hiab forward to meet it . He grabbed the load , brought it closer and landed it on the trailer , moved the hiab backwards , grabbed the load and began slewing left . It is at this point that the wagon tipped and ejected [NAME] from the seat resulting in him hitting the ground . [NAME] stated that he has no recollection on delivering the last load . A site FLT driver went to [NAME] assistance who by this time had picked himself up . He escorted [NAME] to the site office where he was assessed by the site manager who is also a first aider . [NAME] was in a dazed state and seemed confused . He had taken a blow to the right side of his head , as there were graze marks to his hard hat . [NAME] was complaining about pains to his knee also . With the hospital only 0.2 miles away the site manager organised a labourer to take [NAME] to the hospital where he was later diagnosed with concussion and a fracture to a carpal bone of his left wrist.Based on witness statements , photographs and without an engineer report on the operability of the hiab equipment , it appears that the wagon toppled due to an over-extension of the boom coupled with a reduced stability of the wagon as the load decreased. [Name] has no recollection of what happened immediately before or after the accident but he confirmed that he was lifting the load over the heras fencing and 100mm blocks .The operator’s lack of experience in not realising that the wagon’s lateral stability was reduced , coupled with a perception that the heras fencing and blocks to the left of the wagon were an obstacle to avoid , may have affected his usual method of operation. A review of the training provided to the driver/hiab operators should be undertaken to ensure that only the established procedures for unloading are adhered to. Toolbox talks or refresher training is recommended to review all procedures for all drivers arriving on site . A review of the risk assessment/method statements to include a section on what actions are to be taken when there is a change of location , procedure or method due to the limits of the site .Review the type of equipment used.Consider using equipment that has seat belts fitted .
<NAME> was placing his tool bag through a window onto the otherside.  As he lent through the window he hurt his ribs.  To reduce the weight in the tool bag  and walk round with tools.

The employee was using a magnetic drill on a metal beam section at Height . the drill bit jammed in the second hole that was being drilled , causing the drill to spin around , losing magnetic contact resulting in the drill hitting the employee in the head , cheek and nose . the drill had not been secured by chain or carver clamp . The employee was taken to the local hospital where his injuries were assessed the hospital stitched and glued the injury to the cheek . The employee returned to work the following day  <NAME> . Due to continued discomfort he sought further medical intervention at his local hospital ( <NAME> ) We have now been informed that he has a fractured cheek bone , and waiting for an appointment with the Maxcillofacial unit.Following this incident a full training session was carried out to reinforce the safe use of Magnetic Drills.

The operative was set to task pointing flags for the day . When rain was on the horizon he borrowed a ladder from the client and was trying to install a draped cover from gutter level over the pointing in order it did not get wet and also did not touch and mark the wet pointing .

The lorry driver was unstrapping his equipment and one of the straps was caught . He climbed on to the neck of the trailer to release the strap and when it gave way he lost his balance and fell to the ground . The delivery was on a public road but the road had been closed by <NAME> <NAME> to undertake works that included using the level crossing . We are a sub-contractor to <NAME> and at the time of the incident was delivering <NAME> plant equipment to work on track . We have had similar incidents with lorry drivers and have trained/retrained drivers using the <NAME> Loader/Secure training , the IP has undertaken this .

IP was delivering roof trusses to the yard of a construction site for new homes . Whilst standing on the back of the vehicle ( 7.5T) , he missed his footing and fell off the vehicle . He had received H & S information , instruction and training , he was aware that he was not supposed to stand on the vehicle at any time . During investigations into the accident , the IP stated that he should n't have been doing what he was doing . The IP has sustained a fracture to the pelvis ( right side ) . No operation is required but the IP is off sick as a result of his injury .

Operative was off loading 1 tonne excavator from a beaver tail lorry . Whilst tracking down ramps of the beaver tail after a rain storm the tracks of the excavator came into contact with the metal frame of the ramp , This caused the excavator to slip sideways slightly . The operative then tried to right the excavator not realizing that the track was close to the gap between the ramps . The excavator slipped again and fell between the ramps. The operative tried to exit the excavator but it slipped again trapping his foot . Inmediate action: all 1 tonne excavators to be banned from tracking on to beaver tails .

The IP was pushing a PAV ( push around vertical )ECO lifter up a small plywood ramp towards a goods lift to move it between floors . For reasons not yet determined the IP lost control of the lifter which roll backwards down the short sloping ramp and forced his left hand backwards resulting in a fractured left wrist. The ECO lifter weighed in excess of 300 kilos , the operative was handling the equipment on his own. Incident is being fully investigated and briefings have been arranged for all staff regarding handling of PAV equipment on sloping ground . New manual Handling arrangements are being compiled for this equipment .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: At the time of the incident <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> were providing a traffic management setup for the surfacing works on the <NAME> , by <NAME> junction.On <NAME>  <NAME>  the team started laying out at 1830hrs approximately . The Injured person ( IP ) was working on the crash cushion vehicle . He was laying out cones from the cone well in the side of the crash cushion . One other operative was also in the back , passing cones to the IP. The main carriageway had already had 40mm planed off the surface . The team had a briefing prior to starting to lay out the job . They discussed that when they arrived at the <NAME> junction , the driver would stop the vehicle and the IP would leave the cone well of the vehicle and move the pre-laid cones to the front of the taper to close the junction of the <NAME> . The crash cushion set off heading south on the <NAME> in lane 1 of the carriageway laying out cones . At 1945hrs approximately they were at the predetermined location . The driver stopped the vehicle & the IP stepped out of the vehicle from the cone well . He has stepped off leading with his left foot . His foot has landed on the longitudinal joint that had been planed out . With the momentum of him getting down from the vehicle and his foot landing on the joint this has caused him to overbalance and then land on the carriageway . He has then jumped up and hopped over onto the verge . Once on the verge one of the operatives came across and undid his left lace up boot , at the IP's request to try and relieve the pain in his ankle . The site agent arrived and took him to <NAME> A and E in his car as this was quicker that getting an ambulance to the site . Once at <NAME> A and E the IP was x-rayed within  an hour & his ankle then put into a cast then re x-rayed to check the alignment . The IP was then released on <NAME> and informed it would be at least two weeks till a surgeon could be found to carry out the operation to repair his damaged talus bone .

Whilst carrying out the removal of a blockage on the crusher , the safety guard was raised , in an upright position but not secured correctly using the fasting provided . As a result of this the guard fell onto the operatives hand . An accident investigation has been carried out by the appropriate manager . Statements have been taken from all witnesses , along with photographic evidence . The information was reviewed at a health & safety meeting with senior management and corrective measures put in place which includes a revised Safe System of Work, Risk Assessment , and mechanical modification . Team briefing have been held with all operatives to ensure that Safe Working Systems  are followed .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: 1 of 2 (1 pushing and 1 guiding) moving a bin towards a hoist down a ramp, towards end of ramp operative 1 (guiding) sliped (boot heel caught on something) and fell backwards onto his rear, was helped off ground by operative 2, after a short while operative 1 began to feel discomfert when breathing, he went to inform his manager and then got changed and went home, early the following morning he attended hospital as pain was worse, was diagnosed with acute L1 fracture
He was unloading a podium step from the side of the van and the momentum of the podium steps going over the edge pulled him over . Jumping to avoid missing the podium steps landed awkwardly .

whilst pulling rods back from a horizontal directional drill shot , a subcontract drilling operative sustained several serious injuries . The injuries were as a result of stored energy within the rods and initial poor communication between the rig operator and the drilling operative . Due to problematic ground conditions the reamer was being reversed out of the bore hole . Drilling rods were being disconnected on the reception pit side by the subcontract operative . As the first rod was pushed through the subcontract operative began the disconnection process . The rig operator then loaded the second rod and proceeded to push the second rod through despite the fact that the operative was still disconnecting the first rod . To disconnect the first rod the operative had restrained the rods with Stilsons . When the second rod was loaded by the rig operator the turning effect of the rods , coupled with the restraining effect of the disconnection process created stored energy within the rods . When the energy was released from the rods the operative was thrown into the air and suffered several injuries , including a fractured Fibula to his right leg , a pelvic injury and blow to the head . The injuries are not life threatening and the operative will remain in hospital for 48 hours for observation .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The IP was loading out materials (tiles and trim ) in the morning from outside the property into the new building when he lost his footing and stumbled and fell . The IP fell onto soft grounding but fell awkwardly and took his body weight on his right arm resulting in a fracture . We have reviewed the working area and our site specific RAMS and raised the accident with all of our operatives to prevent any recurrences . Site management have also completed a further assessment on the ground conditions to ensure all working areas are as level as possible . We do believe that this accident was caused from the IP not paying sufficient care and attention when loading out and will be re briefing him on the company health & safety procedures when he returns to work . We are currently completing an investigation with the Principle Contractor to ensure that we have no recurrences of this type of accident again . All materials where loaded out as close to the access/egress points as possible .

Whilst drilling a hole to mount an wireless repeater box at a height of approx 3 metres <NAME> <NAME> was stood on the 6th step of a 8 step " A" frame ladder - he lost his footing and fell from the ladder landing on the 110v transformer unit he was using causing his injuries . It was not known to our organisation that <NAME> <NAME> had been engaged as a sub contractor by our partner company <NAME> and their approved contractor <NAME> IP. The risk assessment provided to <NAME> by <NAME> 's approved contractor <NAME> IP states that for an operation at this working height different access equipment should be used ( podium ladder or mini scaffold tower ) . as part of his everyday duties , the IP was delivering building materials to the site . This involved the IP using a moffet vehicle ( similar to a forklift truck ) . During the unloading process it is apparent that a pack of concrete blocks had become unstable and were leaning against the drop side boards of the vehicle . The IP was aware of this , however as he undid and lowered the side board against which the blocks were now leaning , the weight of the blocks meant that the side board dropped uncontrolled and collided with the IP 's right forearm . the IP continued with the delivery and returned to his place of work following a drivers break . On arrival back at his workplace the IP reported the incident and was taken to [Name] walk in A and E dept . there he was X-rayed and it was confirmed that he had fractured his right wrist . The IP will be absent for up to 6 weeks from work and a full and thorough investigation is now underway to ensure that similar incidents cannot happen again This will look at aspects of what the IP did , how the load was loaded and any other contributory factors .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> <NAME> ( IP) , groundwork labourer was carrying a 12.5kg <NAME> TE 1000 <NAME> breaker from the site storage area to the south central area of site for a colleague to carry out remedial works on holding down bolts . To get to the storage area from the workplace , IP took a shortcut across site rather than using the designated site walkways . IP moved some established segregation barriers blocking his path , collected the tool from the storage area and walked back the way he had come through the segregation barriers and over a loose bundle of rebar positioned on the ground . Whilst walking over the loose bundle or rebar , the operative lost his balance and tripped forward injuring his left ankle . X-ray details a closed  Weber B fracture of L distal fibula.There was an alternative clear designated blue route which was available for the IP to take and of which he was aware and had used previously to get to the work area.The works carried out and availability and quality of designated access routes were in accordance with <NAME> & <NAME> <NAME> safe systems of work . The IP's injury was not caused by a system failure , but was from choosing to take a shortcut across a route where materials were being stored and moving barriers which were in place to prevent access . A safe system of work was in place and suitable risk assessment developed , on which he was briefed.-The IP is a competent labourer who has received training in manual handling and has over 30 years construction site experience.-The IP was put to work safely throughout the day by his <NAME> & <NAME> supervisor . He attended a morning briefing on the day and subsequent advice from his supervisor.-IP has attended internal AJM and <NAME> <NAME> ( Principal Contractor ) behavioural safety workshops whilst on site . Specifically a briefing on short cuts and safe decisions carried out on <NAME> .Upon investigation , it was found that the IP deviated from the RAMS and AJM standards , and training provided , to take what was deemed by the IP ,  "a quicker and easier  route .We are working with our client and external professional organisations to help engage with our workforce to improve decision making and risk perception .

Instead of seeking advice of the best form of access equipment for the task , and asking for the temporary ceiling to be removed in order to carry on the works , the operative leant a 3m ladder against the wall to the right of the temporary ceiling and the area which was to be boarded . He then climbed the ladder with the board . He fixed the board on the right but to reach the left hand-side of the board he had to over-reach . As he did this , he lost his balance . As he tried to regain his balance the ladder slipped and he fell to the floor ( 2.5m fall ) , knocking the temporary ceiling down as he fell.At this time , there was no supervisor or operative in the area to witness the fall , or witness him climbing the ladder and fixing the board.The operative was found by an electrician who was onsite at the time and was taken to the hospital immediately by the site manager.All steps were immediately removed from site and all operatives on site were given toolbox talks on  Safe Working at Height and Safe Access Equipment. During this work activity the steel channel fell over onto the IP catching his leg on the way and trapping his arm between the steel channel and the floor . His colleague shouted for help and others came and managed to release the IP 's arm . The IP consequently suffered a broken left leg . The steel channel being bolted had not been chocked .

IP was loading out blocks on the concrete slab , as he was opening up the blocks , as he stepped round the side of the blocks he lost his footing and went off the slab onto the scaffold below ( 350mm ) rolling his ankle & causing two fractures in his foot & ankle .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: A works person was in the process of accessing a designated walkway . As he made his way around the external corner of the stairwell the person placed his foot on a small number of steel reinforcement bars , which were placed close to a steel mat in readiness to be installed . This resulted in the steel reinforcement bars rolling away from under his right foot with the foot rotating vertically causing his injuries.The injured person attended hospital on the same day of the accident but the nature of his injuries were confirmed on the <NAME>. The site management incorporated the details of the accident into a Toolbox Talk and the daily brifiengs to increase awareness and prevent further accidents .A preliminary investigation was undertaken by the health and safety department recommending :1.Ensure pedestrian routes are easily identifiable using barriers/fencing and spray paint.2.Work locations need to be clearly segregated from designated pedestrian routes where possible .3.Do not allow loose materials to encroach onto pedestrian routes at any time .4.Adequately plan the work locations considering all aspects of the tasks to be undertaken , including any out of sequence activities due to unplanned occurrences .5.Plan/reroute pedestrian walkways to ensure work locations and material storage do not create potential hazards.The site management implemented the recommendations .

The Injured party ( IP ) was busy fixing doors to door frames within the bottom dwelling of a block of flats . There were a number of doors that had been brought to his working area by labourers and stacked neatly next to the area the IP was working . The IP set to work to fit the first of the doors into its allocated doorway ( which was next to the delivered stack of doors ) and proceeded to manoeuvre the single door into place . Whilst in transition the IPs left hand that was helping to slide the door into place caught the remaining stack of doors , to which he lost his grip on the door being moved . The loss of grip resulted in the door then falling to the ground and unfortunately for the IP the 49kg door landed on his left boot in an area not protected by his steel toecaps . The IP made his way over to the site office to report the accident where he was told he could enter his details into the accident book but had to wait for a while as the site agent had numerous queries he had to attend to . So the IP sat on a chair and rested until the site manager was ready . During this time the IP then decided against completing the accident book as he felt the injury was not sufficient enough to warrant any prevention of work . He had also broken bones before and felt that the pain at the time was not of the same magnitude , so he went back to his area of work . However when he tried to manoeuvre another door the IP realised that the pain was too great and decided to make his way home , as he could not continue with his working day .Once he had reached home his partner suggested that he attended the local walk-in centre . They x-rayed the area and discovered that he had fractured his left foot and it needed to be rested until after xmas .

In the morning , <NAME> <NAME> requested some help to rake out soil behind plots 33 down to 29 . <NAME> <NAME> was appointed the task to assist him . <NAME> was in control or 1.5t mini excavator and a 1 tone dumper of which the keys for both machines were on one key fob . <NAME> had loaded the dumper on one occasion and taken it to the spoil heap to tip the load . The route was a firm and stable tarmac road with a small spoil heap at the end . He then returned for a second load . Before taking the second load , <NAME> checked between the plots further up to see if any debris had been missed , ( machine keys in <NAME> 's possession ). When <NAME> returned the dumper was gone , this was quickly followed by a phone call from <NAME> requesting help as he had hurt his leg . <NAME> investigated <NAME> 's location , found the dumper on its side running and <NAME> was approx three meters away . <NAME> turned off the dumper and asked where he had the key from . <NAME> replied that he had it on his own bunch of keys . <NAME> then phoned <NAME> <NAME> who went straight to the scene . On arrival and after a brief conversation with <NAME> an ambulance was called . It was evident that the dumper had been driven partially into the spoil heap with right front wheel up the incline and causing the <NAME> of gravity to shift to the left . The dumper slowly tipped to the side at which time <NAME> says he removed his seat belt and jumped off , landing awkwardly . <NAME> had tipped the loads without incident previous to this in front of the spoil heap insuring that the machine was on a firm level standing at all times as instructed . The tyre pressures were checked at the time and found to be within guidelines . <NAME> <NAME> had already told <NAME> once previously to not attempt to use any mobile plant until he had completed his training . <NAME> was made comfy waiting for the ambulance . Circulation was checked in his foot and he was monitored by the site first Aiders for shock and kept comfortable . The ambulance attended the scene and issued pain relief then took him to <NAME> <NAME> hospital . <NAME> attended the Hospital with <NAME> . At the time there was no confirmation of extent of injury . He called today to confirm a fracture of lower leg . Up until this point we were waiting on further information , today this was confirmed . <NAME> has today given a signed statement accepting liability for the incident and for unauthorized use of the plant in question . He admitted to taking this risk of moving the dumper in the hope to finish work , to start his holiday early as he was due to finish at lunch time . At no time were any keys left in plant or any plant left running unattended . All of my staff have been instructed that under no circumstance should they carry keys for plant they are not fully authorized and trained to use .The Clients have also investigated the matter and are issuing company wide safety alerts in relation to unauthorized use of plant and CPS certification requirements .
Removal of external decking using hand tools.Timber joist wer supported at both ends . The supporting timber to the joist was rotten and gave way . Causing operative to fall .

An operative was operating a 1.5t 360 excavator in close proximity to a pile cap which had been previously broken down , this had left the rebar exposed horizontally . The rebar should have been cut off before continuing work around the pile , unfortunately due to a stihl saw not starting he continued to track the excavator forward . Whilst tracking the machine the rebar got tangled in the open frame of the excavator and recoiled into the operatives shin . From my talks with the site team he has broken a bone in his leg but I have not been able to confirm 100 % what damage has been done .We have produced a toolbox talk to reinforce the procedure of safely reducing the pile and protecting the operatives from the rebar prior to the construction of the slab . We will also ensure a backup saw is on site now in case one fails .

description: [NAME] was walking from her place to her car In  [NAME] when she slipped and fell . [NAME] is a [NAME] Staff member employed by [NAME] as a [NAME] in the Resource Management Unit ( RMU) . To get to her car [NAME] has to turn left and walk along the path in front of the portacabin. She would then have to negotiate a small amount of steps then turn right up an inclined driveway to the front of [NAME], she would then again negotiate several steps. [NAME] would then turn left and walk along a pathway which leads to the front then to the side then to the back of [NAME] where she would then turn left up a path which also consists of several steps. Pedestrian barriers are in place along the path to the rear and along the path up to [NAME]. The route that [NAME] would have taken temporary metal fencing had been erected to her left . This is surrounding the building work which is being carried out . However there are no signs which would indicate any possible presence of slippery surface or surface water . On the day in question it there was prolonged heavy rainfall and the surfaces were wet around Headquarters there were lots of muddy areas due to the ongoing building work and due to the movement of heavy plant vehicles .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Following completion of CFA piling the concrete line was being cleaned when a blockage occurred . As per procedures supervisor was called and came to area . Concrete line was broken to release pressure , supervisor checked this had been done . However what no one could tell was that there was also a second blockage within the line , creating a pocket of stored energy . Supervisor tapped the hose to try and clear blockage - this succeeded but resulted in a sudden release of concrete which knocked the two men over , one on top of the other . As a result each man suffered a single fracture - one to his wrist and one to his hand.All operations were immediately stopped on this site , and all CFA piling was stopped on all other Expanded projects pending an investigation . For future operations a mechanical valve has been fitted to all CFA rigs in the fleet . The RAMS have been reviewed & updated . An investigation report has been circulated to Expanded senior management , and a safety note will be provided to the <NAME>. There were two men injured - this is notification 1 of 2

Operatives were on site carrying out last minute 'tidy up /snaggin' details to completed works we have carried out at the above address , one of our operatives ( <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ) incorrectly secured the ladder to the scaffold from ground level to gain access , he used a piece of cloth & only secured one stile ..when on the ladder descending the cloth snapped causing the ladder to slide & the fall of our operative .All our operatives are fully up to date with all Health and Safety training including working at heights, safe ladder use etc..........copies of tool box talk refreshers carried out aug 15 with the operatives signatures & acknowledgment of understanding can be provided - they all also have NVQ L3 Slating & Tiling qualifications which covers Health and Safety too. Following this accident <NAME> <NAME> has been given a formal verbal warning for non-compliance with our Health and Safety standards.  We are also carrying out more tool box talks - training refreshers regarding safe use of ladders & ensuring that operatives use ladder access within the scaffold at all times , this will be carried out by our independent Health and Safety advisor <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> .

Work involved installation of flat roof windows on a ground floor extension . The person involved with the accident had fallen from the flat roof level onto a concrete sub floor approx 3 metres down .  First aider had attended the scene straight away and emergency ambulance had been called for . The person injured had been concius all the time and complained about pain from the hip . The person injured had been wearing PPE kit at the time of the incident . The work involved with the opening was comunnicated with by the carpenter . We are looking into providing additional safety measures and will be updating our staff on this unforunate incident .

The Employee was Changing the fitting of hydraulic pipe connections on a 35t Excavator and an Auger Attachment. The driver of the excavator had lowered the dipper arm of the excavator in order that the fitter could gain access to the connections. The fitter was using spanners to change the connections, however, one was proving stubborn. To gain extra purchase, the fitter used a cradle that was attached to the Auger to gain some additional height to ( in his mind) make the job easier. Whilst attempting to crack open one of the connections, the employee slipped on the cradle and his momentum carried him forward resulting in a fall with major impact on his shoulder. The employee was in severe pain and taken to the local hospital where it was found that he had broken his shoulder blade in two places.A Bulletin & tool box talks have/ will be conducted at all other locations in the company highlighting the problem of using an unsafe method of work for gaining height and not using correct appliances to complete the job.

Manual handling discussed with operative and need to take a little more care.  Operative had received manual handling training in <NAME>.

On the morning of the <NAME> , at approx <NAME> , two A-one + Operatives and an A-one + Steward were undertaking an emergency clearance of large stones from the edge of the <NAME> carriageway . The two operatives were using brushes to sweep the stone from the edge of the carriageway within the 1m hard strip , back towards the filter drain where the stone had previously been disturbed by an unknown vehicle . The location was on the northbound <NAME> near the on-slip from the <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> 49/7 , between <NAME> and <NAME> . A vehicle was travelling northbound on the <NAME> and the driver lost control of his vehicle . The vehicle travelled across the highway and onto the verge , with the rear of the vehicle hitting the Operative in the process . The vehicle continued moving and came to rest facing towards the carriageway , yet up the incline of the soft estate . The opeartive that was hit landed adjacent to the vehicle ( approximately 10 metres from where he had been working ) . First aid was provided by the 2nd operative on site , whilst the Steward arranged for the emergency services to attend . The injured operative was initially unconscious , but did awake and was aware of his surrounding and colleagues . The injured person ( IP) , was removed from site by the ambulance service and has been taken to the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> in <NAME> . Emergency treatment has been provided . A CT scan has been undertaken and further tests . Initial reports are that a head injury has been avoided , yet damage to ribs ( fractured ) and potentially a punctured lung has resulted due to the impact . This is to be confirmed .
Whilst driving dumper , roll bar was erected without installing locking pins / bolts where not put in place .

The operative had finished his main work for the day and was measuring up for the following days work . In doing so stepped forward with his left leg onto a scaffold plank which had moved and was no longer adequately lapped onto the adjacent board . The plank gave way under his foot causing him to fall forward onto his left arm and shoulder which took the impact of the fall .
A limestone sheet was being loaded onto a storage frame using mechanical means . The sheet broke at two points horizontally with one of the sections impacting the leg of the IP.

Operative was working on site conducting minor work ( laying of slabs ) . He required some more cement for his task and used the dumper with the intent of fetching more from the site on the opposite side of the road . As operative was driving he approached a turning and as he pulled into the turning the dumper rolled onto it s left side . The dumper stopped and the operative walked into the site to alert somebody of what had happened . The operative was then taken to hospital where he received treatment for a fractured arm .

The work being carried out at the time of the accident involved the pumping of concrete to backfill an area behind a concrete block wall , in the rear basement of the building . The concrete was being pumped into the site via a mobile pump , using of a rigid pipe . Two workers were present to distribute the concrete using shovels . The pipe was resting on top of the wall.The construction of the wall , which was 2.8m in height , had been designed by an engineer and backfilling work was planned and carried out in phases . ( The low level behind the wall was backfilled at an earlier stage ).As the concrete was being pumped , it was noted by the two workers that a small quantity of concrete was escaping from one end of the wall . The injured person ( IP ) was , at the time , carrying out other duties in an adjacent area . He became aware of the concrete escaping and decided to assist by inserting a timber stop end.As he was doing so , it is believed that the concrete pump rigid pipe caused the wall to fail . The IP was struck on the back by concrete blocks .It has been established that the IP should not have carried out a work activity adjacent to the wall whilst the concrete was being poured . This was not an authorised activity. <NAME> are continuing with an internal investigation and a report will be prepared .

description: The IP was stepping out of his vehicle ( FJ57 JHO , 18 tonne with HIAB attachment , [NAME] ) and stood down onto uneven ground . In an attempt to brace his fall the IP injured his left hand.The IP initially returned to work carrying out his normal duties , the IP went on to deliver and collect equipment to and from customers after which he returned to the depot complaining that his hand was still “sore ” the hire controller sent the IP to A & E at around 15 :00 . The depot manager received a call from the IP at 18:59 informing the manager that the IP suffered a fracture in his wrist . CCTV footage of the incident is inconclusive as the view of the incident was obstructed by the vehicle mentioned in this report .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The employee was leaving the building and stumbled on the bottom step of the stairs causing him to 'go over ' on his left foot .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: IP was delivering stock to the new home development and whilst walking across site stated he lost his footing on a muddy / unclear pathway , put his hand out to brace himself causing the injury . He then returned to his usual work placement and complained that his wrist was hurting . It appears the IP did not report the incident to the site . The IP then drove to hospital where a fracture of the wrist was confirmed and a cast fitted . The IP has left his employment so the facts have just been established . The IP did not complain of any other injuries sustained at the time . A Safety memo is due to be circulated to staff reminding them of slipping and tripping hazards when delivering stock to unfamiliar sites to be mindful of housekeeping . IP was employed by <NAME> <NAME> who work closely with their Safety Consultants - <NAME> who assist them with auditing at their branches .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> <NAME> was clearing the spare materials on and indepentant scaffolding , this was erected in floor level lifts and at the time the scaffold was dismantled down to the 1st floor level fully boarded working platform , he went to pick a tube up and he stepped back onto a spare fitting that was situated on the lift and twisted his ankle .

Working from a ladder without asking for the ladder to be footed . Ladder slipped and engineer fell from height . Spoken to on the importance of having ladders properly footed . Engineer advised to attend accident & emergency .

An operative was using an MST to carry out work and instead of alighting from it between operations , he asked someone to push him . This resulted in the MST overturning . We have carried out TBTs with the operatives involved and also across the company generally .
taking tools down from scaffold , had a petrol disc cutter in one hand and went to change the disc cutter to the other hand and fell back off ladder

Job instruction received by the client to replace light fittings in plantroom , two men ( <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> ) assigned to task due to nature of work . Job file raised before work commences including ; permit to work from client with reference to task specific risk assessment and separate 'working at height ' risk assessment . Engineers went to location to assess the task and carry out a dynamic risk assessment at the coal face and to establish what equipment will be needed . The task was to fit two fluorescent tubes situated approximately three meters from ground level . <NAME> <NAME> was footing the ladder to a certain level but had to move out of the way for <NAME> to make his way to ground level due to restriction of space i .e . encroachment of a large fan housing . On his way down the ladder , <NAME> <NAME> twisted his body clockwise and used a floor mounted motor as a step for his right foot to transit between the third or fourth rung of the ladder and ground level . Holding on to the ladder with his left hand and holding a lifting eye on the fan drum with his right hand he proceeded to lower his left foot from the third or fourth rung of the ladder to the ground . It is believed that at this point his right foot slipped from the motor and <NAME> fell backwards to the floor hitting either the corner of the fan belt guard or the corner of the concrete plinth ( or both ) on the way down.An accident investigation is being undertaken to establish immediate and root causes . Witness statements have been taken . Since the incident all operatives have been given their own ladder and step-ladder guide as a laminated guide . All operatives verbally briefed to reinforce hazards , control measures and safe working procedures of working at height including correct use of equipment . Prior to the incident the toolbox talks issued for <NAME> are on the topic of working at height . Also , prior to the incident a health and safety memo was written to be issued in <NAME> 's payslips with the topic being Working at Height . Site Safety Inspections are to be carried out to ensure safe working methods are being followed .

Two men were dismantling a mobile tower ; one man on the apparatus and one man at floor level . The tower was partially dismantled ( handrails removed ) . The injured party fell during the process ( but not whilst passing components at the time of the fall )

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: IP was a bricklayer repairing bricks on a completed property , he tripped over his down takings resulting in a injury to his left foot . This was subsequently diagnosed as a fracture to one of the small bones in the foot .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: As the IP was vacating the cabin/hydraulic room , he stood on a wire cable laying outside , it slid on the steel deck causing his ankle to twist , on reporting to A & E they diagnosed a sprained ankle . The IP then subsequently visited a separate hospital and was diagnosed with a broken ankle . Hence the delay in the submission of this form .

The injured party , <NAME> <NAME> , was working with a window fitting company installing glazed units in a block of flats under construction . At the time of the accident he was carrying units from the ground floor to higher levels . Safe access was available via external scaffold , but despite his site induction and the provision of a fork-lift <NAME> <NAME> was accessing the upper floors internally via a hop-up and steps not intended for that purpose and provided by him/his employer . He apparently slipped , falling some 1.7m to a 1/2 landing and a further 1.3m to the first floor.The emergency services were called and all other site operatives further cautioned against the use of unauthorised means of access .

The IP was manually handling doors in preparation for transport from the storage container to the point of work . The doors were stacked on their edges . Assistance was sought from another operative . Approximately 8-10 doors toppled pinning the IP against other equipment by his legs.The IP felt pain in his right knee and was taken to hospital.Immediately following the incident , all the doors in the storage container were laid flat and stacked to prevent a reoccurence .

He had just fitted a new window and needed to seal the out side of the frame . He put the ladder up and fitted the ladder mates in place as this is company policy and then while silicone sealing the side of the window frame he leaned over instead of moving the ladder , while doing this he lost his balance and fell to the floor.All our fitters and sub-contractors are issued with HSE instructions for working at height and HSE safe use of ladders and step ladders plus HSE top tips in use of ladders and steps and the use of ladder mates upon induction when they start with this branch , all these are also covered in our site employees health and safety hand book issued to employees and sub contractors.All the above that we issue is signed for by our contractors and documented . Since the accident we have held further meetings with our fitters explaining the importance of working with-in our safe working procedures regarding the use of all equipment .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: on arriving at the work area <NAME> <NAME> step over and placed one foot between the shuttering for the front steps to be form in concrete to the new entrance but slip on the hard core stone and fell over ,one foot got stuck and he twisted his knee this has fractured his tibia

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: How did the accident occur? The <NAME> <NAME> claimed that he fell from a set of steps he was using to gain access to patch small holes in the brickwork in the bathroom . He also claimed he was working from the top step however as the only steps in the room he was working in were 2 metres high and as the ceiling height is only 3 metres high this would not have been possible .Toolbox talks held with every site operative prior to activity ( also <NAME> <NAME> on the morning of incident had signed risk assessment to the activity he was carrying out )

A <NAME> qualified slinger signaller working at the <NAME> <NAME> project fell backwards , over a handrail from a flatbed trailer while loading materials onto the trailer . He fell circa 1.7m , rotating as he fell and landed on his head . His hard came off in the fall and he sustained a nasty gash on the top of his head that required immediate first aid treatment . He remained conscious throughout despite the head injury , but also advised he had chest pains . He was treated at the scene by site first aiders and an ambulance called . He was subsequently treated on site by the ambulance paramedics and then taken to the <NAME> <NAME> hospital in <NAME> . The wound on his head required seven stitches and a CT scan gave no indication of further head injury .The IP remained in hospital overnight on <NAME> &  <NAME>  . During a hospital visit on  <NAME>  by <NAME> management , the IP appeared well , was lucid and was able to move around freely , although was feeling stiff and sore from the fall . The chest pains were bruising caused when he landed on his radio and were feeling better . The IP has received a fracture to a vertebra . The IP was discharged from hospital  <NAME>  and came to work to give the witness statement on  <NAME> . The IP does not require any further treatment and anticipates returning to full work when he returns from his holiday , as has been pre planned by IP prior an accident.The trailer from which the IP fell was equipped with double handrails , proprietary aluminium steps for access and was parked alongside an access gantry to allow loads to be landed safely . The IP was able to fall from the trailer as he stepped onto a bundle of aluminium beams to retrieve a sling , causing the top rail to be at knee height . The sling had become trapped so the IP pulled on it to release it , as it came free he lost his balance and fell backwards over the top railAll the Operatives and Slingers have be re-briefed on the method statement and risk assessment as a refresher . This RAMS includes sequencing for the loading of a vehicle so that the operative works back to the access gantry preventing the need to climb on loads . <NAME> set up a workshop for visualisation of the safe ways of loading/unloading delivery vehicles for operatives involved in loading/unloading operations as a further reminder to all operatives of the safe working practice .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The IP was operating a rubber tyred 360 excavator spreading topsoil on a batter adj to new construction bridge works at <NAME> . The road was subject to a closure order to allow night time operations . He parked his machine at end of shift and was asked by the supervisor to retrieve a tracked Yanmar 5t minidigger from its position at the top of the batter and safely park it for end of shift . He did this , parking the machine next to a stores cabin and directly adjacent to laid blacktop on the main carriageway . He stepped out onto the blacktop , turned and closed the door , then turned back and stepped away from the machine . As he did so he turned his left foot and ankle over on the edge of the raised blacktop ( approx . 450mm ) . He fell to his L landing on stone below the finished level of the road . He got up , realising he had hurt his ankle , hobbled to his car , parked some 200m distant , then phoned his supervisor to report the fall but saying he would be back that evening to start the night shift . He drove home to <NAME> <NAME> but later that day ( 14-30hrs ) his wife took him to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> hospital where he was x-rayed and diagnosed with a fracture L metatarsal L foot . Foot placed in brace boot and IP signed off work for 4 weeks .

Our operative was erecting a 1.5m podium access tower when it fell on him . He stood on the lower rung of the podium lent over to engage a brace arm for the lower level access ladder and the unit folded towards him causing him to fall backwards onto the floor .

<NAME> <NAME> was working in a different area of the building , he came over to this area where 2 of our contractors were working to ask them a question when he walked on the box gutter section it collapsed and he fell through . As <NAME> fell he hit some ducting which spun him and he landed on his shoulder on a sheet of ply . I have had a meeting today with our H & S consultant and it has been decided that the current RAMS for this job will be reviewed and updated . We have also addressed any scaffolding issues with the principle contractor <NAME> ' s which are being addressed tomorrow . We are also going to place a check list for this and future projects for ascertaining different parts of sections of roofs as to establish how structurally sound the decking is and its make up , ie . what type of material . If any decking is in a poor condition or if there is any risk of falling there will be a crash deck in place before any works can proceed .

The IP was standing at the entrance to the side door of his van when he fell backwards approximately 300mm and took the full weight of his body on the heel of his foot . He was attempting to remove the ladders from the roof of the van . The decision has been made to provide a larger van so that the steps may be stored inside the van as opposed to on the roof .

Outside contractors working on erecting 3 geodesic domes . Basket containing two contractors detached from lifting equipment . Corrective action : Stronger rules for checking contractors ' health and safety provisions .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured party had turned on the heater and was turning round to turn on the light when she slipped and fell . She put her arm out to break her fall which broke a small bone in her wrist . There was water on the floor from the basin . Absorbent mats have been placed down until a better slip resistant floor has been installed

Using a ladder to secure glazing bars in the conservatory when he lost balance . He put his arm out to stop his fall , fracturing his arm and dislocating his elbow . We have had all staff take a refresher course in health and safety , especially working at height .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Telephone report- Notifier advises , The operative working , stepped out of the dumper truck letting go of the handle and he missed the bottom step . He lost his balance and fell down onto his left side onto the water barrier . Site manager and first aider at premises assisted IP , and IP drove home . It was confirmed to us on the [Date] at 6.30 that there is a fracture . IP broke 3 rips and bruised lung.IP was sub contracted to [NAME] county council by [NAME] .

IP said that his foot caught on the rung of the ladder and he felt pain in his foot.Toolbox talks are underway in relation to site safety , further site monitoring will also be undertaken

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: operative was carrying 1 no 3m tube on shoulder when he slipped on a dusty banking dropped to one knee extended is right arm for support and struck the previously erected scaffold adjacent to him . TBT to be undertaken by contracts managers for slips , trips and falls
Fell through a gap in the scaffold boards, whilst carrying blocks. Twisting arm. causing cuts to fore arm and pain in arm.

Whilst carrying out electrical work in the kitchen jonathan was pulling cables through conduit for a new cooker hood.  Whilst leaning on the cooker hood the cooker hood gave way and jonathan lost his balance on the step ladder and fell to the floor.  No further work of this nature will be carried out until the cooker hoods have been removed.
Man put his fingers between a metal fence post and a wall and then another operative pulled fence post towards the wall trapping mans fingers and breaking one finger
Our health & safety people are currently carrying out an investigation into the cause and what we can do to help prevent a similar incident

The operative was removing barriers from the rear of his vehicle which were required to cordon off an area where glass had to be removed when one got stuck , he climbed into the van and proceeded to tug at the barrier to release it lost his balance put his hands in front of him to break his fall but fell awkwardly on both hands . In future two operatives will assist in removing similar items from the vehicle one to be in the vehicle to pass the goods to the operative outside of the vehicle .
I got to second tread of ladder and then I was on the floor , I must have slipped .
IP fallen from 2nd floor attic area of the building to the ground .
operative over reached plaster boarding a ceilng .operative aluminium tower now being used with handrails in place

A <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> was cutting up an old tank , when the piece he was cutting off fell uncontrolled to the ground , bounced on the concrete and hit his foot past the steel toe cap area of his own foot , thus breaking a bone in his foot .

Employee was not following company procedure while stripping scaffold , he removed frame work which helped to stabilize the staircase so when attempting to remove the handrails on stair case by shaking the scaffold this caused the frame work to distort putting pressure on fittings which then gave way and caused the stairs and himself to fall 2 m . This could have been avoided if he had followed company procedure which should have been to remove the stair way first then the frame work around it . All employees will be given a toolbox talk in regards to following company procedure while erecting , stripping scaffolding and highlight that removal of stair cases is a two man operation .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The incident involved a demolition subcontractor operative who was removing the suspended ceiling from the area above the ground floor landing within the pumping station building . The ceiling tiles had all been removed and the injured person was pulling at the ceiling grid from ground level with a pick . In doing so , it is assumed that the person stepped backwards to avoid falling debris , misplacing his footing on the three steps behind him . His foot has slid against the edge of the top step causing an ankle injury to his right inside ankle . Following the incident a barrier was placed at the top of the steps to prevent a re-occurrence .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> <NAME> was walking across a brush concrete finished slab and slipped , falling onto his arm . RE:  RIDDOR  reference <NAME> Further to the broken arm incident on  <NAME>  with RIDDOR reference as above , we now need to revise the injured person details .The name that we were given at <NAME> along with <NAME> card was fraudulent and the injured person is now confirmed as <NAME> <NAME> - D.O.B-<NAME> - Address <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> , <NAME>.There are no further revisions to the report and actions are ongoing regards the false presentation of Identity and how this affected the incident .
Operative was placed through health and safety induction and advised how to mount and dismount from 2 meter scaffold . Operative then dismounted from lower lever scaffold in a incorrect manor .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Stepped up onto a steel beam ( Aprox 1 1/2 foot high ) to drill two holes in duct work then the engineer lowered himself back down with one hank on a rail and one hand on duct work stepping backwards off of the steel beam . His foot slipped and with his own weight on his arm it broke

Unloading timber from trailer by pulling & lowering . Timber slipped & landed on left foot.The operative was not wearing safety footwear , although the risk Assessment stated safety footwear to be worn

IP was coming down an extension ladder , he was carrying a tub of liquid plastics and had three points of contact , the extension ladder was being footed at this time by his work colleague . The IP 's went to put their foot down on the next level on the extension ladder where the rungs slightly step in , their foot slipped and it went through the space between the extension ladder rungs this then resulted in them falling backwards onto the grass . We have only received this morning <NAME>  <NAME> 's line confirming injury ( clinically fracture right clavicle and muscular injury to neck and shoulder ) . Requested that tool box talks be carried out on working at Height with an emphasis on ladders

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: On [DATE] at [Name] operative was working on site forming a cut line by track saw method on the ground floor slab between the existing catering building and the demolition work . [NAME] was in the process of moving the track saw leads when he stepped backwards and caught his foot on a bracket which then in turn with momenturn made him fall over backwards . His elbow took the full impact of his body weight when he fell.The on site First Aider was called and  [NAME] was immediately directed to the A&E department where he was advised to take six weeks from work to allow the injury which was a hair line fracture of the left elbow , to repair .

As part of an asbestos removal contract the site manager involved was following the main contractor around some risers to scope required drilling through encapsulated surfaces . When poking his head through the 3rd floor riser to look at the ceiling , his foot fell through a 940mm gap in the floor . There was no protection or signage in place to the riser .

In the main construction site the IP was striking shuttering with his colleague by removing a universal steel waler that was above head height . The IP was inside the room with his colleague on the outside pulling on a dywi dag bar to release the waler . The dywi dag was removed by the operative on the outside . As the injured person removed the waler he pulled it away from the dywi dag that was still casted in & in doing this lost control of the waler which resulted in him trapping his hand onto the waler below as he was trying to recover the waler from falling out of his hand.The methodology of striking columns has been reviewed were everything is done from the one side with both operatives there . The waler must be pulled from the divi rather than the divi being removed out of the waler . The height of the waler being removed was measured at 1.8 meters from the slab & this must be undertaken by two operatives at all timesRisk assessments will need to be amended & reviewed to include changes with all relevant operatives briefed on the latest amendment . An internal Plan V Actual inspection review to be undertaken following amendment of the main method statement & visual task sheet. Hand protection toolbox talks to be undertaken to all operatives on site

Whilst the engineer was manoeuvring his way through the cluttered property he hit his left hand on something whilst at the same time carrying his tool box . After a short time the pain became stronger , so the IP visited a local hospital where he was advised that he has a metacarpal hairline fracture .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Telephone report - IP was in an almost completed house , somebody had stacked doors in the property , IP leant over these doors to fit a vent on to a door and he lost balance and slipped over .

2 x experienced employees Instructed to undertake a site survey for the replacement of skylights and Ruth Seats . The intention although not directed was to inspect on ladders . They decided whilst on-site to go onto the roof to inspect the roof and valley gutters . They had been informed that the building was opened so they could inspect internally before looking externally . Whilst on the roof [NAME]  crossed the middle of the roof falling through an obscured skylight . Both employees are extensively component in there duty 's .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The Injured Person was carrying out emergency surfacing works on the main runway at <NAME> on a nightshift contract. The IP and the surfacing Foreman had been looking at some patching that had taken place earlier  on the strip of asphalt that runs adjacent to the main runway. This strip is 10m wide. The main runway has a historical overbanding that sits approximately 50mm higher. The IP & the foreman were walking from the strip at the side towards the main runway. The IP has caught his foot on the lip, causing him to fall forward, with his right arm under his chest area, causing a fracture to the bone below his elbow ang grazing the heel of of his left hand.

IP was transporting a broken down cast iron bath out of the property . IP and colleagues placed each part of the bath on top of each other . When the final piece of bath was placed down , it rolled off towards the IP landing on his foot . Upon investigation this risk was deemed as foreseeable and the IP and colleague should have used dynamic risk assessment to place items safely on the ground . Reiteration of dynamic risk assessment , safe working methods and safe manual handling is being delivered to teams together with reviews of risk assessments .

Whilst taking the small 3 piece ladder down the top section became snagged and came loose from the rest of the ladder which fell and hit <NAME> <NAME> on the nose . <NAME> <NAME> was taken to the local <NAME> where it was confirmed that he had a broken nose and he was told to take the rest of the day off .

Two of our operatives were carrying out repairs to the hip tiles of the roof which were slipping and falling off the building . An access platform was erected with a standing platform of approximately 1.2 Metres high . The operative <NAME> <NAME> was standing on the platform whilst the other operative was on the roof passing tiles down to him before placing them on the ground . Whilst this work was in progress one of the platform clips broke and the platform became unstable and the <NAME> <NAME> fell through the platform putting one foot down to support himself , unfortunately this was at an angle and all his weight was taken by that one foot on his heel causing the injury .Since the action all access platforms have been withdrawn from use to be thoroughly inspected and only Access Towers / Platforms hired in from Hire Companies are being used for the foreseeable future.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Having drilled a hole through a joist the injured person ( ip)climbed down the step ladder he was working from and as he placed his right foot on the ground he twisted his ankle . The ip believes he may have put his foot on an offcut of wood and this caused his ankle to twist .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> was plastering the ceiling to the underside of the gallery , working of the floor in the main worship area when he caught his foot on the lead runing to a plasteres light , causing him to stumble , he attemepted to steady / right himself and in doing so stood on the tripod that supports the light , <NAME> then took 2-3 addional steps across the floor before spinning round and sitting down on a part pallet of plaster . we think that the damage to his foot was caused when he stood on the tripod ,though at the time of the incident <NAME> complaind more about a pain in his knee . In order to minimise the potential for a re-ocurance the site has been tidied and the leads runing to the lights re organised so that they are tidier , the quantity reduced and they have been run around the edges of the building which should help to minimise the risk of trips , site operatives have been instructed to keep the site tidy and if they move a lead or cable to make sure it is not causing a trip hazzard , the instalation of the main / final lights has been brought forward in the building program to enable the tempoary lights to be removed ASAP.
The IP was on the 2nd or 3rd rung of the access ladder to scaffold Less than 1 metre fell backwards and broke his wrist

An independent analyst was carrying out an air test and visual inspection of an enclosure following the removal of asbestos insulation board when he fell from a set of our inspection ladders . The ladder leg buckled causing the analyst to fall to the ground . Our employee who was in the airlock ready to commence his decontamination procedure , heard the analyst call and returned to help him .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

I mas moving a loading bay arm when it caught onto the other arm which was stacked against a wall , this caused it to fall against my hand trapping it between the two .

<NAME> was holding the front communal door open for <NAME> <NAME> who was bringing his tools onto the job . The door blew shut and <NAME> tried to stop the door slamming and trapped his hand in the door.After hearing of this injury the manager made a visit to the site of the reported incident and found that the door was an internally opening door with a fully functioning door closing mechanism that prevents the door from slamming , making this door limited to external influences like wind making it slam ..The reason <NAME> has trapped his hand in this door on my opinion it would be through his own carelessness and nothing further can be done to ensure the safety of others using the door as it is working as it should be by design.This employee was interviewed along with his colleagues . He was holding the door open with his left hand stood outside the door , as the door closed he put his right hand onto the door frame to stop the door closing fully .
An employee was using a drill when the drill snagged causing his hand to be brought upwards sharply and hit another joist .

He was reaching the top of the ladder to get onto low roof to access windows opening over the low roof to fit safety catches onto the window openers . Base of ladder was onto patterned concrete drive . Ladder slipped just as he was at the top of the ladder .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
