riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: On exiting the property slipped on driveway ( which was covered in moss ) and landed on wrist . Attended doctors on [Date] and sent for an x-ray where fracture was diagnosed . Wrist set in plaster cast .

Whilst installing the roof on one of the new build properties a roofing operative namely [NAME] tripped and fell from Height from a scaffold due to an alledged gap of around 4 inch , [NAME] managed to fall underneath the loading bay arm onto the ground below .

*TELEPHONE report: The IP was stepping onto the lower ladder , he missed his footing and fell to the ground . The IP went to the site managers office and explained what had happened , he was asked if he had any injuries and if he needed any first aid attention . The IP said 'no ' so the site manager got him to sit down to talk to him and made him a cup of tea so he could observe him . After twenty minutes the site manager asked again how he was feeling . The IP responded that he was starting to stiffen up a bit and the site manager informed him that he did n't want him going back up the ladder and thought he needed to be checked out . The IP went home following that . The site manager then spoke to the IP on [Date] ( the next working day ) when he didn't turn out for work , the IP was aksed how he was . The IP responded that he had been in some discomfort over the weekend and had returned to the hospital ( had originally attened the hospital on the day of the incident ) and had another x-ray which showed he had two cracked ribs . The site manager checked the ladder and scaffolding on the day of the incident and took photographs , the scaffolder came on the [Date] and the scaffolding was checked over again and no faults could be found . The access and the egress was good to the ladder . The scaffolder and site manager were happy with the scaffolding . The site manager then went around the site and done a tool box tour about an individuals responsibility for health and safety to themselves and others .

Whilst walking down a set of stairs , there were scaffold boards at the bottom of the temp stairs and my foot got trapped in between a gap in the scaffolding board which resulted in a fall . The boards were immediately moved to decrease the gap by the site manager.

The IP was closing the stores for the evening and was attempting to close the metal doors but could not due to an obstruction.The IP moved a piece of carpet that he thought was the obstruction but the door still would not close so he used more force to shut it and his hand slipped from the handle striking him on the wrist.The cause of the obstruction was the redundant lighting cable which was catching the door at the top
Whilst working on stairs slipped approx . 1.5metres and broke right ankle .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: [NAME] was walking across site to speak to his supervisor with regard to the next phase of the works .

Off loading timber from forklift onto scaffolding then onto building at roof level .Stepped back with timber in hand and fell to first floor level of scaffolding through ladder aces .Leg caught in ladder ,fell back onto broken blocks laying on scaffold hitting head and breaking three ribs on my left side .Managed to walk to <NAME> <NAME> car who then took me to <NAME> general hospital where I was admitted overnight and following day.The ladder aces had no protection around it and all scaffolding was substandard with large gaps in scaffolding where boards where missing .Ladders too short to be safe so wrong angle .Now unable to work and recovery time is advised to be six weeks . I was subcontracting to <NAME> <NAME> at the time of the accident .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Repair of fall protection systems on a standing seam barrel type roof. Roof pitch 10-15 degrees. Installation personnel connected to fall protection system, wearing full body harness, correctly adjusted lanyard. Engineer was wearing safety boots and the roof was dry, weather was Sunny. Upon returning the the powered access equipment by 'crabbing' across the roof the installation engineer snagged his boot on one of the 100mm standing seams causing him to roll his foot over, and because of the tools/equipment he was carrying, he put all of this weight down on his leg which caused his ankle to break. He fell backwards/ sat back onto the roof and after a short time was helped into the powered access basket which was located approximately 5m from where the incident took place.

A length of 100mm plastic pipe was being cut at height on a MEWP prior to installation into the soil vent pipework system. The worker lost his grip of a section of the pipe which then fell to the ground. It then bounced up striking another worker who was standing nearby, causing him facial injuries. The injured person was subsequently diagnosed with a fractured cheekbone following medical investigation on <NAME>.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: clearing cut sheets from site slipped on mud

The injured person ( a carpenter ) was adjusting one of three push pull supports ( <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ) . He was using a metal tube to rotate the support at the time , during this task his hand slipped and in attempt to stable his balance he knocked his left wrist onto a lower support . The injured person was checked over by a onsite first aider who advised that he should attend the local A & E hospital where it was confirmed to be fracture to his left wrist .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Coming down ladder with in house (down through stairwell ladder) stepped back onto  (half) brick debris left on floor.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: IP was coming down the staircase in plot 15 and slipped . IP put out his right arm to steady himself and fractured wrist . The staircase was free from any obstruction . He continued working that day assuming it was a sprain . When he got up the next day he decided to visit hospital , after an x ray they found it was fractured . A toolbox talk was completed on site emphasising the importance of using handrails when using stairs .
Whilst walking along scaffold an unfixed scaffold plank gave way causing a fall through the gap .
Carrying scaffold ladder from front to rear of property the injured person stooped to duck under a low transom , when he stood up he collided with the next one .

Witness statement . ' Around 8.10am myself and the injured party <NAME> <NAME> set about unloading empty plant crates from the inside of a 7.5 tonne curtain sider truck . As they were empty we handles them manually . The tail lift was lowered halfway down so as to be used as a step using the external controls , these were placed inside the load area and we proceeded to drag the crates back towards the tail lift . <NAME> then stepped with one foot onto the tail lift whilst lifting the crate which then rested on top of the external controller buttons causing the tail lift to rise trapping <NAME> boot between the platform and the rear of the truck . I jumped down from the truck and grabbed the external controller to lower the tail lift but it failed to lower . I then tried to lower the tail lift using the controls fixed inside the truck but to no avail . We then removed the tail lift from it 's fixings to release <NAME> 's trapped foot . The ambulance arrived shortly after to tend to <NAME>.  Action to prevent a similar accident : We will inform staff not to place the external controls on the bed of the truck and will provide a sign on the back of the truck stating the same which can be clearly seen .

IP was working on podium steps on tower level 1 . IP opened the gate and whilst holding onto the handrails started to exit down the steps . Whilst holding onto the RHS handrail it broke away . IP lost balance and fell approx . 1ft landing on the floor slab and sustained a suspected broken rib based on doctors note ( no x-ray taken ) . There were no witnesses - report is the account of the IP. Inspection of podium steps revealed what looked like a failure of the weld that joined the handrail to the main body of the podium steps . Raised with hire company who are investigating further . Visual inspection of podium steps before use did not identify any issues .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Got to fetch a piece of timber to place on sleepers . On return slipped on a pieces of strand that had been left on the floor .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The operator of 13T excavator was getting down from his machine ,to move a pipe and twisted his ankle on uneven ground .
Building a conrete pond - kneeling on concrete while using float to spread cement caused alkali burns through PPE to knees and shins .
IP was changing the orientation of an inline heat meter when a small amount of hot water was emmitted causing scalds to both hands .

Task  was to break through concrete at front of shop to feed through alcathenein preperation for utilities company to connect water to building.electric cable coming in to building was hit causing flash and electric to go offcontractor received burns and was taken by ambulance to hospital, was kept in on saturday and sunday night and released today (<name>)changes for future make sure individual rams are carried out instead of generic for job of this type and signed by contractor once he has read and understood.cat scanner to be on van at all times rather than rely on hire of this equipment.also booked course for use of scanner, more toolbox talksand more regular audits of works carried out to be logged

Ladeling hot bitumen from boiler to bucket when bitumen flared up causing the operative to eject the ladel into the air causing hot bitumen to coat his right hand glove which penetrated onto his index finger of his right hand .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: A roadmarking labourer tripped over whilst ascending the lorry and spilt a small amount of hot thermoplastic on to right side of his face . He suffered burns ( [10 % body surface ) and was treated at [NAME] [NAME] hospital . He was then referred to [NAME] out patients where he was further treated where the affected area was cleaned , cream provided , appointment for next [NAME] made to check healing .  Sick note for 1 month from today with advice to keep wound clean .

<NAME> was planning to cut a steel drum with a disc cutter to aid disposal . <NAME> thought that the material in the drum was inert however once he started to cut into the drum the contents ignited . <NAME> was stood in front of the drum which was laid on its side secured . The hole that was in the top of the drum now being in front of his leg effectively became an exhaust for the ignition and caused severe burns to his leg . <NAME> said he thought there was no risk of ignition because he had left the drum open for a number of days.The activity is not normal practice and as such no risk assessments have been carried out for this . Immediately after the accident we have issued a company wide memo to ensure that this activity should not be undertaken in any circumstances and that if any chemicals are placed into a drum which is n't labelled to contain them they must be marked/labelled and stored correctly . We have also contacted a chemical waste disposal company to arrange for safe removal of any chemical waste to ensure this never happens again .

The engineer <NAME> ,attempted to check an automatic air vent on the water section of the central heating boiler has he checked the plastic thumb screw the vent came apart and emmitted hot water . <NAME> sustained scold burns to his hand and for arm has he tried to stem the flow .

During excavation outside the back door of the premises , the worker came into contact with the electricity cable causing damage to the cable and resulted in fire caught by the worker clothes . fire was put off immediately . there were burns that can be seen on arms and stomach area at the time . he was conscious and talking at the time of accident . He was taken immediately to the hospital for checking .

On the morning of the <NAME> the <NAME> <NAME> was carrying out general tiding duties around the site in a work party of three . At approx 8.30am the IP was loading empty paint tins on to the back of flat bed truck to be disposed off . During the motion of lifting the empty tin of the back of the truck , the tin caught the side of the truck resulting in some residue solvents which was at the bottom of 25l tin , splashing onto the IP face . First aid was immediately applied asp er MSDS and COSHH assessments which were available onsite , including the use of eye wash to remove and drenching the IP party with cold clean water by the supervisor to wash of all of the solvent which had came into contect with the <NAME> At the time of the incident the had been wearing standard <NAME> for site including safety glasses , hi-vis jacket , overalls , safety boots and hard hat , barrier cream had been available onsite however the IP had not applied any that morning . Once first aid had been applied the IP was given the option to attend site medic medic however he refused as he said he was all right to continue work . After the incident the IP was given a fresh change of clothes and continued working for the rest of the day on lighter duties . The IP was monitored for the rest of the day .After the IP had finished his shift at 17.00 he then returned to his accommodation , later on in the evening the IP attending A & E at <NAME> <NAME> hospital in <NAME> where it was diagnosed that the IP had chemical burns to areas of his face and would require treatment . The IP was discharged from the Hospital on <NAME> the <NAME> and then returned home to <NAME> . After attending his local doctors the IP was signed off work until the <NAME> . In future all paints tins with resdues left within are to be fully emptied into waste paint drum before moving from work site . Any tins with any materials left within must be securely sealed with lid , before moving.greater situational awareness to be carried by all personnel when carry out tasks to ensure they are aware of what in in tins prior to movementsBarrier cream also used by all personnel .
After wood treatment in the loft area the tenant opened loft hatch door and was allegedly splashed in the eyes and face with fluid present on polythene around the hatch opening .
Operative using jack hammer to break out concrete when he made contact with an electrical cable.

Injured person was setting up a string line as a level for laying kerbs , the process involves using steel pins to hold the string line in place the pins are placed in a track that has been excavated in order to lay the new line of kerbs . The injured person was hammering a steel pin into the ground within the excavated track ( depth around <NAME> ) and struck a electric cable in a duct ( low voltage ) with the steel pin . There was a flash and a flame shot up from the ground causing burns to the injured persons left forearm and face . He was then taken to hospital were his arm was placed in cold water for two hours . In this instance the risk assessment was not followed , services drawings were on site and showed location of cable but the CAT (Cable Avoidance Tool) was not used , location of services not marked on site by chalk or paint .Refresher Course in CAT  training will be organised and reinforcement of following correct proceedures when excavating . Injured person has been fully trained in excavations . Burns are less than 10 % closer to 5 % .

As part of an annual electrical installation testing procedure and following the completion of the testing of the circuits from a three phase distribution board referenced “####” located in the [NAME] 7 [NAME] 2” the distribution board cover had been re-fitted . [NAME] was tasked with inserting the blanks to the board cover to ensure that the board was left in a safe condition.The blanking pieces are of the type that fit into the cover of the board and when these covers are removed the blanks move out of their correct position and therefore can only be re-inserted once the cover has been re-fitted over the mcb’s .Some of the blanks for the board were found to simply clip into position while others were more difficult to fit ( this was due in part to the use of modified non propriety blanks ) , [NAME] used the tip of a screwdriver to lever these blanks into position . When re - fitting one of the blanks in this manner the screwdriver slipped and entered the distribution board bringing it into contact with the "live" rail causing a short circuit which resulted in an electrical flash causing burns to [NAME] arms and in particular [NAME] right forearm. Prevention : 1.Use only proprietary blanking pieces that fit the distribution board correctly. If there is no alternative other than to use the odd blanks then the boards should be isolated while the blanks are fitted. 2 . Do not use tools to prise blanking pieces into place unless the board is isolated

On [Date] at approximately 1230 , IP was part of a two man crew working at the [Name] grounds in [NAME] , carrying out line marking duties on behalf of [NAME] . IP’S role on the day was that of bucket man . This involves decanting thermoplastic paint from truck mounted boilers into an awaiting bucket . The decanted paint is then lifted from the truck mounted boilers area and poured into an awaiting line marking mould .On the day of the incident , IP had decanted white thermoplastic paint into his bucket from the truck mounted boilers . He placed paint into the awaiting mould and stood just behind his chargehand who was marking a “keep clear" sign on the road . When standing , IP felt extreme heat inside his right gauntlet and screamed out in pain removing the gauntlet from his right hand . Upon removing the gauntlet IP realised that a quantity of paint had accidently got inside his glove and under the cuff of his jumper and was now burning into his wrist and the side of his hand. Due to IP letting out a loud scream in pain his chargehand stopped what he was doing and assisted IP. Chargehand was assisted by [NAME] employee and both men attended to IP wounds by applying cold water to the visible effected area . ( Water was stored on lining truck ) . Due to the severity of the injuries IP was taken to local accident and emergency hospital by [NAME] employee . When at hospital IP presented the staff with his RSMA Thermoplastic burns information card . The injuries were assessed and IP was informed that he was going to be taken to the burns unit at [Name] hospital [NAME] . At 1530 IP was transferred to [NAME] and assessed in the burns unit then treated for his wounds.The control measures of [Name] risk assessment states - Ensure appropriate PPE is worn at all times ; Hi Viz trousers and jacket , safety footwear and gauntlet gloves with extended cuff . Hard hat and face visor must be worn when filling / discharging from boiler and during boiler cleaning.On inspection of the gauntlets worn by IP it is clear to see they have had their blue extended cuff removed.The last audit of [NAME] and [NAME] was carried out In [NAME] . Health and safety folder was present in truck ( Contains all SSOW and RA)Gauntlets readily available from stores Both men have been issued their employee handbook discipline proceeding against both chargehand and operative . Charge hand - It the changehands role to make sure all personnel on site are safe , irrespective of experience . Breach of  [Name] [Name] and HSWA Section 7.  Operative was fully aware that the gauntlet he was using was defective but continued to use it in its unsafe condition , instead of alerting the manager , this is a clear breach of not only  of [Name] [Name] and RA but the HSWA section 7 and PPE Regs Section 11. Safety alert of Incident ,Management  audits to be carried out as per schedule. All Operatives to be issued with gauntlets , All Charge hands to be given further guidance around their role and responsibilities

A number of Concrete slabs were needed to be constructed as a result of a drainage upgrade needed in our <NAME> <NAME> depot . Prior to the concrete pour the gang were engaged in slab preperation . C40/50 concrete had been ordered for 8.00 am on the <NAME> . And at 8.15am the discharge began . The weather was warm but light rain was experienced resulting in some standing water on the concrete . The concrete was placed into the bay using a 5ton 360 excavator . The concrete was then leveled and screeded to level using a 50mm x 100mm timber . One edge of the pour was against a wall and the adjacent edge was form work to provide finished level . It was necessary for an operative to operate the screed against the wall and for another operative to assist with screeding and fiber floating the concrete in the middle of the slab . The two operatives found themselves kneeling in the concrete and this led to <NAME> <NAME> receiving the cement burns to both of his legs which has led to the RIDDOR report . Subsequent to the incident a full investigation has been completed by the Safety department . The site manager is now subject to a disciplinary investigation/Action . The operatives have been rebriefed into the Risk assesment for concrete works . Mechanical means for placing and finishing the concrete have been sourced . The labour resource has been reviewd and the resource has been increased . The <NAME> department will issue a memo on the concequences of cement burns to highten awareness .

RE-SUBMISSION - from advise of HSE advisory team, no record found of orginal submitted form done in <NAME>. Call out to job to unblock wash hand basin, chemical poured in to unblock had re-action and sprayed up into face of engineer.

Operatives engaged in the construction of a services manhole/inspection chamber across electrical cables . The area had been cleared by safe means and all the services identified . Operatives were to have worked around an adjacent brick structure but decided to widen the work area to suit . An electrical hammer tool ( "kango" ) was used on the brick structure and in the process an electrical cable was split . No further works to the area until full review .

The IP was requested to remove a broken bollard on <NAME> <NAME> . The IP arrived on site and conducted a CAT survey , which identified an electrical cable in the pavement . The IP assume this passed the front of the bollard , so commenced breaking out between the bollard and the back of kerb , at a depth of approximately 145mm the IP hit a street lighting cable , which cause superficial burns to his arms and chest .
Excavating a post hole for the erection of the boundary fence , a voltage cable was struck by an operative causing an explosion .

IP was carrying out a repair to a box roof . As he was applying green mineral felt using heat application , the wind caught the piece of felt and it folded back , landing on his forearm . He immedietly went to A&E and received treatment for the burn .

Operative had been working with cement/lime/sand mortar that day , either mixing or distributing to plasterers . Operative had no issues when he removed his PPE work boots after work to put on his own personal footwear to go home . When home operative took off shoes and socks and noticed redness and soreness to the top of his left foot and could not place foot in bath water . Operative went to <NAME> <NAME> ( <NAME> ) and referred to <NAME> <NAME> The <NAME> <NAME> hospital  and diagnosed with a thermal injury (cement burn ) . Signed off work for two weeks

Filling loop spindle on gas boiler had a loose jam nut . Spindle popped out and water from the primary circuit sprayed out and onto hands . Thumbs on both hands burned when refitting spindle and jam nut . We have instructed our gas consultant , <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , to investigate the circumstances of the incident and to report findings to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> .

We were heating up a room to get it to dry out with the help of a gas heater .The heater went out when this was inspected after commencement and <NAME> went to relight the heater but due to a build up of gas there was a flash over causing shock and minor burns to him . . he went to his colleague . who was working next door to get help . This person called 999 and the fire brigade ,police and ambulance all arrived <NAME> was then taken to the hospital where he received treatment and was discharged . He is currently off work and attending the out patience to change his bandages and to be checked over . We will update our policy and risk assessments to ensure all cylinders are checked for leaks along with ensuring all rooms are fully vented when these are been employed .

One operative was charging the new air conditioning system with R410A refrigerant in the rooftop plant enclosure . On completion of filling the system and during disconnecting the gauges the Shrader isolating valve did not hold and leaked a ( relatively small ) quantity of liquid refrigerant . The operative suffered freeze burns to both hands through his gloves . He attended [NAME] [NAME] 's Hospital at [NAME] . He was discharged and returned to work the same day . Although he is back at work the incident is being reported under RIDDOR on the grounds that he is not yet able to undertake his normal duties within 7 days . A colleague who came to help at the time of the incident suffered minor freeze burns to one finger , which is not reportable .

DP was one of a team of 3 operatives erecting scaffold in a chemicals plant. DP stepped onto a trough containing lime, and received severe chemical burns to his foot. DP died several weeks later, after apparently making a recovery.

The IP was picking his bag up from underneath the kitchen counter. The IP lifted his bag over his shoulder, in doing so, one of the handle straps snagged the tap of a Birco Boiler, which pulled the boiler off the counter, spilling hot water onto the IP's foot.

Whilst carrying out a ceiling replacement/repair <NAME> touched his head on a fire alarm and received an electric shock he was stood on his hop up at the time and was with his labourer . Job was shut down until area has been checked , Area Surveyor sent out to attend and take photographs .

While infilling around a heating pipe which passed through a brick wall , the IP knocked a lever which opened a drain down valve on a steam pipe . steam sprayed out and injured the IP on his leg and arm .

<NAME> <NAME> was refueling a JCB with a pump.  When he removed the refuelling hose from the machine he spilt diesel over his trousers.  There was very little diesel spilt over the roadway.  <NAME> <NAME> then tried to "dry" the diesel off his trousers using a propane burner.  His supervisor advised him to move away from the flame but <NAME> refused.  <NAME>'s trousers then burst into flames causing injury to his right leg.

using a 100kg SWL Bag and Pulley, , began to lift the transformer tank from the deck of the vessel to the working platform of the mono pile . Wearing gloves we managed to lift safely to the point of the monopole platform . Suddenly the pulley system failed for reasons unknown , this resulted in the tank falling onto the bow of the <NAME> <NAME> resulting in the technician instinctively clasping harder onto the rope .

The IP ( injured person ) was supplied by <NAME> <NAME>  to <NAME> <NAME>  on a labour only basis . The IP was carrying out steelfixing works under the direction and supervision of <NAME> at the time of the accident . The accident occured whilst the IP was cutting some reinforcement on a beam cage section at the site entrance . Whilst the IP was in the process of using a petrol disc cutter ( supplied by <NAME> ) to cut some reinforcing bars the disc cutter burst into flames . The IP threw the disc cutter to the ground but petrol must have leaked out spilling onto the IPs right trouser leg and left glove . The resulting fire caused burns to the IP right shin and left hand.The IP did not fill the disc cutter with petrol at any time , it was being used by other workers during the course of the day and the IP used it when it was free.The IP attended hospital where he was diagnosed with superficial burns to the right shin and left hand - 7 % superficial mixed depth burns to the shin - dressings applied

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Surfacing squad operative was beginning an operation of tarmacing/asphalt laying and was moving to the side of the paver machine in order to assist laying/compacting fresh asphalt . The paver had been placed in position ready for the first run of the day at approximately 0930 hours . The operative moved around to the side of the machine and slipped/tripped on the " side-gate " of the paving machine , in the area where the machine extrudes asphalt , and the strip between the machine and the " cut-edge " of the road to the left . This area was also demarcated by traffic cones as there was a line of live traffic to the left of this .Operative stumbled and put hands out to break fall , and fell to his knees and put hands into direct contact with hot asphalt . The operative was wearing gloves at the time , but received burns to both wrists and some burning to the lower palm area , and small burns to three finger tips on the right hand . The operative immediately took the gloves off and was attended to by work colleagues who poured cold water over the injured areas . The operative was then immediately transported to <NAME> hospital accident and emergency department which is less than 1 mile from the site . Approximate time of incident was 0945am and arrival at the hospital was approximately 0955am . The operative was treated at the hospital as an out-patient in the A & E department and then discharged within 2 hours and was taken home . The operative will be recovering for at least 1 week .Accident investigation , incuding all key learning points is currently underway with injured party having been interviewed on <NAME> and other site investigation taking place also . Once all learning points and preventive action is known risk assessment review and Toolbox Talks will take place to brief Managers and Surfacing squad operatives. A safety alert will also be issued as an interim measure , on <NAME> .

Employee was screeding concrete and laying flags , ( he was wearing 2 pairs of pants and knee pads at the time ) . He did not notice anything until he got home from work and noticed skin had come off his knees . He attended work as normal the next day , when he mentioned this to his manager he immediately sent him to the health centre to have the injury assessed . He has suffered burns to both knees from the cement .  Investigation was carried out into the product used and also how the task was being completed . No other employee who was working on the task at the time has been affected . The Risk assessments are being reviewed again . Alternative PPE is being explored .

<NAME> Consultants <NAME> <NAME> ) employed a specialist sub-contractor , <NAME> <NAME> Specialists <NAME> , to undertake excavation works at this site for the purposes of in-situ testing of the pavement construction . The work involved a petrol-powered generator to drive the breaking-out tools . Having worked for some hours , the generator stopped . The <NAME> supervisor removed a spark plug to assess what the problem might be . During this operation and testing for a spark , some vapour/fuel ignited and caused burning to the supervisor 's face and right thumb/forefinger . The supervisor , who was wearing eye protection , was taken to hospital where he remained for five days . <NAME> 's immediate actions have been to reinforce in our relevant RAMS that all plant must be operated in accordance with the manufacturer 's instructions and that this must apply to both normal work activities and to repairs/maintenance , with only suitably qualified/trained personnel being used . <NAME> have indicated that they are to review their use of petrol-powered generators and move to diesel-powered units in future .

Working at back of lorry gas from an unused boiler was ignited by the adjacent lit boiler causing a gas blast that caused scorch damage to the back of <NAME> 's hand and hair loss to the back of his arm . Examination of control box found that the correctly functioning thermocouple shut off valve had been wired closed with a zip tie , thus by-passing a safety system . This will be highlighted at the next safety meeting and we are working on a way of putting elementary controls outside the control box and then securing the control box with a padlock .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured person had just alighted from a forward tipping dumper whilst it was being loaded with hot tarmac. The IP had his back towards the dumper when some material was flicked into the air as the loader emptied its ' bucket . The hot material landed on the IPs back arms and neck .
IP was pouring concrete when he started feeling pain on the top of his feet . He removed his boots and saw his feet were burnt .

An operative was carrying out works in the kitchen using expanding foam to fill two holes under the installed kitchen units . The applied expanding foam then expanded too quickly causing superficial burns to the skin of the operatives face and arms .

Our engineers mate was asked to check the operation of a pump by removing the centre screw cap and checking the rotation of the pump . during this process the centre cap was released under some pressure of hot water and the centre cap fell to the floor . The mate used a bucket to collect the water whilst locating the centre pin . In attempting to replace the centre pin he dropped it in the bucket of boiling water and proceeded to retrieve the pin from the bucket with his hand on three occasions . On the third attempt he was successful and replaced the pin , it was at this stage that he realised he had burnt his hand , he went to the toilet and held his hand under water for approx 20 mins and was taken to hospital where he was treated for a badly burnt hand .

On the above date , [NAME] (IP) was tar and chipping a bridge at a location on [NAME] [NAME] he was working with another company employee  [NAME].  The two employees had just arrived at the site and they were setting up ready to undertake the work required. The IP set up the tar pitcher, and lit the gas . The pitcher already contained some bitumen from a previous job and the gas started to heat that residue bitumen. At this point [NAME] had moved away from the van and was undertaking another task . After approximately 5 minutes IP opened a tub of solid bitumen, which was already slightly soft in texture and moved it towards the pitcher . IP at this point had chosen not to wear any of the PPE provided , and on further investigation had not taken any to the site in the company vehicle. IP stated that even if the PPE had been in the van he would have not worn it, as he never believed that he would not be harmed and had become complacent. IP then held the whole block of bitumen above the pitcher, thinking mistakenly that the residue bitumen in the pitcher had yet to turn to liquid. However the bitumen had melted but there was crust on the top and this led IP to believe it was still solid. At this point the bitumen slipped out of IP's hands and fell into the pitcher causing the residue bitumen to splash back and cover certain areas of IP's body . At first IP did n’t realise the severity of the situation and when he saw a farmer passing by he hid by the side of the van so that he could n’t be seen . However IP was not there long as the bitumen had covered part of his right hand and a copious amount had covered his forearm and spots had gone on his face . The bitumen on the palm of his hand had started to burn so he started to try and scrap the bitumen off with his left hand . At this point [NAME]  had returned to the van and saw the problems that the IP was having. [NAME]  applied water to the affected areas which caused the bitumen to foam and ultimately harden. IP telephoned [NAME] who advised him to return to the depot. IP had to drive back as  [NAME] is unable to drive . When IP started to drive the pain started to increase , and when he arrived back [NAME] took him straight to hospital where he was treated .

we were asked to disconnect an Aga from the hot water cylinder ready for another contractor to remove the boiler.The Aga had been on and the cylinder was hot . The cylinder was drained by syphoning out the water with a hose leaving the water in the boiler and the circulating pipe work . Once the cylinder had been drained a hose was placed on the pipe work drain point next to the boiler , this turned out to be seized . the drain point was removed and allowed to drain into a bucket , it was at this point that his hands were burnt as the water was still very hot.

The gas burner on the boiler which is used to heat up the thermoplastic road markings material , had gone out . <NAME> <NAME> attempted to re-light the boiler , without waiting the prescribed time to allow the un-burnt gas to disperse from the boiler . He reached down into the boiler area to attempt to reignite the pilot light , using a lighter . The unspent gas within the boiler caused a blow back of flame , which covered the back of his right hand , causing the injury .

The accident took place within the heating substation located within the basement area of the construction project . The IP was installing copper pipework into a low level valve on the heating system . The process involved screwing the short pipe into the valve until finger tight in preparation for soldering in the differential pressure control . As he was installing the second length of pipe the valve he was screwing into split and blew off , causing the injuries . immediate actions taken to prevent a recurrence were to isolate the heating and hot water boilers and pumps and allow the pipework and supply water to cool down . All peripheral installation was stopped , and the remaining valves of the same type that failed were removed . A review of the RAMS for the process of fitting ancillary items to services pipework was undertaken , and a long term view on the work sequencing of the ancillary component installation will be carried out .

The <NAME> on <NAME> contract is a reactive eartworks project for <NAME> <NAME> . Due to a land slip large volumes of quarried stone had to be pushed up against the existing embankment to stabilise it.The work was 24 hr working from <NAME> until <NAME> . The IP was working as a gateman directing stone lorries onto site on nightshift . At 01.30 he went for a scheduled break in the mess hut . At 02.00 he filled a hot water bottle with boiling water from a kettle and tucked it under his clothing in the small of his back . At 02.05 he leant back against a temporary lighting set and the hot water bottle burst , scalding him . The foreman learnt of the incident at 02.15 and after assessing his injuries he took him straight to the A & E department at <NAME> hospital . He was later transferred to <NAME> <NAME> burns unit .

Incident occurred when the IP was sheeting 2 tons of hot rolled Asphalt material after being loaded at the suppliers plant . The hot material come into contact with a small 750ml can of tack coat and as the IP proceeded to cover the hot materials this can exploded , propelling hot bitumen over the right hand side of the IPs face and neck . The IP sustained minor burns .

The injured party , <NAME> <NAME> was hand excavating around a live <NAME> <NAME> cable using an insulated fork . He was clearing soil from underneath the cable when the cable erupted  and there was a flash of light and flames , which travelled up his arms causing burns to his left arm and face .Managing director , <NAME> <NAME> attended site to investigate the incident and photographs are available to support this report.The burn mark in the soil clearly indicates where the cable blew several feet away from where <NAME> was working . On excavating that section of cable during our investigations it was discovered that the cable sheath and armours were worn by a stone that was present on top of the cable in a section that was not protected by cable duct , and it was here that the cable had erupted . <NAME> <NAME> inspected the insulated fork that <NAME> had been using and this showed no sign of burning or other damage. <NAME> concluded that that <NAME> did not hit the cable with the fork , but instead whilst excavating around the cable further along the route that <NAME> had disturbed it , causing the stone to imbed further in the cable and resulting in the subsequent eruption .

The task was to install an isolation valve on the CT circuit for a local heater water circuit . This was due to the existing isolation valve passing water . The IP then contacted the duty holder to isolate the water within core 5 riser to release the pressure from the systemThe IP and duty holder first looked at the 'AS BUILT' drawings to check details , then they went to core 5 riser and identified the CT circuit pipes by looking at the identification tags on the pipework , the circuit was then isolated . The  duty holder then drained off the pressure in the isolated pipes within the riser , the IP then went to the work area and stated that he opened the local drain cock , no water drained from this position . The IP then went back to the core 5 riser and informed the duty holder that this appeared to be the correct system that had been isolated Upon cutting the pipe , 85hot water was released under pressure and the IP immediately reached for the new isolation valve and pushed the valve onto the pipe to stop the hot water flowing out of the pipe and then isolated the supply within approximately 30 seconds . It is believed that the identification tags that were not on the correct pipeworkThe IP then looked at his gloves and his first thought was to remove them due to the heat retained and realised that the hot water had burnt his left hand ( Three fingers ) . The IP immediately went to inform the duty holder what had happened and then attended A & E department for medical attention ; the IP's left hand 3rd , 4th & 5th fingers were blistered . The wound was dressed and the IP returned to work at 11:30 and carried on supervising the works on site for the rest of the day . He has since then not returned to work
Working on water pipes valve came apart from pipe on live side & struck operative on forehead .

The injured party was working doing decorating work as part of a <NAME><NAME> project . The delta deck platform he was working on gave way and he fell from the platform , he was struck on the head by a guard rail as he fell and landed hard on his back . An ambulance was summoned and he was taken to hospital

Pushing a telehandler machine that had broken down into the warehouse . <NAME> <NAME> keeping watch blind side of the vehicle whilst machine was being moved into building . For reasons unknown stepped between the machine and a steel beam . The machine was immediately pulled forward to release <NAME> . He had lost conciseness but came round within seconds . The first aider cleared his airways and put him into the recovery position . The emergency services were called and he was taken to hospital .

A 5t excavator had thrown a track and our site team decided to attempt to push it back into position. During this activity <NAME> was using a scaffold pole as a lever and when the track was slowly spun by <NAME> this resulted in the pole being wrenched out of <NAME> hands and struck <NAME> on his safety helmet and also on his (L) ear.

<NAME> were undertaking refurbishment works at the <NAME> <NAME> head office in <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> . Materials were required to be removed off site to a secluded area to the outside of the building away from public reach . Ther rear exit that would normally be used was blocked so a decision was taken to take the materials out of the from entrance of the <NAME> <NAME> building.The site foreman aided the operative through the <NAME> <NAME> building until they got to the front entrance where the operative was left to carry materials on to a public pavement . The operative surveyed the pavement and thought it was safe so he procedded on his way carrying the materials length ways . Coming towards the operative was members of the public so he stopped in order to let her pass then when he thought this person was clear he continued on his way , it is at this point it alleged that this member of the public was hit in the face and head.The operative stated he felt the materials make contact with something due to the jolt . The operative then took the materials to a secure place and asked the member of the public if she was OK. The member of the public was apologised to and taken on to the site where she was given a type of cold compress . The member of the public then left the site feeling ok and went to work .Upon arriving at her workplace this lady explained to her workplace the incident that she had just been involved in to which their first aider gave her an ice pack and some nurofen . By lunch time her symptoms were much more severe so after calling NHS direct and ambulance was called and took her to hospital.After arriving at hospital this lady was seen by a doctor to be examined and told that she had a concussion and a whiplash type injury and was only allowed to leave if she had someone that could watch over her . After nearly a week of rest this lady returned to the hospitl as her symptoms were not getting any better to be advised that the symptoms could be like this for a number of weeks .At this present time we have no evidence that this lady in question ever went to the hospital or if an ambulance was indeed called . There were also no witnesses of this lady being struck by the materials either .

<NAME> had been visiting the court to check the works that were being carried out as part of the refurbishment project on which she is the building surveyor . The scaffold was erected inside the courtroom and as she walked up the steps towards where the Magistrates would sit , she had to stoop under a very low scaffold tube . Once she thought she had cleared the tube she stood up . Due to her restricted view ( whilst wearing her hard hat ) , she had not cleared the low level scaffold tube and banged her head as she stood up . She went directly from site to A & E and was accompanied by colleagues . She was diagnosed as having concussion and was off work for 6 days as a result of th incident .
DP died from head injuries after being struck by a manhole cover being lifted with chains by an excavator. DP was working in a drainage trench.
Employee unloading vehicle when DP insisted on helping. A timber pallet moved from the telehandler & pinned DP causing fatal injuries.
DP was operating a mobile elevating work platform (MEWP) to install a roller shutter door. DP became trapped between the top rail of the MEWP and the roller shutter assembly.
DP was an HGV driver was found on the floor at the base of his cab he appears to have fallen from the cab and sustained a significant head injury. Following 5 weeks in hospital the DP passed away.

The IP was installing a balcony on <NAME> block north side 4th floor whilst working from a balcony below on the 3rd floor , as he was repositioning a set of podium steps . As he moved backwards to an unprotected open edge then fell onto the balcony below with the podium steps falling with him . The IP initially was unconcious then received first aid on site walked from the accident area to the site office then went to hospital by ambulance . The IP was later released with minor brusies and a broken finger.The accident has been investigated and the method statement and risk assessment reviewed with changes to the method and sequence of work

DP fell approx 50 feet from an overturning lorry mounted cherry picker, and suffered leg injuries. DP died in Hospital 24 hours later from fat embolism syndrome, which was related to the leg injuries.

I was given a CAT scan along with treatment and medication and kept overnight for 24hr observation suffering from bruising and swelling to my head , trauma and concussion .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: injured party ( IP ) was in the process of scraping walls during the asbestos removal process . IP turned during the course of his work and tripped over an aluminium spar located at ground level . IP fell , hitting right chest / rib cage on a additional spar located parallel . IP was winded straight away , and had to be helped from the asbestos enclosure by other site operatives . Once IP regained his breath , he decontaminated as normal . IP was still feeling pain in his ribcage and was taken to hospital by a fellow employee . IP was taken to hospital and diagnosed with internal bruising to ribs ( no x-rays taken ) . IP was referred to their GP who supplied them with a sick line and given ibrufen / paracetamol . IP has been absent from work since the incident and is expected back to work on <NAME>  <NAME>

Prior to the accident we <NAME> were in the process of carrying out a level access bathroom installation for <NAME> <NAME> which commenced works <NAME> , on <NAME>  our electricians ( <NAME> ) were last operatives to be on site to conduct their 1st fix installation , We were due back site <NAME>  to commence with day 3 of our works. <NAME> <NAME> of  <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> was visiting his ex-wife <NAME> <NAME> at  <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ,  <NAME> on <NAME>  <NAME> . At approximately 4:00 pm <NAME> <NAME> was getting ready to leave the property on exiting the living room he caught his left foot on the plastic proplex floor protection which he states was not taped down to the floor . Subsequently he lost his balance and fell forward banging his head against the knocker on the front door which was open in the hallway . <NAME> <NAME> landed awkwardly on his left side and ended up lying in the communal area where lay unconscious for 5 minutes . <NAME> <NAME> proceeded to attempt to wake <NAME> <NAME> by tapping his shoulders and face . Due to the nature of the injury the mother of <NAME> <NAME> decided to take <NAME> <NAME> to hospital . On receiving treatment at the <NAME> <NAME> a doctor confirmed he had sustained a small cut to his forehead . Also after his left arm was x-rayed he was informed his arm was badly bruised . He was given leaflet about concussion injuries and told to rest for 48 hours . On  <NAME> at 11:00 am <NAME> <NAME> called <NAME> <NAME> at <NAME> ( Quality and Performance manager ) and reported the accident . At 3 pm in the afternoon <NAME> <NAME> ( Project manager ) and <NAME> <NAME> ( Project supervisor ) attended the property to take a witness statement from <NAME> <NAME> and take photographic evidence
Scaffold tube struck operative on head

Operatives were exiting roof via access ladder after erecting scaffold system for builders work , two operatives descended as appropriate but the apprentice decided to slide down the ladder with feet & hands either side of the frame without using the ladder rungs as trained . Upon the descent he lost his balance and hit the floor feet first which caused him to fall backwards and land on his behind before rolling backwards , at the time he did not report the incident and did not complain of any discomfort or pain due to the incident .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Whilst installing a king post which is a 12mtr long x 260mm x 260mm steel H section beam into the pre augered hole in the ground , attached by a snatch chain to a 25 ton excavator , both tested and certified under LOLER 98 , was lowered into the hole and was being placed into its position . The post required to be vertically plumb was being levered using a timber prop . <NAME> <NAME> who was keeping the beam in position until the packings were in place , slipped causing the lever to jump up , which caught him on the side of his head and he collapsed onto the floor at which point he passed out.Environmental conditions were dry and firm level ground.Immediate cause : <NAME> <NAME> who was keeping the beam in position until the packings were in place , slipped causing the lever to jump up , which caught him on the side of his head and he collapsed onto the floor at which point he passed out . Underlying cause : Due to underground obstructions it was not possible for the rig to drill a vertical hole , resulting in the deflection of the post and requiring the additional levering of the post into a plumb position.Root Cause : The design solution employed was based on the Site Investigation Report, which was inadequate and did not fully identify underground obstructions.The kingpost solution was decided upon based upon the findings of the Site Investigation Report however , following a reduced level dig it was found that the ground was not as expected , with boulders causing complications with the drilling operations . These unexpected complications resulted in changes to the proposed methods of construction and <NAME> should have ceased operations and paid due diligence to other options rather than amending the existing method of construction.The complications mean't that the post was not inserted vertically plumb and as a result an inappropriate method of work and equipment was adopted to plumb the king post . By using the timber prop <NAME> <NAME> was put at risk as it should have been foreseeable that if the timber or himself had slipped or the post moved then the lever would slip and possibly cause an injury , which is what has happened . Actions taken :Pay due diligence to site investigation reports and consider all alternative proposals in selecting appropriate solutions at the design stage .Ensure that suitable equipment is available and utilised.Assess all changes to the method of work and the associated foreseeable risk . A delay in reporting from site to head office ( IT problems on site ) resulted in delay in notification .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

The council <NAME> <NAME> was and is carrying out major works i .e . building works to my building and on more than one occasion I have had masonry , metal , and plastic fall from a 3 storey building onto my head , back , shoulders causing stratches and bruising to my body

<NAME> <NAME>  exited plot 3 on the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> development . He was later discharged with symptoms of concussion , with advice to rest and consult his local GP the following day .

DP was attempting to paint spokes on the tyres of the Thwaites Dumper truck. He entered the space between an active 21 tonne excavator and a stationary dumper truck. The subsequent collision between the moving excavator and the stationary dumper truck trapped DP leading to his death.'
DP was driving a forward tipping dumper on a slope when it overturned onto its roll bar. DP was not wearing seat belt, crushed by the overturning dumper.

Operative was the traffic marshall and was assisting in the reversing of a lorry into the unloading area along [NAME]. The lorry had several attempts to reverse and the operative moved along side the lorry to assist in marshalling the lorry into position . As the lorry moved he bacame trapped between the lorry chasis and the hoarding .
As the scaffolders were erecting the scaffold the scaffolding upright fell on to <NAME> <NAME> 's head

IP was tiling in kitchen of tenant 's property and struck a newly fitted wall cabinet adjacent to the floor-level cooker. The cabinet ( dimensions w300mm x h720mm x d280mm , fitted with 16mm depth door ) fell, striking IP on head before hitting the floor . Investigated by departmental manager, HR and H & S. Corrective actions include toolbox talk to ' Kitchens ' Team to raise awareness of incident , installation procedures and reporting of damaged / faulty equipment and or materials .

Maintenance to the <NAME> , whilst laying tactile paving slabs in to position on the footpath manually . Suddenly while placing the paving slab to the ground the employee had a sudden pain in his back . The size of the tact tile was 450mm x 450mm x 60mm weight approx . 15kg.The operative has had manual handling training in <NAME> , on return to work we will issue a refresher course .
DP fell 3m through access hatch on mobile tower and suffered fatal injuries

IP was installing roof trusses on a new building site . The IP was in the process of installing temporary braces to the toeboards of the scaffolding , having had them placed by the site crane . A strong gust of wind caught the trusses and they toppled in a domino effect onto the IP He was hit across the back of the head and collapsed to the floor of the scaffolding . Emergency services attended the scene and he was rescued .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Two electricians were sent to install cabling to a decking area in preparation for installation of external lights . There were in fact two decking areas one was safe to work on and the other was not . There had been previous problems with the job whereby the electricians attended site on [DATE] and could not install the cable as the area was not ready to be worked on . By the time of the second visit , a failure of communication had arisen which lead to us being told that the decking area was now safe to work on . In fact the particular area we were to work on was not in a safe condition and was barriered off to one end . Both of the electricians climbed over or through the barrier to access the area . After working for a little time he stood up to move and stood on the trap end of an unsecured board causing it to " seesaw " he fell and became wedged between the joists . Afetr a few minutes he was able to get to his feet and walk off of the decking area . He was taken to [NAME] and treated for bruising and a minor laceration to his abdomen . He was told that he had a suspected fractured rib but this was not visible on X-ray . After kidney function checks he was discharged but has now been off work for a period of seven days .

The activity required the moving of 1 metre length pieces of lightweight insulation material ( weighing less than 500grams per length ) from a box on the ground onto the platform of a scaffold which was 2,8 metres from the ground . The scaffold was surrounding a Surge Drum that was in the process of being insulated . The Surge Drum itself is supported on a steel frame.This activity was performed using a set of new aluminium 6 rung steps . The person involved is n't sure exactly what happened but believes the steps gave way beneath him causing him to fall off the steps onto the floor and the supporting steel framework of the Surge Drum resulting in bruising and grazing to his back .

The injured person was dismantling a partition within unit <NAME> . He could not access the drill bits for the drill and instead used a hammer and crowbar to dismantle a parition wall . While dismantling the partition a peice of plaster board fell and struck him on the back of the head .

IP was carrying out roofing activity . IP stepped backwards unaware that scaffolding had been removed and fell through the gaps in the boards catching himself on protruding scaffold standard . An investigation has been carried out and remedial actions to be instigated by the PC

<NAME> <NAME> had been directing his team mate <NAME> <NAME> to park his MEWP ( hired MEWP ) to the correct position . Then  <NAME> opened the side door on the MEWP to obtain some tools for the job . Whilst doing this <NAME> <NAME> had deployed the stability legs on the MEWP.  As the legs were bring deployed the leg on the side that  <NAME> was standing came down and crushed his left foot . On inspection after the incident  <NAME> checked his foot and it was his little toe on his left foot that had been bruised . He continued to work for the rest of the day and it was the following <NAME> ( <NAME>) that the swelling was so much that he could not put his work boots on . Since the incident the manager has informed the operative to take time to make himself familiar with his vehicle and hired vehicles .
Loading of one skip into another to facilitate emptying of first skip , lower skip tipped up and caused an arm to be trapped between the skips

Access to a telecoms site required personal to climb over a 60cm high dry stone wall . At 15.00 whilst exiting site over the dry stone wall the IP stumbled forward and fell resulting in segments of the wall falling onto his left ankle .Retraining on assessing risk to be conducted with IP and safety alert to be issued to remainder of business

Working on fitting cladding to front elevation of liner building , moving composite sheet from pallet , sheet had ice on it causing to slip from , hand , also slipped on frozen ground causing sheet to strike left hand . [NAME] came to work next day but had to go to hospital . X-ray showed bruising , still attending Doctor
<NAME> entered onto incomplete scaffolding and fell between two unsercured boards
Stepped off upper level on split level scaffolding when board on lower level snapped. IP threw himself to side landing on leg and hurting knee. IP had knee replacement surgery earlier in 2014.

A public vehicle illegally drove through the road closure , striking an item of plant with its offside wing mirror before striking the IP with its nearside wing mirror . Police were contacted later that day .

While installing chipboard to the half landing of the internal staircase , The IP stepped on to the stair at which point it gave way causing him to fall to the flight below . The broken stair then fell on top of him .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Operatives slipped whilst walking down staircase and fell to bottom . The metal staircase is an integral part of the cabin arrangement and securely fixed in position . At the time of the accident the staircsae was clear of any objects / trip hazards .
<NAME> was removing a shed base from a void property , he did n't have proper control of the lift and it dropped trapping his thumb .

IP was climbing down a ladder when his foot slipped on the rung causing him to fall . IP was taken to hospital by site manager to which it was confirmed that he did not break anything and had severe bruising to his right elbow , shin and foot .

Plumber driving to next job and was involved in a road traffic collision with a member of the public . The police are investigating the accident . Internal investigation not yet complete due to employee 's absence .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The engineer was walking down the stairs from the upstairs office when he slipped on the third step from the bottom landing on his back at the bottom of the stairs . Prior to the accident there were no signs of the carpet being lose . On investigation is was found that the underneath of the carpet had perished and had not been fitted correctly seven to ten years ago , only glued into place . The area has been made safe and a new industrial carpet is being fitted on <NAME>  <NAME>. There were no indications that the carpet was lose prior to the accident .

The IP was preparing to secure his slings to the hook of the main block of a mobile crane . The crane operator had overridden the limit switch due to a head room restriction and in doing so this allowed the small block to travel in toward the jib resulting in the block jamming and bursting the rope . The block fell and brushed the IP 's shoulder and back of arm . The IP fell and was taken to hospital and released after he had been checked for injury . He was given painkillers and may have a chipped bone in his shoulder

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: IP was working on the mezzanine floor located near the rotunda . Upon leaving work at 17.15 , he exited via a staircase that was installed but not completed , instead of using the authorised access route . He slipped on the top step that had been painted with fire proof paint and fell down one flight of steps .

On the morning of the <NAME> our site manager <NAME> <NAME> went to the security office  to collect a new starter for induction, the IP was sitting in the smoking area whilst <NAME> was collecting the induction folder to take the IP to the site canteen for induction, whilst collecting the folder a cordless drill that was attached to an operatives belt hit the handrail as he was descending the the site access staircase above the security office, the drill went over the side of the staircase and hit a light fitting above the security office and bounced, this then struck the IP on the top of his back.The IP was examined on site and was found not to have any cuts or visual signs of damage, we applied Ice to the area of the injury and transported the IP to the hospital for further assessment.Once the IP was taken to the hospital we carried out an investigation into the cause, The staircase that the operative was travelling down was for personnel only and not transportation of materials or plant, the operative stated that he did not use the hoist for the tools as it was in use at the time.To prevent this happening again we blocked off the access scaffold staircase above the canteen and carried out a tool box talk with all site operatives in the usage of the staircase. all personnel access was changed to the internal staircase of the building for operatives to get to the work areas.

Operator had left his excavator cab to closer inspect crushing operation he was carrying out. On his return to his cab he took a seated position and put his hand down to release the locked open cab door using the release handle. As the door released very high winds slammed the door shut  latching it in the door closed position. He was unable to open the door normally because the door frame had pinched his left arm between an internal handrail and the door. He called assistance and a fellow operator opened the door from outside. He was then assisted from machine and taken for hospital treatment

The injured person was supporting a plant operator excavating in the garden when the excavator broke down . The injured person was assisting in repair of the excavator when the excavator cab unexpectedly came down and crushed the injured person 's wrist . This resulted in hospital assessment realising soft tissue damage to the wrist but no broken bones . The injured person has been be unable to work for three weeks .

The IP , whilst working on a scaffold , bent down to pick up his brick hammer . In doing so he knocked a brick of the top of a stack of bricks . the brick then fell onto the ring finger of his right hand . He attended hospital where an x ray was taken that showed no breaks but cartilage damage to the finger . The IP has been absent from work for over 7 days .
