IP was using hand held hammer and hit his own LH causing a hand injury . TBT re safe use of hand held tools .

The driver of one of our HGV vehicles was securing his load whilst on the bed of the trailer . At the same time as he exerted his full force to ensure the ratchet strap was secure , the retaining hook came loose from the load . As he attempted to regain his balance , he tripped over one of the securing hooks on the side of the bed and fell from the bed , landing on the ground , on his l/h side . We have reviewed the incident with the driver and our independent transport consultant , and as a result have implemented a process by which drivers must secure loads from the ground , and not whilst on the bed of the lorry .

<NAME> was being shown how to change the bucket on the CAT 432 by the machine operator . As he released the bucket from the quick-hitch it swung forward and back , and is it did it came free of the quick-hitch . The bucket fell onto his foot underneath from a height of approximately 20 " above ground.The method for bucket changes has been re-iterated to ensure that the bucket is positioned as close to the ground as practically possible before attempting to change it .Since the accident , the operatives have also received additional instruction through a toolbox talks . The machine operator who was demonstrating the bucket change has been given additional instruction to raise his awareness of the issues with working with less-experienced operatives. <NAME> went to hospital following the accident to check the extent of his injuries . He has now returned to work .

Injured person was walking outside a building carrying bricks on his shoulder.  A scaffolding tube was thrown and bounced off something and hit the bricks off his shoulder and injured the shoulder and top of the arm.  An xray was taken and there were no broken bones, badly bruised.
<NAME> leaned over the ladder and fell down onto his feet .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> <NAME> is a 61 year old plumber employed by the <NAME> & <NAME> of <NAME> to carry out response maintenance works to <NAME> owned housing stock. <NAME> had been repairing a W.C leak within a domestic property . When walking down the stairs , <NAME> slipped on a loose carpet , injuring his right knee . The employee will be absent from work for more than 7 days as a result of his injury .Risk assessments are in place for slips , trips and falls . The employee was wearing suitable safety footwear at the time of this accident .

The barge crew were preparing a jack up barge to move to the next piling location at high tide .  Task lighting was in place and weather conditions good. As part of the move the piling gate had to be relocated . The team decided that in order to make the lift easier they removed a double I-Beam on the gate . This resulted in a gap of 370mn being created between the barge and piling gate . The injured person is a LOSC welder/burner working as part of the barge team . He walked to the work location which had the 370mm gap and for reasons that are unclear at present he fell through it . The operative fell approximately 7M into 1M of water where his lifejacket self-inflated . The operative made his way to shore unassisted and was taken to hospital by the Senior Engineer . The operative was kept in hospital under observation and then released during the late morning . We have reviewed the design of the gate with the designer and he has confirmed that it should not be necessary to remove the double I beams on future lifts and the lifting arrangements have been reviewed and proven that this is the case .A full investigation has commenced in order to identify any other areas of improvement required to prevent future reoccurrence .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: An investigation was carried out by [NAME] on [DATE] regarding an accident that occurred on site at  [NAME] , [NAME]   on [NAME] [Date] . The site is a new build medical centre , which is being constructed by [NAME]. [NAME] was walking to the site toilet , he stepped on a manhole cover which flipped in the air causing him to fall into the manhole . He sustained injuries including bruising to his upper right leg , cuts on his right ring and little fingers and jarring to his left hand and arm. [Name] sat to down for a while to recover from the shock of the fall ,  [NAME] , our site supervisor attended to [NAME] and took photos of the site and the injury to his leg and right hand . After a short rest [NAME] resumed his duties .On [NAME] [Date] at approximately 11.00 hours , [NAME] attended his local GP practice as he was suffering from pains in his left arm and back . He was advised to take a few days off work and not to carry heavy objects for 10 days and given medication. [NAME] from [NAME] the [NAME] contractor working on site was on the scene of the accident shortly after. After reviewing the information and photos , it looks like there was a hosepipe that had been passed into the manhole , if this was the case and the cover was replaced it would not have sat correctly and therefore flipped when [NAME] stood on it . The manhole should have been either cordoned off or covered with a more appropriate cover to prevent an accident of this type happening. Action taken to avoid further accidents of this nature – The manhole was covered a sheet of plywood that was lying on the ground in the vicinity and reported the accident to [NAME] [NAME] site management.Toolbox Talks on [DATE] will be carried out across the company week commencing 19/12/11.This accident is being reported now , so long after the date of the accident because [NAME] carried on working until [Date] so it is being reported within 10 days of becoming a reportable accident .
Fell from second floor when floor collapsed .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: General worker was stepping down from van on to uneven surface when he fell over hurting his foot and left arm causing cut and bruising to arm and bruising to right foot .

Following an interview with <NAME> <NAME> , the injured party , the following is a conclusion from the details obtained . For a more detailed overview then a formal investigation will need to take place .On <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> got his leg trapped between shuttering and a 360 ? JCB plant machine by the vehicle moving and trapping his leg . This resulted in an injury to the righ knee ligaments which required hospital treatment and time off work . From the duration of time off work , the accident is classed as a RIDDOR  Over 3 Day Injury  as the IP was not able to return to work for Normal Working Duties  on the 4th day .

IP was driving the 800 yard advance sign vehicle ( <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> Up)as part of a National highways sector scheme, 12c mobile lane closure to facilitate grass cutting operations s part of ther highways maintenace contract ..All the advance warning vehicles were situated on the hard shoulder in accordance with the layout prescribed in traffic signs manual chapter 8. IP 's vehicle was struck by a third party vehicle ( 7.5t box van ) which veered off the carriageway .IP required to be cut form the vehicle by fire brigade and he sustained cuts and bruises . He has yet to retrun to work and has been signed as unfit for work for a period of 4 weeks .

The crane driver was doing his daily check on the crane and he realised he had n't put the engine cover back on correctly . He got out to re-fit it , after fitting he turned , twisted and fell off the bed of the crane . This could not have been prevented as it was totally the drivers fault and could not have been envisaged .

IP was replacing the bathroom light . As she descended her step ladder she miss-footed the second step and slipped off landing on her ribs on the bathroom sink . Slip resistant safety footwear is provided and used , and the ladders are subject to routine inspection .

<NAME> <NAME> , an employee of <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , was working on a new terminal building at <NAME> <NAME> on a <NAME> <NAME> site . <NAME> <NAME> was applying touch up paint to some reworked support steelwork on the mezzanine floor above the check in floor . The work area was above a void between the concrete floor slab & the adjacent wall . The main contractor had installed plywood floor panels over the void to prevent a fall from height . A dry wall contractor was working in the area installing fireboarding to the void . This work entailed the removal of the individual plywood floor panels , the installation of new fireboard sheets & the subsequent reinstallation of the plywood panels . <NAME> <NAME> left the area shortly before 10.00 hrs to liaise with his site supervisor , <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> who was working in another part of the building . <NAME> <NAME> returned to his work area at 10.10 hrs to resume painting . The dry wall contractors were not present at this time as they had gone for their breakfast break . The dry wall contractors had failed to replace the plywood panel over a section of the newly installed fireboard . <NAME> <NAME> stepped onto this non-supported fireboard & fell 3m onto the marbled tilled floor below . This unsupported section measured 510 x 720mm . The dry wall contractors had failed to install any protective barriers or warning signage to alert personnel of the fragile nature of the floor . <NAME> <NAME> sustained a whiplash type injury to his shoulder & minor abrasions & bruising to his upper arms . <NAME>'s  GP has signed him as unfit for work for an initial 7 days , subject to a positive improvement in his injury . The accident was immediately reported to the main contractor by a member of the airport staff who were in a meeting on the check in floor , adjacent to the site of the fall . The missing plywood sheet has been subsequently reinstalled with an attached " Warning Fragile Floor " sign .

Both tradesman and the apprentice left the main school building from a side door . The side door auto closed , locking them out. The I.P.climbed a security fence between boiler house and main building to try to gain "quicker " access. The main access door , a short distance away at the front of the school was open . While he was attempting to climb over the 2000mm high metal palisade fence/gate (<NAME>). His foot got caught at the top and he fell from the top onto other side of fence ( grassed area ) and landed on his upper torso . There was no immediate reported injury and he continued working the full day.The I.P.consulted his GP next day who prescribed painkillers for " swollen Muscles" Both parties were interviewed and warned that this is not acceptable behaviour and that reocurrence will result in disciplinary action being taken. I would appologise for the late reporting of this incident as this was an oversight on my part .

Telephone report. The surveyor was surveying the tank room , A frame ladder was been used . These were fully extended but were 18inches short of the top of a concrete wall which was his access point . The ladder was footed by another surveyor . The surveyor took the decision to go beyond the maximum height of his ladder to reach an access point . As he returns to the ladder he realised he could nt step directly onto the ladder and struggled to reach to the top of the ladder causing discomfort to his chest and ribs and minor cuts and bruises to his leg . Notifier advice IP has been trained and if he followed his risk assessment he would never have attempted to access the top of the concrete wall .

The injured person is a delivery Driver for <NAME> <NAME> Supplies <NAME> and was unloading at a building site . The injured person was engaged in unloading building materials from the flat bed of a lorry with a mounted crane . In order to attach the load to the crane the IP climbed onto the edge of the lorry bed and was moving along the edge , during this he slipped off , feet first and landed on his feet on the floor then fell back onto some stored stock bruising his back . The unloading was being undertaken in a dedicated area , with no time pressures from other waiting vehicles . This accident prevented him from being able to work for over seven days . The injured person is an experienced driver and has undertaken workplace transport training in <NAME> and in <NAME>  underwent his crane off loading training . Both these training items cover the correct method of moving on the lorry bed and the controls to be followed . The injured person was wearing appropriate safety boots with good grip and a hard hat with a chin strap as dictated by our risk assessments . A witness has suggested that the injured person had not accessed the lorry bed using the dedicated steps . This will be addressed when the IP returns to work . The injured person , along with all other drivers will be reminded in writing on the correct method for working on lorry beds .

It was a clear, sunny morning.The person who sustained the injury along with the foreman and another tarmacadam operative wereunloading plant, in the form of a bobcat loader, from the Roll On/Roll Off lorry and trailer on to site. During the reversing of the plant down the start of the ramps, its sudden movement resulted in the injured operative, who along with the foreman was standing in the bucket to act as a counterbalance, jumped off. On landing on the lorry bed, he slipped twisting his ankle as well as striking it against the plant.With immediate effect the unloading of plant at site was transferred to a specialist haulage contractor whilst methods of work and training are reviewed and the accident investigation takes place.
Whilst operating a mini-dumper IP recieved slight injuries when machine turned on its side . All operatives given tool box talk and work re-assessed .

The initial investigation states " The injured person ( IP ) was initially dismantling the loading bay gates in order for the scissor lifts located in the plant room to be removed . There was then a problem with getting the full length of the forks into the lifting points of the scissor lift and some pushing and pulling by the IP was required in order to ( jiggle ) the scissor lift onto the forks as they were inserted . This was being carried out to the side of the scissor lift initially and in view of the forklift operator.Then the IP went round to the back of the scissor lift , positioned themselves between the scissor lift and a scaffold tube , which was running across the rear of the loading bay gates , in order to push the scissor lift onto the forks , at which point they were out of view from the forklift truck operator . The forklift operator , thinking the area was clear , then pushed the forks forward to enable the forks to be fully inserted at which point it pushed the scissor lift back as the forks caught trapping the IP between the scaffold tube and the rear of the scissor lift . As the forklift operator tilted the forks back to ensure the scissor lift would not slip off when lifted , the IP was able to free himself . The IP then made his way down the fire exit stairs and outside to have a conversation with the forklift operator about what had just happened ".A full investigation is in progress , where corrective / preventative actions will be discuss and implement and lessons learned issued to all parties .

the employee lifted a portable electric drill ( SDS) which had the drill bit attached . He activated the trigger and his protective glove got caught in the chuck of the drill causing the glove and his fingers to bend .

On <NAME> 14th <NAME> at approximately 16 :15 hours , <NAME> <NAME> ( self-employed bricklayer ) accessed an approximately 1.8m high platform in order to point in the blockwork built earlier that day . He had been working for approximately 3 minutes from this platform when it progressively collapsed under him , spilling <NAME> to the floor. <NAME> was shaken up afterwards but felt well enough to drive home himself . No first Aid was necessary . Once at home <NAME> started feeling stiffness in his leg , back and neck . Later that evening , ( 19:30 hours ) <NAME> went to the <NAME> <NAME> & <NAME> <NAME> to be examined . He had an X-ray which confirmed there were no fractures although bruising and swelling was evident particularly on his knee and ankle . He visited the hospital again on the 20th <NAME> and was advised by the Doctor he should not return to work for 6 weeks . All parties involved will ensure appropriate remedial actions are taken . A toolbox talk on pre-use inspection of scaffold structures will be provided to all bricklayers . Other remedial actions from the principal contractor have been asked for and will be confirmed in the next 2 weeks .

Please note : The IP did not go on sick leave until the  <NAME>  , 5 days after the incident.As part of an asbestos removal project the IP was removing cement roof sheets . One slipped out of the IP 's grip causing the IP 's right hand thumb to be caught between the sheet and a steel beam .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: As the IP headed to the workface where the ganger was working , he walked along the walkway and had just stepped over the bagging from the pump that was laid into the manhole for the over pumping . As his leading foot took his weight which was his right foot , the IP began to slip . The IP grabbed hold of the handrail to steady himself as he fell , but his left leg just below the left knee came into contact with the concrete surface of the walkway . The IP thought he had only banged his knee as he stood up it felt as if it was bleeding , the IP lifted his trouser leg up and all he could see was a red mark where his knee had hit the concrete . The IP was taken to <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> for a check up and was discharged with painkillers the same day , and returned to work ( same day ) . He was advised by the hospital to rest the leg , however he failed to pass this onto the supervisors on site . He was at work continuously then until <NAME> <NAME> , when the works manager noticed that he was still hobbling . On inspection , it was clear that the bruising / swelling had not gone down . The works manager instructed him to go back to his doctor , which he did the following day , <NAME>  <NAME>. At this appointment , the doctor told him that he MUST rest , as he had been told to do by the hospital . He was then off work from pm 26th <NAME> until a return visit to his doctor on <NAME>  <NAME>  . At this visit , the doctor advised that whilst the leg was now healing , it was too soon to return to work . The IP relayed this information to the works manager at site . It also became clear at this point that the hospital had wanted to prescribe anti-inflamatory pain killers , but that the IP was allergic to these , hence only paracetomol had been given .

description: [NAME] is a carpenter employed by the [NAME] & [NAME] of  [NAME]  corporate building and property services to carry out repair and maintenence to void residential properties owned by the [NAME] . While returning to his van to close the door , carrying his tool box , [NAME] tripped whilst walking down the steps to the front of the property . [NAME]  was fixing brackets onto a tray in the front reception area of  [NAME] . He was crouching down on one knee to carry out the job so was unaware when a door frame , which was propped against a wall behind him , fell over and hit him in the back of the head/neck area. The door frame was dislodged by someone in the area stepping on it [NAME] was collected by his wife and taken to [NAME]  where he was given Paracetamol and Ibuprofen and told to rest over the weekend . He returned to doctor on [Date] as the pain had worsened and was advised to stay off work and continue with pain killers . He returned to work on [Date] and attended work briefly on [Date] before having to go home due to pain and dizziness . He attended his doctor again on [Date]  where he was prescribed stronger painkillers , signed off work for a week and and referred for physiotherapy .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Operative reported that he had slipped and struck the right side of his torso on the bodywork of his van whilst securing items to the roof rack [Date]. Steps and ladders were available for him to use , but the operative had instead stood on the front seat of the van to reach the roof rack . The operative said that the injury was caused when his foot slipped off of the seat.The operative did not report the incident at the time , and was on annual leave [Date].The Operative telephoned the office to report the incident on the morning of [Date] , following up with an email statement , adding that he had felt increased pain over the weekend and had visited his GP that morning , ‘…and found out I have two fractured ribs’.Operative self-certified for the period between [Date]. He emailed the office to notify his intended return date , and returned to work on full duties on [Date] . He did not provide a doctor’s fit for work note. Operative attended the office on [Date] to meet with his line manager to complete relevant HR paperwork and meet with the QSHE Manager to complete an Accident form and to review the incident as part of an Incident Investigation.At the incident review the operative said that he had visited his GP who had diagnosed badly bruised or broken ribs and prescribed painkillers ( co-codamol – course completed) . Operative said that the GP had also given him a series of exercises to complete 7 days after the incident , and that if he was able to complete the exercises then he would not need any further medical attention or painkillers , and that bruising to his ribs was likely . He said that he was able to complete these exercises on [Date]. The incident investigation included a root cause analysis and corrective and preventive action will be taken for identified causal factors.The incident and its findings will be shared across the business , along with a Toolbox Talk on loading and securing loads on vehicles . A refresher on Incident and accident reporting procedures will also be delivered to all Operatives .

<NAME> <NAME> was monitoring a road closure . There were signs and cones in place to identify this road was closed . A vehicle approached the closure , stopped and removed the cones in order to enable them to gain access to the road . <NAME> approached the driver and informed the driver that the road was closed and put the cones back into position . The driver od the vehicle proceeded to drive over the cones and collided with <NAME> . The police were contacted ( incident log number <NAME> ) . <NAME> went to hospital to be checked out .

Two operatives were working together to relay metal grills over a void following building maintenance works . The injured operative was pushing one of the metal grills into place with his feet when the grill moved too much and fell through the gap . The operative tried to grab hold of it and in the process lost balance and fell through the gap also .

Having climbed up the ladder , the IP was static on the ladder for no more than 5 minutes when he fell onto soft ground . The ladder had not moved and remained insitu . Having now discussed the incident with the IP , there appears to be no reason for the fall and the IP has no recollection from being on the ladder until arrival at hospital . A second employee who was working in close proximity at the time heard nothing to indicate that the IP had fallen , there was no scream , shouts or ladder movement . Although the IP was in hospital for over 24 hours , no major injuries were sustained and observations were made about the IP 's general health . There are current investigations being made by the employer into the IP 's medical history .

Feet got stuck in the silt in the bed of the channel , lost balance and fell over. Injury sustained to right arm as it hit the fork handle. <NAME> <NAME> was in the property which was being rewired for a new tenant , so this meant the need to run some new cable up in the loft space to new light fittings . <NAME> entered the loft space by means of a loft ladder that had been left from the old tenant and carried on with pulling cables . Once the task had been completed <NAME> went to exit the loft by the same loft ladder once both feet were on the second to top run the fixing point for the ladder broke away with no warning and the next thing <NAME> came through the loft hatch to the floor below with his tools and a bucket of screws . landed on the loft ladder . One other person was in the house at the time but did not witness the accident as he was on the ground floor and only heard a thud and a cry . <NAME> got to his feet and the other operative came up the stairs . <NAME> was made to the supervisor and to the office a few minutes after the incident . The supervisor attend <NAME>and and found <NAME> a bit shaken but still working , the offer to call for an medical assistants was turned down and <NAME> was able to drive himself home at the end of the working day.That evening <NAME> did not feel well so took himself to the hospital and was checked at <NAME> and sent home that night . <NAME> did not feel well over the weekend so attended his <NAME> on the following <NAME> and was told to go home and rest until the <NAME> of that week <NAME> when he was due to return to work . <NAME> called into the office on the <NAME> and said he had seen the <NAME> again and was due back on the <NAME> . I have spoken to him and <NAME> has told me he has strained his chest and will return <NAME>.On the following <NAME> after the accident all oprative were call in to the office for a tool box talk on the use of ladders and the need to inspect the ladder before use and were ever possible not to us any loft ladders fitted by others .Following a managers meeting a memo has been sent to all on the subject of loft ladders and were possible remove and place in the loft space away from the loft hatch and only ladders issued by the company to be used . A Risk Assessment has been taken and all ground teams have added to there paper work .

The sump holes had been dug in order to drain water from the work area . The sump holes were around 600mm deep & 400mm wide .

4 men were unloading a bath from a van using planks . As the 2 men at the top lifted the bath , 1 of the men at the bottom did n't hold his end and the weight of the bath hit the other man at the bottom ( IP ) full in the left knee

The <NAME> electrician ( IP ) was working off a set of 8 tread step ladders in proximity of the main contractor ( <NAME> <NAME> ) joiners , when the joiners removed a centre piece of pharmacy gallery partition walling , an end section of the gallery curved partition fell in the direction of the IP 's step ladder , the partition walling struck the IP 's step ladders causing the IP to fall off the step ladders to the ground .

There was a gap in the scaffold – there was a loose board on top . [NAME] said he trod on the loose board , his left leg fell through the gap . [NAME] caught his hip and ribs on the corner fascia and bruised leg on scaffold poles underneath .

[NAME] the injured person ( IP ) went to get a skill saw and whilst returning with the skill he stepped down into a formed beam in the deck which did not have steel rebar placed in it ( a step of 400mm ) . The IP stood on a partially completed shutter , which he reports moved leading to him twisting his right ankle . -The deck and surrounding was tidy and clear from any waste and materials. - The work area was clean and tidy.-The IP was briefed on the project slips and trips risk assessment and received regular toolbox talks.-The IP was briefed on relevant method statement and risk assessment for the task he was carrying out when the incident occurred.-The IP was wearing correct safety boots with suitable ankle support and laces.-The IP attended A & E at [NAME] where his injury was confirmed as soft tissue injury to right ankle .Investigation carried out , Method statement and risk assessment reviewed , company wide incident alert briefed within organisation . The IP , [NAME] has returned to work .

Accident happened in a goods and passenger hoist . [NAME] opened the inside sliding door , and then the external gate . When closing the external gate , the inside sliding door fell and hit [NAME] on/above his left eye .

Whilst operative was in the process of raising gully lids during cyclic gully cleaning operations along the [NAME] [NAME] [NAME] between [NAME] 9 and [NAME] 8 , operative was in the process of raising a gully lid with prescribed lifting tools , tool slid off underside of lid during the process of lifting up and wrenched back into his rib cage with force .Operative continued on to complete shift. Operative visited Local GP next day to get advice , and was informed that he would need to rest for at least two weeks .

A number of pipes (2.5 metre long, 300 ml diameter) were stacked in readiness to be used on the site.  The IP was slinging one of the top pipes to enable a mechanical lift.  There was blocks in place under the pipe to enable easier method of slinging.  The IP went to the pipe to place sling in the appropriate position.  The IP then saw the blocks were incorrect to enable him to sling efficiently.  He went to move the block from one side of the pipe.  The IP continued to remove the block with one hand, whilst holding up the pipe with the other hand causing the pipe to roll onto the IPs left leg in particular the knee area causing painful pressure.Action taken to date - toolbox talks for the topics of Slinging and Safe Working Practices, Communication of Incidents.  Reviewed and updated the method statement.  Held a Lessons Learnt Session to capture any improvements we can make.  This case will be highlighted at our Stand Down Day planned for the <NAME> where we can communicate the accident and the actions already taken to all the employees.

He was over-reaching and the steps slipped underneath him . We are currently looking into the most suitable form of access equipment to prevent any issues should a similar situation rise in the future .
Fell  from single stage ladder resulting in falling down stairs

The IP was making collection of a mobile welfare unit on an unattended site .The welfare unit was on swampy ground . The front axle did not lock properly , the unit fell forward and the towbar trapped the IPs right foot . Injury was limited because the ground was soft . IP was able to hydraulically lift the welfare unit onto the wheels releasing his foot . IP was able to complete the collection and return to the depot at <NAME> . A colleague at the depot took the IP to the hospital where an x-ray was carried out .

The IP was using the main pedestrian walkways to gain access to our storage area to get materials for bricklayers . The pedstrian crossing point was blocked by our client 's delivery vehicle from [NAME] Supplies [NAME] which was delivering stone to phase 2 of the development . The vehicle was stationary with the engine running . The IP walked behind the rear of the vehicle and up the near side to get to the crossing point . The lorry moved forward to prepare to reverse up to phase 2 and turned the wheel to the left . The second steer hit the IP and ran over both feet . The vehicle stopped and the IP was given first aid and taken to hospital for treatment . The IP suffered soft tissue damage to both feet and was admitted overnight for a period less than 24 hours . The delivery driver states he did not see the IP approach the vehicle . The client 's banksman states he was positioned ahead of the vehicle waiting to guide to reverse to plhase 2 and did not see the IP approach the pedstrian walkway . The IP states there was no banksman in place .The IP states he walked behind the vehicle and up the side to to gain access to the pedestrian walkway . A safety alert has been issued on the incident and memo is to be issued to all suppliers with regards to traffic management on site . Principle contractor has reviewed traffic management system to improve segregation of pedestrians and vehicular traffic . A waiting area has been set up to control deliveries to site to prevent blocking of pedestrian crossing points . Signage has been installed directing delivery drivers onto site .

Telephone report - HF - Walking along the scaffolding putting some joints on the floor from the house . Whilst doing this noticed that one joint was the wrong was around , he moved over to the middle of the house picked up the joint and started spinning it around . In doing that his right leg went though the scaffolding board beneath him . An hour later he took himself too hospital , where they stated his leg had soft tissue damage and badly bruised but as a result has been off work since .

We were undertaking emergency excavation works to locate and repair a burst district heating main , The operative in question ( [NAME] ) stepped back outside temporary fenced and coned off area into a passing car .

Operative was working on roof construction of timber framed building when he required additional timber to complete his task . In order to obtain the material , he had to descend the scaffolding to reach the stock pile on the ground . When descending the scaffolding , instead of using the appointed proprietary stairs which had been installed , the operative used the emergency escape ladder as this was a more direct route . On descending the emergency escape ladder , the saw that the operative was carrying caught on the scaffold , this caused the operative to lose his balance and his foot slipped out of the rung of the ladder and he fell the remainder of the distance to the scaffold platform below.The operative complained of having hurt his back and was attended to by one of the sites appointed first-aiders , however no treatment was appropriate and he was advised to seek further medical attention . The operative later reported that he had been attended to at hospital and had bruising to his back , no other injuries have been reported . The operative has now been absent from work for a period of more than seven days and at present is still absent. On investigation , no issues could be identified with the ladder that the operative used and the conditions at the time would not suggest that the rungs of the ladder or the operatives boots were slippery with water or mud . It is believed that the operative failed to maintain three points of contact on the ladder due to him carrying a saw in his hand which he intended to use to cut a piece of timber.All operatives on site have been reminded that the ladders on the scaffold are for emergency escape purposes only and that the proprietary stairs are to be used for access and egress on scaffolding . Operatives have also been briefed on the safe use of ladders with particular focus on maintaining three points of contact at all times and not to carry any tools , equipment or materials whilst using ladders .

Whilst loading out " trad deck " system with concrete blocks a panel within the system partially failed causing the blocks to fall through the 1mtr x 1mtr panel this in turn resulted in the operative having a controlled fall through the panel .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured person being a Sales advisor on a new housing development went in to the plot to view some remedial work . Prior to accessing the plot she was allegedlly told that a piece of flooring had been removed in order to undertake a repair on the first floor landing . Apparently she tried to straddle the loose piece of flooring & tripped over it , causing her to fall into the gap between the landing floor level & the top of the ceiling on the groundfloor . The fall caused her to put her foot through the plasterboard ceiling , causing brusing to her legs & shoulders .

The operative was carrying out painting work ( staining some wooden panelling ) off a ladder . He had worked with a colleague earlier in the day , but had moved to a different site not taking his colleague to support the ladder . The base of the ladder slid outwards and the top of the ladder slid down the face of the building caused him to slip with the ladder to the ground . This caused soft tissue injuries i .e . bruising and lacerations to his hands , knees and shins and chin and bruising to his chest . All operatives have been re-briefed on the procedure to issue Working at Height Equipment and the importance of carrying out a site specific risk assessment prior to commencing work to ensure all control measures identified are being deployed to prevent this type of incident . All operatives have been re-trained in the HSEs and Company Guidance on Working off ladders and stepladders.

[NAME]  states he was installing conduit pipe to a high level socket within the plant room at the time of the accident . Access to the plant room is via a ladder positioned on the inside of the building , up onto a mezzanine floor and a further access ladder down into the plant room . This is the only access into the plant room as the ground floor access had been blocked off by a pallet which had been screwed across the entry doorway . This was in position to block access externally as groundworks were being carried out in the area. [Name] states he was descending the ladder into the plant room when he felt the ladder slip to the right which caused him to lose his balance and fall to the floor approximately 1.5 meters below , landing heavily on his left hip and side . [NAME] states he was wearing safety boots , Hard Hat and High Visibility Tabard at the time of the accident . [NAME] shouted to another electrician , [NAME] who was standing on the mezzanine floor , to go and get [NAME] 's colleague , [NAME]. [NAME] climbed down into the plant room where he found [NAME] on his feet , holding onto his side and leaning against a MEWP which had been stored within the area . [NAME] informed [NAME] that he had fallen from the ladder . [NAME] checked him over and went to find the [NAME] foreman [NAME] . [NAME] returned with [NAME] and they both climbed down into the plant room . [NAME] checked [NAME] over and they agreed that the best course of action would be to talk [NAME] to hospital to be checked over . [NAME] insisted on climbing the ladder out of the plant room , which he did while [NAME] footed the ladder . [NAME] followed [NAME] out with [NAME] leaving the plant room last . [NAME] climbed down the access ladder to the library floor below and located the scissor lift . [NAME] reversed the scissor lift as close as possible to the wall and raised the platform up to the same level as the mezzanine floor . [NAME] stepped into the scissor lift and [NAME] lowered him to the ground . [NAME] took [NAME] to [NAME] hospital in the company van and whilst [NAME] was being checked over , placed a call to [NAME] , informing him of the accident . [NAME]  telephoned me and I returned to the head office to await [NAME] arrival at the head office from hospital to complete an accident report and take a statement from him .  [NAME] said that the hospital had diagnosed him with bruising and swelling to his left hip . They had told him to take paracetamol and ibrufen for the pain and to rest up but remain as mobile as possible . I took a further statement from [NAME]  and then [NAME] dropped [NAME] at home and returned to site . I visited site myself along with [NAME] and we met with [NAME] site manager [NAME] . He showed us the area that [NAME] was working in at the time of the accident and we took numerous photographs . I discussed my initial findings with the site manager and my recommendations . I followed this up with an email to the site manager which included the photographs .

This is a resubmittance due to having no email confirmation recieved for previous submittance. IP was stripping out old electrical circuits when they caught their finger on a screw in a base unit . This caused a cut to their third finger on right hand . IP pulled away their damaged finger and on doing so banged their elbow on the wall behind. Risk assessments and method statements have been reviewed and a tool box talk delivered to remind operatives of their content . The tool box talk also included the topic of awareness of working area and hazards such as protruding nails / screws .

Operative 1 was clearing out a small excavation hole on his hands and knees . Operative 2 was breaking concrete out around the leg of an A-line swing frame in another hole adjacent to operative 1 . Operative 2 broke out some concrete and removed the hydraulic drill from the hole . At this point the leg fell over and struck Operative 1 on the back . After checking the leg it was easy to see that when it was originally installed whoever installed it has cut approx . 40cm off the length that should have been in the ground and that the concrete was not deep enough . To prevent a similar incident happening in the future , operatives will prop the legs up to give more stability if required to move them again , and not make the assumption that they had been installed correctly in the first place or an additional one or more operatives will support the post during this phase . They will also ensure that there is no-one in the vicinity that can be hurt if the post falls unintentionally .
Jumper leading roller and dumper. Roller started and moved forward catching his leg between the roller and dumper.

i ) A trailer was parked on the haul road to enable distribution of scaffolding . 2 test weights ( 1.05 te each ) were delivered in front of the trailer ready for testing which was subsequently cancelled . ii ) Two operatives were moving the test weights to enable access to a trailer . The weights were being raised onto bearers using a scaffold pole as a lever to enable a pallet truck to move the weight to a new location . During the movement the weight slipped causing the operative to let go of the tube which struck him on the outside of the ankle causing bruising . iii ) 1 . The test weight company to be contacted to ensure the weights when delivered are stored appropriately , on sufficient bearers and in an area not causing obstruction . 2. Confirming areas are 100 % ready for testing prior to arranging .

While exiting a shallow excavation under the loading bay , a scaffold platform fell one storey from the loading bay striking the IP above the right knee . After arriving late , [NAME] had not been present at the supervisors meeting at the same time as [NAME] and other trades.The IP and [Name] were working in a trench underneath the loading bay at love street elevation . Before commencing these operations , both the IP and [Name] had been briefed the task by [NAME] . While the IP & [NAME] were working below the loading bay , [NAME] & [NAME] were working on the 1st floor level loading bay . [NAME] had instructed them to bring banded material into the slab from the loading bay via pump truck ( Which had been normal practice previously ) once on the slab , the band would then be cut to release the materials . On this occasion , the pump truck would not fit under the banded materials , so [NAME] & [NAME] decided to hand-ball the material onto the slab . [NAME] & [NAME] cut the bands to free the material . As they did this the boards sprung free with 3no . metal boards falling approx . 6.5m to the ground . One of the boards struck the IP as it landed .

The operative was working in <NAME> <NAME> unit 98 which is a terraced house under construction . He was working alone , air testing the installed 1st fix plumbing . He was testing an already installed pipe to an inner wall . At some stage in the process of testing , plaster boarding that had been stacked against the same wall and that was obstructing his access to the piping fell trapping him against the stack of boarding on the floor and caused his injury . to prevent similar accidents happening in the future we are reviewing our risk assessments and method statements to include such unsafe conditions and what action to take when an operative comes across them . We need to ensure that all current operatives on site have a tool box talk on action to be taken regarding this . We will ensure that a copy of our RAMS are available in the office and signed by all operatives . We will ensure that operatives are aware of potential risks and their duty to report any unsafe conditions .

The IP was working in a gang of 3 carrying out repair and maintenance works to the external windows of a retirement home . The works included the washing of windows frames and general painting of other areas and items .On the day of the accident the IP was cleaning the PVC frames at 2nd floor height . On a site for this client , work from ladders beyond first floor height is normally prohibited , but in this case the client agreed that MEWP 's could not be used due to the landscaping and access issues.The IP was working from a ladder which was unfooted and untied , contrary to the risk assessments and method statement . The ladder was positioned on the grass lawn , which sloped slightly away from the building . As the IP was up the ladder , the bottom began to slip on the grass . The IP remained on the ladder until it became footed against an external perimeter wall and at this point he fell ( approximately 2m ) into bushes below . The IP 's colleague called an ambulance and the IP was taken to <NAME> <NAME> infirmary for assessment , where it was found that he had suffered no serious injuries , other than some minor internal bruising and superficial scrapes.Upon completion of the accident investigation , the company will be reviewing its entire health and safety management systems . The IP will receive refresher training regarding the safe use of ladders and this information will be conveyed to all other operatives .

the operative was using a scaffold access gate on a loading bay when the gate dropped crushing his right hand . Causing nerve and tissue damage . The accident was reported to the main contractor who had the scaffolding company check over the gate .

The injures person is a trainee scaffolder who at the time was under supervision with a charge hand scaffolder overseeing the dismantling of scaffold. however the charge hand was called away to reposition the lorry when the trainee took it upon himself to access the 4m level scaffold and start to dismantle scaffold.the handrails had been removed via sg4:15 step system by the chargehand .the trainee accessed the top lift 4m level to remove scaffold boards and clear rubble left on the scaffold lift by others instead of removing boards from the lift below.the trainee had no harness on as required as per working at height regs 2005 and nasc sg4:15 guidelines.it was whilst clearing the rubble with his feet he stumbled and fell to the ground. this operative has been warned of his future conduct regarding his actions by letter and on his return to work further instructions given with toolbox talk /continued training and advice on procedures in erecting and dismantling scaffolds.attitude played a part in this incident and further investigations will be conducted with him on this subject.

[NAME] ( IP ) was tasked with topping off the last 3 courses to the internal cavity wall on both sides on the 1st floor of the main block . A wall collapsed and then proceeded to fall onto the other side of the cavity wall where  [NAME] was working . The blocks which were now in place on the lower area of  [NAME] were removed by  [NAME] and [NAME]. [NAME] site manager were informed who attended to administer first aid and an ambulance was called. [NAME] was then taken to [NAME] hospital but was later allowed home . [NAME] have now taken the following action to prevent similar incidents : All blocks & bricks are to be covered to stop getting wet and increasing the weight , retarder mortar will be used only when necessary and in small amounts , No work is to proceed until wall strength is checked by site supervisor & internal block work cavity walls are to be built at the same time not allowing one skin to be more than 675mm higher than the other

[NAME] [NAME] is a 55 year old roadworker employed by the [NAME] & [NAME] of [NAME] . While opening the tailgate of a lorry during high winds he damaged a finger , his left hand and his wrist . The injured person attended A & E on [NAME] [NAME] and was absent from work for ten days as a result of his injury .Risk assessments were in place for the work being carried out at the time . Relevant instruction , training and supervision was provided . Appropriate PPE was worn at the time of the accident . The accident occured as a result of adverse weather conditions .

The injured person was asked by another subcontractor to clean out an area where the subcontractor was erecting steel columns . The subcontractor was lifting steel column (RSJ) into position when it became detached from the lifting chains and fell to the ground . The subcontractor shouted and the injured person was running clear of the area when the steel caught him a glancing blow on the back . Even though there was an exclusion zone set up to stop unauthorised access to lifting area , the operative was allowed to continue working . going forward , all operatives not directly associated with lifting operation will be excluded from works area . Toolbox talk given to all site operatives and staff to advise of changes in work methods and to re-emphasise that subcontractors should not instruct other subcontractors works directly but must go through correct management chain .

IP was seeing the delivery by forklift of a pack Ytong lightweight blocks , as the forklift loaded them onto the ground the blocks plastic covering split and fell on to the IP causing him to fall backwards on to a newly laid wall

Concrete was being poured behind block work on retaining wall to fill an undercut / void to support a footpath above. The top layers of blocks were displaced and fell onto working platform causing the IP to fall approximately 1mInvestigation has revealed that after the final course of blocks had been laid , the air temperature dropped . It is considered that this is a key contributing factor to the incident as it is likely that the temperature fall delayed the setting of the mortar used to lay the blocks .Investigation also revealed that during the concrete pour a vibrating poker had been used to agitate the concrete mix to allow it to flow better.It is considered that the combination of unset mortar and subsequent vibration led to the blocks being displaced and subsequently the IPs fall from the platformA full review has been undertaken and safety bulletins issues to all sites warning of potential impacts of temperature change on constructed brick and blockwork

The IP was in the process of the construction of internal partition walls ( dry lining ) , which involves cutting plasterboard sheets to size to screw to the metal frame . The plasterboards were placed in the corridor leant against the wall horizontally with the longest edge on the floor. The IP had to cut the board along its length by measuring the cut and running a Stanley knife along the length of the board , which resulted in the off cut coming loose and falling onto the IPs foot above his steel toe cap . The IP immediately knew his foot was injured and removed his footwear and quickly noted his foot was swelling and it was not possible to put his boot back on . His colleague assisted him in making his way to the site office where it was decided the injury needed to be assessed at a hospital so site managers took some details for initial accident reporting to be undertaken and the IP left site for hospital . Due to previous injuries , initial X Rays were inconclusive to whether the foot was fractured , but a cast was applied and a follow up appointment was made at the fracture clinic . At the next appointment 7 days later it was confirmed that there is not a fracture but some tendon damage so another cast was applied for another week . The cast has now been removed and the IP has been advised to take further rest . The IPs absence from site has delayed full investigation which is on-going at the time of completing this report , but the method of cutting the boards is to be reviewed .

Whist moving around the outside of his works flatbed van he was moving materials on the van when a scaffold board fell onto his foot. [NAME]  took him immediately to [NAME] who examined bruising and recommended rest . Subsequent to the Easter Holiday  [NAME] 's leg was sore and he visited his home doctor who signed him off work from [Date] .  [NAME] and [NAME] have today visited the offices to go through the situation and confirm the Genie lift had its wheel brake on ( Genie lift inspected [Date]) . Statements and sketch of incident have been filed together with accident report and investigation . We are satisfied the both persons training is up to date and CSCS qualifications etc., are all in order. We can find no fault of labour or equipment to cause this accident . [NAME] is to return to work [Date] and be on light duties supervised by [NAME]  and the contract manager until  [NAME] , in fact , has a week 's holiday booked from [Date] .

[NAME] was removing a section of RSJ from the roof structure of the gymnasium block using a demolition excavator . Once it was released from the building he slewed round to the right , on his blind side , with the RSJ protruding from the machines attachment , and struck  [NAME] on the shoulder . [NAME]  was outside the machines working perimeter picking rubbish from demolition arising’s on the ground but with the added length of the RSJ, he was hit while in a safe area . [NAME]  claims to have seen  [NAME] at the last moment and immediately slewed the machine to the opposite direction . The delay in the hydraulics due to the momentum of the machine prevented the machine from stopping or reversing its direction immediately and the momentum carried the machine around with the protruding RSJ then connecting with [NAME] [NAME] shoulder . This operation had been going on all day with [NAME] [NAME] removing sections of the steel roof structure , slewing round and depositing the steel in a pile behind him.  [NAME] [NAME] had been working alongside [NAME] [NAME] all day and was aware of the excavators working perimeter and had stayed at least 3 metres outside of this all the time.
