IP was carrying light fittings to place of work and fell down an unprotected pit for a trampoline installation .

Excavator was moving forward and victim walked alongside the offside of the machine and tried to cross path . victim . immediate toolbox talk with all concerned regarding the dangers of moving vehicles and machinery , risk assements are currently being reviewed and new training will be added if neccesary

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Operative was moving from first floor internally to external scaffold when , instead of using the existing access , he decided to jump up onto the intervening cavity wall and then jump down onto the external scaffold . As he reached the top of the cavity wall he leant forward to grasp the top of a scaffold standard , to steady himself , when he was temporarily blinded by the low winter sun and as a consequence lost his balance and fell forward onto the external scaffold .
the engineer was working from a pair of step ladders and over reached and slipped off the step ladders
solar panel installer slipped freom bungalow roof.

A set of temporrary works shoring frames had been removed from a cofferdam and had been placed away from the works ready for collection by the supplier . The shoring frames were stacked flat , 2 frames high , with a frame laid in front of the other two . The IP was removing stone from the flange of one of the stacked frames . The frame slid forward and in doing so trapped the IP 's feet . The IP was able to free his right foot , however , his left foot remained trapped until help arrived and the frame could be lifted clear .

<NAME> <NAME> was on site inspecting the site as reports of rubbish and debris from the site is over spilling and is being allowed to spill under the temporary fence , the fence is on a public right away to residential property at the rear , she slipped on a brick and fell over , a lump as appeared on her leg and was clear for all to see , the previous day the owner of the shop was approached by <NAME> <NAME> to ask if the site could be tidied up as it is a danger to the public and is an eyesore to the town , he was assured this would take place , but as yet nothing as been done , the construction site is left for long periods in this state .

The injured party was carrying materials to a work area on a proprietary access/crash deck and was in the process of accessing that work area from a lower scaffold area ( 'birdcage atrium scaffold ) traversing an open gap . During the process the injured party lost his footing and fell backwards from the upper level , striking the lower level and down through the gap to the floor below.Edge protection has been provided along the open leading edge of the birdcage scaffold and the leading edge of the proprietary roof deck work area .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Operative was removing sides off a trailer in the yard and fell backwards after tripping on a piece of wood , he banged left leg knee area , went to hospital A & E  to get checked out . Action taken : to in future ensure ground area is clear of debris/objects that could cause slips/trips/falls
IP injured his hand when timber battons fell . Attended hospital - contusions/bruising to fingers . Further actions : Ensure that timber is stored correctly , and further investigation taking place .

The operative had finished his break and was returning to his place of work along the access route when he stood on a Manhole Cover . The cover gave way under his weight and his left leg went into the chamber (600mm deep ) striking the side of the chamber he was then assisted to site office where he was treated for a bruised and cut knee . As he was feeling sick and dizzy he stayed in the office untill the end of the shift then went home . On investigating the accident , it was found that the plastic frame was severly damaged and parts missing . The frame was replaced and concreted into position . The Site manager for churngold Construction went around the site inspecting and placing warning signs on other manholes highlighting their positions , if there was risk of plant crossing over a manhole then a road plate was placed over them to prevent any damage . On the day of the accident it was <NAME> last day as he had been given notice the day before , On the <NAME> the <NAME> the manager phoned <NAME> to see how he was feeling ,he told him that he was sore and would go to the Hospital for a check up as he was feeling stiff in his shoulder , at the time of his treatment he had not mentioned any other injury . On the <NAME> <NAME> was contacted again to find out how he was ,he told the manager that he had been signed of for two weeks by the doctor and that he had been refusing work which had been offered to him . The site manager spoke with the agency on another matter and they informed him the they had not offered <NAME> any work . As we have no proof that he is working or not working , we have reported a RIDDOR in the avent that he is not working due to his accident on site severn days ago .
IP was getting materials from strong box when a gust of wind blew the lid down onto IP 's arm causing bruising

Concrete lintel on a door opening was disloged while the person injured and his collegue were maneuvering plasterboards into position to fix to the ceiling.The door opening was around 6ft 6in high and the lintel struck the injured person on his upper thigh area as it fell. Person was off work for 8 days with brusing and swelling to his thigh

The IP was gaining access between flats on incomplete scaffolding when he fell through the loose boards onto the lift below.There was no reason for the IP to access the scaffolding as all his works were being carried out internally with provided by internal stairs for accessing different levels . The scaffolding had clear signage to indicate the scaffold was incomplete and had the necessary stop end rails fitted to prevent access , information had been displayed at the site entrance detailing what scaffolding was being worked on . The IP climbed over an adjoining parapet wall around the stop end rails gaining access to the incomplete scaffolding.The injuries were mainly bruising to his left armFurther investigations are currently be completed when the IP returns to work

Operative was pulling cables through ceiling joists when a length of timber which had been fixed to the under side of the ceiling joists ( being used for propping ) became dislodged , fell and struck the operative on the shoulder/neck .

While guiding a horizontal steel stanchion supported by chains, suspended off a telehandler, the stanchion slipped in the grip of the chain and hit nathanial merrills foot, between the end of the stanchion and a pertruding man hole cover.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: I was not on site at the time but as reported to me [NAME] tripped on the scaffolding & hurt his chin & neck .

A fall from height of approx . 2.4m was reported to have occurred on site involving the [NAME] Homes site manager . It was reported that two sub-contractors ; a [NAME] and [NAME]who work for a plumbing contractor by the name of [NAME]  had removed a sacrificial flooring cassette from the stairwell of plot 91 in order to gain access via a ladder to the first floor area of the building to carry out plumbing works . No fall protection had been installed prior to the removal of the cassette , leaving an open edge fall from height risk of approximately 2.4m in height. It was during this time that [NAME] arrived at the build area. Upon seeing the open stairwell , [Name] instructed both [NAME] and [NAME] to cease operations until fall protection had been installed . AM then indicated that he would install the fall protection himself. Both [NAME] and [NAME] turned away from [NAME] It was at this time they heard a ‘thud’ . Upon turning back to see what had happened , they noticed that [NAME] had fallen from the open stairwell and onto the concrete floor below . [NAME] attended to [NAME] while [NAME] left to seek first aid assistance from the [NAME] First Aider [NAME]. Upon arrival at the scene , [NAME] recognised early signs of shock setting in as [NAME] lips and mouth had begun turning blue . It was at this time that [NAME] felt it necessary to call an ambulance. It is the recommendation that a change in [NAME]  company procedure is put in place to ensure sacrificial stairwell cassettes are kept in place until such a time the stair is ready to be fitted . Floor cassettes should not be removed unless fall protection is first put in place . A full review of findings and recommendations is available and has been submitted to [NAME] [NAME] to action .
Joiner was removing fibreglass ladder from roof rack . The ladders stuck initially then suddenly released causing IP to fall on his back

Whilst moving external generator into plant room IP was standing on data chamber cover . As IP maneuvered generator cover of chamber flipped causing IP to slip/fall into the chamber approx 500mm deep .

At approximately 09.45 we entered the <NAME> switch room to commence the disconnection of the cable . We identified the cable that was to be disconnected . We then identified which floor panels where to be lifted in order to gain access to the cable . We installed barriers in the area to cordon off the work area . The two floor tiles where removed using suction pads . <NAME> <NAME> then proceeded to lower himself down below the floor level . In order to assist <NAME> <NAME> with the cable disconnection I then proceeded to walk in front of the <NAME> across the tiled flooring to the other side of the open access . As I stood on the first tile this gave way . I then proceed to fall through the first tile . On the way down I grabbed the hand rail and then fell through the second floor tile injuring my knee , thigh and shoulder . I then picked myself up using the hand rail on to the main flooring . My leg had become inflamed instantly and I was in considerable discomfort with the pain in my leg and thigh . ( Please see pictures attached ) . I was helped by <NAME> <NAME> back to the van and then asked <NAME> to take me to the hospital . I requested he take me to <NAME> <NAME> hospital so I was nearer home . We left site at approximately 11.00am .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: IP stumbled and fell while carrying tools & steps after finishing job inside house going back to van , On investigation no contribution from activity or footpath , IPstates he just stumbled
The IP was installing crash barrier to the car park . IP picked up one of the steel posts , lost their grip on it and dropped it . The corner of the post hit the IP 's ankle .

During installation / excavation of a drainage chamber an oprative was postioning a suction hose to enable the chamber to be pumped clear of ground water , the chamber was still under construction hence a 360 excavator was working adjacent to the chamber , unbeknown to the excavator operator a site opertive who was placing the pump hose into the excavation entered the area immediately behind the excavator , as the excavator slewed round the opertive was pushed against the trench sheets from which he suffered brusing and pain to his back , oprative appeared to be ok but was advised to attend hospital for a check , he was advised by the hospital that nothing was fractured but advised to reattend for an MRI scan , he attempted to return to work for approximateley 2 days but was a little stiff so did not continue working , he has since been to his GP and has been signed of for 2 weeks Action taken was to investigate the accident which had conflicting statements as to whether the excavator operator knew who was where at the time of the incident , we have generated a safety alert regarding plant awareness and working in the proxcimity of machinery / plant , this safety alert was communicated to all site opertives in the way of a tool box talk with confimation that the tool box talk had been carried out via signitures sheets returned to head office , Daily briefings are held with the site opertives to discuss hazards / risk and the control measures in place .

operative was a fork lift truck driver in the process of moving pallets of kerb stones , on doing so there was a kerb lay on the floor of the pallet , he then tried to lift the kerb onto the pallet on doing so droped it onto his foot above the toe protection area , a manual handling assessment was in place on site and acknowledged , a further memo will be issued to all sites relating to the assessment to ensure correct procedures are followed .

IP was putting protection film onto work surfaces in the tenant 's kitchen . The IP then dropped his scraper , and as he bent down to pick it up , the large roll of protector fell from the worktop onto the IP 's right wrist . IP went to A &E but it cannot be confirmed if there is a fracture or otherwise given the amount of swelling . IP has to return to be re-assessed 26th [NAME] . Since the accident has occurred , a method of work has been communicated to other plasterers whereby the roll of protection film has to be rolled to the floor before the film is cut in order top prevent the falling object issue .

IP was assisting the electrician t o remove an extractor fan . The electrician had isolated fan and was in the process of removing the fan inside the kitchen whilst the IP was holding the fan and removing the silicone . As the fan was removed the wind caught the fan resulting in the fan moving and trapping IPs thumb in the fan . The manager has since reviewed working practices and informed staff to wear gloves and to wedge the fan blades into position .

The IP was working from a working platform constructing the peak on a gable end of plot 268b , when he decided to step over the wall andd stand on the truss gangplate . This gave way and he fell to the floor below , approximately 2.4 metres .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: A [NAME] staff member was attending a site meeting . Whilst walking from the site office to the main gate the member of [NAME] staff slipped on a muddy path and landed on her bottom . She continued to work until [Date] and visited GP after work [Date] , because of back pain . The GP diagnosed a strain and bruising , prescribed painkillers and recommended refraining from work for 2 weeks . After initial investigation , the following has been actioned : •re-stoned the route on the office side of the path , •introduced twice daily cleaning of the key route , •re-inducted all [NAME] sales / voids and allocations staff •ensure visitors are wearing appropriate PPE. Reinforced that visitors should not move around site without a member of [NAME] staff in attendance .
was hit by a moving vehicle

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Lost footing on customer site whilst moving genie lift SLA 15.Equipment impacted on left leg

The operator that was injured was along with another operator in the process of raising a steel beam off the floor to rest on packers ready for lateral movement into position . One end of the beam had been set up as agreed but the opposite end of the beam slipped and rolled onto the operators inside leg . Causing heavy bruising and swelling .

6 male individuals attempted to remove a mock stage bus fender/windscreen from a contractors truck . The height of the truck load platform is 800mm from the floor and the weight of the item approx . 80kg. <NAME> position is in the corner by the windscreen as it is removed and following its removal from the truck , the weight is apportioned more so in his corner and following a minor slip , the item falls upon his arm causing immediate pain to his inner right arm and bicep area.H&S intervention following the accident . For future lifting practice , one person will take the lead and detail the exact actions of his/her colleagues .

The injured person approached a 360 excavator to speak to the operator  the machine operator raised the dead man handle  whilst holding a conversation  as the injured person turned to walk away  the operator lowered the dean man handle  but as he leaned back in his cab - the left operating joystick was snagged  by his jacket as a result of which the machine dipper arm crowded in the bucket which struck the injured person in the chest . An investigation was commenced and it was found that baggy  clothing was the primary issue  the company immediately sourced and issued outer hi-vis clothing that will prevent a re-occurrence  they will be issuing both winter and summer versions of the outer garments .

In the process of dismantling scaffolding they were passing down boards the scaffolder on the top lift was hanging a board over the side waiting for the person below to take the board he says the board broke in is hand and he lost grip
Assembling steel frame on the floor , whilst swapping end frames one of the frames fell onto <NAME> 's lower right leg

Whilst carrying out a kitchen and bathroom replacement , we had put <NAME> <NAME> ridged carpet protector on the staircase of the property .The tenant slipped down the stairs.The tenant was wearing outside type UGG boots
Worker was on site , and walked into an area where a plant operator was driving a digger . He came into contact with the digger as the bucket hit him on the head

Operatives had completed a pot-hole/patch repair to carriageway and had loaded all plant/machinery onto towable trailer . Injured party ( IP ) lifted the tailgate of the trailer to engage the two securing hasps on the upright posts at the rear of the trailer. As the tailgate raised IP had unwittingly placed his left hand on the upright with his thumb adjacent to the securing hasp; thumb was then 'pinched ' between the upright post and the frame of the tailgate. Both operatives returned to depot , approximately 5 minutes drive , and IP was advised to seek medical attention . IP was x-rayed and informed there was a 'slight ' fracture to the thumb . Advised to report to fracture clinic the following day .Following consultation with the doctor in attendance IP was advised there was no fracture only bad bruising , subsequently advised to rest the thumb for a couple of weeks .

The injured person , was part of a working team completing internal roof covering in a refurbished barn.the team where working on both fixed scaffold and mobile tower scaffold , in and around a old fashioned cider press . the cider press had fixed scaffold around it and the workers were using a mobile tower scaffold to both sides of the fixed scaffold.The cider press has a large flat timber oak table that has 4 large bolts at each corner . This table was affecting the movement of the mobile scaffold and the workmen had tried to slide the table slightly to allow the mobile scaffold to pass . The workmen had put supports underneath the table to stop any cantilever issues but had not done this high enough , and with the weight of the table creating a cantilever sliding effect , the injured person had got his hand trapped between one of the bolts and the actual cider bar .Since this has happened we have stopped the press table from being able to slide or move in any direction and that scaffold assembled and dis assembled as needed around the project .

The IP was using a pneumatic <NAME> breaker to break up concrete to expose the rebar . The IP had already stated how hard the concrete was to break up . The IP had been using the Breaker for a short period of time holding it close to his body as is normal practice . As the IP continued to use the Breaker the IP stated that he felt the chisel land on top of his right foot . The IP immediately dropped the Breaker and sat next to the access tower removing his safety boot to view the extent of the injury . The foot was bruisd from the impact so the IP called for assistance from colleagues working along side him . The IP was taken to A & E in the company van where an xray was carried out . No fractures were found , however , the IP did suffer severe bruising .

The top three courses of a light weight block wall was somehow dislodged and fell onto [NAME]  whereby he sustained injuries to his back . The exact reason for the displacement of these blocks is unclear but it has been said that a site tipping skip had been placed in such a way that the temporary prop for this wall had been dislodged . [NAME] was taken to hospital where he was checked out and had x-rays but was discharged and informed that he had suffered heavy bruising to his back . [NAME] is still off work but is expected back in the near future .

The Injured person is a driver of a mini excavator . The first job every morning is for the two mini excavator drivers to move their machines away from the doors of the two steel containers , as they have been used overnight to protect the doorways to the steel containers.The Injured Person had moved his machine and had got out of his machine and walked to another area of the site compound , which was adjacent the second mini excavator.The second machine driver carried out his pre-start checks , checked his mirrors and blind spots , thought the area was clear and began to reverse his machine away from the steel container . At the same time as he began to move away from the steel container the injured person inadvertantly stepped backwards and his foot became trapped under the rubber track of the machine .Site operatives in the vicinity shouted / signalled the driver to stop immediately and told him to pull forward.The injured person was helped to walk over to a pack of kerbs where he rested and began rotating his foot . It was decided that the injured person should go to hospital to be checked out.The IP was taken to hospital where he was diagnosed with bruising to his foot . The IP has subsequently returned to the doctor for a check up and he reports that he has been told that he has a suspected fracture to a metatarsal , ( not confirmed ) , and bruising to his foot .

One of our employees had placed a wooden fence post on pack of paving slabs to remove a metal bracket , one of the slabs became dislodged and fell onto the top of his foot.Since the the incident we have instructed all employees to use work benches when available or a solid surface with someone to hold the timber ( material ) being used .

As part of his everyday duties , the IP was placing the sling to his lorry mounted crane through some beams which were being delivered to a construction site . as the IP reached to pull the sling through the beams , one slipped causing him to try to grab another beam which led him to fall . The IP is fully trained and recently underwent induction training highlighting the need to follow relevant risk assessments associated with the activity . On his return to work a full investigation and interview will take place . This could lead to the risk asessments being updated or highlight further taining requirements to do with slinging and load security

We were asked to remove counters and displays for a cosmetics brand . We did not originally supply these . We removed one component , and mistakenly thought the remaining part was still secure , but it was held by only one screw which failed causing the panel to topple over . It bruised the injured parties lower leg and cut the palm of his left hand . Hospital treatment was not required .

<NAME> ( known as <NAME> ) was putting away timbers onto the bed of his mobile crane after completion of work . He lifted a piece of timber ( a half sleeper ) onto the bed of the crane and after placing it , it slipped back towards him . This took him unawares and the timber pushed him over so that he fell to the ground with the timber landing on to his chest , pushing against his mobile phone in his left breast pocket . The impact caused him ( what he believed to be ) muscle pain in his chest and he did n't think he required a medical check at the time of reporting the incident to me ( at the office a couple of hours after it happened ) . He told me that he did n't report the incident on the site , as no one was around to report to ( his job was completed ) . He went home and called the office early the next morning to advise that he did n't feel well enough to work . He is currently signed off work by his GP for " contusion , chest wall" . His sick note period is from <NAME> until <NAME> and it states he will not need to be assessed for fitness to return to work at the end of this period . He brought the sick note in to the office in person .
[Name] was renewing plastic corrugated roofing sheets to a conservatory/garage area, and fell unstable footing

The task he was carrying out was to remove some external cages from low level windows . Instead of using the ladders supplied , he took it upon himself to put a worktop on uneven ground , then put a chair on top , he then stood on the chair . However it had been raining and all surfaces were wet , which resulted in him slipping and losing his balance and hurting his ribs he said . When challenged by his colleagues , he said he was stupid to do what he did and should have used the ladders provided . He then carried on working for the rest of the day as normal . We are submitting this accident report in retrospect due to the fact he then took 2.5 weeks leave for which he signed for . Upon his return he has since complained of sore ribs so we felt it prudent to report this incident without prejudice .NB We have gathered this information from work colleagues as the injured party has not contacted us himself over this injury .

[NAME]  a young groundworker working for  [NAME] [NAME]  , had previously been instructed by  [NAME] the  [NAME]  site manager to operate a 6t dumper . [NAME] had indicated to [NAME] that he did not have a license to operate the dumper but was told that it would be ok . [NAME] proceeded to use the dumper and at 15.28 on [NAME] the 31st of [NAME] , was driving from the bottom of [NAME]  to the compound at the top of [NAME]  , when the banking collapsed next to a foundation approximately 1.000m deep . The dumper was thrown violently into the excavation and stopped suddenly , throwing [NAME] from the dumper , as there was no functioning seatbelt , which caused [NAME] to be thrown a considerable distance , causing injury to his spine and side . [NAME] hard hat was crushed under the roll bar , where the roll bar landed , which thankfully narrowly avoided crushing [NAME] skull . [NAME] has attended hospital and this GP and has now been signed off from work with strong painkillers . The dumper was removed from the trench using an excavator , not before pictures were taken of the incident . The incident has been fully investigated and recorded .

IP was ascending a ladder from the basement to the ground floor level when the ladder slipped away at the base causing the IP to fall to the floor of the basement . The ladder had been installed as a temporary arrangement to give access to the cellar area whilst the original access staircase from a trap hatch was boarded over to support a tower scaffold being used to provide safe access to first floor level of the building . Following the accident , the work to the first floor was completed and the original access to the basement ( through the trap hatch and down the concrete steps was reinstated and the suspended timber floor reconstructed over the new opening

This accident occured to [NAME], an electrician's mate, employed by [NAME] This accident was a high-potential event that could very easily have resulted in much more serious injuries. [NAME] was injured when a [NAME] non-powered elevating platform , weighing around 180kg , toppled from the forks of a telehandler striking him on the side/back . The platform was being moved from level 1 to the ground floor in preparation for being off-hired. According to [NAME] , a witness to the event , the telehandler driver was attempting to lift the platform over the top of the edge protection guard-rail , and was not lifting the platform by utilising the purpose made “fork slot ” lifting points , but rather the forks were inserted beneath the platform.The telehandler and driver were supplied by the principal contractor  [NAME] who are responsible for vertical movement of materials around site , in this case from level one to ground.The allocation of lifting work to the telehandler was by an ad-hoc process instigated by the work teams themselves . The  [NAME] site supervisor was allegedly consulted , and gave his permission to undertake the lift . The driver had opted to undertake the lift by lowering his forks over the top of the guard-rail onto the first floor slab . From his cab the driver would not have been able to see the forks or how the platform was being loaded onto the forks . However the [NAME] operatives were assisting the telehandler driver from the level 1 slab , acting as Banksmen/ loader. After this accident  [NAME] dismissed the driver and reprimanded the [NAME] operatives . Observations1 . There does not appear to be a telehandler lifting plan for the site which describes how [NAME] control the operation and use of the telehandler , the security and weight of its loads , the safe lifting and lowering of loads etc.2 .[NAME] did not have a trained Banksmen/ loader to assist the telehandler driver with this lift.3 . [NAME] and it ’s contractors did not adequately supervise the movement of this piece of equipment and allowed an unsafe lifting operation to take placeRecommendations1 . That [NAME] develop a telehandler lifting plan for this site2 . That [NAME] employ a trained Banksmen/loader to assist the telehandler driver .3. That [NAME] and its sub-contractors properly supervise all aspects of work activity on site . In particular all operatives must be instructed not to undertake any work that they have not been trained , or are not competent to undertake i .e . Banksmen/ loader/ slinger work . The IP injuries are bruising to his side and back . He has been signed off work for two weeks .
Whilst lifting a paving slab from a stack another paving slab fell on to his right foot . Has been told to make sure the paving slab stacks are secure before standing in front of them .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: While passing signs and frames to a fellow worker he misplaced his footing and fell banging the back of his ribs on the edge of a footwell . He was winded but worked on it started to hurt more as the night went on .

The accident: [NAME] ( IP – Injured Person) had completed the works as instructed by site management and was returning to the site office for further work instructions , when as he ( IP ) walked from the front door of Plot 1 , he ( IP ) stepped on a unsecured 18’ ’ inch / 2 feet approximately sized diameter manhole cover and fell into an exposed manhole . As he ( IP ) fell into the manhole, he ( IP ) managed to grab hold of an existing scaffold pole which prevented him from falling back further. During this fall and an attempt to prevent himself from falling further, IP sustained injuries to his lower back and buttock areas of his body ( according to the medical examination and report conducted ).The accident was witnessed by 2 other operatives who took pictures of the accident scene and assisted the IP to the [NAME] site office to report the accident and receive treatment from the site first aider . Following this , the IP was then driven by [NAME] (site manager ) to the local A & E /Hospital /Walk-In Department to receive further medical treatment.  At the time of writing this report the IP was driven to the site office to be interviewed and to present medical certification of the extent of his injuries and the medication that was prescribed to him.  IP is currently not working and at home on the advice of his doctor . It is not known how long he ( IP ) will be off work recovering from his injuries . What action have you taken to prevent a recurrence ? All advised of the accident on site . The loose manhole covers have been secured , guarded and spayed with bright / fluorescent spray paint . Specific toolbox talk given to raise awareness of designated pedestrian routes , obstructions , manholes and to report any issues seen. Increased vigilance and concentration when walking next or over manhole covers .Better communication between all parties concerned . More signage displayed warning of site hazards .  Better planning of work activities where operations are conducted close-by or where multiple trades are working in close proximity . What further recommendations do you make ? Increased supervision . Ongoing daily site inspections of working areas by [NAME] and [NAME] site management to be continued . Site supervision/ management to ensure that all operatives are made fully aware of all known hazards before working or entering particular areas . All future working practices and documentation on site to be regularly externally audited / inspected by [NAME] to ensure compliance and safe working practices .

The boom Lift was being Driven between sites following completion of a job. Towards the end of the journey the banksman signalled stop by raising his hand but the machine continued to travel running over the banksman's foot.  Driver had asked for assistance in form of banksman. IP was banksman, communication system was established use of hand signals machine contact with banksman running over foot ( Root Cause ) Driver untrained for type of machinery Lapse of concentration from driver. Process failure for key allocation for equipment

<NAME>, was lifiting a concrete 8ft post, approx 40kg (4" x 4" x section approx) with another member of staff. They were walking the item to a stationary forklift. During this <NAME> explained that the post had rotated in his hands, <NAME> consiquently lost grip and it fell onto <NAME>'s foot. Item fell from a max height of 3', landed on <NAME> foot missing the proctecitive end, and striking top of foot, below ankle of left 'foot'

We are carrying out remedial works to the clients bathroom , she came up carrying a cup of tea for our tradesman who was working in the bathroom with the door shut . She went back down stairs and slipped falling to the bottom of the stairs . Water was on the stairs which was sheeted in roll and stroll protective plastic when our trades went to her aide as a bucket which had been near the top of the stairs had been knocked over , but this occurred when she fell and not the cause . We are unsure what caused her to slip . The lighting in the area was not on as our trades turned this on when they heard <NAME> <NAME> fall down the stairs . To prevent this from re-occuring we are removing the plastic sheet protection from the stairs at close of play today .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Coming down stairs when he stood on a piece of brickwork left on the stairs , this happened during 1st fix electrical works .

The IP was part of a team of five scaffolders who were in the process of dismantling a traditional tube and fitting scaffold . As they were dismantling the last four remaining vertical tubes at ground level , one of the remaining upright tubes toppled and struck the IP on the shoulder . To prevent a reoccurrence of this injury , all scaffolders employed have been given instructions to ensure that no tube that has the potential to topple , is left unattended in an upright position .

The injured person was using a hand saw to cut a piece of wood , a loose splinter from the cutting action was released and caught the injured person in the eye causing a scratch/sawness to the eye . The injured person was not wearing provided safety glasses whilst cutting . The department has been informed of the importance of wearing PPE which is provided to them to protect them from incidents and a rerfesher course on safe working and PPE will be carried out . Increased active monitoring is due to take place to confirm the use and supply of PPE to prevent this type of injury from re-occuring .

IP was working on the stair , sanding filler on a wall . The stair was covered with plastic protection . Due to having mud on his footwear , the IP slipped and slid down the stair bruising his back and spraining his left arm . The injured person was cleaning out the screed pump as part of the daily routine at the end of the shift . During the process operative did not use the tripod to hold the hose into the skip . When the pressure build up , the hose went uncontrolled hitting the operative in the abdominal area , causing internal bleeding . He was taken by an ambulance into the nearest  A & E hospital and diagnosed with liver fissure . Post actions by [NAME] : In house training is being provided for all screed pump operators and refresher courses ; Tool box talks have been send out for screeding operations ; Risk assessment and Method statement have been updated with clear ( step by step ) instructions how to use/ clean screed pumps ; check up list will be displayed on the screed pumps .

The IP <NAME> <NAME> ( <NAME> slinger erector ) was in the basket of his MEWP at first floor level he had bolted both ends of a small beam that he had erected with 2 bolts . He then gave a command by radio to the tower crane TC2 operative <NAME>  from <NAME> to lower the chains , then to stop . This was to allow him to unbolt 2 bolted brackets which connected the beam to the hook . The IP had unbolted one bracket and as he was unbolting the second bracket the chains tightened causing the hook to swivel up and toward the IP 's right hand which was on top of the bolt head to prevent it turning whilst he was removing the nut with his left hand . This resulted in the IP 's right hand being crushed between the underside of the hook and the bolt head . The IP sustained broken bones in his hand and was taken to hospital and has now been discharged . All works were suspended pending investigation . Investigations are still ongoing howeverToolbox talks have been given to all employees involved in lifting operations .

[NAME]  is employed as a painter on our site by [NAME] . He presented himself in the site manager's office and informed us he had chest injurries . He was taken off site by ambulance . And we have been informed that he had 4 paslode gun nails in his lung , heart and chest cavity His brother has informed [NAME]  the owner of the company that he fainted whilst moving the paslode nail. It is not possible to do this operation unless the trigger is activated and the gun is pressed against something solid . With the individual having four x 63mm nails in his chest cavity. We dont believe it is possible to do this with the safety mechanisms associated with the nail gun. He would have had had to depress the barrel and pull the trigger four times to have these injurries . It is only in my perception that this could be self harm or inflicted by the individual. Upon outr investigation , two witnesses have come forward and informed us, that he was acting strange in the morning . Having spoken to [NAME] in the [NAME] office this morning . We have sent the gun to an independent company to check the paslode gun . Ou

Employee was 'cutting into ' a wall at the top of the wall . To access this area of the wall , a ladder was used . Employee was descending from ladder , as employee was approaching ground level , subcontractor who was 'footing ' the ladder , apparently moved away to allow the employee to access the ground . The ladder 'wobbled' , and the employee stumbled from the 3rd/4th rung of the ladder , grabbing onto a pipe that was on the wall to steady himself , before falling to the ground . The ladder was footed , and as it was on an uneven surface , had a 'wedge ' device under , to provide a level platform . Method statements for working at height have been reviewed , and a statement to the effect that ladders must be footed at all times from initial ascent , to descent where the person using the ladder is back on the ground fully .

The following parties were involved and interviewed. [Name],  [NAME] crew member.  [NAME] [NAME] [NAME]  crew senior crew chief, [NAME] [NAME]site foreman, [NAME] [NAME] senior tent builder. [NAME] had been asked by the [NAME] foreman for volunteers to go onto the roof and perform the task . riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: [Name] have been appointed as principal contractor to undertake asbestos removal at [NAME] in [NAME] . The works comprise of the removal of non-licensable asbestos containing materials from the barrel vaulted roof of the [NAME] . [Name] have established a specific welfare area for use during the period of the works . The welfare area is located within proximity to Materials Feeding . [Name] approved car parking area is located on land above the welfare area and a grass embankment separates the two areas . [Name] are required to park vehicles within the approved car parking area and then to transit to the welfare area on foot , to minimise vehicular movement on site . A roadway provides access between welfare and car parking area . On the morning of [Date] [NAME] (asbestos removal operative for [Name] ) arrived on-site and parked within the approved parking area . He was alone at the time . Instead of using the approved route to gain access to the welfare area he walked down the grass embankment which leads directly from the car park to the welfare area . As he walked down the embankment he states that he felt what he described it as 'cramp like ' pain to the area above his knee and inner lower thigh . It is believed that he may have slipped or fallen , however [Name] specified that he did not fall and had no other injuries . He shouted to alert [Name] operatives and the site manager ([NAME] [NAME] ) , who had arrived on-site a short while before and were awaiting the start of their shift . They retrieved the injured person and sat him on a chair external to the site welfare area.[Name] Site Manager ( first aider ) and the Clients first aiders examined the IP. After assessment the decision was made to contact an ambulance . The ambulance crew elected to transfer the patient to the ambulance on a chair and for further examination at the [Name]. IP later contacted [Name] to state that he had received examination and xray . He stated that he had torn the muscle at the top of each knee cap and that he would require an operation . The operation was conducted on [Date] . The IP has since forwarded a 4 week sick notice to [Name] .

<NAME> ( <NAME> ) <NAME> was operating the <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> ( <NAME> ) <NAME> and <NAME> ( <NAME> ) <NAME> the slinger/Signallers. A frame shutters were moved .During this lifting operation <NAME> <NAME> injured his left shoulder.A frame shutters are single sided shutters 4.65 metres high by 3.l metres wide and weigh 2418KG/2.418Tons , comprising of Doka panels, Doka clips and wailings ,heavy A frames with screw jack feet attached to the back of the shutters.The Shutters are used to concrete walls against large pile caps.To hold the shutters in place twin anchors are cast into the concrete slab.The shutter is offered up to the twin anchors , A wailing brace extends over the top of the anchors and bottom of the A frame and secured down with Plates and spinners.The back screw jack feet are then used to plum the shutter.The A frames' are designed to sit sturdy .The weather was calm with no wind and good visibility .The site is tight with space a premium the area on the top was used to store materials but , the area has to be kept clear at night so that the NHS could gain access to the tanks.  <NAME> and <NAME> were aware of this and as the time was around 4.00pm they decided to clear the area . <NAME> went onto the top area to sling the shutters ; <NAME> went below to position the shutters.The shutters were stood upright , <NAME> banked the crane over to the shutter , hooked a ladder onto one of the J bolts, accessed up the ladder and hooked a chain on the A frame . <NAME> then came down the ladder , re-positioned the ladder to the left side , hooked the ladder again around another J bolt. <NAME> then took the second chain and flicked it over a hop up bracket on the back of the shutter , so not to catch when lifting.Accident <NAME> then climbed up the ladder to attach the 2nd chain.As <NAME> was 3-4 rungs up the ladder he felt the shutter moving forward so started to get down the ladder and jumped , as he did this his foot/feet became tangled . <NAME> was thrown to his left and his shoulder hit the left A Frame he managed to keep on his feet but felt pain in his shoulder.The shutter was then lowered by the crane operator and <NAME> . <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> came over ; <NAME> and <NAME> moved the shutter and <NAME> took <NAME> for first aid . <NAME> was taken to the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> in <NAME> where his shoulder was X-Rayed and discovered he had dislocated it . <NAME> attended the hospital the following day and was informed there was a small dint in the balls of his shoulder. <NAME> was instructed to keep off work between 6 and 12 weeks. Ladder not footedBlock not directly over the top of the wall and still in motionMeasures to prevent re occurrenceToolbox talks on the safe use of Ladderssafe slinging of loadsSchedule of common lifts to be amended to lift the A frame shutters and re-briefed RAMS to be amended to store the A frame shutters

description: <NAME> <NAME> is a <NAME> year old carpenter employed by the <NAME> & <NAME> of <NAME> . While carrying out planned external maintenance works to Local Authority owned housing stock , the employee was drilling into an exterior wall to fix a soil pipe clip . Unfortunately, due to an administrative error over the Christmas period there has been a delay in reporting the following over seven day injury. <NAME> was working with a group of operatives within the <NAME>. The work was controlled under prepared RAMS and under the direct supervision. The work area was in good condition although the floor surface was wet due to ingress of rain. The floor surface was linoleum covered timber floor. Housekeeping was good and maintained throughout.  <NAME>(Injured Person) was carrying out pre-demolition soft-stripping activities. This required using 1 metre crow bar to remove fixed door frames. The IP had successfully removed several door frames previously. The IP appears to have initially removed the architrave and then proceeded to remove the upright of the doorframe. The IP appears to have inserted crowbar to the centre of the upright door frame and pulled the crowbar towards him  with maximum body weight  leaning back. The effect of this resulted in the timber splitting rather than removing the doorframe complete. As the IP pulled / leaned back the crowbar the IP appears have had his feet close together  not a stable stance. The effort of pulling suddenly overcame the resistance between the soles of the work boots and wet linoleum. The IP was unable to correct his balance / stance and fell to his side and right leg twisted  resulting in dislocation of the knee. A Colleague telephoned the Site Supervisor who attended the IP. The Emergency Services were called at (13:59) but declined to attend due to low severity of injuries described. The Site Supervisor assisted IP to hospital at <NAME>  Casualty Dept. IP received treatment for dislocation / tendon damage of right knee and discharged with advice to attend <NAME> Fracture Clinic. IP returned to site at 15:50 and was driven home by colleagues.

On the day in question <NAME> <NAME> was part of a team of five steel fixers who were working fixing steel work to precast box units , whilst walking across the deck he lost his footing resulting in a loss of balance and fall , he broke his fall with his hands and dislocated the second finger to his left hand.The investigation carried out has lead to the conclusion that the accident was a result of a momentary loss of concentration , this was may have been brought about due to windy conditions which led to him losing his footing on the deck grid and his foot travelling through the deck bars , he dislocated his finger breaking his fall . Moments before the accident occurred , <NAME> <NAME> who is the Steel Fixing Supervisor had given instructions to stand works down as a precautionary measure due to gusts of wind . Weather conditions are a concern on site as most works are weather/tide dependant , daily briefings highlight weather conditions and their effects within work areas .

[NAME] ( [NAME] employee – Painter ) was undertaking external painting works at No 7 [NAME]  in [NAME]. [Name]had positioned his ladder to the right hand side of the first floor bedroom window using a stand-off and ladder matrix , he proceeded to cut in and then repositioned the ladder under the window sill to start the next stage of painting and as he was about to climb the ladder he realised he had left his paint kettle hooked onto the arial clamp , [NAME] moved the ladder back to the previous position and when he climbed the ladder to retrieve the kettle the ladder slipped and fell face down vertically to the ground and [NAME] fell to the right hand side taking the full impact of the fall to his right shoulder and grazed his right thigh and shin , when the ladder was moved back to retrieve the paint kettle [NAME] did not place the anti-slip devise ladder matrix at the foot of the ladder and this resulted in the ladder slipping .

During a partial tissue machine refurbishment project, as part of the housekeeping procedures on site one of our contracted fitters and his working partner were transporting an empty propane gas bottle from the construction site to the empty bottle facility in the storage area compound.They were utilising a trolley to transport the bottle.The trolley was pushed along the tarmac access areas and on to the hard standing ground of the temporary storage compound (this is made up of self-settling pathway hardcore). The temporary gas bottle compound was a Heras fenced compound 3 to 4 metres away from the made up ground on a grassy area. The grassy area had become slippy due to rain. This was the first rainy night since the project started. The Heras fence of the compound was opened. It was pushed back and left slightly ajar. The empty gas bottle was lifted off the trolley by the two operatives. As one of the two fitters walked backwards with the load he slipped and fell. This incident occurred on the night shift at approximately 01:30 am The fitter had apparently dislocated his left shoulder. The fitter initially self diagnosed the injury as he has a pre existing condition and he has dislocated his shoulder on several occasions before (not work related). The ambulance was called through the agreed first aid procedure. The attending paramedic put the shoulder back into position and after a suitable rest period and following a post incident briefing and discussion with the fitter (where he expressed his desire and suitability to return to work) he was allowed to return to his normal duties. He has not reported any further effects as a result of this incident. All [Name] site operatives have undergone a mill H&S induction, a CDM H&S induction and must possess a current CCNSG safety passport. The temporary gas bottle compound has now been relocated onto the hard standing ground. A revised risk assessment of the compound area has been undertaken. The location, timing and appartantly minor effect of the incident on the injured person contibuted to this injury not being reported until today (after the weekend). This was the earliest opportunity to gather and collate the information needed for this report. It has been reported through the online RIDDOR reporting method as a reportable major injury as it involved the dislocation of a shoulder joint.

The IP was working in a loft space , following a cold water feed to investigate a leak . He leant on a rafter to support himself and felt movement in his ribs . He did not experience any pain at the time and attended work as usual until  <NAME>. A visit to the hospital on  <NAME> diagnosed a dislocated rib .

As water levels reached a point where by they were level with the top basket operatives [NAME],  [NAME] and [NAME] began to fix the railing to the top basket within the causeway . [NAME] walked up to the far end where [NAME] and [NAME] indicated to [NAME] not to continue any further as the top basket ended within a couple of metres . At a period of a few seconds [NAME] continued fo walk forward and put his foot passed the last top basket causing him to slip off the edge . In front of this basket was a 1m basket , this had to be placed on the previous one metre as the long reach excavator had a computer issue and it was deemed on site to be unsafe to lift the baskety out . As steve fell off the top basket he placed his hand on the basket in front causing his weight to be placed through his right arm . He began complaining of pain within his arm and had limited movement . [NAME] and [NAME] along with the boat emergency rescue team ( placed on site to aid with any water bound operatives ) escorted [NAME] into the site office where his flash jacket was cut away . [NAME] ( site supervisor ) and [NAME]  made the desicion to send [NAME] to the local A & E where a professional assessment could be made . [NAME] returned to site to inform the team that [NAME] had dislocated his shoulder and was being sent to [NAME] where the shoulder could be repositioned . [NAME] was then taken to [NAME] in an ambulance and [NAME] followed behind . [NAME] shoulder was then repositioned and placed in a sling .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The IP had attended the property as a multi  trade operative to carry minor repairs to the ceiling in the kitchen.To access the area he had positioned a set of steps and began to ascend them when his foot slipped off the rung causing him to fall forward.As he did so he put his arm out against the wall to steady himself at which point he injured his shoulder which was later confirmed to be a dislocation.The steps he was using were those issued by the company which are EN 131 classification , they are tagged and had been inspected within the previous month . The IP had also conducted his pre use checks that day confirming the steps were in fully serviceable condition and had no obvious defects.The IP has received training in the correct use of ladders and steps and was wearing appropriate PPE including issue safety footwear , which again were in serviceable condition and the soles were clean and dry as were the rungs of the steps.It is the IP's belief that he did not have his foot fully on the rung as he climbed the steps which is why it slipped off . Although he fell forward he did not fall from height. He has also stated that due to previous injuries ( prior to joining the company ) his shoulder does have a tendency to pop out  and has done so on a previous occasions . This was the first time he had declared this.After the accident the IP attended the A & E for assessment / treatment , following which and at their advice he returned to work . The details of this accident will be reviewed with operatives . The correct procedure for climbing steps will be reiterated to the IP and all operatives to prevent further instances.The IP has been asked to keep his line manager informed of his condition , especially if this is an issue with any allocated tasks ( ie manual handling ) , so additional arrangements can be made if necessary .

The staircase flight had just been propped in preparation for a general overhaul to include renewal of newel posts , handrails and re-wedging/tightening up of all treads and risers which were exposed following previous removal of plastered soffits.The carpenter who had just installed the props had walked up the flight of stairs to check the landing above and then walked back down the flight of stairs to continue with his work . As he trod on the fourth step from the bottom it gave way causing him to fall which then knocked through the last couple of steps . He was stopped from falling further by instinctively reaching out with his arm at the stringer and by a nearby colleague who grabbed him . He was helped to an adjacent room where he could support his injured arm/shoulder , an ambulance was called and he was comforted by colleagues until the ambulance arrived . Once the ambulance had taken him away the staircase was blocked off and the two plasterers working on the first floor were instructed not to attempt to climb up onto the second floor until further notice . I followed the ambulance to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> and remained with <NAME> during assessment/treatment and discharge , after which I took him back to his sister 's house .

Labourer was removing timber from <NAME> No  scaffolding when he stood on or near a live [NAME] cable causing electrical shock . No visible injury but shook up . Taken to hospital as a precaution , ECG clear at <NAME> <NAME> hospital . Area evacuated and <NAME> <NAME> called to make cable safe .

An incident occurred resulting in a yard operative receiving an electric shock to his left hand . . The IP was kept in hospital until the afternoon of <NAME> <NAME> .On the day of the accident the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> briefed IP to get panels ready to go out for a customer . The procedure to get the panels ready is for the operatives to place the panels on beams to wash down and then buff using a buffing machine to remove excess concrete from the side of the panels . To use the buff machine an extension cable and an 110V 5KVA transformer is used and plugged into an outside portacabin . On the day of the incident weather conditions were poor it had been raining all day . Therefore , the IP took his gloves off , as they were wet . He then leant down to plug the extension cable into the transformer and when he received the shock and started to shake . As the IP lifted up the flap on the transformer he received a shock . ( He did not plug in the extension cable ; he received the shock before it was inserted ) . He had the cable in the right hand and lifted the flap with his left . We know this information because the <NAME> driver witnessed the event . He stated he seen a blue flash and <NAME> started to shake . The driver then shouted to the other yard op to assist as <NAME> was getting a shock . The yard op then ran over and asked the driver to get the manager , as he is the first aider . When they arrived at the scene the IP seemed to be ok just shaken up , he was conscious talking and did not want to go to the hospital . The Sales engineer assessed him and removed his boots to ensure no external burns .Soon after he started shaking and complaining of pains to his neck , chest head and finger . At this point , it was agreed an ambulance was needed so the emergency services were called . A first response vehicle turned up within a couple of minutes , quickly followed by two policemen and an ambulance . The ambulance took over from the paramedic treating the IP. The police interviewed the site manager and stated no follow up action would be needed . We believe that as the IP bent down to plug the extension cable into a transformer with him being wet ( witness statements ) there has been an arc event . The likeliest root cause at this time is water running off <NAME> jacket ( waterproof hi visability coat ) and entering into one of the outlets and causing an arc . People usually tip the transfer on a 45-degree angle so as to gain better access to the outlet.The cabin and electrical equipment were isolated immediately . The fixed electrical installation for the portacabin and the electrical test on the transformer were checked and found to be in date and certification available however , we got all equipment re tested independently as a precaution and all was found to be satisfactory . We have produced a learning point communication which will be shared across the business of the importance of electricity and water mixes .

Our works on the [NAME] site on the [NAME] [NAME] [NAME] involve the installation of large electrical cables within the 2nd floor plant room area and on the roof of the building . It is necessary to take the large cable drums into the goods lift at the ground level and wheel them out on the 2nd floor in the plant room to await installation within the building . 2 of our site operatives , [NAME]  &  [NAME] , noted that the cable drum was too large to fit into the goods lift and proceeded to trim the edges off each side of the wooden cable drum so that it could fit into the lift , in doing so they unintentionally made the drum harder to roll and turn . Site supervisor [NAME] & [NAME] were called down to assist  [NAME] & [NAME] with the movement of the cable drum so that it could be rolled into the goods lift , the normal procedure of a team effort to spin the drum was followed but as the drum was being turned [NAME] lost his grip of the cable drum and stumbled backwards , he trip on an hard adjoining site barrier that is in place to segregate the pedestrians from the road , as he tripped he put his right hand down to protect himself from the fall and injured his right hand.Although the site operatives state that the cable drum was not turned on the cut off section of the cable drum it is likely that this was a contributory factor in causing [NAME] 's hands slip as he was turning the cable drum as there would be a much larger surface area of the cable drum contacting the ground thus creating more friction than what would normally occur . We have made provisions to use a cable drum carriage for any future cable drum movements , this will alleviate the need for any manual handling of the cable drums .

The IP had been working with his assistant in a car park which had a height restriction barrier at the entrance ( 2020mm high & 6200mm in length , posts inverted L shape , the removable bar section was 4700mm long made of scaffold tubing & 21Kg . When replacing the removable bar one end fell from position . As the bar fell the IP attempted to keep hold of the bar but released it as the right hand side struck the ground , as it hit the ground it bounced back up striking the IP on his little finger on his right hand causing some pain . The injury was assessed at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> then <NAME> <NAME> where the injury was diagnosed as a spiral fracture to hi right little finger . Investigation findings have identified that the IP & assistant are fully authorised & trained for the works , no risk assessment or safe systems of work were in writing for removing or replacing car park height restriction barriers , however the works occurring were documented . Both the IP & assistant were wearing full PPE including gloves .On investigation of the height restriction barrier it was identified that the removable bar had been previously damaged causing the bar to be bent . When in situ & secured by the bolts the damage evident was consist with vehicle contact . The damage meant that the bar when in situ was being held in place against gravity by the bolts . When the securing bolts are removed the bar twists due to gravity & the angle of the bend . Recommendations from the investigation are to communicate with employees that the height restriction bar to the adjacent car park is not to be removed until repaired / replaced . Employees are to be made aware of this incident & the importance of visually inspecting these types of barriers prior to opening.The damaged height restrictor is to be reported to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> as requiring repair & improved design .

The injured person ( IP ) was in a gang pouring concrete directly into a trench footing . A ready mix concrete lorry arrived at the position where the concrete was required . The IP approached the stationary vehicle and pulled down the extension delivery chute at the rear of the vehicle with his left hand . He was standing on the off-side of the vehicle . His right hand touched the mid part of the chute on the bottom , which is a mechanical joint . His right index finger was trapped by the unfolding chute and as the chute bounced when it reached its full extension , the finger tip was released . The IP realised he had been trapped but was not in pain . He took off his glove and realised he had a cut to his finger and reported this to his site supervisor who sent him for first aid and arranged for another operative to take the IP to hospital as a precautionary measure . The IP reported his injury to the [NAME] site manager as a cut finger , a plaster was put on his finger tip ,and he was then taken to the nearest A&E . His finger was x-rayed and strapped and bandaged . He wa sent home and a appointment made for the following morning at a different hospital department . There he was booked in for an operation the following Monday . His finger tip was found to be fractured : the operation involved removal of his finger nail to allow the resetting of the bone and subsequent stitching back of the skin at the end of his finger . he was given penicillin , but had an allergic reaction to this . Site was unaware of the treatment received and understood the injury to be simply a cut finger . The ready mix lorry had the following signs on the rear : " This equipment only to be operated by [NAME] trained personnel . " " Wet concrete burns , authorised operator only . " " Keep clear of vehicle , only driver is authorised to operate controls . " Despite this the risk of entrapment in the chute was not understood . The risk has now been communicated across the Company with a specific instruction not to touch the delivery chute . The newest ready mix lorries have a hydraulicaaly operated extending chute which does not require any manual operation to extend - the warning notices relating to this now state an exclusion zone of 6.0m . is required as the chute can extend to 4.5 m . remotely operated by the driver . This has now been communicated across the Company as the practice until now has been to stand close to the delivery chute and indeed guide it in placing concrete.The reason for late reporting was that the extent of the treatment was not understood at site level and when the IP did not return to work , the at work injury was not thought to be the reason for absence . Our reporting and recording procedures have been reviewed and changed to ensure this does not recur and all sites have been made aware of the necessity of recording all accidents to allow investigation as early as possible and reporting if required in a timely fashion .

It is alleged that the injured person was installing a 160mm duct line and in doing so the draw cord jammed inside the duct. To assist in freeing the draw cord , the injured person and a colleague tied the end of the draw cord to the bucket of a mechanical excavator to attempt to release a jam. The contractors had tied a pneumatic hammer tool ( acting as a draw weight ) to the opposite end of the draw cord as an aid to feeding the draw cord into the duct lengths. During this activity the draw cord then became unattached from the excavator bucket and recoiled back into the duct , due to the tension . The draw cord pulled the pneumatic hammer tool back towards the duct at speed and the injured person was struck on the lower right leg just above the ankle. The first aider was in attendance and called for assistance, due to the remoteness of the site the air ambulance was in attendance and the injured person was taken to hospital .Following the accident a full investigation was conducted and immediate control measures implemented to prevent a reoccurrence. Instructions and tool box talks were carried out to ensure safe practices were observed in similar activities . Since the accident all ductwork is now complete and the contractor now has minimal activity on site .It has been confirmed by his direct employer [Name]  [NAME],  that the injured person spent three days in hospital and is subsequently still off work.
While ripping out plaster board from a step ladder , the bottom support strap broke and <NAME> <NAME> fell from the ladder

Employee was joining counter weight guides in the lift shaft and was using a remote minifor hoist to raise and lower . The guides suddenly dropped sharply causing his finger to be caught under the full weight of the load until the minifor could move the weight . The signal from the remote to the minifor was intermittent .
While drilling out a hole , item was snagged causing it to spin and grab hold of thumb causing a cut and fracture to the knuckle

The injured person ( IP ) was laying sub base in a pavement on the site . He required the whacker plate to compact the material he had just laid . He approached the telescopic fork lift driver and asked if he would bring the whacker plate to the pavement with the fork lift . The forklift driver said he would do it in a couple of minutes as he had to move a partial pallet of lock block first . The forks were set too wide for the pallet of lock block and it appears the fork lift driver asked the IP to move the forks so they would fit the pallet . The IP agreed to move the forks to help out as he has done so throughout his career . The forks were positioned in such a way that the fork had to be lifted clear of the carriage before it can be repositioned . He lifted the fork with his right hand and placed his left hand at the heel of the fork and was pulling at the fork to move it . As he was pulling the fork it slipped from his right hand and the fork fell back against its resting place on the carriage trapping his left hand between the fork and the carriage causing a fracture of the metacarpal bone on the ring finger . He attended hospital and underwent surgery where a steel plate was attached to the fractured bone to hold it in place . The IP is very experienced and has re-positioned fork lift forks several times . The forks were left parallel with the ground while being moved . They should have been tilted forward until the heel of the fork came away from the carriage preventing the need to lift the fork to move it . Work procedures and risk assessments are being reviewed . The review will involve discussions with training companies , agency providers and company safety reps to ensure this issue is permanently addressed .

Our <NAME> site supervisor was requested to remove 4Nr retractable access steps inside one of the recently completed apartment blocks , by the <NAME> <NAME> project manager . A safe method to remove each retractable steps was discussed in detail and agreed between our Supervisor and the <NAME> Project Manager . Our Supervisor explained in detail to the three operatives undertaking the task the method that should be followed and assisted with removing the first set of steps to ensure the works and sequencing are fully understood . The first three sets were removed in a controlled and safe manor without any issues , as directed by our SSSTS Supervisor adopting the agreed method with the Principle contractor to the witness statements , the agreed method was not followed by <NAME> <NAME> when removing the final set of steps which caused the steps to slip and trap his fingers .Weve undertaken an in house investigation of this incident over the past few days and had several conversations with our H&S advisor ( who visits our sites on a monthly basis ) . I have also spoken at length with each of our SSSTS/SMSTS Supervisors across all of our sites , as well as requested additional toolbox talks to be undertaken on all our sites on Following method statements / risk assessments  and the safe use of access equipment .

Accident occured before working hours began. Employees used a JCB with a cage to take a photograph of work on the building. The cage became detached and two individuals who were in the cage fell to the ground with it. What they were doing was not part of any construction operation

Precise Location : single door access point to left wing on the ground floor of <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> . Brief description of how the incident happened :At approximately 12:00 to 12:30pm on the <NAME> it is believed that <NAME> <NAME> had come from his residence on the second floor to the first floor and had broken through the taped and signed barrier restricting access to the first floor left wing and then slipped on the wet latex floor levelling compound that had been laid at approximately 10:30am that morning . <NAME> <NAME> was discovered at 12:30pm by a member of <NAME> <NAME> staff who immediately contacted the site manager for assistance , the <NAME> <NAME> arrived at the incident at approximately 12:45pm , <NAME> <NAME> was complaining of pain in his left shoulder , the site manager called for an ambulance to attend.The sheltered housing manager for <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> attended the incident as the first aider and she assessed <NAME> <NAME> and placed his left arm into a sling for support , <NAME> <NAME> was them moved to the communal lounge area for comfort until the ambulance arrived.The ambulance took approximately two to two and a half hours to arrive at the property , <NAME> <NAME> was assessed by the paramedic and then taken to the hospital with a suspected dislocation or fracture to his left shoulderimmediate action takenThe area was secured off again , this time with a ridged barrier at both ends of the hallwayA <NAME> <NAME> employee manned the work area until the latex floor had driedAll further works of this nature at the property have been suspended until all parties are satisfied that addition control measures have been implemented to reduce or remove the risk . Short term actions introducedThe risk assessments and method statements have been reviewed and the following additional control measures will be introduced before work is allowed to re-commence :All barriers will in future be rigged plastic safety barriers , with No entry signage meeting the required safety signs regulations 1996Work of this nature will take place after 11pm at night for the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> propertyThe latex area will be manned by a member of staff at all times during the estimated four hour drying time.  Latex will be applied by roller to provide a more consistent coverage with the view to reduce drying timesWhat long term actions have been considered :<NAME> will investigate the use of other products that may have shorter drying times for projects similar to this one in the future .Specific vulnerable person risk assessments must be discussed at the planning stage with the property manager to ensure that individuals requirements have been considered and accounted for prior to commencing the project

This is not the normal method.<NAME> hammered the top of the clip to close it whilst <NAME> supported the hose underneath . <NAME> did not see <NAME> hand underneath the hose and hammered underneath hitting <NAME> finger .

[NAME]  was working in the underpass at [NAME] . He was trying to remove a metal clamp bracket ( top hat ) from a section of trunking that ran through the underpass at a height of 2.13 meters from ground level . The bracket made from galvanised sheet steel was formed to fit over the rectangular sectioned trunking and held in position by two screws fitted into the wall of the underpass .  [NAME] was standing on the second tread of a pair of glass fibre step ladders 0.4 metres high so he could reach and undo the retaining screws . He was having difficulty in unscrewing one of the screws and was manipulating the bracket by hand to try and loosen it . The bracket suddenly broke free throwing [NAME] off balance and causing him to fall to the ground breaking his right arm in two places , at the wrist and elbow .

IP was using a [NAME] [NAME]  & had been tasked to punch holes in 1.4m lengths of 2" x 1/4 " ‘mild steel flat bar’ . This operation required manually placing the ‘steel flat bar’ into position & using the foot operated switch to punch the holes in the steel . As the punch mechanism retracted upward , the ‘steel flat bar’ returned with the punch mechanism . As part of IP training a 'safety paddle ' was shown to be used for this task to prevent fingers & hands coming into contact with machine equipment or materials . The investigation found prior to the incident the IP had punched several lengths using the paddle . When the accident occurred , IP had not used the paddle . IP’s left hand index finger was pinched between the flat bar’ & the ‘stripper head’ . IP used this machine on a frequent basis . IP reported this to his line manager & was taken to hospital for further treatment . IP was diagnosed as having a broken index finger on his left hand . IP returned to work the following day & worked for several hours but was unable to continue .

The injured party was loosening ground and old fence posts in order to remove them prior to installing a new fence post . Whilst using a 6ft bar to help loosen the ground and an old post he slipped and trapped his hand in-between the bar and an existing fence post . At first it was thought he had just bruised a finger but after several days it transpired that the finger had been fractured . The operative was wearing a stout working glove at the time of the incident . The operatives line manager has briefed all other regional operatives about the need to be aware of their surroundings and to avoid movements that could cause trapping where possible . Due to the location / access and nature of the task it would not have been reasonably practicable to mechanise the task with a digger etc , however the H&S Manager is to investigate the potential use of an air pick for future operations of this nature .

IP was accessing a shaft via a temporary HAKI staircase . He was descending the middle flight of three when he slipped and fell , twisting his left ankle . It was confirmed that the IP had suffered fractures to 2 bones in his foot and was fitted with a plaster cast and prescribed pain killers . He was discharged at about 15 :00 hours .Signage was in place at the time of the accident , warning all personnel to hold the handrails . All site personnel were briefed of the incident and the tally man , who controls access to the shaft , was instructed to remind everyone accessing this location to maintain 3 points of contact when using the staircase.The metal stair treads have an anti-slip surface however they were wet at the time of the incident .
