Works were being undertaken at the roof level of the [NAME] wing at [NAME] to remove the steel structure of the former heli pad that served the hospital . At the west elevation of the roof , there are 3 ‘V’ columns , a beam runs North/ South connected to these columns from which 4 beams run from West to East . It was during the removal of the second of these beams (W-E) that the incident occurred.The burner , [NAME], working from a MEWP operated by [NAME] , removed a ‘V’ shaped section from the webbing area of the ‘I’ beam and then proceeded to remove the top section of the beam. As this piece was released , it fell towards the roof level . Directly beneath the location of the cut , a pre-existing hand rail is located which the piece of steel hit and bounced away from the roof area to the site processing area 6 floors below – falling approximately 26m . It was here that the IP , [NAME]  was working when the steel hit him – first striking the left side of his hard hat before continuing on to strike the collar bone & shoulder of his left side.The piece of steel that hit the IP was 10mm thick and 170mm x 100mm , with the approximate weight being 1.3kg The I.P. was carrying out works under the Method Statement for Soft Stripping / Demolition Works in [NAME] [NAME] : [NAME] with field control sheet [Name] removal of helipad structure on the Roof of [NAME] [NAME] in place under which the burner was carrying out his works at roof level .

Operative was standing on ladder once painting the kitchen wall , he stretched too far over and fell breaking his left upper arm bond . The ambulance was called and he was taken straight to hospital .

IP was working on a scaffold at the property renewing the guttering , has he pushed hard on a gutter clip onto the outlet his right thumb bent back resulting in a sharp pain . He carried working he phoned in sick on the [Date] and sent in a sick note on the [Date] . The IP had an existing injury to his right thumb .
IP attended with colleague a breakdown of a ladder hoist on site. IP was fitting replacement hoist and feeding cable in. Finger became caught in roller section.

Exploratory holes were being advanced using hand held window sampling equipment.  The incident occurred whilst extracting the window sampler barrel and rods from a exploratory hole using a hydraulically powered ram set.  Note due to the depth reached within the exploratory hole this was the first time the ram set had been used.Whilst extracting the window sampler barrel the drill rods are split and unscrewed during the extraction process. Whilst extracting the rods from the borehole the operator went to split a joint between two of the drill rods using a set of stilsons at the base of the ram set.  Whilst trying to undo the thread the drill rods slipped through the roller block at the top of the ram set which was holding the drill rods.  This resulted the operators thumb on his left hand getting temporarily trapped between the side of the ram set and the drill rods / top of the window sampler barrel towards the lower section of the ram set.After the event it was noted that only one of the two roller blocks provided with the ram set were being used.  This was due to the second set not being able to be positioned correctly within the lower part of the ram set due to the position and length of the hydraulic hose at the base of the ram unit.  This second set also assists with holding and extracting the drill rods.The second set of roller blocks had previously been identified as an improvement by the operators and had been ordered and provided to the drill crew to ensure the ram set could be used safely.  Following the incident it became apparent that the lower roller block set could not be used as the lower hydraulic hose between the two rams prevent them from being positioned correctly.Actions following the event include refresher training for all operaitves who use the hand held window sampler and associated equipment and checking all ram sets to ensure the lower set of roller blocks can be inserted and operate correctly.

The IP was struck on the right hand/thumb by a falling scaffold pole as it was being altered by a colleague to improve access and egress which was impeded.The IP was watching his colleague when the pole became dislodged and struck the IP on his right hand/thumb as it slid.The IP was able to complete his shift and later attended the A & E at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> in <NAME> where x-rays revealed a fracture and also possible ligament damage .The IP was referred as an outpatient to the trauma clinic and has been absent from work since this date .

Lifting vibrating plate onto wagon in a duel lift with colleague. Plate slipped falling onto knuckle of Right Hand. Procedures and training are in place and the employee did not appear to be injured initially.

a small unic crane was been moved under it 's own power along a pre designated route to the site of operation by a trained operator . the machine was turned through 90' to access the lower part of the site via a small ramp pre-constructed by the main contractor . the small tracked crane was then moved under it 's own power until approx 25 % of the crane was on the ramp..at this point the operator checked the ground conditions when the ramp gave way pinning the operator between the machine and existing wall by his fore arm
Whilst caring out kitchen and bathroom refurbishment works in the property the lady of the house fell over in her kitchen at approximately 9pm and fractured her hip and had to go to hospital .

<NAME> personnel had excavated a drainage trench approx . 150mm wide by 300mm deep in the garden of the property at the address above . The operatives had informed the resident of the property not to go into the garden that evening . After the operatives had left for the day the resident went into the garden and on her return as she attempted to stride over the excavation slipped on the damp grass , and fell fracturing her shoulder.On investigation it was discovered that although the resident had been instructed not to go into the garden , no barriers had been placed around the shallow excavation , which is standard practice .Work operatives have been given a toolbox talk and reminded that ALL excavations must be guarded to prevent access to it .

Two operatives were working from a aliminium tower scaffold . They were tasked with taking out a redundant sprinkler pipe system . For five weeks previously to the incident , this had been undertaken with the use of Genie lift fitted with a pipe cradle to support the off cuts and then the pies cut into lengths of about 3m . These were then lowered to the ground in a controlled manner . At the time of the incident , the men cut a 6m length of pipe . The cradle was not used as the operatives intended the off cut to fall to the ground . When this began to fall , it swung into the aliminum tower causing it to fall over with the men on . First aid was provided on site and an ambulance called .

Joiner was using a pedestal drill to machine wooden dowels . Hand made contact with the rotating drill piece . Injury sustained was a broken thumb , laceration to the thumb and removal of thumb nail .

In the process of removing an old bar top the top dropped and seperated from the wall which in turn caused <NAME> to drop his end of the work top causing his hand to become caught between the top and bottom half of the unit.On inspection by a first aider staff member ( <NAME> <NAME> ) it was recommended that he visited the A & E dept . <NAME> returned to work to report that his little finger was broken and a hairline fracture to the third finger. He revisited A & E the next day <NAME> at which time he was given a 7 day sick note .We will be going through the RA and SSW with <NAME> on his return to prevent this incident occurring again

Incident is currently under investigation to establish what happened . There are no witnesses to the incident and the injured person has not been interviewed at this time due to receiving medical treatment in hospital .

TELEPHONE REPORT IP accessed adjacent existing roof next to the new build and was loading materials to a location that was not agreed . Because it was not agreed for him to be on the existing roof the existing roof had not been installed with edge protection . During lifting of roofing materials assisted by fork lift truck he slipped backwards and fell from 1st storey flat roof down onto ground level . 2 members of school staff attended to the IP.  They called an ambulance . IP was conscious and able to communicate . IP was taken to <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ( roofing sub contractor ) attended <NAME> . <NAME> <NAME> was carrying out his normal duties working with colleagues on his overhead line team . They were erecting a new intermediate 16 metre wood stout H pole configuration to carry overhead power lines and replace the existing poles . The new pole configuration comprises two poles that are joined by a temporary bracing beam . This beam holds the poles at the correct separation and orientation during erection . On completion of the poles being erected , the permanent top cross arm was fitted and the temporary bracing removed . The beam was then lowered using rope and running blocks by <NAME> and a colleague who were stood at ground level . Whilst lowering the beam <NAME> colleague lost his grip on the rope . <NAME> Accident site. <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> ,  morning of <NAME>,   I asked <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> to inspect for a cause to damp penetration on upstairs ceiling , possibly caused by faulty flashing to front chimney stack , if they had time during the day . I did not do a risk assessment at the time as it was to be only an inspection , not to carry out any remedial work .At the time in the morning there were no signs of gusty winds , otherwise I would not have even considered asking them to do this. I was not aware of the accident until <NAME> <NAME> rang me when it happened and immediately went to site. A paramedic was there , he called for backup , which came as Air Ambulance Helicopter. <NAME> <NAME> was asked to come to the office and we completed attached report . Obviously this was <NAME> observations not <NAME> <NAME>.   <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> are considered as very competent people . ?Made by <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , accident site. <NAME> <NAME>  <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME>.   <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> were asked to look at cause of damp penetration on upstairs ceiling , possible cause faulty flashing to front chimney stack. <NAME> and <NAME> put up ladder and crawler and fastened them together to examine stack . They then decided it was too windy to do anything ( they did not go onto roof ) . <NAME> then went up the ladder with <NAME> at the bottom to take back down the crawler.A sudden gust of wind caught <NAME> and the ladder moved so <NAME> appeared to jump down feet first and landed in a standing position onto some concrete slabs. <NAME> immediately collapsed to floor shouting Oh my ankle <NAME> immediately called for an ambulance and a paramedic arrived very soon after . He gave <NAME> various tests and called his station . An air ambulance helicopter then soon arrived and <NAME> was taken apparently to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> by <NAME> <NAME> ( <NAME> ) <NAME> , <NAME> .

description: A site security guard [employed by the principle contractor for guarding purposes out of site operating hours ] followed an unauthorised route to the toilet block , which involved him jumping over a site fence/handrail . In doing so he slipped from a loose wall slab and fell , sustaining a broken arm . The security guard was familar with the site , having worked there for several days , and had been inducted by the Site manager who had showed him the route to the toilet block from the site cabin as part of that training . The alternative route he was following at the time of the accident was provided for contractor use during the day , and had a gap between a fixed post and the fixed handrail / fence , through which any person could access - It is not known why the guard jumped over the rail , when he could have gone through the gap , or between the intermediate and hand rail , or have moved the fence panel which was butted up to the post , however he should not have followed this route in the first instance , and had not been instructed to do so .

The sub-contract Floor layer arrived at property the evening before the incident to fit the new vinyl flooring . The IP is a resident of a social housing dwelling undergoing bathroom refurbishment . As part of the works ' carpet guard ' self-adhesive polythene sheeting was laid on the staircase to prevent soiling/damages to the carpet when site operatives accessed the bathroom area . At 20:30 on the day in question the I.P. was descending the staircase to the ground floor and misplaced her step stumbling down the bottom 4 or 5 steps to the entrance hallway hurting her right ankle .The I.P. during our subsequent investigation stated that although the carpet guard sheeting had been down for around 5 days , it was correctly stuck to the steps and was not raised in any way . The I.P. stated that she was wearing slippers at the time of the incident but when asked the condition of the slippers stated that she had thrown them away because they had become damaged during her accident.The site manager when questioned indicated that the carpet guard was left in place as we had worked in the property that afternoon and were intending to return on the 16th to lay the floor screed in the bathroom prior to laying vinyl flooring.The IP phoned for medical assistance and the attending paramedic arranged for an ambulance to take the I.P. from her home to <NAME> <NAME> for treatment that same evening .(Note : The Company has used the same make of carpet guard sheeting in similar locations on over 90 properties on the same site without any reported problems with building users slipping on the sheeting )

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The accident occurred during the filling of the new beam and block floor . The task involved carrying concrete blocks , lifting concrete blocks and placing concrete blocks in between concrete beams . <NAME> had been instructed on how to carry out the task and was carrying out the task when he put his foot into the gap between the concrete beams , causing him to fall , landing on his right hand <NAME> did not report the accident to the site office until the site supervisor noticed he had a swollen hand and was then asked if he required any medical assistance . He replied that he was OK and did not need any medical assistance .Later that evening , he attended a walk in centre as his thumb was hurting and was told that it was fine . <NAME> returned to work the next day . On the 11th <NAME> <NAME> was still in pain from his thumb and took himself to A & E that evening . He then emailed the office on the 12th november to show an X-ray of his thumb which appears to be broken and informed the company that he had an appointment on <NAME> <NAME> in which the hospital will pin his thumb . I spoke to <NAME> on the  <NAME> and he advised that he was told he would have to take 2 weeks off work to recover.Witnesses on site have stated that he was not carrying anything in front of him at the time and could easily see the gap in which it was his task to fill . Witnesses have also stated that <NAME> told them that he has had previous issues with the thumb on his right hand and it was noted that he had a scar already on his thumb (right hand). <NAME> was inducted onto site prior to his starting working on site and was wearing appropriate PPE at the time . He was also working with an experienced bricklayer , with more than 20 years experience . We are hoping to roll out more toolbox talks on slips , trips and falls in the next week .

description: TELEPHONE REPORT: The IP was making his way down metal open grated stairs when he mis-judged the last step thinking there was another step and landed heavily on his right foot . Whilst carrying out the sealing of sub base concrete the injured party who was on his knees did grab hold of the base plate of a handrail stanchion to support himself whilst stretching to re-apply sealing compound to an area of the sub base . The handrail stanchion sheared off the handrail without warning and the injured party 's hand , still gripping the base plate and stanchion , travelled around 100mm downwards then collided with the sub base . The force of downward travel resulted in the tip of the 5th digit of the left hand ( pinkie finger ) being squashed by the stanchion base plate . The injured party attended hospital to have the injury assessed and treated . The following day the finger was operated on and the shattered finger tip bone was reassembled within the finger , the surrounding flesh was stitched up and the hand was bandaged . The injured party has been signed off for a period of 4 weeks to allow the injury to heal . The accident investigation has established that where required re-applying the base sealing compound could be safely performed by using a paint roller fitted with an extension handle thus avoiding the need to stretch to re-coat the sealing on the sub base . The Risk assessment and method statement will be amended to identify that handrail stanchions are not be be used for support and paint roller with extension handle is to be used to reach those awkward positions requiring re-coating .

Against company risk assessment and training the IP was loading two tower staging platforms (total 40kg) on to vehicle when one fell and hit his hand .

Taking off a 1m ladder section , this was attached to header structure . Then because the bolts where put in from the top I could not fit a nut running in to open the nuts , so I took off the bottom bracing clamp which is inch and half by inch and a half . The bottom brace clamp came off and then top brace clamp was still attached . So I pushed the one meter ladder section up vertically so I could fit my nut running to open the nuts on the top brace clamp . I opened the brace clamp and the ladder section came down to the original position and therefore my thumb was in the way .
IP injured his toe when turning over a table in order to store it .

Bricklayers were completing the last few courses of blockwork on the final wing of an apartment block . A TRAD safety deck had been erected for the work and for the subsequent installation of the roof structure . There are 8 flats on each floor and all 8 flats had been decked out with TRAD decking together with the communal corridors . The bricklayers had loaded out the TRAD Decks to all of the four flats on the final wings before morning break . Shortly after returning from break , one of the TRAD Decks gave way whilst a bricklayer was laying block . This caused the bricklayer to fall through the deck onto the concrete floor below . Initial reports were that the lower leg was badly bruised and swollen . As the bricklayers finished the work shortly after the incident , we have only just found out that a bone in the foot has broken and that the individual has n't been back to work since .

An ambulance was called and the IP was taken to hospital where he was diagnosed with fracture's to the rib's, elbow and skull.

A member of the public tripped on a roll of carpet and fell causing injuryTenant of a flat within the working area was escorted out of the working area and led down stairs The tenant then came back up the lift and tripped whilst entering the working area. We had signage up around the area which was clearly visible and the tenant was physically escorted out of the area in the first instance .She was aware of the work taking place and we took all precautions to ensure the materials were stored in a safe place during the uplifting process.The one roll of uplifted material was stored up against the wall leaving a clear path through the working area.This was an unfortunate accident and we did all we could to prevent it from happening .

Floor level in communal corridor had been reduced due to replacement of sub floor , as such step of circa 150mm in place between internal flat threshold and current temporary floor level in corridor . Elderly resident stepped out of flat , fell and broke hip .
Injured party slipped and fell from a low level work platform ( hop-up ) as descending . He struck his leg/hip on installed edge protection (scaffold pole ) .

<NAME> <NAME> - carpenter visited the property which was prior booked in for flooring works to take place , <NAME> moved a piano which was on skates and the piano fell off the skates and landed on the top of his right foot . <NAME> was wearing Steel Toe Cap boots and was in pain , however continued to work and took some painkillers , <NAME> was aware he should have waited for the other team member to arrive before attempting to move the piano .

The construction of the building was designed to enable the lower levels to be constructed in conjunction with the upper floors / levels . Once the piled wall had been installed to the perimeter of the building footprint , the lower ground floor would be installed then the upper and lower sections would proceed once the lower ground floor slab had cured.Timber decking form work was placed on top of the formation to cast the lower floor slab . Included in the lower ground floor slab was the opening to be formed for the lift shaft . A 200mm high up stand deck was built off the lower formwork deck to form the opening/start of the lift shaft.Once the lower ground floor slab had been completed excavation works for the basement area commenced . The formwork from the underside of the lower ground floor slab was struck during the basement excavation leaving what had been the 200mm up stand deck within the lift shaft opening . This deck had not been fixed to the lift shaft walls but had been built straight of the slab support deck . During the excavation of the basement , the lift shaft wall starter bars had been bent inwards and were supporting the lift shaft deck . Once excavation works had reached a suitable level the lift shaft wall starter bars were straightened leaving the lift shaft deck unsupported , remaining wedged in place only . At the time of the accident IP had been asked by the site supervisor to find / locate any reinforcement spacers on site in preparation for the construction of the first floor slab. Whilst on the lower ground floor slab IP noticed that there were some concrete spacers within the decked area of the lift shaft. When IP entered the lift shaft onto the ply board deck it gave way almost immediately and IP fell approximately 3m into the basement area.IP landed on his feet then fell to his left side . The first aider ( site supervisor ) attended the IP who was siting down and appeared to be ok and to have no visible injuries but said that he felt a lot of pain in his left foot.The supervisor ( first aider ) applied an ice pack to the injured foot and took IP straight to hospital for further treatment.Following an assessment and X-ray ; IP suffered a small fracture to the rear of his left foot .
injured party descending step ladder slipped

The ip was fitting a 'stiffener' against the web of a beam, this required to be knocked into position, he was holding the item with one hand and using a 2lb hammer to knock it into position, he struck the hand holding the item with the hammer.

The IP was drilling a 50 mm hole in to a 600 mm x 600 mm metal service tile using a Hilti Drill with a 50 mm hole cutter attached when the drill snagged on the tile and twisted his wrist , causing no immediate pain , however , swelling occurred overnight and the IP subsequently visited the hospital A and E department the following day . The Risk assessments and method statements are being updated to ensure the correct procedures are in place . A bulletin is to be issued to all personnel and Toolbox tools held on the safe use of drills and attachments , distributed throughout the company and displayed on all notice boards .
Scaffolder- Twisted ankle unloading scaffold materials from lorry .

The i/p arrived on site at approximately 07.40 hours and proceeded to put his ppe on of which would comprise of a safety helmet , safety footwear , high visibility vest . However , whilst undertaking this task the IP saw the principal contractor's site manager struggling to remove an 8 x 4 x 3/4inch board which had been wedges with the other similar sized boards between the shopfront and the roller shutter by another operative on site .It appeared that the other operative had rammed/wedge the board and did not report this to his site manager. When the i/p approached to assist the site manager <NAME> <NAME> , the i/p held the front facing board with the <NAME> <NAME> and as they manoeuvred the board the rear board slipped down and struck the IP 's big toe on his left foot . The IP instantly had bruising and swelling to his toe but proceeded to work on for the remainder of that day and also the following day to complete the work as he thought that he could work it off . The IP returned to <NAME> on the afternoon of the following day , <NAME>  and felt no improvement to his toe . He then decided to attend the A & E department in <NAME> in <NAME> <NAME> in the morning of <NAME> the  <NAME> . The IP was informed after receiving a consultation and having an X-Ray that he had fractured his toe and was required to attend a fracture clinic the following day , the <NAME>  at the <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> . At the fracture clinic , the IP was informed that he had bruised , fractured and crushed his left big toe and was given a four week unfit for work statement . The clinic bandaged his foot and gave him a boot/brace and crutches to use as he could not use his left foot to support himself . The IP was also told that he should keep his foot elevated until his next appointment at the fracture clinic on <NAME> .

Operative whilst opening sash window got his hand trapped between the two opening sashes of the bay window . These were temporarily bandaged by the first aider and the operative then went to the nearest A & E hospital for treatment . He had broken one finger and needed stitches . This incident occurred on the <NAME> . On the following <NAME> all site personnel on the site were given a tool box talk relating to the accident and measures introduced to avoid any further accidents ; these included labelling window of sliding sashes , ensuring that the sashes were only opened as necessary with 2 operatives ; including being added to the site induction of new personnel coming to the site .

[NAME] has tripped and fallen whilst carrying fish plates on his shoulder.  As he’s broken his fall with his hands the fish plates have fallen off his shoulder and landed on his fingers.  First aider attended to him straight away.  [NAME] injured his left hand and left ankle.  He broke his finger and tore the tendons’. Ankle was not broken.

The IP is employed by [Name] as a loft Insulation Installer. The IP and his work colleague were in the process of unloading and loading rolls of insulation material from their vehicle into the customers property. The route they had to take included walking through the property up the stairs and into a bedroom, which is where the loft hatch was located in a cupboard.Whilst the IP was carrying a roll of insulation on his right shoulder holding the roll steady with his right hand he had to manoeuvre around an overhead obstruction. It was during this process that the roll of insulation on his shoulder fell and whilst trying to steady the roll as it fell, his right wrist was forced back.Immediately after he felt some discomfort in the wrist and rested for a short while. After resting for a few minutes he felt able to continue with his work and completed the days work at around 5pm. It was during the evening whilst at rest that his wrist started to swell and ache. He attended the local A&E hospital at [Name] that evening [DATE] where his wrist was x-rayed. The IP reported the injury to [Name] accident/incident report line on [DATE] where it was confirmed he had sustained a fracture to the Scaphoid bone in his right wrist

A sub contractor was working for [NAME] at the address detailed above . [NAME] were working for [NAME]  via the main contractor , [NAME] . Our sub contractor needed to access the loft so obtained a suitable ladder to gain access . On lifting the loft hatch he found that it was very heavy and did not have means to be supported whilst open . He therefore climbed down again but on closing the hatch , it became to heavy to support and it dropped onto the back of his head . He had no restriction of movement at the time and carried on with work for the rest of the day . Over the weekend he began to experience pain with movement of his neck . He came into work on the morning of [NAME] 11th [NAME] but left early and went into [NAME] hospital that evening . The hospital staff took x-rays , which were inclonclusive . They later carried out an MRI scan and found that there was a fractured vertebrae between C5 and C6 and minor disc bulges from C5-C7 . He left hospital on [NAME] but is required to wear a neck collar for 6-weeks . We have a written report from the sub contractor and a copy of the hospital report .

Whilst performing a mid-air shift of an access cradle the independant Skylock appears to have failed causing the cradle to fall 4/5 feet . Due to the cradle falling the operative within the cradle was injured from the sudden impact to a hard surface ( roof ) , the operative stayed within the cradle . The weather conditions were calm and dry and there was no report of any other factor causing the incident . The equipment was used on site for number of weeks prior to this date and had been involved in multiplie mid-air shifts during this period . A mid-air shift is a standard industry activity and those involved had performed in on numerous occassions . The equipment in question has been verified as maintained and was taken back for independant assessment once it had been removed from the scene .We are currently reviewing our process of mid-air shift in light of the incident and once we have agreed improvements we will take them to the industry board of which we are members and communicate our learnings to them .

description: Amendment to Incident Reference Number ####. I am the person involved in the accident and wish to report information missing from the original report . I have only just returned to work and seen the report . I was stepping over a two foot wall carrying a leaf blower . There was an electrical extension lead draped over the wall running from Plot 6 to Plot 5 . There was a water sprinkler in the garden of Plot 6 , placed by the site manager , which was spraying up to , and over , the wall . As I stepped over the wall the water started to land on me and as my trailing left foot came over the wall it became entangled in the electrical cable . I lost my balance and fell to my right hand side . My right foot was tight against the wall and as my body twisted the foot did not , resulting in a double fracture of the ankle .

Re-roofing works are taking place at the property . 2 Parts of a 6 part scaffolding refuse chute had been left in the front garden at  <NAME> <NAME> by scaffolding sub-contractor to be used at a later date , the grandaughter of the tenant who is a child , ran towards the front door of the back to back property , part of the chute had been allegedly left in the walkway and the child tripped over the object , causing a fracture to the ball joint of the elbow . Nobody was working on site at the time of the incident . The sub-contractors method statement states that 'when not in use all materials must be removed from site ' . The sub-contractor insists the chute was left secure by operatives , but on this occasion they did not follow the method statement and remove the offending object from site . Work process has now been changed so that any chutes are stored at the principle contractors ( <NAME> ) depot when not in use . The sub-contractor has been interviewed following the incident and a tool box talk is to take place on housekeeping and following safe working practices .

He had removed the fixed covering boards and was in the process of removing two , temporary , fixed joists , when he over-balanced and fell to the ground floor below .

<NAME> <NAME> <NAME>  was working on the installation of the Cold Feed section of an Asphalt plant installation when the incident occurred . An operative was lifting a grid weighing approximately 250kg onto the cold feed hopper which is approximately 4.5m in height from the ground level using a telescopic handler . During this operation the telescopic handler turned over trapping the operator in the cab of the machine with his feet trapped under the cab . A witness statement reports that the operative tried to pull himself up by holding onto the steering wheel as the telehandler was falling.A tool box talk was delivered to all <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> employees at the site on the safe use of telehandlers and MEWPS on <NAME> by the MD of the company .Risk assessments for telehandler has been amended . The same tool box talk will be delivered to all <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> employees currently working elsewhere . The director of <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> has concluded that on future projects , these components will be installed by use of a mobile crane rather than a telehandler . Daily risk assessments forms are currently under a full review .

3 <NAME> qualified scaffold operatives were dismantling a 5 lift scaffold . All operatives were wearing full PPE including gloves . It was not raining at the time , but it had been raining that morning , therefore all scaffolding equipment was damp . The scaffold foreman ( [Name] ) was dismantling the top lift of scaffolding , and passing equipment down to the 2nd fixer ( <NAME> <NAME> ) who was on the 3rd lift . The labourer ( <NAME> <NAME> ) was on the ground at the bottom of the scaffold . <NAME> <NAME> passed a 13ft scaffold board down from the 3rd lift to <NAME> <NAME> . The 13ft scaffold board slipped out of <NAME> <NAME> 's hand as he was passing it down to <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> was able to catch the board , however in doing so he brought his hand down on top of a 5ft scaffold tube , which was standing upright against a small mental fence . <NAME> had been leaning these tubes up against the fence during the dismantling process . <NAME> ' hand was crushed between the 5ft scaffold tube and the 13ft scaffold board . Immediately after the injury was sustained , <NAME> and <NAME> both climbed safely down from the scaffold to assess what had happened . <NAME> called <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> 's offices to explain what had happened , and suggested an ambulance was called . The ambulance was called immediately and arrived within 20 minutes of the incident . <NAME> was taken by ambulance to <NAME> <NAME> 's <NAME> , where it was determined that he had sustained damage to his index finger on his right hand , which required an operation .

As undertaking the breaking out the breaker slips as a section of the concrete has been released , the operative has started to topple forward with the momentum of the breaker and was able to safely push clear the breaker and then looked to jump down from the ledge . Upon landing on the apron the operative twisted ankle and broke ankle . Ambulance was called and treated on site , then taken to hospital .

DP was self employed electrician using a stepladder to replace light bulbs. DP jumped or fell from the step ladder and suffered a fractured ankle. Following surgery and recovery, DP suffered complications, was readmitted to hospital two months later and died from a deep vein thrombosis and embolism. Inquest cited work related injury as contributing cause of death.

Two operatives were carrying out exploratory works to an existing culvert. Water flow had been dammed and overpumping in progress. Existing stone arch culvert some 2.5m high had previously been repaired by inserting a 1.2m diameter UPVC pipe through culvert, void backfilled and ends closed off by blockwork around and above UPVC pipe. Using an electric 110v drill with isolated generator ( all wiring pinned above water level with no opportunity for contact with any flows ) the operatives were carefully breaking out single blocks to establish extent and nature of the previous stopping up works. With no warning a section of masonry broke free pivoted on top of the UPVC pipe and fell on to the lower limbs of one of the operative trapping him on the burn bed.

The main activity was an excavation to allow a new water main connection by others . The trench sheets used to shore the excavation were being extracted on completion of backfilling the excavation and stacked at an adjacent area to allow removal by the supplier . The trench sheets were extracted by the mechanical excavator using a proprietary shackle for removing trench sheets . One of the operatives assisting with the operation held the trench sheet in place on top of the stack of previously laid trench sheets and as the trench sheet was being lowered onto the stack , it slipped and struck the operative on his right foot . The process for carrying out this operation was altered , removingthe need for anyone to guide the trench sheets into position .

While cutting grass to the front of the property , the ped mower became wedged between the front wall and the boundary fence . In an effort to free the wedged ped mower <NAME> <NAME> placed his hands underneath the body of the ped mower to move it thinking the mower had turned off , the still rotating blades struck his left hand.  <NAME> had been fully trained in the use of the ped mower during his Induction and instructed not to place hands or feet ( or anything else ) underneath the mower whilst still in operation . Additionally , stickers are in place and clearly visible on all machinery , reinforcing this message . Action taken:  to avoid similar Incidents 1 . All contract managers and Supervisors to use <NAME> accident as an example to illustrate to new starters during induction the dangers of not ensuring machinery turned off before moving or examining underneath , as well as paying full attention to the job in hand at all times . 2. Toolbox Talk delivered immediately to all staff highlighting accident . 3.Accident will be highlighted and discussed in <NAME> compliance bulletin , to reinforce message .

The writer was called to a vehicle on the rear yard and one of the demolition workers asked for a bandage . He had a bloodied toe and said that a piece of timber had fallen down onto his foot . Because of the liklihood of stitches and tetanus injection I told his co-workers to take him straight to A&E for treatment . On  <NAME> I was able to speak to him again and get further details of the injury . He now says that he had put one foot on the side (outside ) of a scissor lift to reach in for a crowbar and as he lifted the crowbar out either his elbow or the crowbar hit the lift control whereby the scissor lift lowered trapping his toe . The IP has safety shoes but was not wearing them . The company carrying out the demolition is <NAME> <NAME> who are independently contracted for all aspects of the demolition process and the IP is an employee . The toe was fractured in a number of places and the nail removed then replaced . This will be an over 7 day injury hence reportable under RIDDOR and the report is made by <NAME> as being "in control of premises " . Please note : the injury is "over 7 day " not "major " but I have had to tick the "major " box to get this report through to you - it would not let me select over 7 day . I have spoken to your helpline who advised me to complete the form in that manner

The IP was going to erect goal posts for the overhead cables on the site . Weather conditions were wet . The goal post stands were at the rear of the ford transit vehicle . Other equipment and materials were in the back of the vehicle , including a manhole cover which was leaning against three cut-out plates . As the IP opened the tailboard to get the goal post stands , the manhole cover slipped from the back of the vehicle and landed on the IP's foot . The IP was wearing steel toe cap safety boots but the weight and size of the manhole cover still fractured three of his metatarsal 's . The IP attended hospital where x-rays confirmed the fractures . He returned to his doctor seven days after the incident and the doctor signed him off for a further seven days . A full investigation is ongoing in to the incident to identify the root causes of the incident and the necessary corrective and preventative actions .

<NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> were working in a courtyard area ( <NAME> <NAME> ) where there were several other trades working within the area , <NAME> <NAME> attracted the <NAME> attention who was working on a 5 ton 360 excavator , he was excavating a tree pit within the hard standing area . <NAME> acknowledged [Name] and stopped the excavator and motioned for him to approach . They discussed the job in hand and agreed a course of action for the next process of the works . <NAME> then turned away to move away from the machine and <NAME> turned the excavator back on to continue the job , <NAME> then proceeded to inch the machine forwards to get closer to the pile of topsoil unfortunately the machine was turned the other way around the in relation to the controls and <NAME> backed up onto <NAME> foot . Once the attention had been raised by <NAME> that the machine was on his foot <NAME> moved the machine forward and turned the machine off and then lent assistance to his colleague.They proceeded to the site office to report the injury to the first aider and fill in the accident book , <NAME> left <NAME> in the first aiders office and proceeded to the work area to secure the machines to be left overnight , <NAME> then on the first aiders advice drove <NAME> to the local A+E department . <NAME> had an x-ray at <NAME> <NAME> and was informed he has fractured a metatarsal and has hairline fractures in 2 others ; <NAME> was offered a cast but refused as he felt it would heal quicker without it .Once <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> was aware of the incident involving our employees we carried out an accident investigation into the incident and got witness statements from the two employees involved , <NAME> witness statement was completed the following day , however due to <NAME> resting we did not get an opportunity to get his statement for another 7 days . <NAME> also intends to start back to work on <NAME> on light duties ( mowing grass etc. )Following our investigation into the incident [Name] has come to the conclusion that <NAME> did not properly assess the working area prior to using the machine due to <NAME> was still in the strike area for the machine , <NAME> will need further training on awareness when working machinery on a construction site and intend to book him in for a refresher course ASAP.

The injured person was one person in a two person crew which had been installing roadstuds on the [NAME] motorway . The work had been completed and the crew members were securing the hydraulic stabiliser legs of the lorry with steel pins before travelling home .The injured person dropped one of the leg pins on the road and picked it up again . He then put his left index finger in the hole where the pin goes . At the same time , the machine operator moved the hydraulic leg control lever which trapped the injured person 's finger end with a shearing motion . This action cut the skin off his finger end . The injured person was in possession of the correct safety gloves but was not wearing them as specified .Operatives have had a toolbox talk about the accident , operation of this type of machinery and wearing the correct PPE.  Warning signs have been affixed to the equipment . The company is looking at a method of shielding the operatives from the leg securing pin holes .

While removing section of tiling and plasterboard from metal studwork in shower one section came away from studwork quicker than anticipated , this section of tiles and plasterboard caught our employee across the back of his gloved right hand , the tiling cut through the glove and into his hand making a 1cm cut onto a tendon .

The employee was operating a FLiP SAW whilst the saw was on the back of the van and the employee was standing on the ground , causing the saw to be at chest/shoulder height . The employee was trimming a piece of MFC infill board . The saw guard was not in place . When the cutting of the object was complete , the employee reached across the saw to pick up the required piece of board without isolating the power to the saw and his right hand came into contact with the cutting blade . He received lacerations to the fore finger and middle finger of his right hand . The injuries required immediate medical attention ( first aid provided by a work colleague who was present ) and an operation was carried out to repair some nerve damage to the fore finger . The prognosis is for a full and timely recovery .An external health & safety officer has undertaken a full investigation into the incident , including statements from the injured party and his work colleague . The H & S officer has also carried out a full review of our internal health and safety procedures and has provided revision training to line managers and staff . reminder posters have been posted in all loading bays (visible to all fitting teams ) and all saw users have been individually spoken with in respect of best practice to minimise risk . A back-up supply of saw guards has been sourced so that there should never be an incident of a guard not being available should one be damaged or removed . The monthly inspections of portable electrical tools is continuing , but with an increased emphasis on closer inspection of the tools combined with questioning the allocated user in relation to any issues they may have experienced .
Trimming back damp proofing with a Stanley knife when the knife slipped causing a cut between the thumb and index finger of the left hand require hospital treatment and a subsequent operation .

[NAME] was using a chop saw to cut 4x2 for propping the gaurd on the chop saw failed to return and [NAME] put his hand under the saw it caught him on the top of his let hand causing a 10mm x 100mm deep cut he was taken to hospital where he was x-rayed and found no permanent damage was done he received x seven stitches , on my return i removed the chop saw and will take it to a repair shop , My men on site failed to inform me of the faulty spring although the chop saw was only a few months old ,at our next tool box talk they will be told to report any equipment faults or defects as they arise and to not use them

The injured person was working on the installation of a new boiler and five raidiators and associated pipework ,all exposed pipework to be encapsulted with plastic truncking.The injured person had been instructed to fit the truncking to the pipework whlie undertaking this task he sustained a cut to his hand between his thumb and finger ,he was using a stanley knife to perform this task . Our employee was installing composite panels on a roof area when while he was walking past a pack of panels he caught his hand on the corner of a panel , the sharp edge of the panel sliced through his finger causing a deep cut to the finger , our employee at the time was not wearing his gloves that are mandatory on site .
