He was advised by the hospital not to attend work for 10 days as the stitches would need this time to heal the wound .

On the morning of [Date] [NAME] & myself were erecting a steel frame building supplied by another supplier.We were first erecting the columns which were 152 x 152 x 37kg universal columns aprox 6m in height. A-Lift cranes were contracted slinger banksmen / lift supervisors & appointed persons.Their banksman had lifted a column with a single chain sling & had inserted a piece of timber to prevent chain slip.The column was lowered successfully onto its pre set holding down bolts . I was positions in a MEWP & was stabilising the top of the column . [NAME] was crouched at the base of the column applying the nuts to the holding down bolts.The banksman was to the side of the column & the crane driver had a good clear view of the processes.It later became apparent that the crane driver leant forward to adjust his shoe in the downtime while nuts were being added , in doing so he knocked a lever ( rope down or jib down ). I did not see any considerable movement in the chain but there was enough to release the timber causing it to slide down the column face . The timber was aprox 2" x 1.5 " x 24 " long & was on the back face of the column from where [NAME] was crouched.This struck the "fleshy pad " on [NAME] 's left thumb & removed a section of flesh. [Name] was conscious & able to move so was taken to [NAME] [NAME]  A & E , he was later referred to [NAME] [NAME] where he spent the night then late on [NAME] received treatment . He received a fracture to the end of the thumb & has lost a section of flesh , but is expected to make a full recovery . He will be off work for at least a few weeks .There are 2 other methods of lifting column sections which we will insist on being applied when lifting for us , a round sling could be used in a "bite " or a double wraped chain could be applied

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: [NAME] was cutting some ties that were holding bundles of mesh together and slipped on the mesh while holding a stihl saw . One foot came off the mesh and the saw fell back on him cutting him above the knee on his left leg .
<NAME> <NAME> was carrying part of the fire surround and it broke into two pieces resulting in one piece deeply cutting two sections of his left arm .

Injured person was digging a hole with a long handled shovel. The shovel  has a T handle. A work colleague was also digging a hole in close proximity with a similar shovel, As the injured person pulled his shovel out of the hole his colleague was chopping his shovel into the ground. The injury was caused by the hand being trapped between the T Handles on both shovels.

The IP is employed as a Regional Handyman . He was working at the <NAME> Depot on a minor works project to extend and re-fit an office . He was putting some waste into the skip and as he brought his hand out of the skip he caught the back of it on a discarded light fitting , sustaining a deep cut . He received first aid treatment at the depot and was taken to hospital where he was told he has severed a tendon and will require an operation to re-attach it on  <NAME>. At the time of the incident , he was not wearing gloves , although gloves are readily available and staff are told to wear protective gloves whenever there is a risk of sustaining cuts or puncture wounds .
The IP was using a disc cutter to cut scaffold tube into smaller pieces for the purpose of transportation down an internal staircase when the cutter slipped causing a laceration to his ankle .
Ip was marking out a door check using a stanley knife. Knife slipped and cut ip left hand
boiler case slipped cutting finger

I/P states that he was stuck on the head by a falling scaffold board , however this cannot be confirmed . After investigation it ca n't be identified how a scaffold board could fall into this area and therefore the exact cause of the incident is still unknown .

During delivery of bulk building materials utilising HI Ab the operator offloaded a pack of building blocks . On returning the crane to unload another pack the builder approached the crane grab from behind the driver and entered the area of the crane grab. On entering the operators line of sight and the danger zone the operator stopped the movement of the grab and suspended the operation . In stopping the operation quickly due the builder continuing to approach the area ,this caused the grab on the crane to swing from side to side . The grab then came into contact with the builder . All drivers have been made aware of the incident and to ensure working area is clear of persons before any operation is carried out . All drivers advise any workers to stay clear of the vehicle at all times when arriving on site and before any off loading commences these actions are already company proceedure. A risk assessment is in place for this activity and all drivers have full indipendant training. Risk assessments will be re visited with all operators. A full investigation has been carried out with the driver and details have been documented and recorded including a diagram of the incident. The accident has also been entered into the branch accident book and reported .
Employee was cleaning his plastering trowel when his hand slipped causing a deep cut to the back of his thumb . The injury was cleaned and dressed and employee was taken to hospital .

The scope of works for this project comprises the renewal of kitchen & fitting of over-bath showers with redecoration and upgrades to the electrics.  <NAME> had worked elsewhere on the scheme but only in this specific property that morning . At the time of the incident , <NAME> was descending the stairs and caught his foot on the nose of stair tread approx . five steps up from the bottom . He was not carrying any tools or equipment at the time  <NAME> ( Electrician , <NAME> ) was working in the kitchen upstairs when he heard <NAME> shout out . <NAME> went to the top of the stairs and asked <NAME> if he was alright , <NAME> replied that he had falled . <NAME> descended the stairs and asked if <NAME> had banged his head , to which IP replied that he had hurt his elbow and knee . <NAME> checked <NAME> elbow , which seemed OK and was capable of movement . IP then rolled his trouser leg up and a large gash became visible . <NAME> shouted to another passing operative to contact <NAME> <NAME> , site supervisor , immediately.  <NAME> <NAME> ( joiner , <NAME> ) was walking past the entrance to the property and noticed <NAME>  laying on the floor , then heard <NAME>  asking for help in contacting  <NAME> , which <NAME>  did.  <NAME> attended the property within minutes and , with <NAME> help , carried IP to the site welfare vehicle parked nearby . <NAME> then administered first aid but , due the depth of the gash , took IP to <NAME> <NAME> infirmary for further attention . When being attended to , it was discovered that there had been some damaged to IP's tendon , a further appointment was made and minor surgery carried out the following day . IP was not kept in hospital but discharged on both occasions for recuperation at home .

Operative was instructed to cut a wedge to help with roofing . Operative was instructed to use a skill saw with timber fixed to a work bench = two handed operation . This was unsucsessful . Operative decided to use chop saw and held back guard contrary to instruction . Blade pulled wood and hand in to saw . Blade created severe laceration to the top of the left hand .

While positioning structural steelwork , a steel plate slipped off of the top of another beam , causing a slicing action between the steel plate and the wall . Causing one of the operatives fingers to become partially severed and another to be crushed

Whilst erecting a steel column with the use of a mobile crane the IP was trying to position the 4 holes in the base plate of the column over the four holding down bolts in the foundation . Whilst attempting this he located three bolts and was trying to locate the last bolt so the column could be lowered off and tightened down , the IP could only access one side of this base area so he was trying to bar the column across , the last bolt located , the column dropped and trapped the bar slapping it onto the adjacent ground which was higher than the top of the foundation trapping the IP fingers.To prevent similar accidents occurring operatives should have unobstructed access around 360 degrees of the column base , with the ground level with the foundation top . Holding down bolts should have free movement within the cone cast in the concrete , it should be checked that the crane has not released too much weight and a longer bar would be advised .

My operative was tasked with the repair and painting of the ceiling soffits around the perimeter of the ceiling areas on both the ground and first floor of the sales area , my operative was repairing the soffit on his stepladders when he fell . I am currently putting together a Toolbox Talk on the use of stepladders that will be delivered to all my employees by my supervisor to raise awareness of the use of stepladders .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Laying bricks on scaffold , the scaffold pole was sticking up by 18 inches with no cap on , walking backwards and hit the pole casuing a nasty cut , site agent took to hospital - eleven stiches was administered .
drilling on worktop for a washing machine socket when the bit lost it 's guide hole and made contact with left hand index finger .
IP working on a ladder stretching and reaching to a work area, ladder gives way and IP tried to hold onto MF ceiling frame to limit the fall injuring his hand.
Operative discussing progress of works with site manager in site office. Gust of wind forced the site door shut onto his left thumb.Door now to be secured open
Was cutting insulation sheets to size and when adjusting his footing , the knife slipped and made contact with his ( R )hand at the base of his thumb pad to wrist
Whilst cutting a upvc soffit board with a battery saw, the saw blade came into contact with fingers of the left hand holding   the soffit board which was being cut down in width.
<NAME> had been carrying out soundcoat plastering with his father . When they had finished he was cleaning the machine and cut his finger .

IP was rendering the top part of a reveal around the door of the property using a small hop-up . IP stepped back and lost his footing and fell with his trowel and landed on the trowel causing a laceration to right wrist area . Managers/supervision to ensure extra care is taken when using hop-ups and communicate with operatives to ensure increased awareness when using this type of equipment .

<NAME> was cutting a timber noggin using a new hand saw. when pushing saw on downwards movement the saw jumped off timber and went down <NAME>'s thumb on his right hand which was holding the noggin on the bench.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The IP had attended site to rectify a fault . Having completed the task he made his way to leave site through an access gate in the site palisade perimeter fence ( 2.4m high ) . He could not close the gate as the top of it had become entangled in some netting that had been installed previously to prevent footballs from entering the site . The IP recalls attempting to untangle the netting by reaching up and whilst doing so , slipped and his hand came into contact with the top of the gate causing a laceration to the palm of his left hand . The IP administered first aid whilst his line manager called for an ambulance as IP was not fit to drive .

<NAME> <NAME> was cutting down two pieces of wood to get them on to the hoist , he was using a hand saw when it slipped out of the wood he was cutting and cut in to his thumb . Whilst carrying out the cutting activity <NAME> was using a metal hop up to support the timber

<NAME> was cutting a mdf board using a battery operated circular saw with his left hand and was holding the board vertically with his right ( he is right handed ) . When part of the mdf fell away <NAME> tried to catch the piece with his right hand which came into contact with the blade as the guard was to the rear .

Whilst moving a 4m x 200mm piece of wood from a pile on the scaffold to fix to the roof , a freak gust of wind caused the wood to smash my thumb against scaffold pole and severe the end off my thumb . From this incident we are in the process of reviewing our risk assessments and procedures for working on scaffolds/rooves in adverse weather conditions .

Erecting side steel plates on a new storage tank , wedges are used to raise or lower plate position and it was a wedge that was removed by an engineer who thought this was free but was n't so when he pulled out the wedge the plate dropped oprroximately 50mm catching his fingers .
While nailing pieces of timber together using a nail gun the nail slid off the knot and pierced back of right hand .

IP was asked to direct pedestrians while cabins were being delivered . The driver asked the IP to move spreader plate while he extended the the outrigger . IP caught middle two fingers of left hand under the speader board which resulted in injury to the fingers . IP was taken to hospital by the Site manager. He returned to hospital on the 20th [NAME] when he recieved stitches . He made subsequent visits to the Doctors and the hospital for check-ups and re-dressing and returned fully to work after 7 days . Action being taken are : Ensure that RAMS are up to date for all works the site labour are asked to do . Carry out a toolbox talk on site duties and individual tasks . Ensure the need to ensure that any person carrying out a task is aware of what is required of them and if there is a significant risk , that there is a method statement/risk assessment in place which has been read and understood . Ensure the company making the delivery that they need to be self-sufficient when it comes to replacing or removing cabins . They should not be asking for assistance with rigging of trucks or placing of cabins . Ensure that all methids of work used to rig and de-rig trucks and methods for placing cabins are described in the companies RAMS.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: At around 11:50am [Name] contacted the Duty manager via the radio and requested he attend the FCC room as he has trod on a nail and believed it had pierced his skin , the duty manager gathered the first aid kit and attended the FCC room to evaluate the injury , The nail had clearly pierced [NAME] skin however he confirmed that it had only pierced , The duty manager asked [NAME] if he was certain of this before we attempted to remove the shoe which he replied ‘’yes ’ ’ upon removing the shoe blood was clearly visible at the top of the base of the foot , The duty manager informed [Name] that he would perform first aid to the injured area which he politely declined and asked that he attend to it himself [Name] used an antiseptic wipe to on the injury and then applied a loose dressing , after this point the duty manager informed [Name] that he would need to attend a Hospital to have it properly cleaned due to the fact that it was a nail and this could cause potential decease if not treated properly . [Name] was offered the chance to use a taxi on our behalf but declined stating he wished to drive instead .

Whilst removing existing timber and putty glazed window a piece of glass broke away and struck the left gloved hand of the injured party piercing the glove and damaging the tendons, tool box talks on ppe working with glass and risk assessment.

A small piece of wood fell off the top of a hoarding which was erected to separate the general public from the shop fitters internally installing the new building entrance the hoarding was inside the internal scaffold legs the piece of wood 500mm long by 75mm by 20mm struck a female pedestrian on the head causing some small injuries we stopped all internals works and assisted the lady as a precaution we got an ambulance and sent her to hospital our inspection immediately showed the piece of timber had come loose on the top of the hoarding over the doorway on the outside and struck the woman the carpenter internally was unaware he had caused any problem until one of the lads outside immediately alerted the site staff and sit agent as a result all work was suspended and a full site inspection of the hoarding and street scaffold was undertaken and will continue tomorrow morning i have called for a site meeting to review all site works in particular areas which involve work to the entrance of the building any additional protection to hoarding and scaffold protection including our method statements risk assessments our CPP with the help of our safety officer and CDM coordinator i am horrified this happened and will take every precaution to keep the general public and site staff safe Thankfully we have made contact with the lady this evening and she confirmed she is ok had a check up a small bandage and is being sent home .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: He stepped out of the back of the van onto the ground , a stanley blade was either stuck to the bottom of his boot from the van or embedded in the ground as he stepped down from the van . The blade penetrated into the heel . A compression bandage was applied & an ambulance was called . To prevent this accident happening again , it would be best to store all blades in a sharp objects container , also to purchase protective soled work boots with carbon plate .
Whilst using a hand saw to cut a piece of timber , the saw slipped and accidentally cut the employees hand
Battening and felting roof using nail gun and somehow shot a nail into his thumb.
IP was team-lifting a stone window cill into position . He tried to slide the cill into position on his own and trapped his finger .

Worker was cutting timber with a hand saw , the jumped in the timber which then cut his left hand in which he was holding the timber . No gloves were being worn at the time he was cutting the timber , action taken is a tool box talk regarding working in a safe manner and the wearing of gloves when working on construction sites .

General joinery works were been undertaken to the empty property to upgrade the dwelling before being released for rent . However , the injury occurred when cutting cover mould to size with a hand saw . The PVC cover mould was to finish off the window reveals internally . Cutting of the mould was undertaken in the kitchen/dinning room .Lighting was adequate with ample space and no site based hazards to contribute to the injury . As stated the property was empty with the only the IP and 1 other operative . The cover mould was been cut with a hand saw and rested for support on 2 hop ups and a tool box as the cut progressed.The incident occurred when the handsaw snagged and jumped out of the cut , cutting the IP left hand that was been utilised to hold the material steady . The IP was taken to the hospital by the operative where he received medical treatment and stitches to the top of the hand between the index knuckle and thumb knuckle . It was identified that no gloves or clamps to secure the pvc moulding were been utilised during the operation as the IP assessed the task and made the decision neither would be required.After investigating , the IP did not have a set of clamps with them on the day . <NAME> pay a monthly tool allowance of <NAME> to purchase , replace and maintain tools . <NAME> is a qualified joiner with 30 years experience .Actions to be taken by <NAME>. Review of the risk assessments and method statements to reduce the number of documents and improve the communication on information and instructions . This shall also include the review of use of gloves and glove types . Provide a list of hand tools required as a minimum that the employees are expected to provide and maintain within their tool allowance . ( Aprentices receive a tool kit and all power tools are supplied by <NAME> . It shall be communicated to the workforce at the next H & S team briefings that plastic PVC materials can be ordered and picked up from the stores to omit on site cutting of materials .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured person walked between a bund and a forward tipping dumper when it is believed that he slipped hitting his right leg and foot against the machine . When the dumper driver remounted his machine he observed the injured person on the ground . The injured person was helped to his feet and was taken from site for medical assistance .

<NAME> <NAME> is employed by <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> as a site manager , at the time of the incident he was fitting some key Clamp protection to prevent staff from coming into contact with <NAME> units ( Refrigeration Units for cold rooms ) . <NAME> was cutting the Key Clamp section with a 9 angle grinder when suddenly the blade began to break up causing the angle grinder to kick back and make contact with <NAME> right leg above the knee . <NAME> stopped work to check his injury which was around 50mm long . <NAME> completed the initial accident report form and e- mailed this to his line manager and myself . at around <NAME> <NAME> drove himself to the local A & E department <NAME> <NAME> where the wound was cleaned and dressed . <NAME> decided to travel home and re visit a hospital nearer his home the following day for the cut to be sutured , this was done the following day . I visited <NAME> following the accident to find out the circumstances and to see if we can prevent a re - occurrence of this type of incident . having looked at the incident I have decided to review our risk assessment for abrasive wheels to include the use of a metal chop saw to be procured in future . This will enable material such as this to be secured and cut safely as opposed to using an angle grinder where there is an increased risk of kick back re occurring . <NAME> has had abrasive wheel training in the past . Following this incident I plan to update our training matrix to include abrasive wheel refresher training .

Our on-call heating engineer was called to the property as the tenant , <NAME> <NAME> , had reported a heating fault .when the engineer arrived <NAME> <NAME> showed him to the kitchen where the boiler is located . The engineer set his toolbox directly to his side and after discussing the fault with <NAME> <NAME> she turned around to show the engineer the location of the time clock and walked into the toolbox cutting her right ankle . <NAME> <NAME> was taken to hospital by a neighbour at 23 :00 hours and was discharged to home at 01:00 hours on the  <NAME> .

TELEPHONE REPORTThe IP was nipping ceramic tiles by hand , cutting out cuts with his tool because the cuts were too small . The IP was resting the tile on a workbench using his hand to keep the tile steady whilst nipping small cuts off , as he was half-way through the tile it suddenly broke in half resulting in the tile slipping upwards into the IPs arm slicing into the left wrist . The IP called out to a colleague who attended and applied pressure to stem the bleeding and called for a first aider . The first aider called for an ambulance which took the IP to hospital .

The IP was walking on the 2nd floor to where the labourers were working . As the IP walked down the corridor a <NAME> <NAME> operative was forming a door way . As the <NAME> operative was installing the head to the door he lost grip on the head track and it swung downwards striking the operative on the right arm .
Whilst removing some guttering [NAME] 's hand slipped off the tool he was levering with causing his hand to strike the guttering and a cut to his thumb
Operative was fitting kitchen sink unit . Unit was upturned to mark out for placement and operative turned quickly and caught finger of exposed sharp underside edge .

[NAME] was emptying a skip into the main site skip with his hands and not wearing gloves at the time . There are 2 chains holding the skip that come down the middle and whilst tipping it should lock into place , . This didnt happen and whilst it was moving [NAME] finger got caught and got crushed . It was on his right hand the index finger .

On the [Date] at approx . 16 :25 whilst carrying out the grouting up of pali radice pile No. 109 at the [NAME] [NAME] site [NAME] contract No. [Name] , spanner man [NAME] was removing a 1 m length of casing with a weight of 65 kg ,.To do this the winch on the [NAME] drill rig , No. DR 22 is used with a LiftinGear vertical lift clamp with a SWL of 2000 kg ( AKA. Cam Lock ) . This was attached to the unscrewed length of casing by [NAME] and he then locked it in position . The drill head was removed up and to the side and [NAME] then gave the driller [NAME]  , the signal to lift the casing . Once the casing was lifted [NAME] then took hold of the base of the casing and pulled it towards him and clear of the rig . At this point the casing slipped out of the clamp and fell to the ground taking [NAME] hand down with it trapping it between the casing and the vice block . This caused a deep laceration to [NAME] right hand , ring finger . He initially thought he was ok until he removed his glove . He was taken to hospital .

The IP needed to gain access to the first floor in Plot 38. A staircase had been put in and he asked the carpenter whether the staircase was ok to use.  The carpenter advised that "yes, the staircase is propped and screwed down, just take it easy".  The IP was on the second to top step when the staircase slid down and hit the floor in one movement.  In order to prevent himself falling the IP reached out to grab at the landing floor when metal stud base rail had been fitted and sustained a deep gash to the index finger of his right hand, approx. 4.5 cm in length.  He also banged his head in the fall and sustained several abrasions on his left wrist.  He received first aid treatment from the site manager and drove himself to hospital on [Date] for further assessment.  He is currently off work and will not be able to return until his finger is healed and can bend it again.  In order to prevent similar accidents ocurring, access will be blocke to unauthorised personnel in areas where staircases are being fitted using barriers, warning signs will also be displayed to prevent operatives from accessing staircases that are only termporarily supported.
Laceration

Whilst planing an airing cupboard door with an electric planer the planer slipped off the edge of the door and came into contact with [NAME] 's finger , resulting in an injury to his third finger on his right hand .
IP was cutting a strip off plywood for new floor board when the hand saw jumped out causing cut injury to IP 's left thumb .

Roofing tiles had been sited on the property drive .On the evening of <NAME>  <NAME>  we were informed that a member of the family , daughter aged <NAME> , had tripped on the tiles and had sustained a cut to the face  which resulted in a visit to the hospital where the wound was 'glued' alleged that as she was making her way back towards the front door of the house she forgot  that the tiles were there and tripped over them . Whilst no exact timings of the incident are known it was approximately 10pm and dark , due to cloud cover , and the property does nt benefit from either street lighting or any external lights.The siting of the tiles in preparation of the reroofing of the property has been standard practice on this type of project for a number of years . The tiles are sited to maintain safe and unobstructed access/egress to the property as far as is reasonably practicable .The tiles are normally sited immediately prior to the reroof and arent in location for any length of time i.e . delivered and fitted within 2 days . On this occasion once the roof was stripped asbestos containing materials (ACMs ) were discovered and all work ceased . Consequently the tiles were left in location.This type of refurbishment project has been completed on over 1500 houses over the last 4 years and this is the first reported incident of this nature . All contractors involved in the project are approved by the client , <NAME> , and the PC . They are very experienced and competent tradesman and fully understand the need to maintain safe access , egress and use of the property by the tenants throughout the work .Every operative receives a full site health and safety induction and work consciously and respectful of the tenants needs and are subject to regular inspections and audits by both the client and principal contractor.Every property is subject to a full survey and the tenant is visited by the appointed Tenant Liaison Office (TLO) where the details of the project are confirmed , discussed and agreed . The tenant is also given the opportunity to discuss any special requirements , i .e . access to outbuildings , family concerns , disabilities etc and arrangements are made accordingly .Throughout the project the safety of the tenant , family and visitors to the property are of paramount importance and never knowingly put at risk . The tiles have been removed from the property . The working practices , particularly the siting of all materials and equipment within the property boundary , will be reviewed to include tighter controls and liaison with the tenant and agreement of the proposed position and arrangements to maintain safe , unobstructed access to both vehicles and pedestriansAll storage areas will have suitable barriers/restrictions in place to significantly reduce the risk of tripping or coming into contact with any materials and/or equipment .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Person in the incident was carrying with his work colleague a length of electrical trunking containment when he tripped and and fell on the trunking he was carrying and cut his wrist.
TELEPHONE REPORT The IP was cutting duct work overhead, the section fell and fell on to his fore arms, causing deep lacerations to both left and right forearms.
<NAME> was scribing the back of lengths of timber architrave with a hand held circular saw when it got caught on a knot in the timber , slipped and cut round the perimeter of his left thumb .
<NAME> was dismantling filing cabinets to remove from the basement area . A part of the cabinet slipped and caught <NAME> on the arm causing a laceration to his left arm and tendon damage .
Backfilling behind retaining wall when the top section failed resulting in partial collapse & fall of <NAME> <NAME> <NAME>

The IP was chipping at tiles as part of his work experience . He caught his finger on a sharp edge of a tile and cut his finger . At hospital the finger was stitched and splinted . A follow up appointment was made at <NAME> <NAME> 's Hospital to get the finger re  assessed . The IP may have possible tendon damage . The IP had " correct " PPE on at the time of the accident . He had the rest of the week off school . He is a pupil at : <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME>
Some blocks fell on his leg while outside the property

[NAME]  , injured his left eye when he was struck in the eye with a small nail when he removed a small section of carpet gripper approx . 30mm long with claw hammer . The injured person is a joiner and was carrying out joinery works when he noticed the piece of carpet gripper still attached to the existing floor that was preventing him installing timber over board . [NAME] has suggested that he placed end of the claw hammer under the gripper to remove and during this operation , the piece of gripper then sprang off and it is alleged that the nail that was holding it down hit him in the eye.The injured person has suggested that during the previous strip out of the carpet grippers from that area , that he had been wearing his safety glasses , however he had thought that all of the grippers had been removed so took them off . He then came across the small piece left in situ and forgot to put his safety glasses back on that were in his top pocket , he was not wearing his safety glasses when he was hit in the eye.The injure person visited A & E and was diagnosed with abrasion to his left eye . [NAME] was given antiseptic cream and told to rest .

Employee moving lightweight insulation material to top of container from low accessible side , said he fell off from other , full height , side , and caught his leg on metal window shutter causing a cut. Employee taken to hospital . Employee has a tendency to rush and has previously been advised by site manager not to jump off containers/walls , etc. to use ladders/access provided and to slow down and take care generally .

An operative for a sub-contractor planting plants in the plant beds , in cold weather , the ground was frozen in places . Using a fork to the break up the ground , he managed to drive the fork the wrong way round into his foot . One prong of the fork entered his boot between the steel toe cap and the laces . Actions taken : All staff and sub-contractors have been reminded through inductions and tool box talks on the correct use of hand tools and the correct maintenance of safety footwear .

IP was carrying out gutter and fascia replacement to a outhouse , and was cutting the plastic fascia with a battery powered saw . The saw had a fitted guard but snagged on the fascia causing the saw into contact with the IP finger causing injuries .

IP was clearing debri from the basement, this also included clearing derbi from underneath a non operating hoist. The ip was adjusting his hard hat when an object struck the ip on the back of head in the middle. The ip then climbed a ladder to seek first aid as his supervisor was at the top of the ladder on the first floor. The supervisor (from <NAME> <NAME>) then took the injured party to hospital, where the ip recieved first aid. The ip had a 4 inch gash to the back of his head in the middle. The ip's injury was glued together. I <NAME> have contacted hse today as i recieved a b176 form from the social with regards to the ip, where it asks if the incident was reported to the hse. 3d personnel was told this incident was reported by eight construction the client the ip was working for at the time of the incident. This was not the case as i (<NAME>) was informed by a lady i spoke with this afternoon. I asked advice from the lady i spoke with who said the incident needs to be reported which i am doing now.

The operative was moving the Gutter VAc System along approx 10yards when the main cylinder causing cut/laceration left index finger. Toolbox talks with all operatives has been held to insure safe handling of the equipment in the future.

<NAME> and other collegues sub contracted to <NAME> by <NAME> <NAME> were starting to dismantle the roller shutter door inside the entrance of G5 phase . They cut the bolts off the cylinder to remove the shutter drum . They then had to use another bolt to push the cut bolts through the holes of the steel end plate . When <NAME> got to the last bolt , it got stuck so he lifted the plate with his hand to release the pressure and push the last bolt through . When the last bolt fell out , the steel plate then spun around very quickly as it was spring loaded and caught <NAME> 's right hand causing injury. <NAME> was treated using first aid on site and then in <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> . He sustained 2 broken tendons and 1 cut tendon to his right hand .

Security officer refused entry to site to member of the public as they did not have authorisation and were under the influence of alcohol . The IC1 Male then assaulted the security officer striking him a number of times in the head and pushing him in to a door . This caused a cut above the officers eye and left him feeling dizzy .

The plumber has just climbed up to the third tread on a pair of step ladders approximately 500 mm from the ground , the steps are on firm level ground , he lost his balance and put out his left hand to steady himself . resulting him catching his left hand on metal ceiling track and cutting his hand between wrist and little finger on his left hand .he fell to the ground where his work colleague came over to assist him up and put on a temporary dressing . His work colleague took him to <NAME> <NAME> were he had his left hand stitched and was taken home after the hospital . The work colleague did not see the actual fall he only saw him on the floor with the cut left hand .
Whilst using a drill fitted with a hole saw to cut MDF the drill slipped and the hole saw cut into the IP 's left wrist

The injured party was stripping the sheath of a steel wired armour cable using a stanley knife whilst doing this the operative struck his lower arm with the stanley knife causing a laceration to the arm

An operative was changing a depleted blade on a hand held scraper . he put too much pressure on the handle and screwdriver in opposing hands not following written guidance and when both the screwdriver and blade handle slipped , a coming together of the two elements resulted in a severe cut to the hand .
Grinding stone shattered in angle grinder ( further investigation ongoing ) .

Whilst drilling a fixing tie for UPVC window , the durium drill bit snapped causing the drill machine to move forward and cut into the operatives left index finger , he continued working that day and the following day . On the <NAME> evening <NAME> whilst at home he felt the pain increase and decided to visit A and E at the <NAME> hospital <NAME> . He was examined and advised to return on the <NAME> morning of <NAME> where the daignosis was that he had a piece of his ppe glove inside at his tendon sheath which had been infected and they performed a surgical washout procedure to clear the infection and inserted 15 stitches to his wound . The operative was wearing his allocated PPE at the time of the incident .
hit thumb on saw blade while not looking what he was doing

The injured person was in the process of cutting a piece of steel beam on the band saw . The material was too short to reach the roller bed of the particular saw he was using . He needed to support the beam in order to press the control button and clamp the beam . He was forced to stretch across to reach the control button , and in doing so he was not concentrating on the position of his hand . When he pressed the control button his left thumb got caught and pinched the tip of his thumb off . The operator was using the incorrect piece of machinery as there is an alternative saw designed to cut material this length . The corrective action is to use the correct saw so that the material sits on the roller bed .

The employee was delivering window formers ( plastic formers that are built in to openings prior to windows being fitted at a later date ) . The tail lift was down on the back of the lorry . On the end of the tail lift there is a protective edge to prevent items falling off . The employee climbed out of the lorry on to the tail lift , the edge of the formers he was carrying caught the protective edge raising it slightly . When walking off the tail lift , the employee caught his left leg on the protective edge . This resulted in a cut requiring 9 stitches .

[NAME]  was trying to cut a bolt to reduce its length by holding it in his left hand with a pair of pliers and cutting it with his right hand using a hacksaw . The blade of the hacksaw bounced of the bolt onto his left hand cutting it on the back near his thumb . [NAME] was administered First Aid on site and taken to the [NAME] minor injuries treatment centre in [NAME] and after his assessment was made an appointment to return to the [NAME] the next day for further assessment . On investigation it was identified that he had not been wearing protective gloves as identified in the method statement which he had read and signed for or used the correct procedure when cutting a bolt down to size ( holding it in an appropriate vice , freeing his left hand while cutting it with a junior hacksaw ) . It was also noted that selection of appropriate sized bolts could have been used removing the need to cut down the bolt in the first place . Preventative actions to ensure this does not happen again is 1 . To retrain [NAME] [NAME] in Safe Working Procedure [Name] Use of Hacksaws and Risk Assessment  - Use of Hacksaws [NAME] and retraining in following the method statement and the wearing of PPE , 2. All other engineers on site to have tool box talk on the safe work procedure [Name and Risk assessment [NAME] . 3. Method statement review to all supervisors for all tasks before cutting is required is there an alternative if not then selection of correct equipment for the task . 4 . Using the accident record as part of the next [NAME] 's Health and Safety quaterly review meeting and disseminating the information on the lessons learned to everyone

Whilst removing a screwed brass fitting from a pressure valve , IP lost his grip on the unit . As the unit turned through his hand , a jagged edge cut through his R hand , resulting in a visit to hospital for treatment

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

[NAME] was erecting heras security fencing to the site boundary with two other collegues .  [NAME] and one of the work collegues were hanging a heras gate , they pushed the top onto the bolts , when they were putting the gate onto the bottom bolts it dropped approximately 2 inches which nipped [NAME] right hand palm . [NAME] reaction was to pull his hand away from where it was nipped , which thus tore his palm.  [NAME] stated that they could have lifted the gate back up to un-trap his palm , but his natural first reaction was to pull it away. Action taken : We have purchased heavier duty gloves, which are cut resistant and due to the reinforced palm covering a better grip will be maintained . A tool box talk has been arranged to discuss PPE and Manual handling
Working with colleague fitting new sash window . Colleague dropped sash window which hit injured party on the back of his head

IP and another operative were lifting a tool vault lit to gain access to tools held within . On attempting to close the lid It slipped from the hold of IP and trapped the tip of IP 's finger causing severe cut .

At approx 12.30 noon on <NAME> 2nd <NAME> while the IP was walking through an external access door into the break room at <NAME> yard the wind blew the door to trapping his finger between the door frame and the door . First aid was on site and attended at the point of report from the IP A deep cut to a finger on his hand was bandaged up to stem the bleeding . The IP was then taken to the A&E in <NAME> in a works van as the first Aider advised due to the cut depth. The IP then went to see his doctor who advised not to return to work for the rest of that week so as to keep the finger still and free of dirt while it was mending.This is the first accident and report that the door has become a hazard when the winds are high to blow the door too .

An operative was using a 4" grinder with a metal cutting disc in good working order to cut 10mm thick metal plates into smaller pieces to be used to pack the undersides of steel beams that were being installed. He had carried out 7 cuts and on the 8th cut, the grinder slipped and cut into his middle finger. He was using a tile cutting bench to cut the plates and had G clamps holding the plates on the bench. On investigation, we discovered that the 4" grinder had had its' side handle removed that made it more easy to use a single handed operation. It looks as though that rather than relocating the clamps to carry out the final cut, he used his left hand to hold the plate in place which was when the accident occurred.

The Injured Party was working on the ground flooor, cutting a plasterboard slightly above head height with a handsaw.  He slipped whilst cutting and the momentum took the saw over his left hand/thumb.
2 operatives were moving toughened glass panel from inside to the skip outside the main shutter , during transit the glass shattered and covered operatives hands with glass fragments .

Two year old boy stepped on to damaged aluminium / mild steel manhole cover ( 6oomm x 450mm ) and went down into it striking his chin on the manhole cover as it flipped back up at him causing a laceration to the right side of his chin / neck that required stitches at the local hospital . Fall depth was approximately 500mm .
ip was tightening a bolt on a windpost with a spanner . The spanner slipped and caught the thumb , causing cut to the tendon on top of the thumb .
While employee was cutting tile with knife in right hand he cut through his left finger and thumb .
100mm Core Drill which came loose, spun off drill and made contact with lower leg (shin)
electrician vut finger when using stanley type knife when cutting cable trunking .
using angle grinder , when it jammed in the wall and kicked back and hit the contractor in the stomach

I was drilling through a 3" x 3" timber post to make up shelves inside the container , - the wood 10mm drill bit came through the wood , - I had my hand too close to where the drill came out of the wood , and the drill bit caught on my glove and punctured my right hand between my thumb and index finger .

Operative was told over three times to rest the fence rail on the trestles to cut the corner off with the hand saw , operative repeatedly ignored this , he took another rail and when the incident happened he was holding the rail between his knees to saw the end off , slipped as the rail was unstable and sliced the bottom of his thumb open with the saw .
The injured person was curious on finding a ceramic electricity pylon insulator . On hitting it with a hammer a shard flew off hitting the back of his left hand by this 3rd finger .
Storage heater case became stuck , when pulled it slipped causing a cut to right hand middle finger
Plasterboard and metalwork wall was being cut with a grinder , whilst cutting the metal the grinder jumped and cut the back of the right hand .

While finishing installing a new hot water cylinder the IP fell backwards out of the cupboard , making contact at the shin with a small table . This caused a laceration of the shin to the extent that stiches were required . IP was signed off by GP for two weeks . We are investigating the accident and reviewing risk assessments around this task with particular regard to working spaces and the feasibility of moving potentially hazardous objects in close proximity to the work area before commencing .

Whilst using an 18V battery circular saw , the saw jammed and causing it to lurch forward out of the draft . All guards and guides were on. Causing injury to his left thumb and adjacent finger , and tissue between his thumb and finger .

The Injured Person  (IP) was fixing metal ceiling grids off a 2 step podium tower.As the IP stepped back onto the lowest step he slipped, stumbled and fell approx 300mm, causing his left shin to come into contact with the podium leg upright to the end of the step. The podium steps were not fixed into place by a locking mechanism and subject to lateral movement, the lower step tread was projecting minimal due to inward movement.This displacement of the step resulted in the foot slipping off it as not enough tread was present for a firm foot placement.The podium leg uprights were not protected with end caps.Podium in question quarantined until supplier inspects and confirms correct configuration/installation of steps, this is then to be briefed to operatives.All work platforms to be inspected daily and before first use by operatives, to ensure fit for use.TBT to all on safe use of lightweight working platforms.

Apprentice using a handsaw to cut a length of timber, cut across his own knuckle (left hand), caused deep laceration.   Environment was dry and bright no distractions apparent.  In conjunction with college will re-iterate safe use of handsaw, and general H&S.

While carrying out underwater operations to remove an anode the operative has sustained a crush injury to his hand , this occurred while investigating why the crane could not remove the anode , at this stage . The anode then suddenly became free resulting in the operatives hand being crushed .

Whilst installing timber blocks to form a herring bone parquet style floor surface , IP was using a mitre saw to cut the blocks to the correct size . During the operation of cutting the blocks he cut his knee with the mitre saw .
The IP was changing a tap for our Customer and had difficulty in removing a screw . The IP used his cordless 18v drill to drill the screw out and in doing so , slipped and drilled his finger .

Following a routine visual inspection of a blocked drain at the above named property , the IP was attacked by the tenants dog . The IP had attended the property earlier that day and carried out a piece of work to unblock the drains but was called back later on the same day as the drains had backed up . The IP was aware of dogs in the rear garden of the property on both occasions , but as the dogs had shown no signs of aggression (either earlier that day or prior to the attack ) and no warnings were provided by the tenant , the IP assumed their was no cause for concern . The dog attacked whilst the IP was inspecting a rear drainage outlet in the rear garden . In terms of remedial actions and prevention for recurrence , the following have /will be implemented : 1 ) Tool box talks to all operatives re : dealing with dangerous/aggresive dogs , 2 ) review of risk assessments , training packages , guidance and other documentation to ensure dogs/pets included , 3 ) Injunction to have dog removed/destroyed , 4 ) Warning markers on house files/systems for other persons who may visit the property , 5 ) Press release to all tenants re : the law , the action the organisation will take on tenants/dogs etc. , 6 ) re-communicate all guidance/information with regards dogs/pets .

a circular saw was being used and the guard got caught , went to move the guard and the saw came back onto the finger whilst still turning quite fast . now waiting for saw to stop fully before adjusting anything

<NAME> was inside the asbestos enclosure with his mask on , ready to remove asbestos (artex ) . He realised he needed to put a blade on his scraper and used a scredriver which he thought may be too wide to change his blade . He was trying to be quick as everyone else had started work . The screwdriver slipped and the blade went into the top of his knuckles , cutting his hand - depp cut with lots of blood . He went to the supervisor who instructed him to decontaminate ( having been in the asbestos enclosure ) . He did so , went outside of the area and the supervisor bandaged up his hand . Blood was still seeping through the bandage . <NAME> explained that he would carry on working however the supervisor on site insisted that he went to the nearest hopsital . He walked to the hospital where he was seen and was later asked to return to have hand operated on due to damaged tendons . A toolbox talk was given to all other workers on the site to ensure they understood the need for wearing gloves and the procedure in changing scraper blades .
Whilst taking down some racking , a piece of racking fell and struck the nose .

To reach the site entance there are 5 steps to double dooors approximatly 5 foot wide , these doors are locked at all times with hazard signage screwed to them . these doors are manned in the mornings when people arrive for work and when bringing in materials , when you walk through these doors there is another barrier and bollards resticting passage .while bringing in two rolls of insulation an elderly lady from the chinese restaurant climed the steps to the doors ,when entering the doors the operative manning the door told her that she was not allowed in and to leave , the lady turned to go back down the stairs and fell backwards falling on the barrier and banging the back of her head on the floor . I was called and immediatly got to the ground floor , I rang an ambulance and began to see if she was alright . The lady then tried to get up , at this point a person from the chinese restaurant came in and spoke to her , he helped her into a chair and we placed a large bandage on the cut on the back of her head .at which point the ambulance arrived . her daughter then came in from the restaurant and she was taken to hospital . We have today had our Health and Safety advisor <NAME> <NAME>  of <NAME> & <NAME>  and done a full audit of the site , we now have the security operative at the bottom of the stairs and not the top whilst unloading. I have been to the chinese restaurant and have been told thankfully that the lady is now fine .

The operative ( <NAME> <NAME> ) was removing a fence post by digging around the base . The injured party was cutting slab insulation on a table saw as part of a two man team . The injured party describes in the accident report that he had his hand in the wrong place , the saw blade came half way the thickness of the insulation sheet and nicked the palm of his hand .Our initial investigation of the incident has revealed that the injured party removed the guard from the table saw , we have reinforced with our employees that such an act is prohibited .

IP was kneeling on the floor cutting out a section of carpet when he cut his knee on something sharp (unknown ) . This caused a clean straight cut . The injured party works for a small subcontractor on site and had been working on site carrying out his work activity for some time without any incidents . Whilst transfering sheet metal cladding between 2 levels wearing PPE a gust of wind caught the sheet ( approximatly 2 meters square ) and caused it to slip and cut the wrist of the injured party between the gloved hand and long sleved outer clothing . Although PPE was being worn a review for wearing kevlar wrist/forarm protection is being considered by the injured party 's company as a review of PPE
putting crane feet used back onto the bed of the truck after use

Whilst checking the oil levels of a small 6 ton Forward tipping dumper whilst closing the engine casing trapped middlefinger in the hinged door crushing the end of the middle finger between the access panel and the engine surround .

Cutting through rubber seal for glass and has cut through the end of the finger causing a deep laseration which needed surgery . Gloves were worn but not protecting the end of fingers . Ensure that full protective gloves are worn in future .
On erecting steel columns , when positioning of columns to foundations , hand became trapped between the column and foundation resulting in injury to index finger and thumb on right hand .

Whilst passing double arm scaffold section up to the next lift (2nd) it slipped and fell back trapping the ips middle finger against the ledger. He was immediately given first aid by the site manager and taken to the lincolnshire county hospital. He is to attend <NAME> hospital <NAME> for further examination.

<NAME> <NAME> was erecting a triple section extension ladder at <NAME> <NAME> 's <NAME> <NAME> in preparation for installing a down spout . He was accompanied by a colleague , <NAME> <NAME>. The ground had recently been levelled at the request of the team following a call by <NAME> <NAME> to his contract manager , <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> and the involvement of the site manager. The team had extended the ladder and they were manoeuvring it into place : leaning it against the wall of the property . As they did so , the bottom left hand foot of the ladder slipped which caused the whole ladder to twist and resulting in the right hand side of the ladder lifting off the ground. <NAME> <NAME> immediately placed his foot onto the bottom rung of the ladder in an attempt to stabilise it but as he did so , the top section fell towards the ground , striking <NAME> <NAME> on the side of his head.Mr <NAME> was wearing a hard hat at the time of the accident and this reduced the severity of the injury but unfortunately , <NAME> <NAME> suffered a cut to the side of his head which , following a visit to <NAME> was glued into place.  <NAME> returned to his normal duties  <NAME>. The ladder in use was supplied by <NAME> 's plant hire and was in good condition and fit for purpose . The ladder supplied came equipped with an integral safety device which , when engaged by the operative , prevents the sections from becoming detached.  <NAME> <NAME> has planned to carry out tool box talks , refreshing the training for the team in ladder use and manual handling .

Containement building is clad internally on the walls and ceiling and due to the testing carried out in the building requires replacement one of the timber sleepers within the ceiling had been replaced and had not been secured correctly causing one end to dislodge swing down and catch the IP on the head

Whilst walking up garden path to knock on tenants front door as part of his work , the tenant 's dog bit the IP 's hand . This was dressed appropriately . when lifting a piece of slate , the employee trapped his finger between the slate and the pallet it was sitting on , causing loss of skin on index finger

Excavation to install and connect a road gulley to a surface water manhole ( SWMH 2 on plan ) had been carried out and [NAME], [NAME] and  [NAME] were tasked with lifting into place and fixing in concrete a pre-cast concrete gulley in the correct position prior to connection via clay drainage to the nearby manhole . The gulley was stropped and lifted into place with an 8.5 tonne excavator , using the bare hitch on the end of the boom arm. In order to set the final position and level of the gulley prior to final haunching and re-filling around the gulley , the 8t machine was used to hold the gulley whilst the levels were checked . This was achieved by positioning the bare hitch on the gulley top and applying pressure to hold it still . [NAME] then placed a level across the gully top to check the gulley was level , at which point the machine arm slipped ( i .e . Lost connection with the gulley top ) back towards the machine and made contact with  [NAME] hand and caused the injuries listed above .

Using hand-held electric planer to remove excess material from a door . Machine slipped and caught the middle finger of right hand , removing skin from end of finger .

As part of the soft stripping activities the IP was carrying a fire door to the storage area . The IP lowered door onto waste pile and as left hand raised it came into contact with something sharp , assuming small shard of broken glass and cut his finger . Angle grinder cutting disc shattered causing lacerations to hand despite full PPE being worn .

<NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> were in the <NAME> yard building to unload tools and equipment that would not be required on their next job . They got ready to remove a road saw from the pick-up with both taking up a position at either end of the machine . <NAME> had a purpose made handle fixed at his end and a guide bar was situated next to this handle . This guide bar should be pushed hard up to the body of the machine prior to lifting but this was not done . <NAME> reached around the guide bar and gripped the handle with his right hand and the guide bar was left resting against his chest . When they lifted the machine , the guide bar was forced forward by  <NAME>'s chest and this caused his right thumb to be caught between it ( the guide bar ) and the handle . This resulted in the tip of his thumb being crushed . Both operators immediately set the machine down It was realised the <NAME> was in need of medical assistance and <NAME> took him to the A & E department of <NAME> <NAME> hospital . His wounded thumb was cleaned and dressed and an appointment was made for him to return for further examination and treatment on <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> attended the hospital for his appointment on <NAME> <NAME> and his thumb was again cleaned and dressed . A further appointment to continue this treatment has been made for <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> returned to work on <NAME>  . INVESTIGATION1.There was no mechanical fault with the road saw . 2.The guide bar should be set firmly against the body of the road saw before lifting .3.The root cause of this accident was <NAME> not placing the guide bar against the body of the machine which would have prevented any movement in the guide bar . 4.Gloves had not been worn by <NAME> when the accident occurred , and though they would not have prevented the accident , the result would probably have been less severe .

the employee was cutting a small piece of skirting( 100mm x 250mm approx ) with a handsaw on a bench . He was attempting to scribe the bottom of the skirting to match the contours of the existing floor.To do this he needed to be cutting down the timber which in effect runs in line with the grain.The timber split as he was sawing and the momentum of the saw run across the back of the employees hand above the knuckles to the last and little finger.The employee is a time served joiner who has been working in all types of joinery environments since school . He is now 64 . He described this as a freak accident of which nothing of this nature has happened before .On the employees return to work we will discuss ways to avoid a recurrence of this nature

[NAME]  was undertaking the installation of Stainless steel RSAs secured by M20 blind bolts , one of the bolts extended past the nut and as it would clash with the brickwork it would need to be cut off . this was done with a petrol cut-off saw and it was during this process that the accident happened .  [NAME] was standing over and above the bolt that was being cut , whilst cutting the bolt with the disc cutter this caused the cut off thread to spin off and hit him in the shin.this was a one of operation but a repeat tool box talk wil / has been given on abrasive wheels and cutting
IP was using a stanley knife to open a tube of silicone . Injury sustained was a laceration between thumb and forefinger . Action taken - purchase of guillotine type toppers for silicone tubes .

Whilst operating the roadsweeper , the back doors would n't close and then went to investigate the problem . The pipework was leaking onto the floor and went to see why and where it was coming from . Suspected Hydraulic pipeline had a leak , put hand in handful of hoses to establish which hose had the leak and when it was found the pressure of the hose and leak meant the armoured covering of the hose split and broken into left hand thumb and filling of thumb with hydraulic oil .

26 <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> is recieving social housing upgrage works to the kitchen and bathroom . The kitchen floor had a laytex compound applied to it at approx 15 :00hrs , the tenant had been instructed not to enter the kitchen for the next 3-4 hrs , her washing machine had been placed in front of the doorway , blocking it to discourage anyone entering the room . At approx 16 :15hrs <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> ( IP ) - ( neighbour from No25 ) - entered <NAME> to give the tenant a newspaper , they discussed how well the works in the kitchen had been going , the IP passed by the washing machine blocking the door into the kitchen , she slipped on the wet surface , falling on to her right side , her spectacles causing an injury above her right eye . The IP and her husband left the property at approx 17;10hrs by taxi to go to the hospital , butterfly stiches were applied to the wound . The IP is active and has been about her normal business today .

The injured person was getting onto the ladder to get down from the scaffolding to go to the toilet when he lost his footing and fell down the ladder opening. He grabbed the hand rail to break his fall but it failed to support his full body weight and he fell to the ground. The scaffolding has been removed and a new ladder entry point constructed by the scaffolding contractor.

<NAME>  <NAME> at 13 :05, <NAME> <NAME> was working removing & re installing new fire doors as well as frames on the 8th floor lobby of <NAME>.  He was cutting down 3 inch x 1 inch timber architrave down the length whilst holding it on his saw bench .The rotating blade came into contact with his left thumb the blade cut through the top of his thumb , his tendons & fractured his bone .First aid was administered at the site office , <NAME> was then taken to coventry hospital in by the site manager & our site supervisor . <NAME> was dressed at hospital then asked to return to the <NAME> hospital <NAME> , for surgery on his thumb to repair the fracture & damaged tendons from the cut.We immediatley investigated the incident & stopped use of circular saws . Installer was strapping glass units to an A frame . He was manually tightening the strap when his hand slipped and ran across the top of the glass units . This caused the laceration to his finger .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Egressing a working platform ( podium ) and coming down the three acess steps ( backwards as you would a ladder ) when on the bottom rung foot slipped from the rung causing the operative to hit his shin on the end of the rung ) . The conditions were dry and the operative was wearing safety footwear . The podium was inspected and has a non slip surface on the rungs . The lighting in the work area was sufficient . The operative hit his shin on the podium step and sustained a small 10mm gouge on shin . The operative carried on working and did not report . The company was only made aware of the incident by the operative <NAME> due to complications developing to the site of the original injury . On <NAME> the operative was signed off work for 6 weeks due to the complications and this triggered the RIDDOR report.Once the company was made aware of the injury on <NAME>  a full investigation was undertaken and toolbox talks given to staff to reiterate the need to report all injuries .

One of our employees a  <NAME> was carrying out maintenance work to remove a cracked porcelain sink from a void property en-suite shower room , that is owned by  <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> was clearing up after himself and was lifting small pieces of broken porcelain from the floor when he caught the back of his hand on a jagged piece of broken hand basin that was still attached to the wall . <NAME> <NAME> noticed that there was a lot of blood coming from the back of his hand and cleaned himself up . On his drive home he noticed that one of his fingers was not moving correctly so attended the Accident and Emergency department at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME>.  The hospital diagnosed that <NAME> <NAME> had suffered a severed a tendon to his finger and had to undergo surgery to repair the severed tendon .

The operative ( injured person ) was commencing de-tenting an asbestos removal enclosure . Immediately prior to this the operative put a new blade on his stanley knife in preparation for the activity . The operative is right handed and inserted the stanley knife blade into the 1000 gauge polythene sheeting , he started to cut from right to left , his left hand was holding the framework of the enclosure . Due to the sharpness of the brand new blade the physical effort was excessive and as such the blade travelled extremely rapidly from right to left . Consequently the blade of the stanley knife struck the operatives left hand which due to the circumstances was held quite rigidly . The blade therefore penetrated the skin and took a slither right underneath the skin creating a crescent shaped injury across the topside of the left hand.The health & safety manager has instructed an external consultant to fully investigate the incident and make appropriate recommendations . The final report as yet is not complete and will follow shortly , however , initially the following actions are considered to be likely recommendations  1 ) Review of relevant aspects of existing risk assessment , policy and procedure . 2 ) The workforce will be engaged around the use of alternative hand tools such as scissors , safety knives , or other available safety cutting devices . 3 ) The possibility of using more effective PPE will be considered , once all actions are determined all site teams including contract Managers and site Supervisors will be aggressively briefed ( [Name] ) as regards new procedures , equipment and techniques etc . This will be further supported by the introduction of a specific toolbox talk to complement the existing suite of toolbox talks . To ensure effective change is achieved at site level if necessary , a knife amnesty will be held .

The accident was caused when work was being carried out to remove a breaker attachment from the arm of an excavator . After releasing the front pin ( manually ) , the angle of the excavator arm was such that the breaker was allowed to swing with sufficient momentum that it de-coupled itself from the remaining rear securing pin whereby it then fell to the ground striking the injured party 's foot causing a laceration .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The operative accidentally stood on some A393 mesh he had previously placed down ready for installation into a small concrete pad . One end of the A393 mat raised of the ground and subsequently cut the operatives leg

Operative was given the task of removing a protective film from a metal flashing . To help in grabbing hold of protective film a glove was removed . Whilst peeling film from flashing his right hand slipped and edge of metal flashing cut the right hand between thumb & palm .We have subsequently reviewed the type of glove issued and have now provided a 'fingerless ' type glove which is only to be worn during this particular task .
IP was working from a 600mm high aluminium work platform putting insulation in the ceiling . He overstreched and fell off the work platform catching his hand on the platform
cut to finger whilst using a battery oreated circular saw.employee is banned from using circular saw to cut roofing battens. all employees are asked to use cut grade gloves for all sawing operations.

The IP was working on a mobile drill rig  (Commachio GEO305) , drilling boreholes as part as a site investigation to provide geotechnical data . As the IP was trying to remove the sample shoe from a 113mm dynamic sample barrel on completion of a sample run using a Pioneer 2 Drill . The sample barrel was placed on the drill string trestles and secured just in front of the barrel’s shoe with a set of long handled chain wrenches . The IP used an adjustable pipe wrench to loosen the shoe , however the thread was stuck fast . As he applied additional pressure to the front of the barrel using his bodyweight , the opposite , furthest end of the barrel lifted up and moved off to the side of the front trestle . As the barrel was still attached to the drill’s winch this caused a seesaw effect , lifting the front of the barrel over the arc of the chain wrench onto the IP’s leg . As the barrel fell it struck the IP’s right leg in the area of his calf and slid down his outer leg hitting his ankle . The IP tried to move out of the way but then struck his leg against a large angular bridge stone ( that was laying on the floor close to his work area ) as the barrel made contact with him . The additional pressure applied to the front of the barrel caused the opposite/furthest end of the barrel to lifted up and move off to the side of the front trestle . As the barrel was still attached to the drill’s winch this caused a seesaw effect , lifting the front of the barrel over the arc of the chain wrench onto the IP’s leg . 1 . The barrel should be secured mid-body with a chain wrench and not to the base of the barrel . This contributed to the top of the barrel lifting and dropping to the side of the front trestle . 2. The area around the thread had not been tapped prior to breaking the fast joint . This could have reduced the amount of addition pressure being applied to the shoe .3 . When the sample barrel shoe is overly fast , the co-worker should assist to counterbalance the barrel , to ensure it remains secure on the trestles .4 . The lip at the end of the trestle was insufficient to retaining the sample barrel as it lifted when the IP applied additional pressure to the sample barrel shoe . SOP for Making Up and Emptying Samples Barrells was reviewed , amended and re-issued to all drilling staff.Trestle ends redesigned to retain sample barrels should they lift whilst breaking the shoe from barrel .

IP was operating a power screener used for grading spoil for re-using on site and separating out oversized material . The operation was being carried out to determine if screening of the spoil was required . Whilst standing on the viewing platform checking on the grid for any potential blockage from the material being fed into the screener from the hopper , a blass bottle within the spoil dropped onto the sieving grid and broke . A piece of glass struck the IP in the left eye . The IP was taken to [NAME] [NAME] where the piece of glass was removed . The need for screening has been assessed following the accident and alternative screening methodology has been adopted which no longer involves the screening machine .

person involved was asked to remove a drill bit from the chuck of a cordless drill , his hand came into contact with the rotating drill bit which caused flesh injuries to fingers which needed stitches at the local A & E is in progress to establish if the injured party was wearing PPE ( gloves ) , further training in the use of machinery and PPE is being introduced .
Superivision removal of crane ,bitten by a rotweiler dog whilst outside the site boundary

our operative opened the sliding side door of his van . A bucket of fixing screws began to fall out of the door , his reaction was to stop it from falling and he put his hand out to grab it . A wood saw sticking out of the top of the bucket caught his hand between the little finger and wedding finger of his left hand cutting through his gloves[gloves provided by <NAME> causing an injury .

the operative was using an electric ( 110v ) hand drill and apparently applying to much pressure , half the drill bit snapped ,due to weight on drill the remaining section of drill bit continued down and through the operatives nail on the index figure . the operative was not authorised to use the drill as his duties where that of labourer , he will be interviewed on his return to work and advised that he is not to used plant unauthorised and for which he has had no training . also the tradesmen have been told not to allow him to carry out work of this nature .
Was stripping out a bathroom wash handbasin , it shattered and fragments cut through the gloves and cut middle finger on right hand .

The Operative was cutting a length of Skirting board using a chop saw, he released pressure slightly for a split second on the length of skirting and his hand was pushed towards the blade. He has a laceration on his left index finger.

Scaffolding unlit.No signage ...Ladder not fixed and tied to stop access ..Scaffolding planks left un-used and stacked beneath unlit area..My partner fell over an unlit stack of scaffolding boards suffering lacerations to knee and lower leg

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

Time of injury is unknown . <NAME> visited his doctor on the day after the alleged accident . Due <NAME> being diabetic , one of the symptoms of these causes <NAME> 's skin to be prone to injury . <NAME> will be unable to carry out his duties for over 7 days .
Removing window trim when hand caught on small piece of glass stuck in frame : Job was replacing broken window

Precast concrete floor beams were being placed using an excavator , they were slung using chains from the excavator , the operative involved is believed to of guided the load by taking hold of the floor beams when the chains slipped causing the beams to move inflicting his injury .

During the removal of a tiled wall panel by two operatives control was lost and the panel struck the panel struck the third operative . A sharp edge caught the operatives right hand resulting in a cut to the back of the hand .

While drilling a hole in a galvanised steel box , the drill bit snapped , and made contact with the hand , resulting in a cut . Preventive action , box to be placed on a flat surface , held in position by the feet with correct construction footwear .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
