He had parked up to the side of the perimeter palisade fencing on the outside of the compound . While unloading he stumbled and fell down the gap between lorry and fencing , catching his face above his eye on the top of the fence . He also caused damage to his nose and hand in the fall .
changing glass in window because existing <NAME> was broken , lifting new glass into position and slipped through hand causing laceration on little finger on right hand

The injured person is an experienced road maintenance operative . He was in the process of using a pedestrian hand roller . During the process he trapped his the little finger of his left hand between the roller and a wall . This resulted in a laceration to the end of his little finger . He attended <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> where the damage to his finger was diagnosed as loss of the end of his finger . ( the fleshy part ) No bony injury was apparent . An internal investigation is on-going .
Using circular saw & stumbled on to blade , cut to left thigh , taken to doctrs immediatley
Operative was grinding weld when the grinder caught in weld jumped out and cut left hand with disc.

The IP was working with a crawler crane moving steel ladders in [Name] yard to a raised steel platform near the edge of the yard next to the river [NAME]. IP had rigged two steel ladders together in the shape of an inverted V by using two leg chain brothers , the ladders were swung by the crane 180 degrees and lander on the steel platform still in the inverted V shape , the IP had released the chain brother leg furthest from river and was releasing the chain brother closest to the river when one of the ladders slipped against the other ladder and struck the IP in the right lag and removed the skin from the shin to the ankle .First aid was given on site and an ambulance called , the IP was taken to [NAME] hospital were he had 15 striches in his leg
Unloading shelving units from a delivery vehicle into the building . Finger was caught between the shelving unit being offloaded and the ground causing a crush injury

[NAME] was cutting a worktop using a hand saw . [NAME] was cutting on a diagonal and the cut went to nothing ( the corner of the worktop ) and when he got to the end , the saw slipped and clipped [NAME] 's hand . [NAME] was visiting a relative later that day in the hospital , and asked someone to look at his hand but because it had swelled , he was asked to return on 16th [NAME] . He returned on the 16th and he was told he had damaged a tendon and his hand was put in a pot until he retuned to the hospital on the [Date] for further information . The injury has now become an over 7 day injury . [NAME] is unsure when he will return to work .
Worker was operating a cherry picker , turned to guide the basket down and trapped thumb between the outer edge of the basket and the wall - a protruding sill . Cause of accident - Operator error .

IP was cutting pre-cast concrete kerbs with an abrasive wheel saw . During the process IP was leaning over the kerb and an item of loose clothing caught in the wheel saw causing the equipment to lurch upwards and the wheel saw casing struck IP on the jaw . Revised risk assessment prepared and recorded toolbox talk given to all staff authorised to use abrasive wheel equipment . All authorised users to undertake abrasive wheel refresher training .
Part of pallet of paviours fell on his leg

The IP is employed as a joiner who was engaged in fitting new window frames at the location stated . He was at the time using a handsaw to cut a piece of softwood packing when the saw slipped or ''jumped '' and cut the back of the IP 's left hand ( the hand holding the wood ) . The IP was not wearing gloves at the time , although gloves are issued to joiners to wear when there is a risk of them coming into contact with sharp objects .

The IP was cutting timber as part of the local on site manufacture of temporary doors for individual properties . He was using a 110v portable saw to cut a piece of timber when the saw blade "bit " and then jumped coming into contact with his right hand which was guiding the timber resulting in the tip of his right thumb being removed .First aid was administered locally and he was taken to hospital but not detained overnight . Surgery was carried out the following day .Risk assessments and method statements for the task were reviewed following the event and all operatives on site were given a tool box talk on the dangers of working with power tools on site

<NAME> <NAME> was slinging steel on the ground . When he had slung a piece of steel he stepped back to stand clear as the steel was being lifted by a crane and tripped backwards over a piece of vertical corex sheet sticking up around a concrete foundation . When trying to regain his balance <NAME> <NAME> grabbed an adjacent steel beam pulling it over onto his left leg causing a deep cut in his shin

While lifting a steel door into place , the door got stuck on a cavity closer . The injured person adjusted the closer to facilitate passage of the door . During pushing the door into position the trapped his thumb in the door shutter groove .

The IP was banking the tower crane . Two way radios were being used to communicate between the banksman ( IP ) and the crane driver . Column panel shutters were being lifted by the crane onto the scaffold gantry storage area under radio instruction from the banksman ( IP ) . As the column shutters were lowered the banksman ( IP ) caught his finger between the shutters resulting in a cut/sever to the tip of his left hand ring finger . IP was wearing gloves at the time of incident , the whole finger section of the glove was severed on impact . Upon reporting the incident to the site first aider , the finger was dressed and the IP was taken to nearest A & E hospital by the first aider.The following actions were taken post incident :i) A thorough inspection was carried out on the crane .ii ) The crane radios were tested and inspected .iii ) A tool box talk was given to all site operatives on site hazards and lifting operations .iv) Lifting plan was checked and operatives were re-briefed on the lift plan .v ) Site safety inspection was carried out .

<NAME> <NAME> <NAME> was in the process of ply boarding a kitchen floor in preparation for tiling a kitchen floor . <NAME> <NAME> had just cut the last piece of ply board , a slim piece for the door trim with a hand saw . He then ran his stanley knife along the edge to clear splinters off the ply board . The knife then slipped and <NAME> inadvertantly lacerated the very tip of his middle fnger of his right hand . The tenant drove the injured party to <NAME> <NAME> for treatment and a bandage was applied to the lacerated finger . <NAME> <NAME> took the following day off work <NAME> due to his injury and went on his Christmas holiday to <NAME> over the weekend and returned back to work on <NAME>. As <NAME> <NAME> was uncontactable during that time <NAME> <NAME> was interviewed at the earliest time possible by <NAME> <NAME>HSE Manager on <NAME>  where <NAME> <NAME> confirmed he would not have been able to return back to work until the New Year due to his injury if he had not actually gone on holiday in the first place .

<NAME> was carrying door into building with the assistance of customer and the door slipped out of his grasp and landed on his leg resulting in stitches to his leg . He has subsequently been signed off of work for at least a week .

<NAME>  was assisting another member of staff with the opening of a bin door that was jammed shut. <NAME> was trying to pull the bin door open by using his hands . Suddenly the bin door came open and <NAME> thumb became squashed in the door causing it to burst and leave a cut on the thumb tip . All site staff were instructed not to try and open bin doors using their hands in future .

Operator was carrying out repairs to existing fencing using 9 " angle grinder , angle grinder kicked and operator seems to have lost control of machine and recieved cut to underside of chin . He attended hospital and recieved 8 stitches .

New battery saw <NAME> was operating and he took off top of finger and skimmed the top of next one He was reducing a piece of timber in depth to sit over different heights in steel level and obviously he caught his finger in the saw , he dosnt really know how , we think it must be he pulled the guard back with thumb and fore finger and flapped his other finger into the blade above the bed of the saw as it was set on a low depth . He is left handed which may be a additional factor , We have advised eveyone with this type of saw , that they need to be aware of this and obviously be careful At this we are assuming <NAME> will be off work for more than a week
IP was cutting plasterboard to neaten the edges . Craft  knife slipped and cut right hand index finger . Injury was palm side across the first knuckle joint and required two stitches at hospital .

We were installing a new central heating into the property , we had to gain access under the wooden floor boards in the kitchen . <NAME> <NAME> ( the tenant of the property ) was explaining to our operatives <NAME>  <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> what building work had recentley been carried out under the wooden floor at this point <NAME> explained that he would require access under the floor . <NAME> <NAME> explained and pointed out the position of the existing wooden floor board trap in the kitchen , the trap was in the middle of kitchen floor . <NAME> pointed out this was good because we needed to go under the floor . <NAME> <NAME> said she was going to the shop at some time shortley and would return , <NAME> <NAME> then left the room . We then opened the trap to work on the pipe work under the floor , <NAME> went upstairs to work , <NAME> went out the back door to collect items and go under the floor , <NAME> <NAME> returned from the shop through the front door through into the lounge , into the kitchen tripped her leg into the floor board hatch and fell hitting her mouth we believe onto a kitchen chair . <NAME> had a cut to her leg and had blood coming from her mouth a paramedic was called and arrived shortley , later <NAME> <NAME> was taken to hospital by ambulance with a cut leg , damage to her teeth and brusing to her thigh . I called down to  <NAME> <NAME> about 10.45 to record what had happened and report the accident to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> .
Injured person cut his finger with a Stanley knife whilst cutting a section of plasterboard.

The risk assessment has been reviewed and the type of gloves the IP was wearing have also been reviewed to ensure this reduce this type of injury happening again .

IP had finished installation works for the day and was standing in stores area chatting to colleague , whilst talking the IP decided to pick up a plastic accessory box and proceed to whittle / cut at it with a retractable bladed knife , whilst doing this the IP 's knife slipped and cut into the palm of his left hand resulting in a cut which required medical attention and stitches at the local A & E . the IP was spoken to regards the incorrect use of bladed tooling and a safety bulletin was sent to all operatives regards the incident and the restrictions / rules for bladed items in use at work .

The IP was laying floor vinyl in the bathroom of the domestic property . The IP was cutting some hardboard that was to go under the floor covering . As he cut the hardboard with a stanley knife , his hand slipped and the concave knife blade cut into the IP's thumb on his left hand . The IP applied pressure to the wound first aid was administered and the IP went to local hospital for medical treatment . A Toolbox talk was organised and provided for Ops , as Op was not wearing gloves when using the knife . PPE gloves were checked for suitability .
Moving metal 45 gallon oil drum (nearly empty) to the edge of a vehicle back when he cut finger tips on sharp edge of drum..

Operative was knocking a hole through an external wall using a lump hammer and chisel , on swinging the hammer to the chisel , the hammer hit the operative on the wrist , pushing the wrist onto the chisel , the chisel then cut the operatives wrist in line with his thumb , resulting in the operative having medical treatment on site and then going to [NAME]  in [NAME] [NAME] .

As a result of this , the person is unable to carry out his work and is on sick leave until his injuries heal . Actions taken to prevent similar incidents occurring - A toolbox talk with all the electrical and civil team to ensure they follow the correct method statement outlined in their RAMS.

fixing 4m long galv top hat support bars to new portal frame ,at ground level to first sheeting rails ,when a gust of wind blew a galv top hat support which was leaning against buildinggot caught buy a gust of wind which made galv top hat slide over hittng <NAME> on left hand
fixing a metal wall liner ready for dry lining were he fell of the stool and caught his arm on the metal liner tool box talk given about stools and working from hight

Operator was using a hole saw to drill though a timber joist , the hole saw caught on a hard section of timber and jumped out of the wood running accros the operatives adjacent left hand , causing a deep cut to the bottom , of his index finger , imediate first aid was given to stop the bleed and the operative was taken to [NAME] hospital. To prevent similar accidents happening , robust leather gloves will be issued to operatives , the type of drilling machine used will have a grip for the front hand to be placed on which will ensure that even if the bit jumps out of the wood it cannot come into contact with the operators hands , drill bits will be checked before use to make sure they are sharp and able to cut the matterial they are being used for ,

IP was putting tools into his vehicle on completion of a window replacement job . As they did this the glass that had been removed from the property and put in thevan for disposal began to fall from its resting place . IP 's instinct took over and they put their hand out to stop the glass from falling which resulted in the IP cutting thier 4th right finger .
IP was cutting kitchen kick plate when he lifted the safety guard when the saw was running cutting his finger IP Attended  [NAME] and recieved treatment to the cut .

The IP was part of a team of experienced and trained demolition operatives undertaking the demolition of B BLock at [NAME] [NAME] - a reinforced concrete structure . Demolition was being conducted via remote means ( high reach demolition spec 360o excavator machine assisted by a 50t demolition spec 360o excavator machine ) . The IPs role was to act as one of a team of banksman watching over the demolition works and ensuring the security of the demolition exclusion zone . At approximately 10:30 hrs the IP disconnected a water hose feeding the water tank on the high reach excavator machine ( which in turn supplies its in-built dust suppression system ) . He then used the water hose to dampen debris at low level adjacent to where a smaller 50t machine was working to prevent dust release . The plant operator noted his presence and noted that he was outside of the radius of the excavator machines boom . The 50t excavator machine operator then commenced demolition of a low level portion of the structure . As the structure was being reduced a section of angle iron ( thought to have formerly supported service runs on the underside of the roof slab ) fell to ground level . The IP noted this and tried to move out of its way . The section of angle iron struck the back of his right leg . Demolition works ceased and the site supervisor and his team went to the aid of the IP.  The site supervisor administered first aid and an ambulance was called.The IP was examined at hospital and was admitted until the doctors could determine the extent of his injuries . An operation was conducted to clean the wound and check for internal injuries . None were noted and the IP was informed that he would be discharged on [Date] .
Sliced hand with knife whilst cuttingTalon with a Stanley knife - cutting out for 15mm pipes in top of Talon . Cut right hand deeply needing stitches .

The I.P was part of a team moving a concrete barrier with a Fork lift truck(FLT). They were in the process of packing the barrier off the ground to enable the forks to fully pass under the barrier so that it could then be transported by the FLT. The I.P was holding the (approx 100x100x1800mm) timber packer and was preparing to slot the packer under the barrier from approximately 1.8m away. As he did this the barrier tipped over striking the timber which in turn struck the IP on the ankle causing a laceration which later required surgery. The I.P received initial first aid at the scene and was then transferred to A&E for further treatment. Although the I.P was clear of the block the team did not envisage the block striking the packer. The project team have reviewed the activity and although it is not envisaged that they will need to regularly move the barriers they have procured a lifting clamp to make any relocation easier.

<NAME> <NAME> is in the progress of a re-build of main school buildings , refurbishment of existing technology block and extension of nursery all with associated external works and car parking . Also ongoing is the demolition of redundant school buildings.The area where the accident occurred is currently the school gym , which is to be refurbished into a new dance studio . <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> were brought in to demolish the existing steel framework from top to bottom.This work was to take place on a <NAME> to minimise the disturbance to the school users in the live areas adjacent to the construction site.  <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> had visited the site on 5th <NAME> to enable them to construct their risk assessments and method statements . <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> attended site on <NAME> 14th <NAME> to confirm the work and was informed by the site manager , <NAME> <NAME> of the need to change the work process . This was due to a section of steel work not having sufficient shuttering ; it was felt that the burning process would encroach on the live area and needed to be substituted for an alternative method.It appears that this information was not communicated to <NAME> <NAME> Services <NAME> senior management ; the risk assessments and method statements were not amended .On <NAME> 17th <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> arrived on site with three other colleagues , <NAME> <NAME> , <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> work had been completed as per the prepared risk assessments and method statements with all steel work being cut via a blow torch except the section of steel work without adequate shuttering . <NAME> <NAME> then set up a ladder to work off to cut the last section of steel with a 9 angle grinder.To prevent a similar incident occurring the following has been recommended Avoid <NAME> working or ensure adequate Management cover during the weekend .Abrasive wheels training for all operatives , including selection and use of appropriate equipment.Create a process for unplanned work , operatives to be told not to do any work outside of the agreed safe system of works , RAMS. ( TBT ) Record TBTWorking at Height training for all operatives , including selection and use of appropriate access equipment .
Our employee was planting shrubs close to a safe fence when he caught his finger on the hoop linkage of the fence causing injury to his finger .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

He put out a hand to break his fall and the block he was carrying trapped his finger between the block and the working platform causing crush injury and deep cut to right index finger.Toolbox talk given to operatives emphasising the need for good housekeeping in particular with respect to pallet bands

The IP and mate were removing a filing cabinet from the office when the cabinet slipped as they were trying to get the cabinet out of the door resulting in the IP jamming his hand between the cabinet and adjasent building , the IP sustained cuts and grazing to his hand but shortly after the accident he fainted and struck his head on the floor resulting in a cut to his head .

Operative was unloading lintel from van wearing full PPE. As the operative carried the lintel through the back door of the property into the basement , he stepped down one step into the basement and hit his hand , which was carrying the lintel , against a metal vertical rail .

IP was part of a team involved in returning the office back to landlord status which included partition removal . IP and other colleagues were removing three glazed partitions and setting aside for future disposal . When working on the third partition the IP and workmates attempted to remove the panel using suction lifters when the partition shattered . As the partition shattered a shard of glass fell and struck the IP on the left forearm resulting in a cut . IP received first aid treatment before being driven by a workmate to A & E . The wound was glued and the IP returned to work . The IP did not return to work following this incident . Two more glazed partitions remain in the premises and require removal . This will be carried out by a glazing contractor , who will be briefed into the nature of the incident , and an exclusion zone will be established to prevent any other operatives coming into this area .

At approx 11am I was working on the level 4 landing when I heard [NAME] shout "help me , please help me " I immediately turned to see [NAME] walking from the end of the landing coming from stairwell 1 with his hand on his chin . As we ran to meet him I could see blood dripping from his hand and immediately asked what had happened and had a look at his chin under his hand . [NAME] told me he had cut himself with the grinding disc . After seeing the extent of his wound [NAME] and me walked him to the lift assisted by [Name] from [NAME] , took him to the ground floor and sat him on the tail lift of our lorry . Whilst [NAME] from [NAME] rang for an ambulance , we made [NAME] comfortable , administered first aid to his wound and covered him with fleece jackets to keep him warm . [NAME] wife was also called to inform her of [NAME] condition . After 45 mins the ambulance turned up to treat [NAME] and take him to hospital , during this time I stopped all work on site by [NAME] staff and turned off the generator in the back of our lorry . I also went upto level 2 on the stairwell where [NAME] was working and took photos of the area of the stairwell [NAME] had been working on , the 4" hand grinder and the broken disc on the floor that [NAME] had been using prior to the accident occurring . After investigation it became clear that the 4" flap disc had been removed as had been the guard and a 7 " zirconia fibreflex disc had been fixed to the 4" grinder with no guard in place . This disc is not for use with a 4" grinder only for use with 9 " grinders with a guard . All pictures where taken with everything as it was left by [NAME] after the accident and they clearly state that there were 4" flap discs in the immediate area of work . There was no need for discs to be changed or guards to be removed

Assisting skip lorry driver , put arm below ram of skip lorry to remove net as driver was lowering skip . Trapped right elbow causing crushing injury and bleeding . Ambulance called , treated on site and taken to [NAME] hospital .
While assisting to lift down a low loader ramp , the ramp dropped catching fingers between ramp and road. Bearer to be put in place to leave a gap

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Contractor tripped and fell on hard core . Cut face and complained of hip/leg pain .

The injured person <NAME> <NAME> was cutting timber noggins on a chop saw that was set up correctly on a work bench in the middle of the classroom when the back of his left hand came into contact with the blade of the saw as he was checking that the off cut timber had cleared the machine . He immediately reported this to the site manager who is the appointed first aider who bandaged the wound , he was then taken to the local hospital.The site manager discussed the accident with the remaining work force to reiterate the need to be diligent and careful when using cutting equipment within the work place , this appeared to be an unfortunate accident .

The IP is employed by <NAME> as a Tradesman . The IP was carrying out work at a <NAME> property on <NAME> <NAME>. He reached into his van for a bin bag and caught his thumb on the point of a plastering trowel , which resulted in a cut to his thumb . The IP reported the incident to his Supervisor immediately and was advised to seek medical aid . The IP attended his Surgery at <NAME>  on <NAME>  <NAME>. The IP was advised by the Surgery to attend a local walk-in clinic where , after an examination , glue and steri-strips were applied to his thumb . He was told to re-attend the Surgery in 2-3 days . On <NAME> <NAME> , the IP returned to the Surgery , where he was referred to hospital . The IP was advised by the hospital that he had severed a tendon in his thumb that would require surgery , which is awaited . An investigation of the incident by the Health and Safety and Facilities Manager has concluded that human error on the part of the IP was responsible for his injury . The IP has been instructed to store equipment in accordance with <NAME>  internal procedures.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Whilst getting off the front of the workboat on to the barge our employee stumbled and caught his right shin on the edge of the barge .

Whilst walking along roadway between the [NAME] building and the bowling green during the evening of the <NAME> at approximately  <NAME> <NAME> tripped over road crossing plate ( approx size 2.5x1.250 x 20mm thick ) that was covering a manhole causing her to fall and suffering a cut lip a grazed cheek and damage to some teeth.An ambulance was called and <NAME> <NAME> was taken to The <NAME> and <NAME> hospital A&E department where she recieved attention and was later released .

The IP was installing radiator brackets in plots on site , in preparation for fitting the radiators . While fitting the brackets , a small plastic grommet requires to be pushed into a recess , in order to support the radiator , this is generally an easy push in fit . On this occasion , the IP was forcing it in with a flat headed screwdriver , which slipped and caused his hand to strike the bracket , causing a puncture injury .

When delivering at the customers premises the IP approached one of their employees and informed the employee that he had a delivery of two galvanised sheets. The IP then informed the employee that he would need his Fork Lift Truck to unload the Sheets. When the employee arrived at the IP's vehicle the IP asked the employee if he wanted the vehicle moving as the location that he was in was quite muddy and had limited space. The employee responded by telling the IP that he would put the sheets on a pallet for now and would move them later, the pallet was left on the floor and not put level with the bed of the vehicle. The two sheets where wedged in between some mesh and other plates which were to be delivered to different locations. Both the IP and employee struggled retrieving the first sheet which they placed on the pallet. They then struggled with the second sheet and went to place it on the pallet when the IP lost his grip on the sheet causing it to slip, as it slipped the corner of the sheet caught the IP's Knee. The IP was taken to the customers office and received medical treatment. The IP was then taken to A & E Department were he received stitches to his injured knee. Following the nature of the incident a memo will be reissued and the employee will be retrained in manual handling.

To remove an embedded nail from timber, a hammer was used to hammer a claw hammer behind the nail head. Upon impact one of the hammer heads fragmented sending a shard into the operatives hand. Toolbox talk to be relayed to all Building Services teams, risk assessment to be updated both highlighting the importance of not using two hammers together.

IP was on a stepladder drilling a hole in the joist to fit a pipe . He was holding onto the joist with his right hand and drilling with his left hand , as he was doing this the drill slipped and caught his right hand thumb cutting it in the process .

<NAME> <NAME> <NAME> cut his hand whilst removing waste from the garden to the waiting waste venhicle/ . The cut has requried attendance to hospital and he has been away from wortk for over 7 days . ( laceration to right thumb )
Painting the ceiling off 8 Tred Steps , Lost his balance and fell onto a covered bookshelf case resulting in the injury
Joiner was cutting wood on bandsaw - wood got caught and twisted by machinery - resulted in cut palm of hand and staved thumb on other hand .

Stripping steels Pans at 2m lift of a working platform .IP was turning around to stack material when the board snapped , cutting his shin . This required 6 stitches.To prevent similar incident occurring :Double boarding the walkway to provide extra strength.Centre struts under boards to reduce the span and support weight/reduce deflectionThorough inspection of boards before each use - any damaged or defective boards will be removed and destroyed and replacements used.Looking at an alternative material for walkway boards e.g . Plastic or GRP

The individual was cutting steel mesh with a grinder and removed his left hand from the grinder , whilst still holding and using it with his right hand . He then moved his left hand to remove a stone in his cutting pathway whilst still using the grinder with his right hand . The individual then lost control of the grinder , it then went into his left wrist area , contact with the skin caused the individual to bleed . The individual then immediately was seen by the site first aider . All staff have been re-informed that if you need to take your hand off equipment that requires two hands , you must turn it off first and place it in a safe place .

The IP ( Injured Person ) was breaking out a plinth using a Hydraulic Breaker with a point attachment. The plinth which was at the bottom of a brick wall was sloped and about 300mm above ground level. The IP was leaning his body on the handle of the breaker when the point slipped off the sloping plinth and punctured his right foot . The IP had been seen using the breaker by another member of staff prior to the accident and told not to operate it that way but chose to carry on .

Old window frames and glass units were being removed from domestic window , placed against the house wall . Wind and angle of position caused two to fall and break the glass . Two employees went to clear and remove glass to wastebin , on subsequent removal one employee walked into a piece of glass and sustained a laceration cut to on shin approx . 3" long to right leg .
<NAME> was moving a heavy slab of stone with another operative . His finger was trapped between a timber batton supporting the stone and the stone block when it was pushed into place .

operative was fixing metal sections together constructing metal stud work walls using self drilling screws and cordless drill/driver , whilst applying pressure drill/driver to insert screw into metal stud the drill/screw slipped forcing his hand onto sharp edge of metal causing cut to back of thumb on right hand .

Telephone report- The IP was moving a trus with his right hand , he then caught the trus , catching his left index finger between the trus and the brick wall . This resulted in the IP losing flesh and finger nail .
cutting a floor tile with a pair of tile cutters the tile snapped in two jolting upwards cutting left wrist

Cleaning trowel with stanley knife. cleaning off adhesive 50 that is stuck to bottom of the trowel. cleaning in correct way pushing the blade away from yourself. supped and knife cut to left hand thumb. conditions were dry and gloves were worn.normally trowel would have been cleaned the same day it was used. on the fleece to bottom of rhepanol.  no knife would be needed. unfortunately they forgot and used a knife where as solvent should have been used and not a knife.

During the installation of a 6metre long 900mm diameter plastic pipe , it is reported that the IP entered the previously laid section of pipe ( in breach of the agreed and approved method statement ) and instructed the excavator driver to push the next length of pipe into position . During this operation the IP damaged the tips of both thumbs - the tip of the right thumb was severed between the nail and the first knuckle .

The IP was working at a live demolition site , away from the main activities carrying out repairs on a [NAME] [NAME] . The IP was using a sledge hammer to knock the pin back-in to the track-link . A shard of metal was knocked off the track pin which struck the IP in the groin area causing a laceration . The availability of the correct tooling , a 150 ton track press , is being checked to determine why this was not used . A safety alert , bulletin and toolbox talk have been sent out reminding engineers that they should never use a sledge hammer in such a manner .

Whilst removing a ceiling trim to the plant room caught both hands on a the sharp/jagged edge. The injured operative was removing a trim that was not his duty to carry out, this duty was given to a general operative who had the correct PPE. A tool box talk will be delivered to all our Site Personnel not to undertake duties they are not trained for or do not have the appropriate PPE.
Operative closing a Crittall window, his hand slipped and went through the 3mm window pane.

The person was removing material left by others which where in the way of works to be carried out as he removed one object this caused for a door to become unstable and fall over catching the person on his leg

Working on site caught ring finger, left hand under chop saw just above first joint of finger, chopping through finger to virtually full depth. Top of finger still retained by skin and bone. Driven to <NAME> Hospital, <NAME>. Where he was treated by A&E team resulting in <NAME> staying in hospital for approx. 2 days whilst the plastic surgeon installed bone graft.
Drill bit pierced the skin between the thumb and finger left hand later requiring 4 stitches to each side of his hand .the following morning tool box talk .

IP was assisting with the erection of a side shutter for earth works support system . One side had been assembled and was stood on its end approximately 2m high . The side was being supported by the IP.  The IP turned to get his tape measure letting go of the structure thinking the side was free standing . The shutter overbalance catching IP on rear of left leg injuring his calf .
Removing timber from chop saw and contact was made with the blade as it was slowing down .

The IP 's hand was struck by the landing door which was opened unexpectedly quickly by his assistant causing a cut between his 4th and 5th fingers . Late reporting due to IPs absence overlapping with holidays .

<NAME> <NAME> was on site cutting a concrete slab using a hand-held diamond tipped saw in order to reduce the slab into small squares of a size that could be lifted out . Once he had finished the cutting operation , he was drilling holes for , and installing drop in anchors into which would be inserted screw-in lifting eyes to enable the removal of the cut sections . The accident happened when <NAME> <NAME> was installing a drop in anchor using a manual setting tool and lump hammer . When <NAME> <NAME> was striking the head of the setting tool a small piece of metal , roughly 7 mm x 5 mm broke off the head which caused the lump hammer to veer off course and ended up striking <NAME> <NAME> on the top of the left forearm . The piece of metal that broke off was then driven into the arm causing further injury
Operative reached to top of boiler for air vent. Fingers went inside of sealing cover cutting index and middle finger of left hand

1920 - IP is at top of tower removing brackets after positiong the tower on load out pack1921 - All stop on the lifting operation1921 - Second technician starts first aid1923 - information from second tech that IP has hurt his hand badly and needs an ambulance1928 - supervisor heads to site office1928 - second tech assists first in desending tower1935 - ambulance called1937 - Check call from abulance 1937 - 2001 - first aid ongoing2001 - Ambulance arrives on site .The IP recived a laceration across his left palm that required 5 stiches.The initial cause appears to be the use of informal instructions and not following/being aware of correct proceedure . A reveiw of the proceedures and rigging arrangements is being carried out as well as the manning for the task . The technicians involved in the task have been re-briefed and this will be an on-going process with any new onsigners .

Two contractors where cutting a piece of timber . One held the wood in place . The operative slipped with the saw , impacting on the holders hand causing injury to his tendons.The two operatives where competent and experienced . Toolbox talks over all sites have been carried out reminding operatives of the process and correct use of bench vices at all times . The two operatives have been re-inducted onto site .

Our employee was using a disc cutter to cut a 110mm UPVC drainage pipe. He cut the pipe and as stood up the blade was still running and caught his leg above his knee . He has a 3-4" cut and approx 1" deep .

Whilst removing a double glazed unit from the kitchen window following criminal damage the employee over balanced on his work platform and put his hand forward to stop himself falling . in the process of doing this the suffered abrasion to his index , middle and ring fingers on left hand . The abrasion to his index finger meant that he had to have corrective surgery to repair the tendon.Details on the list of training ( inc . manual handling and relevant Toolbox Talks ) that has been provided to [NAME]  is available on request should it be required .
Cutting piece of wood with a manual hand saw . Cut into own thumb

Surveyor employed by <NAME> was inspecting Insurance reported storm damage to a flat roofed extension to the IP property, the Policy Holder footed the access ladder for the Surveyor to access the flat roof. The surveyor turned round and discovered the PH had climbed the ladder and accessed the flat roof of his own accord, he did this without requesting permission or being requested to come up the ladder. The Surveyor was not aware if the ladder had been moved or altered before the IP climbed the ladder, after the survey had been completed the IP procedded to climb down the ladder, it appears he lost his footing or the ladder slipped, the IPs leg got caught in the ladder and he fell backwards and hit his head. The Patio area the ladder was set up on was slightly damp and light rain had started to fall while they had been on the roof. All surveyors employed by <NAME> are to be advised that they must tell PH that they must not climb any ladders set up by them.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Sole of boot come away causing operative to trip, throwing arms out to prevent fall. Left arm hitting verge slates, causing injury

The fascia board was being cut down to suit different sizes of fascia / soffit requirements . The operation was taking place on the scaffold with the fascia resting on battens for support . The IP took his hand off the trigger to check a measure and on restarting the saw it jumped out of the fascia which was being cut and caught the IP 's thumb . The IP put the saw down and shouted to <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> took the IP down the ladder to the site office to see <NAME> , the Site Manager and First Aider . He bandaged the thumb and drove the IP to <NAME> <NAME> hospital where a nurse cleaned the wound and X-rayed it . The IP had an operation to repair the tendon and a cast was put on . The IP stayed in hospital overnight and was released the next day with medication . The IP then made arrangements to visit his own doctor to have his cast removed and a second cast put on . The IP to be given tool box talk to reinforce and maintain levels of awareness and training.This accident was subsequently reviewed by our <NAME> & <NAME> committee and to prevent similar occurances it was decided that hand held circular saws will be banned from our sites in future .

A piece of ducting was standing upright on a piece of hardboard ready to be installed , a MEWP drove past causing the hardboard to move and the duct to fall over and strike the back of the leg of the operator. The main contractor was notified regarding the loose board and it was tape back down . Operatives have been advised not to leave ductwork standing on its end unattended .

Two Operatives placed an iron-man orange bar between the negative conductor rail and right hand running rail , approx 20m from the front of the rail string to take the load off the 90m rail.One of the Operatives used a steel crowbar to hold the rail in place , his colleague was attaching the iron man clamp shackle to the bull-head rail , when it bounced from the rear end briefly entrapping the L/H index finger of the operative before he could complete the operation .

The injured person was supplied as an agency worker to <NAME> <NAME> . The injured persons role was to work as part of civil team carrying out minor civil engineering works associated with an Infrastructure project for <NAME> <NAME> .At the time of the incident the injured person had been tasked to remove vegetation from around the base of temporary works prior to the removal of the temporary works . This task involved the use of a motorised , metal bladed hedge trimmer to cut aware vegetation.During the task the blade of the hedge trimmer became entangle with some metal cable/debris which jammed the blade . The injured person attempted to pull the hedge trimmer away from the debris with both hands on the trimmer handles but lost grip with their right hand and the trimmer came free and moved in an uncontrolled manner toward the injured person . The blade made contact with the middle finger on the right hand of the injured person.The injured attended hospital A & E , received treatment , including surgery on the wound and is now at home recovering.All persons working on the project have been briefed on the details of the accident.The risk assessments and methods statements for the activity are being reviewed.The training /information provided to individuals using motorised hedge trimmers is also being reviewed to ensure all operators are fully aware of the requirements for safe operation of the equipment including pre work checks of site conditions . Please note that the late reporting of the incident was due to unforeseeable circumstances which resulted in us not being able to speak to , or interview , the injured person , until <NAME> to confirm the above facts .

Engineer was cutting short section of plastic kitchen cladding using a knife . Hand holding piece of cladding slipped into path of blade and engineer cut his thumb on his left hand . Engineer has confirmed that the knife being used was not faulty or blunt . Cut needed treatment at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> in <NAME> . Nine stitches required . Hospital advised that engineer must stay off work so finger can be kept clean and does not get infected . Enginer has now been away from work for seven consecutive days . Following this incident , all other <NAME> engineers briefed on safe use of knives and issued with cut resistant gloves .
During the process off removing an existing window from an opening , a piece of broken glass still attached to the window frame has cut through protective gloves causing an injury to hand

My operative <NAME> <NAME> was on top of a stack of plaster-board to gain access to a window bay in which he had to undertake some plumbing works . He moved towards the edge to gain a better view and the top boards that were stacked were overhanging the other boards and tipped . <NAME> put his hand out to steady himself and his hand connected with the window pane which then broke allowing his hand to go through the glass pane and cut his palm .

Whilst investigations into water leak at  <NAME> s council bungalow were taking place . An unsecured door that had been stored up in the loft placed on the ceiling board , which because of the leak had become saturated ; fell through the ceiling , falling onto <NAME> <NAME> resulting in an injury to his arm . The maintenance worker ( <NAME> ) immediately called the paramedics and administered first aid until they arrived ; <NAME> <NAME> was taken to hospital where he stayed overnight .

The injuried party was on site , working for Formwise , constructing the frame work for <NAME> panelling within the washroom on level 2 of building 2. the facts leading up to the incident are ambiguous . The IP claims to have been cutting soft wood timber battens using a <NAME> walt electric chop saw when a dryliner knocked in to him causing his left hand to come into contact with the rotating blade , receiving deep cuts to the thumb and fore finger area . The dryliner cannot recall colliding with IP but states the carpenter was using a chop saw to notch out timbers . Site management was unable to check and photograph the work area as all tools and equipment was dismantles and packed away immediately after the incident and before site management arrived.The IP was taken to the site office where immediate 1st aid was administered before he was taken to the nearest hospital for further treatment . The IP has been absent from work since receiving the injury .

*TELEPHONE Report: I was on the ground floor and I heard something fall to the ground . When I got to the first floor staircase I saw the IP lying on the ground with the ladder next to him . The IP was holding his head with both his hands . There was a little bit of blood on his hands and next to his body on the ground . The IP was in pain and we lifted him up and he sat in one of the flats and first aid was given and an ambulance was called . He was concscious and he was taken to the hospital .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The IP was fixing board retaining clips whilst working on the first lift , he completed the task and got down of the lift and was exiting the underside of the scaffold . The IP then lifted his leg over the tubes on the first lift and caught his Knee on the thread of on of the fittings .

The IP , together with a colleague , was carrying out the user check on a compressor which had been delivered to site the previous evening but which had not been used until the time of the incident . Both operatives lifted up the lid , which stayed up . As the IP began to check the diesel levels the lid came crashing down trapping his fingers between the rim of the lid and edge of the equipment .

Employee adjusted piece of wood underneath a kitchen unit carcase which was being held on an angle by another employee and his finger became trapped between wood and carcase when lowered . Injured person taken to hospital and has stitches and retuned home same day . A wooden frame to be designed for future installations instead of single pieces of wood .

The IP was using a 50mm hole saw in an electric drill to bore holes in the top panel of a mains switch panel , the panel had been removed and was on a work bench . As the IP began to bore the hole the hole saw slipped and struck his finger , causing a severe cut that required butterfly stitches to be applied at the hospital .

Cutting wood to size. Putting timber through circular saw timber jumped back and left hand went into saw blade causing lacerations to index , second , third and little finger . Little finger bone fractured and tendon cut .
Moving a metal plate at ground level ,plate slid and cut shin Wound was dressed onsite then sent of to hospital for wound to be treated and subsequently stitched

The IP was removing broken glass from the window frames on the second floor of the building (in conjunction with safety exclusion zones, long reach equipment & PPE).He dislodged a piece of glass that was held in place by silicone sealant; the glass then swung in a pendulum motion and fell. The glass broke into smaller pieces and a small section travelled approximately 2 metres and struck his right leg (calf area) causing a 25mm cut which required 2 stitches. The IP was taken to the local accident and emergency department for treatment.The risk assessment for this task has been amended to highlight areas where silicone has been used as a fixing agent and PPE for this task is under review where this task cannot be carried out remotely or mechanically.The IP was kept in hospital for more than 24 hours due to no-one from the physiotherapy department being available as he was treated a number of hours after being admitted to hospital.There was a personnel shift change which meant he was not seen until the following shift.
Whilst trimming some material with a Stanley Type knife the IP slipped and cut his left knee with the knife blade.Use of Open blade Stanleyy type knifes to be reviewed

Erecting ladder access scaffold external of the existing building allowing access to roof ,on the front elevation ,as per <NAME> & <NAME>. <NAME> <NAME> was passing1.3m cup-lock tube over hand from ground level to approx 3m height , where <NAME> <NAME> was receiving and stacking the required tube while standing on a fully boarded platform with a single guard rail( the platform was a non working platform/was only being used to enable scaffolding to be erected in accordance to <NAME> (<NAME> & <NAME>)  were both a little vague when asked exactly what happened they both agreed that as <NAME> past the 1.3m cup-lock tube to <NAME> <NAME> in momentum <NAME> <NAME> turned to pick another 1.3m cup-lock tube leaving his left hand resting on the ledger tube in front of him whilst turning . <NAME> miss judge his grip and the tube slipped throw his hand falling approx . 2m and landing on to <NAME> <NAME> hand which was resting on the ledger below.which caused Two number fingers to be crushed.All employees have been made aware of the accident , And have been cautioned that falling materials at any height can be dangerous ,and a manual handling toolbox talk was held at our depot (yard ) immediately when we were aware of the damage caused .all operatives have been CISRS Trained at all levels.COTS- scaffold Laborer Part 1 -Improver scaffolder(Trainee)Part 2 -Basic ScaffolderNVQ Level 3 - Advanced Scaffolder Re-fresher Course NASC Guidelines TG20:13 & SG4:15

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Carrying an old piece of glass when he tripped over a piece of plywood on the floor causing him to drop the glass and fall forward . The injuries sustained where nit caused by the glass .

The operative was drilling a hole in a kitchen wall unit. He was holding a piece of wood behind the door to stop it spelching, when the wood slipped & he pierced his left hand with the drill.  He attended hospital & was kept in for 48 hours to treat the wound & repair the puncture wound.

During the erection of scaffolding , while laying the corugated metal sheets to create a temporary cover for the replacement of the roof the injured worker lost his balance and fell from partly erected scaffolding about 1.5m on to the roof . During the fall he injured his right hand with pertruding piece of the corrugated sheet .
The installation of altro whiterock sheets to the toilet walls , the incident happened when cutting the sheet with a stanley knife and it slipped and cut his index finger .
2 men removed door to fit new closer at bottom of door and the toughened glass door shattered .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Pallet truck being used to move a stillage bacame trapped on a plywood floor . IP went to assist operator of pallet truck by pulling the stillage . As the stillage moved the IP hand became trapped against an RSJ. Review of operation and surface underway in conjunction with PC .

Our sub contractor was standing on a step ladder approx . 4 to 5 feet high . He was tightening a bolt into a steel beam when the step ladder toppled from underneath him . As he fell he hit his head off a steel post which caused a cut and also hit his right elbow off a metal stud which was in a steel post besides him .
Removing glass to allow replacement of a window . This incident is being fully investigated .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: during a lifting operation over a palisade fence the IP attempted to free a trailer which had contacted the fence and slipped partially impaling his right palm on the spike .

Workman was involved in demolition of brick wall to rear of garage.  One brick came loose and struck the back of his hands.  It ripped through his safety gloves and caused a significant laceration to the back of his hand.

[NAME] was using a Stanley knife with his right hand and was holding a piece of material awkwardly in his left hand . His right hand slipped and cut into the back of his left thumb . All staff are provided with safety gloves to wear on site but [NAME] was not wearing his as the work he was carrying out required finer motor skills .

TELEPHONE report- The IP was turning a twelve inch pipe on two stands , two people were turning the pipe , they lost control and the IP had his hand inside the pipe , there was a chanfer on the pipe which is an angle for welding . As the pipe turned the IP had his hand inside the pipe and on the chanfer , the chanfer cut through the IP 's fingers on his left hand causing damage to the tendons .

IP was lifting a boiler from within a cupboard when a sharp edge caught his right index finger , causing a laceration . IP was wearing gloves at the time . A review of gloves will be undertaken to determine if they are suitable for this task .

Two engineers from [NAME] were carrying out repairs to the water supply pipe in the IPs garden ( inserting a new section of pipe due to a leak ) . Two holes had been dug , one of the holes ( 0.3m x 0.6m ) was directly in front of the access route to the garden from the IP's property . The engineers put blue flexi tubs filled with spoil in front of the access point while they attended the second hole to feed the pipework through . In doing so , the IP appeared and asked them to help understand a letter he had received from the water companu . They offered to help after they had finished working and asked the IP to return to his property and away from the work site . As the IP made his way back to his property , he fell down the first hole ( the blue flexi tubs only prevent access to one side of the hole ) . The IP was taken from site to the local hospital , where he was admitted .
Blade slipped and cut palm of hand

Whilst lifting a scaffold platform the IP slipped off of the ladder and fell approximately 1.6 - 1.8 metres . His left thigh struck the scaffold , either a scaffold butt or its fixing , causing a laceration .

Whilst down on his knees fixing wall panels and jointing straps , he became aware of a cut on his right knee . First aid was administered , wound cleaned and plaster placed over the cut , continued working . Became aware of increased pain and swelling finished work on <NAME>  <NAME> approx . 11:00hrs to attend hospital where he was given antibiotics . Pain and swelling still bad on <NAME>  <NAME> when he went back to the hospital where he was detained for observation and discharged on <NAME>  <NAME> . Sick note not in our possession at this moment in time , however he has one for two weeks . Building works ( property services ) were not made of aware of the full potential of the incident until <NAME>  <NAME> where they have been led to believe that the diagnosis is Prepatellar Bursitus (Housemaids knee). This can not be confirmed until we 've received written confirmation from his GP/ Hospital .
using a stanley knife and lacerated index finger

The IP was performing his normal duties as a roadworker and had been tasked with cutting back an overgrown hedge in order to maintain public access to a stile . The ground conditions the IP was working on was a very slightly sloping compacted stone footpath and the weather conditions were dry and clear daylight . The IP was using a petrol powered hedge cutter when he slipped . The hedge cutter made contact with the IP causing a small cut just above the left knee . The standard issue boots the IP was wearing at the time of the incident are in a good condition . The IP attended <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> where he received five stitches to the wound .
whilst cleaning one of his filling knives the decorator` s hand slipped cutting his other thumb .

The IP has reported to the site manager for first aid.The IP claim that a piece of wood has fallen out of the skip causing laceration to left leg , above knee.The IP was taken to hospital.Upon investigation of the skip area by the company H & S we could not identify any wood which would have caused such injury . No evidence of wood on floor and that which was in the skip was not heavy or sharp . The skip edge is approx 1.2m high and the injury is not consistent with an impact from this height or angle . Accident  is still under investigation .

The person involved in the accident lives in the building concerened ( 5/32 <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> The tenant either tripped , caught her shopping bag or fainted ( there are no witnesses and the tenant cannot be sure ) , hitting her head on part of the stair lift structure that had been installed as part of the lift refurbishment work that was being undertaken at the time . <NAME> <NAME> required hospitalisation and was taken to A & E for stitches.The stairlift has been installed ( and maintained ) by <NAME> lift <NAME> who have supplied any appropriate installation documents . With the new passenger lift now installed in this building this temporary lift is due to be removed shortly
Roof tile fell off scaffold an struck an operative below

IP was repairing the facings around a front door . He was using a non-retractable blade . As he was not wearing his tool belt , which has the holder for the knife , so he placed the knife inside his right side pocket . Forgetting the blade was in his pocket , he put his hand in and cut his hand and wrist . He required stitches .

The injured party was cleaning off the back chute of a ready mix lorry after completing a delivery of semi-dry material . Whilst brushing down the chute he noticed a piece of stone catching on the drum . He tried to remove the stone and in doing so trapped his thumb between the chute and the drum.This cut the top of his thumb across his nail to the back of this thumb . A bandage was applied at site and the driver returned to his place of work . The driver reported to incident to his manager ( [NAME] ) . He then went to hospital in [NAME] where the thumb was re-dressed and an appointment for the following day was made at [NAME] [NAME] , [NAME] At [NAME] the wound was treated and stiched. After a return visit to [NAME] it was confirmed that there was feeling in the end of the thumb and no physio was required . He was signed off until [Date] will a local doctors appointment on the [Date] to remove stiches .

The IP was working as part of a 2 man gang , involved with the installation of telecommunications equipment . During this activity the IP had just completed a task using a petrol driven saw andwhilst placing the saw on the ground the tool slipped causing an injury to the outside of his left leg . The IP was treated in [NAME] ' hospital and released to [NAME]hospital which is close to his home .

Bulk bags of topsoil were weighing in excess of bags SWL limit so bulk bags were being lifted onto podium deck in a crane tipping skip , as the load was set down the arm of the skip jolted cutting operatives finger . A momentry lapse in the operatives concentration holding the tipping skip steady in an area he had been told not too by crane operator resulted in injury . Bulk bags were reduced in weight in the ground to enable safe lifting of bulk bags only ( excluding skip ) . Future deliveries of bulk bags are now refused when over weight , supplier ( [Name] ) of bulk bags and topsoil have no contingency with regards to the safe SWL of the bag and its contents if the contents are over filled or get wet . We have been unable to get clarification of why the bags were over weight furthermore their website specifications state that even when the product is saturated the load would be too heavy for the SWL , the bag is not suitable for the product it contains . To date suppler is ignoring requests for information leaving me unable to fully explain why weight of the bags was exceeded .

Operative was sawing a piece of timber with a handsaw.  Operative lost concentration due to being distracted by another operative and cut across left thrumb with handsaw.  We have given a tool box talk on basic hand tool safety to all operatives.

<NAME> <NAME> ( IP ) was protecting the stone tiles to wall on level 6 , lift entrance . IP was cutting a corner section of corex protection using a downwards actions and applying force , when the accident happened . IP had hold of the corex in his left hand and was cutting the corex with a stanley knife , the blade went through the corex and his glove and cut the underside of his left hand .

An apprentice working for the company was about to start stripping wall paper using a brand new stanley wall paper scraper . He went to change the direction of the blade around as they come facing the wrong way . He used a pocket multi tool belonging to himself to undo the blade and slipped with doing so . He cut across the back of his hand , cutting through 2 tendons . He was given first aid on the scene and taken immediately to the doctors surgery for treatment . He was referred to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> , who kept him in and operated to repair the damage to his tendons . I have spoke to all staff following this and ensured they do not use these pocket multi tools , they are not supplied by us and we do not recommend them using them . We have reiterated to all staff that they should always ensure they are using the correct tool for the job they are performing and should ensure they are doing so in the safest way possible .

IP was unhitching a tar boiler from a pickup . IP had uncoupled the trailer by taking the pin and the IP stated that the jockey wheel was in the down position , but had not moved the breakaway cable . The coupling end of the trailer then proceeded to fall to the ground and the IP 's pinkie finger was caught in the breakaway cable and sliced through the soft tissue of the finger as it fell . The IP was wearing gloves at the time , however his injuries required surgical repair . It is unclear how the coupling end of the trailer fell , as the IP noted the jockey wheel was in the down position . On investigation there was no fault with the jockey wheel . Further investigation will take place on the IP 's return to work .
Whilst working a piece of wood with a chisel, the chisel slipped and and penetrated his left hand index finger on the underside of the knuckle causing a deep laceration

Telephone report LSI - IP walked out of area with a scraper and as he stepped over his area he caught his left leg with scraper . IP called supervisor who come straight away with an on site medic . The medic bandaged his leg and the supervisor took him straight to hospital . IP has cut through to his tendant and requires peroneus longus tendant repair .
<NAME> was struck by a scaffold tube that had been incorrectly handled by the scaffold operative and consequently suffered a cut injury to the forehead

The injured person was in the process of setting-up a lifting operation in his capacity of slinger-signaller . Three steel beams had been delivered to site , strapped together , and he was attempting to separate the beams whilst they were still on the ground , in order to sling and lift the steel beams singly . As he reached out to grasp the guide rope which was already attached , the steel beam which was uppermost in the stack slipped , and his left thumb was momentarily trapped between two of the steel beams , resulting in a laceration injury requiring stitches. Actions to prevent a recurrence include refresher training for the injured person , liaison with the steel supplier to review securing methods for steel beams prior to despatch , review & revision of safe system of work detailed in Lifting plan . Circulation of safety alert to all other <NAME> <NAME> Projects .
Joiner cutting an alluminium clad flooring panel .Firstly cut alluminium face with battery operated grinder . Continue to cut chipboard with handsaw . Handsaw slipped from draft & cut joiners hand .

At <NAME> 12 Noon on <NAME>  <NAME> operative was removing some redundant materials from above an existing suspended ceiling to create space for the installation of new ventilation ductwork . The operative was standing on an <NAME> hired scaffold to acces the ceiling void . The operative was using general hand tools including a small grinder and tin snips to cut away some redundant electrical conduit . After cutting away the redundant materials , the operative was pulling down with some force on a section of particularly stubborn piece of metal trunking when it gave way resulting in the full force of the operatives body jolting downwards and his arm as a result colliding with the existing ceiling 'top hat ' supports causing the laceration to the operatives lower arm just above the wrist . ( location of Injury on the inside of wrist ) Action taken ; Strictly no working in restricted ceiling voids to be carried out . Daily tool box talks to be carried out to enforce restricted working patterns .
Changing a standard, undoing easy fix transom bolt as undoing the bolt his back of hand caught ducting (round) stacked against scaffolding

<NAME> <NAME> was cutting plastic soil vent pipe with a hand saw, whilst cutting with the saw he glanced his finger grasping the pipe cutting trough his gloves and slicing his finger . He was taken off to hospital and his wound was stitched and dressed ( he was told to take time off work for the healing process to take place due to his nature of work of a plumber ) Due to the accident we have put in place a using work equipment safely tool talk empathizing on the correct PPE and keeping tools in serviceable order and working care in the working environment .
Engineer was using his drill, the drill bit snapped, slipped from the trunking that was being drilled then came into contact with his hand

After using a hole saw to cut out a piece of ply wood it became stuck in the end . [NAME] got out his utility knife to remove the wood and was then verbally told by myself to make sure the knife was locked before using . It was not locked so the knife shut onto one of his fingers .

Site tidying works were being carried out during Saturday nightshift . Weather conditions were dry and mild . The employee was helping to change an attachment on a road rail [NAME] T4300 machine in the car park area near the site . The 3rd finger of his left hand became trapped whilst trying to remove a pin and the top of the finger was removed - being left in the employee 's glove . He was taken immediately to [NAME] hospital in [NAME] [NAME] where the wound was cleaned and dressed . The employee was kept in hospital until he saw a consultant at 08.30 . First advice was for the employee to be transferred to [NAME] or [NAME] Infirmarys - however the employee was keen to go closer to home ([NAME]) . After examining x-rays that were taken , the consultant advised that the dressing could be left on until the employee was referred by his GP to [NAME] hospital in [NAME] - this still to happen . The opinion of the consultant was that the finger could be left as it was and the skin heal naturally over the wound - or a piece of bone could be removed to allow for a cleaner cut and more skin to fold over the wound . This to be decided when the employee sees the consultant at [NAME] hospital . The employee was discharged from [NAME] hospital at 15.30.The investigation into the accident is still ongoing . As is normal practice , findings will be discussed by senior management and recommendations and actions to prevent reoccurrence will be addressed and cascaded to all relevant staff . These findings will also be shared with the client .

Carpet was being fit into student accommodation . The carpet had to be tucked under the bed. The bed was raised and [NAME] used his knife pouch to hold the bed raised , with the knife still in the holder . After fitting the carpet, the bed was lifted to remove the pouch , but unfortunately the knife fell from the holder, causing [NAME] to slice his hand on the blade . [NAME]  has acknowledged that he should not have used this tool for the task and should have used an alternative item that would not have the potential to cause harm .

At a customers site - whilst installing a timber outbuilding ,employee was moving a roof panel forward . His handed slipped from the roof and the roof panel sliced the wrist . Employee received a 10mm slit to the risk , cleaned up at customers house and wrapped it up to keep dry - later went to hospital
Staff member was uplifting luxury vinyl tile that was stuck to the floor with adhesive, using a Hook Knife. The corner of the tile chipped and the knife went through thumb, severing two tendons.
Whilst sawing batons for roofing saw jumped and struck IP on top of thumb severing tendon of thumb of left hand
Operative went to pull plastic debris off screener hopper and finger was cut by loose peice of metal . Failed to follow correct procedures in which he had been trained .

IP was working with another bricklayer building an external brick wall . The other bricklayer pulled the string line tight , and in doing so pulled out a steel pin that the string was tied to . The pin flew through the air and struck IP on the back of his left hand , causing the injury .
Amendment to incident report <NAME> , Installing a tile vent in a new roof covering ,struck a nail with a hammer to secure vent and nail pinged back and struck injured person in the eye

Operative using a battery drill complete with 20mm Hole Saw to drill a hole in a steel enclosure , the hole saw pilot bit snapped , this caused the drill to spin off the enclosure and hit the Operatives Left Hand , resulting in a laceration to his ring finger. Preventive measures - Tool box talk on use of electrical hand tools

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: While conducting routine river maintenance work to remove debris from the watercourse ( debris that may contibute to a risk of flooding ) the IP stumbled over an angle iron protrusion on the river bank causing him to fall . He put his hand out to save himself placing it below the water line where he struck a sharp object . The object punctured his glove and the palm of his hand causing a deep cut that required hospital attention . The area of the fall has been visited again and we have removed the angle iron protrusion .
During the process of removing wall tiles from plasterboard substrate a section of wall tile fell onto arm causing laceration .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured person was carrying a length of clay pipe when he lost his footing , he dropped the pipe , which shattered when it made contact with the ground . The injured person put out his hands to control his fall and his left hand made contact with the broken pipe . The injured person was wearing safety footwear and gloves at the time of the accident
Injured person was using a small crow bar to take out a hilti nail/ timber pad which was attached to a sheet pile . The hilti nail sprung loose and hit him in the left eye causing small wound .

IP was put to work by his supervisor to grind out 4” metal guides on a cross brace section , using a 5” grinder . IP ground out two guides successfully , as he was nearing completion of the third guide the grinder kicked downwards dislodging it from his left hand , this action caused the disc to contact his left wrist resulting in a 1.5” laceration to his wrist .

[Name] cut her thumb on a Stanley knife blade , she was cutting some cable ties attaching an earth wire to a copper pipe and the blade slipped . Her thumb got infected and so she has been signed off for 3 weeks
Injured person was cutting in render paintwork behind rain water goods off a stepladder as he descended the stepladder toppled over and he fell on to stepladder .

Our floor layer was fitting carpet tiles with a dolphin knife with a straight blade . Whilst cutting in the carpet tiles he accidently slipped causing the straight blade to cut the palm of his left hand .

The operative was under instruction from an experienced work colleague on site , whilst removing a ceramic toilet The operative placed the toilet on the rubbish area whilst removing his hand the operative caught his hand on the exposed edge of the danaged toilete inflicting a cut to his palm of his right hand.An ambulance was called by the home owner and the operative was taken to hospital for treatment .
Cut to the index finger as a result of separating two stanley knife blades .

Our company was contracted by <NAME> who manage <NAME> <NAME> to dismantle glazed partitioned offices . Our operative applied glass suckers to the first pane of glass in preparation for the lifting of it by himself and another operative . When testing to see if the suckers were securely fixed the glass pane shattered and shards of glass fell onto the operative cutting his left arm just above his hand . He sort assistance from the on site first aiders and an ambulance was called and he was taken to <NAME> hospital where the wound was bandaged . He was later sent to the <NAME> <NAME> hospiral in <NAME> to see a specialist . He was booked in for an operation on the <NAME> for repairs to tendons that had been damaged . He returned to work on the  <NAME> where he worked on another site on a supervisory role only . No further works were allowed to happen and we had an independent survey carried out to inspect the remaining glass and the panel that was taken out . It was deemed that the glass shattered due to the glass being incorrectly installed by a previous contractor . A revised method statement has been written for the safe removal of the remaining glass .
Manual handling of panelling for roofing section . Panel slipped out of gloved hand causing arterial bleed whilst being moved from stack .

Employee was loading bricks onto low level scaffold for garden wall and trapped his finger against scaffold tube end , cutting the end of his finger . Toolbox talk - reminded all employees of the health and safety policies the company have previously outlined
Whilst sawing some plywood the hand saw bounced out of the groove and caught thumb , causing laceration

IP was cutting UPVC with a Stanley knife . He drew the knife over his finger , cutting deeply enough to damage the tendon . He was bandaged up by the first aider and sent to hospital . The hospital re-dressed his wound adding a finger splint .

At around 08:30:2 Operatives manoeuvred a trailer that had a hand held  roller positioned on top to the rear of a 7.5t Highways maintenance vehicle . The IP <NAME> <NAME> then began the procedure of positioning the trailers hitch bar to connect to the towing point of the 7.5t works vehicle whilst the second operative kept the rear of the trailer and roller as stable as he could by pushing and holding  it in position ; during this procedure the hitch bar slipped to the ground , momentarily trapping/pinching  the IP's finger of his left hand . The IP removed his glove to observe a cut and blood to his middle finger of his left hand .

The operative was throwing bricks into a skip following the demolition of a garden wall . The operative 's team leader will investigate this incident and carry out a return to work interview on their return .

[NAME] was climbing a ladder which came loose from the scaffold clip holding it to the scaffold pole .The ladder slid down to next lift . [NAME] hit his face as he fell onto the scaffold lift that the ladder was standing on .

The labourer was climbing out of the scissor lift on site , in a forward manner . He realised his glove was caught and re-entered the scissor lift and released the glove . He took off the glove and realised he had taken the end of his finger off .
Sliding a pallet ( top pallet ) to the side . Trapped finger as it was moved

A cross base for a concrete placing boom mast was being installedThe cross base weighs 1.3 ton and measures 2.3 metres by 2.3 metres and made of metal base was being landed between 8 bolts , 2 bolts on each foot and the bolts stuck out from a concrete slab base .It was during this operation [NAME] injured his fingers. [NAME] the crane supervisor asked  [NAME] the slinger to lift the cross base onto the concrete slab . As bolts stick out from the concrete slab  [NAME] and [NAME]  assisted holding the cross base whilst [NAME] guided the crane down . [NAME] briefed all operatives prior to operation commencing . [NAME] told all that if he [NAME] and [NAME] held a foot each whilst [NAME] banked the cross base down the base should go straight between the bolts.The base was coming down steadily ; [NAME] was positioning 1 foot manually when a base foot got caught on a bolt where [NAME] was . [NAME] went on the radio and instructed the [NAME] operator to stop the lift but as he said stop the base appeared to free itself . When the base was down [NAME] noticed blood on the foot near to [NAME] and asked if he had cut himself , [NAME] replied yes and it ’s bad.As the base was being lowered the foot had got stuck on one of the bolts at the foot which [NAME] had guided down . [NAME] had his thumbs on the top of the foot and his fingers around the side . The base freed itself and went down . As the foot went down it trapped [Name] right index finger and ring finger between the bolt and the side of foot . [Name] was wearing gloves at the time.  [NAME] right index finger was cut open and some flesh removed from his ring finger , [NAME] was taken to the site first Aider where his cuts were cleaned up and then he was taken to the [NAME] hospital in [NAME] and then to the  [NAME] in [NAME] had an operation on his index finger where a wire was placed into It and had plastic surgery . on his ring finger he had a skin graft and has been told to stay off work for 2 months with regular visits to the hospital for monitoring. ConclusionThe accident was a failure of not following an agreed brief and human factors. Measure’s to be carried out to prevent a re-occurrenceToolbox talks to be carried out to all on traps and cuts to the hands and safe lifting operations on site .

the injured person ( [NAME]) was moving roof sheets ( metal decking ) on Block P roof area together with a colleague james hamilton who attempted to flip over 9Nr roof sheets that were stacked together ( 1m x 3m long approx weight 100kg ) to gain access to a larger sheet below . whilst attempting this operation the sheets slipped and caused injury to the inside forearm , wrist and hand .
