The injured party was trimmingt the bottom of an internal door using a circular saw . As he completed the operation and lifted the saw , he slipped and caught the tip of his finger on the blade . The incident is currently under investigation .

We are a [NAME] accredited laboratory testing construction materials . The member of staff in question was carrying out a particle density test in accordance with [NAME] 1377 [NAME] 4 1990 . Part of the test involves putting a sample of dried soil in to a gar jar adding water and shaking by hand until the material is in suspension , during this process the glass gas jar ( very thick durable glass ) sheared/broke in the middle with no warning , as it was being shaken which caused my colleague to have a deep cut to his forearm . All of our equipment is inspected periodically in accordance with our accreditation , however we have disposed of all other gas jars being used and have replaced them with brand new ones , we have also started a system so each technician will check any glass wear being used before each use , to ensure no glass wear is used if any signs of distress are noted

[NAME]  ( Injured person ) was cutting a piece of plywood approx . 1500mm x 500mm in size to use for an infill around a column on the deck . The IP had been cutting the plywood on a timber-cutting bench using a Makita circular saw with guard when the blade made contact with his thumb and index finger on his left . It has been found the operative was using the incorrect cutting technique where his hand was in the wrong position when cutting the plywood . The contact resulted in deep lacerations . The IP received First Aid treatment on site and was taken to a nearby hospital by his Supervisor . The IP has since undergone an operation to repair the damage to his hand and is awaiting clearance to return to work .

project : over clad existing asbestos fibre roof with [NAME] [NAME] bars and single skin cladding.A ( injured party ) and B were laying single skin roof sheet , B " clashed " the sheet down instead of placing it , this resulted in the other end of the sheet being pulled from the hands of A ,

The employee lifted a monoblock along with the soil underneath , a drain cover was then removed , contained in the debris of the drain cover was a needle that punctured the employee 's skin in his hand .
IP was installing a precast Wall. The PC wall was lowered into place and required re-shimming. IP instructed crane operator to lift PC wall. IP was re-shimming when wall came down trapping fingers

<NAME> <NAME> and a colleague ( <NAME> <NAME> ) were de-roping the tower crane (TC ) in preparation for <NAME> dismantling operations the following day . <NAME> <NAME> signalled a request to <NAME> <NAME> asking him to trolley in which he did at low speed . During this process the tips of the fingers on the right hand of <NAME> <NAME> appear to have been nipped between the drum and rope . <NAME> <NAME> came to the cab where <NAME> <NAME> assisted him to leave the <NAME> and obtain first aid treatment .

Responded to an emergency call at <NAME> <NAME> , bad leak into boys gym . Sourced cause of leak to blocked drain on flat roof above . Only access to drain whcih was blocked was through window in the English department. Whilst climbing back through window lost balance and fell onto the cast iron radiator where the bleed valve sticks out about 30mm , this went into leg causing a lrge wound to left thigh , trouser leg quickly became saturated with blood and this caused <NAME> <NAME> to feel faint and sick , at this pint the janitor phoned an ambulance .
Hit self with hammer on finger whilst knocking on steel hand rail
The operative was tightening bolts , spanner slipped and impact of hand with electrical trunking fitted alongside .
When carrying a panel of glass a small section of the glass broke off and fell onto <NAME> <NAME> leg causing a deep cut into his right shin. He was wearing trousers and overalls at the time .
Whilst repairing a boiler the casing slipped and thus cut the enginners finger

IP was working to fix wooden sections of a frame together while construction a new apartment . Due to the location he was holding the frame with his right hand and using a gas powered nail gun with his left hand . the IP is right handed . During the fastening procedure the gun slipped , or was triggered accidentally , firing a nail into the index finger on his right hand . the IP noticed the injury but determined it was not significant and carried on working . The following day he was in some pain but took pain killers to take the edge off and came back to work . On the thursday ( <NAME>) he work in pain with significant swelling and attended hospital where he was diagnosed with blood poisoning . He was kept in hospital for the day and given an operation to help clean the wound and to assess the injury . It was at this point that the accident was reported.The IP had received training on the safe use of the tool and an induction on the site first aid and accident reporting procedure . He is expected to return to work <NAME> though has a further hospital appointment on <NAME> .

The IP is employed as a joiner who was working repairing a UPVC window frame in a rental property . He was using a stanley knife to cut a small section of plastic trim when the knife slipped causing a cut to the base of his left thumb . He was wearing a general purpose glove at the time of the accident.The manager in charge of this section is to source and trial a " secateurs style " tool for cutting UPVC trims .

Isolated timber joist replacement working from the 3rd floor adjacent to the 2nd - 3rd floor staircase . Leaning over to hold a joist end at a lower height ( other joist end was being held by a carpenter standing on a secured platform on the 2nd floor ) , lost grip of the joist end , attempted to retrieve it to stop it from falling down onto the 2nd floor corridor ( which was sectioned off ) loss of balance resulted in person falling down onto the 2nd floor corridor below . Site re-inforced tool box talks , working at heights , safe systems of work by site manager . All sub contractors e- mailed to re-inforce safe working practices , adherance to method statements and to use correct plant & PPE. This is an amendment of previously submitted form notification [Name] incorrectly filed as a dangerous occurrence on [Date]

During removal of old electrical switchgear and mezzanine floor ,some pipework which was part of the old sprinkler system was dislodged from above the main steelwork of the building.This pipe measured 6.5 metres long ,50mm in diameter with 4mm thick walls. <NAME> <NAME> who was working for my company in his capacity as an electrician was stood 3 metres to the left of the mezz floor and checking that during removal the incoming electrical mains cables were not caught and damaged.The pipework some how came down at an angle and caught <NAME> on the back of his helmut and shoulders , knocking him to the floor .

[NAME] brick-layer for [NAME] [NAME] ( IP ) was ascending/descending ladder secured to internal scaffold within newly built store which had been erected as a work platform to complete building of inner block walls .Investigations are on going--IP fell approx . 6m to slab base below and rendered unconscious . Site management called emergency services to scene where IP was transferred to intensive care unit where treatment is continuing .
Crane was lifting a palet above a safe zone on site. Palet wasn't properly secured ,fixed and fell down from the 7 floor hight . Hit one of the operatives on the head , shoulder .

IP was working at height on a <NAME> podium on hire from [NAME] at 1.44m, carrying out internal fixing to a new build school building. Other workers were in the immediate vicinity but did not have full view of the podium and were facing the other way. Heard the tower move and turned to see IP hit the ground.IP sustained a head injury & was unconscious for around 30 seconds. First aid was administered & IP was taken to hospital. Was discharged the same day.Initial investigation ascertained that both brakes were on (customer's site manager & first-aider confirmed); unconfirmed whether IP was working with the trapdoor shut as per his briefing, or whether it was a mechanical failure of the trapdoor which led to him falling, as claimed by IP. Subsequent tests from the ground showed the trapdoor can be opened with a tug of moderate force even when completely locked.The hire company have been informed and will investigate the unit. The podium has been impounded and all of our sites will be examining similar units to see whether this is a widespread problem.

A mobile pump vehicle had arrived on site to to commence pumping concrete in to pile tubes . The boom operator inspected the ground and identified the position where his out-riggers would rest . The our-riggers were extended and lowered on to prepositioned sole plates . The boom operator then tested the stability of the ground by bouncing the rig vigorously . Approximately 45 minutes into the pour the ground under the rear nearside out-rigger collapsed forcing the sole plate into a vertical position thus allowing the out-rigger to sink 1m into the ground . This ground failure tipped the pump vehicle sufficiently to cause the boom to instantly drop to the ground . as the boom descended it stuck <NAME> <NAME> a glancing blow to the back of his head , causing him to momentarily to lose consciousness . ( approximately 3 minutes ) The emergency services were called and they took control of the operation . <NAME> <NAME> was kept in hospital under observation for 24 hours before being released

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Gas engineer while transiting back to his vehicle , triped , slipped , and banged his head against his works van and the operatives belived he may have been knocked unconcious for a couple of seconds .
sub contractors rope snapped whilst he was on the roof of a van resulting in him fallingfrom the vehicle

Carrying a tool up a ladder , that should of required more than one person. Ladder slip , resulting in a fall from height.New method statement to instruct correct use of ladders , correct carrying and manual handling of equipment .

The driver of the wheeled forward tipping parked the vehicle and removed the keys. He faced the vehicle to climb down the footplates to the ground level. He lost his grip on the hand hold and fell to the ground causing a cut to the head and whiplash type injuries.He lost conciousness for a short period of time. An accident investigation was undertaken and no fault could be found with the vehicle or PPE worn. A tool box talk is being conducted to highlight the need to maintain a firm grip. In addition a medical is to be arranged when the driver returns to work and before operating plant.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Not being present , I can only advise with the information detailed on the accident report form.Casualty slipped on slippery brick step , fell , and struck head , the casualty was unconscious for approximately 5 seconds . A cleaning schedule is in place , but the regularity of the cleaning will be increased in this area .

The IP had been pointing brickwork whilst standing in a shallow ( 0.5metre ) excavated trench . The base of the trench was muddy and as the IP stepped out his boot became stuck in the mud . The IP pressed hard on his other foot to free himself but stepped onto a curved length of plastic pipe . The pipe swivelled up and hit the IP in the face . The IP was able to walk to the site office but became unconscious whilst recieving first aid . The IP was unconcious for a few minutes , he was attended by paramedics and was concious when he was taken to hospital . The IP was examined at the hospital and there were no facial fractures . The site is regularly inspected and found to have a good standard for housekeeping . The pipe was being installed by a nearby colleague att the time of the accident . All site contractors have been reminded that good housekeeping standards are important to reduce the risk of this type of incident .
cutting out and removing floor boards , knelt on a board already cut and fell forwards , onto the concrete floor on his head
Whilst transporting a long plastic pipe for re stocking it slipped of the fork lift and collided with employees head .

While working on a low level scaffold ( 1.2m high ) at the rear of the new build property , <NAME> <NAME> went up on the cavity wall ( Wall height 2.8m . ) He got onto the wall to lift the end of a steel ,so a packer under the steel could be removed.The packer was removed by <NAME> <NAME> . Moments later <NAME> <NAME> fell off of the wall.The actual fall or slip was not seen at the time but I ( <NAME> ) saw his feet as he fell from the wall . <NAME> <NAME> fell on the other side of the wall inside the building in the kitchen area . I (<NAME> ) and <NAME> <NAME> went straight to him . He was found lying on the other side of the wall unconscious and with blood coming from his nose . An ambulance was called by myself and first aid given . He regained consciousness within 1 to 2 minutes.The Ambulance arrived shortly after and <NAME> <NAME> was taken to hospital . Before he left site he was talking .All work on the site was stopped and the site has been closed since the accident occurred
TELEPHONE REPORT IP was climbing up the tower , fell backwards onto lower platform and banged head onto wall which left IP unconcious .

The injured person was in the men 's changing room , preparing for the days work when a freestanding metal locker was knocked over and struck the injured person on the head whilst he was bent over tying his boot laces . The locker was dented and the adjacent locker fell onto another person , who manged to stop the falling locker with his arm .

The accident occurred on <NAME>  <NAME>  at <NAME> <NAME> Homes ( <NAME> <NAME> ) . The IP was cleaning in <NAME> 4 of the show houses , whilst wiping the window ledge the curtain pole fell and struck the IP on the top right side of their head . The IP blacked out unconscious for a short time . When they came round their discovered that the heavy curtain pole with curtains had come away from the wall . The IP suffered from shocked and was very disorientated when they came around . The IP made an appointment with their GP on <NAME>  <NAME> and was diagnosed with post concussion syndrome . Actions : - Risk assessments have been developed and implemented for lone worker cleaning showhouses on site . - To replace heavy curtain poles with lighter curtain poles in showhouses .

Form being completed late as we believed this to be the duty of the IP 's employer , Strongclad , but he had not done this and he has asked us to submit it . The IP was involved in the replacement of an existing cement bonded asbestos roof with new fibre cement sheeting . He stepped onto the roof without being harnessed to his anchor point , the sheet broke and he fell to the floor . HSE attended the incident immediately and a full investigation is on going by both ourselves and the HSE

<NAME> <NAME> went to their site container to collect his kneeling pads did not secure container door and and was hit by the door as it swung back during strong winds . in future door is to be fasten open when entering container .

IP was working on cfa piling for foundations for new structure . The concrete line between the pump and the augers became blocked with concrete . In the process of clearing the blockage , a slug of concrete which was under pressure was ejected from the end of the concrete line and hit the IP on the safety helmet . This caused the IP to fall backwards . eye witness reports suggest that the IP was knocked unconscious for "few moments " or " for approx 20 secs " . IP was taken to hospital as a precaution . He was not admitted but discharged straight away . Ongoing investigation being held jointly by employer , principal contractor and ourselves in order to determine root cause and actions to prevent future occurrence .

<NAME> <NAME> (  <NAME> ) has been a subcontractor for <NAME> <NAME>  now for approximately 3 years . He has over 20 years experience and is fully qualified for all electrical and mechanical jobs and well versed on working at height , including relevant safety procedures . Predominantly <NAME> has been based at the <NAME> & <NAME> site and during this time has also completed additional health and safety courses , including Manual Handling, Site Induction all in line with <NAME> & <NAME> own health & safety requirements .After <NAME> were awarded the job to dismantle the mezzanine floor at <NAME> & <NAME> we then contacted <NAME> to give him the job brief on the electrical aspects that he needed to complete . This included isolating a fuse board and taking out the ground floor ceiling lights and associated electrics . As a sub contractor the method he applied to complete this was up to him but <NAME> <NAME> had told <NAME> to be more focused , concentrate and not to get distracted on the day in question.Prior to commencement safety precautions had been put in place including barriers and tape warnings at the base of access points to the mezzanine floor , barriers or warning tape on 1st floor perimeter , site briefing with team specifically stipulating only authorised people can go on the mezzanine , everyone issued Safety Equipment (Safety Boots, Eyewear, High Vizs, Face Masks, Hard Hats etc).On the  <NAME> , <NAME> had isolated the local fuse board ( for the mezzanine Floor ) and had started disconnecting the armed cable between the mezzanine floor and the fuse box . He was aware that the ground floor team were dismantling shelving units , and the racking engineers were on the mezzanine dismantling the flooring . At around 14:30 <NAME> was tracing an odd cable that went into trunking and not to the fuse board , he went to the mezzanine level and kneeling on the floor put his hand onto shelving to look for the cable . In leaning forward the shelving gave way and he fell 2.44 metres to the ground floor and was taken to hospital where he stayed overnight and was released the following day  sustaining cuts and bruising to his face and shoulder.Following the incident , the Racking Engineers do not move any barrier work etc until the flooring area is ready for lifting . Ground floor barriers have been placed at the base of all access points to the mezzanine and at the top of stairs additional precautions have been added , again preventing access . Should an authorised person need to go onto the mezzanine then they have to make contact with the racking engineers to ensure where they need to go is still safe and precautions are in place and secure . A further briefing has been held with all site staff and specific work areas have been designated to ensure that no one is in the area of the racking engineers as well as regular safety equipment checks during the day .

Injured party was laying flooring on first storey of new build property . Has placed board down with glue and then stepped onto board - board has slid where glue was still wet and effectively opened a " trapdoor " in the floor beneath injured party . Has then fallen onto concrete floor of ground level , approximately 2.5 to 3m .

<NAME> <NAME> is employed as a gateman at the project . His duties are to control access and egress of vehicles from the site . He is not authorised to work at height or carry out repairs . There appeared to be a leak from the waste pipe on the stacked cabin and it would appear that <NAME> has taken it upon himself and unknown to anyone else on site to make a repair and has obtained some step ladders . We are unsure of where the ladders are from at present as they are not <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> 's or the concrete frame contractor 's ladders . <NAME> was found on the floor by the ladders and we believe he has leant the step ladders up against the cabin to access the waste pipe and has overstretched causing the ladders to slip which has caused <NAME> to fall and we believe bang the back of his head on the site hoarding . The site first aiders report that <NAME> was not fully responsive when they arrived , but did respond to the Ambulance crew which was called .

At approximately 03:30 , 5-10 minutes after completing spraying the primary lining to escalator 9 & 10 heading , the IP was removing the nozzle and turbo from the aruga , when a large area of shotcrete dropped from the crown onto the bench and then bounced and slid to the ground , on the way catching the IP on his right side pushing him over and into the machine . At this point the IP 's colleague attended to him and removed him from the immediate area , he then removed his versaflow helmet . Although the IP 's eyes were open , he appeared to be unconcious , first aid treatment commenced and after a brief moment he came round . The emergency services were called and the IP was lifted up the shaft in a stretcher . The ambulance crew checked him out and he walked himself to the ambulance .An emergency daily review meeting was held immediately to ascertain the process of making the area safe and to stop all SCL works until further notice . On <NAME>  <NAME> another DRM was convened to review the technical details and the recommendations were:-1 . DRM sheet revised to deal with specialised activities .2 . Recommendation of layer thicknesses with specified time gap between each layer of SCL.In tandom a Senior Managers review meeting was convened to discuss the possible causes and agree an action plan as part of the investigation and close out , which includes:-1 . Re-check all stages have been design checked and verified .2 . Incorporation of specific layer thickness within the RAMs.3 . Review possible reasoning why SCL could have dropped .4 . Setting up permit to Spray - which includes exclusion zone is specifically demarcated .5 . Verification of nozzlemans ' competency .6 . Review the timings ( i .e . weekends/night shift ) of new operations .

My name is <NAME> <NAME> i worked for <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> for about 2-3 years in lots of different construction sites , but on the last site where i was working is called : <NAME> <NAME> based in  <NAME> , The managers on that site are pushing everything to the maximum so they can get good bonuses from their bosses by finishing the job before the specified time they have , and always ignore the construction rules , so the job is done quickly and they are pushing everybody who works in there (Labourers, Handy Man, Ground Workers Engineers) to work harder than they should like slaves , and always put people like labourers to do the jobs that they are not for them , or even cheatting on their work sheets from their computers by telling them you didnt clock in , you ware late that day , maybe you forgot to clock out , you shouldnt stay overtime and even if you worked overtime you are not gonna get paid for it , pushing to work very long hours on electrical tools , like with kangos , floor plenners , heavy drills , they tell us to work 9-10 hours without changing with someone else just so they can get more money for them selves at the end of the job.On the  <NAME> we have been working all different kind of jobs like : drilling holes , concreting , breaking concrete , cutting rebar and at about 16.00 i was lifting with others heavy blue bins of wet concrete on top of 4 weels trolley , i think they are about half a tonne or 1 tonne weight and i felt real bad back pain in that moment but i though i will get on with it and continued working till about 17.30 or 18.00 . But the next day was friday and had to go back to work and i thought i need to get up same like every other day at about 06.00 so i can go back to work but i felt i couldnt move like before and had a very very back pain when i tried to get up from my bed and i have send a text message to <NAME> ( the Project manager ) of that site telling him that i have a very bad back problem from lifting up heavy concrete blue bins and i need to see the doctor to see the outcome of it , but i never got a reply from him , he ignored my message . I got up of my bed and went to see the doctor in <NAME> <NAME> and i told him i had a very serious pain from work and could even lose my job because of this and he have seen me that bad i felt the pain by touching my back , he told me to lay in the bed to test me so he can tell me where the problem is , by lifting up my legs , by moving they around in different positions and he gave me Lablets ( 100 tablets CO-CODAMOL to take them 2 tablets x 4 times a day + 84 tablets ibuprofen 1 tablet x 3 times a day ) for the bad pain i had and he told me to not move so much for at lease 2-6 weeks because its a real big problem and all this happened from <NAME> ignoring the conctrustion rules and pushing everybody to work to hard so they can grab some money for them selves , and dont even care about health and safety at work .

The Injured Party ( IP ) was tasked to undertake maintenance/ cleaning duties within a swimming pool . The IP had drained the pool using the equipment provided . The IP accessed the empty pool using the fitted steps , he went over to the filter cover plate & undid the catch lock using the tools provided.The IP lifted the cover plate ( approximate size 1000mm x 750mm ) . The cover plate had a thin film of grease smeared to it . Under the cover plate was a drop down catch that should have dropped to take the weight of the cover/ hold the cover plate open ; this did not drop down.The IP reached under with his left hand to engage the catch , it was at this point he lost his grip on the cover plate ; because of the grease , and it came down upon his left hand.The IP sustained crush injuries to his left hand . He was seen by [NAME] hospital , the hand was x-rayed - no broken bones , however large amounts of swelling to the hand.The IP was administered pain relief ; paracetamol & Ibuprofen.

<NAME><NAME><NAME> was employed by the company on <NAME>, his role is to install a range of flood mitigation products at residential and commercial premises across the UK.  Previously <NAME> has worked as a bricklayer and has worked in the construction industry since leaving school.  <NAME> initially completed 5 days installation training for flood protection product installation at the Flood Professionals Training Centre - <NAME>.  After completing his training and induction, he was partnered with an experienced installer (<NAME> - start date: <NAME>). On <NAME> <NAME> (together will all company installers) attended a refresher training and awareness day at our Head Office.  The training incl: Manual Handling, First Aid, Asbestos Awareness and Abrasive Wheels.  In addition all installer were provided with an updated Risk Assessment & Method Statement for the installation of flood mitigation products on site.  Also various H&S related ToolBox talks were also covered.  On the date of the accident, <NAME> was working at the advised address (as part of a two man team - with <NAME>). <NAME> started to cut the lawn back (using a spade) in readiness for the installation of an Non Return Valve to a main drain pipe (below ground).  Whilst crouching down, to lift the turf back, <NAME> experienced shooting pains in his back and couldn't get up, so called <NAME> for assistance.  However, <NAME> continued to dig, <NAME> observed that <NAME> stopped and seemed to look stiff.  <NAME> advised <NAME> that he was in pain and couldn't move.  <NAME> assisted <NAME> to lay down, <NAME> then called 999 to request an ambulance.

description: <NAME> was grouting a mosaic wall in a bathroom on top of a hop-up ( 45 cm high ) , he then needed to come down of the hop-up to catch a bucket of water . In the area , where he was working  shower tray , there is a step of 10 mm to make the slop in the tray . After tipping asphalt into the pan of the paving machine , the banksman saw that the tailgate retaining bar had come loose and was in danger of damaging the pan of the machine . The banksman instructed the lorry driver to lower the body and wait until he re-positioned the retaining bar into its correct position . As the banksman reached over the pan side and grabbed the handle , the paver reversed off the lorry and trapped his hand between the retaining bar and the pan side.The banksman failed to adequately communicate with the paver driver of his intentions which resulted in the paving machine moving. Action to prevent a similar occurrence. Communicate the incident to all operational personnel ( including sub contractors ) so they are aware of the incident.Reiterate the correct lines of communication ensuring everyone is aware of what is happening on site .Reiterate that lorry drivers are responsible for the operation of their tailgate .Revisit the use of banksmen with a view of removing them from a vehicle/pedestrian interaction point .

The IP had been asked to position 2metre long concrete beams on the foundation of plot 80 . The agreed practice is for the telehander to lift and position each beam into place , guided by the workers . The IP took it upon himself to position the beam manually and in the process of moving the 2m concrete beam to its required location , dropped the beam on his own right hand , causing a cut . First aid was given at the time for the cut and the worker carried on with his job ( now with the telehandler assisting to carry out the task correctly ) for the rest of the day . The next day the IP called in sick and sought medical advice . It was then determined that he has crushed the guiders in the middle finger of his right hand and an operation will be required . He has not been back to work since and is awaiting the operation , which we believe is to take place today ( <NAME> <NAME> ) . On the IP's return to work he will be interviewed and if found to not have been following the agreed method , he will be subject to the company s disciplinary process. Operatives on that site  including the IP when he returns to work ) will be asked to re-read the method statement and risk assessment and re-sign to confirm their understanding and commitment to following the agreed method . The <NAME> <NAME> supervisor will be asked to closer supervise the ongoing works .

Following removal of the chimney stacks and associated steel frame , the steel plates anchoring the frame to the foundations were being removed . The bolts were being cut using oxy/propane and a telescopic handler used to remove the plate to the steel skip for disposal . There were 5 steel plates in total to remove . This was the last steel plate . All bolts had been cut and the tele-handler /forks projected outwards and used to collect the steel plate . The IP went upto the forks to guide the plate on and instructed the tele-handler operator to tilt the forks back . Unbeknown to them both the forks were stuck on a bolt that had not been cut down to slab level . This caused pressure on the forks and finally when the forks became free the stored energy released 'flicking ' the steel plate in the air and onto he nose of the injured person and in the process breaking it . Actions taken to prevent a recurrence were to ; ensure all bolts are cut all the way through ; whilst mechanical works are in progress all personnel are to vacate the immediate area ; should problems arise and manual assistance be needed stop all mechanical works first until the problem has been rectified .

Removing 134KG roll of lead from scales . Lifting one end to pivot on opposing end.Twisted and pulled muscle , and went home for the rest of the day .Resumed normal duties following day and until the end of that week , 3 days.Claimed industrial injury for the next week , with doctors note , which may be ongoing .
DP was part of a team refurbishing an old toilet block when a section of wall approx 10ft high collapsed on top of him

Telephone report. DP came in to derelict property asking for work from person maintaining building.  Person maintaining building went off to get tools, came back and found that the DP had fell from the roof or scissor lift.

The injured person was using a pick axe when it got stuck under a kerb stone which was being replaced . In trying to release the pick axe the individual decided to use a lump hammer to assist him with removal . He struck the pick axe with a lump hammer and a piece of steel / metal went into the injured persons hand . Operative should not have used a lump hammer for this activity .

The injured person ( IP ) was manually handling rubble from a works van into a waste skip . The rubble was in tub buckets ( “gorilla buckets ” / “trugs ” ) and whilst carrying out this process the IP alleged that he sustained an injury / strain to his lower back . The incident wasn’t reported at the material time . Later in the morning the IP reported the matter to his line manager and took leave from his duties . The IP self-certificated for the first 5 days and has subsequently been declared unfit for duties until [Date] by his GP.  The IP had received instruction on manual handling operations and the requirement to seek assistance should it be required . A tool box talk refresher training session has been delivered to all operatives in order to prevent a recurrence .

A crew member reported that he sustained a muscular injury to his abdomen when manually lifting a cable transfer roller on the cable chute. The lift was carried out alone and envolved having to lift the roller which weighs approx. 30Kg to chest height.The injury was not reported at the time of the occurrence as the IP stated that he thought it was a muscle strain rather than an actual injury. After treatment in Hospital, IP was diagnosed with a umbilical fracture.

Went to his van at 2am to get tape . No lighting in the car park only from the internal light in the van . Bending down pick up tape and struck his eye on 3 brazing rods which was sticking up from his tool bag . Continue with joba nd then drove home
whilst moving a sheet of render board the operative lost grip and sustained a torn muscle injury to his arm

Lifting debris bag which was too heavy resulting in possible hernia.Manual handling training had been given with information regarding not overloading debris bags and testing weight prior to lifting . Now returned to work - refresher on TILE given by manager . This injury was not reported as an accident at work until his return <NAME> .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: <NAME> had left site and realised he had forgotten something , he returned to site to get it and he tripped causing him to fall and injure his knee .

White thermoplastic boiler was lit without due regard to contents . Boiler was practically empty and left too long . Employees decided it was too hot and potentially a gas blast could occur (this is in their RA) and decided to open the lid with a metal mould . This they did with no consequence , thinking they had gone past the danger period they then reached across to open the lid fully . On fully opeining the oxygen got to the superheated pastic causing an instantaneous flare up that caught employee on the left forearm causing a flash burn . He was off work for two days , the weekend and the following week , a total of nine days .Investigations revealed that he was wearing the wrong type of glove ( a cold work glove instead of a leather gauntlet ) and not wearing forearm protectors . A meeting was held at the company HQ on <NAME> to review the circumsatnces of the accident . Employee was re-introduced to the systems and importance of wearing correct PPE reinforced .

A  landslip occurred, during a period of heavy rain, above an area where a retaining wall was being built.  The land entered the building and one occupant died.  The building was subsequently demolished.

[NAME] appeard to trip over a bucket of mortar causing him to fall through a void in the floor onto the fall arrest system below . [NAME] appears to have hit his head on a fixed steel beam during his fall resulting in head trauma .

The operative was bending/folding sheet metal . 45 degree bend completed , final fold operation being undertaking by folding metal. Inserted into press to form folded edge . The right hand arm of the press was in an open position whilst inserting metal .Press arm came down trapping and crushing right hand index finger in the jaws of the press .

Employee was inspecting drainage investigation works but not involved in the operation of plant, jetting operation was being undertaken in excavation at rear of footway, jetting hose withdrawn from excavation, employee who was stood around 3m away from the excavation was splashed with water.  Employee was not aware of any issue at time of incident but had probelms with eye the following day and subsequently got bacterial corneal ulcer on eye which may have been caused by some contamination in the water.  Employee has been informed by doctor that the infection may or may not have resulted from the water.  Operation staff on jetting operations wear face visors, visiting engineering staff generally are not close to operation and have not previouosly been instructed to wear safety goggles when visiting these sites.  This willl now be reviewed

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Lost footing and fell over on to a steel bracket
The installer was putting/sliding his ladders back into the rear of his van ( <NAME>  ) , about waist high , using an underarm motion , when he felt pain in his left forearm

<NAME> <NAME> ( IP ) was in the process of conducting a routine task which involves lifting a sample of concrete in the sampling bucket to manufacture concrete cubes for testing . As he lifted the bucket which contained only half of the sample he felt some pain in his back . He later visited his doctor who advised him to rest to assist in recovery .
Whilst standing in the smoking shelter having a cigarette a dust particle blew in to his left eye causing scratching to his left eye

DP was undertaking minor roof repairs (first floor bay window roof). No witnesses. He either fell from the roof or from his untied ladder. He sustained a head injury, was taken directly to hospital and did not recover.
DP suffered head INJURIES WHEN HE WAS LOADING MATERIAL INTO THE BUCKET OF A TELEHAMDLER. The DP was struck by the raised bucket.

When clearing site the injured person was using a pallet truck to move a site box down a ramp to be loaded into the van . He chose to ignore standard operating procedures by pulling the pallet truck from the front instead of pushing from the rear and , when he began to lose control , instead of dropping the the truck to lock it in place and prevent movement he chose to turn the handle to the side causing the truck to skew and and the site box to catch him on the leg . This resulted in a torn calf muscle .

Working on roughcasting and re-roofing of a tenant 's house when the employee said whilst working on scaffold that he fell through scaffold batons on the mid-lift on to the ground . The batons on the mid-lift would have to have been moved at least 400mm for this to happen . There were no witnesses to this accident and the scaffold batons were immediately reinstated . All employees were advised to carry out a visual check to ensure the scaffold is safe to use and has not been interferred with or damaged before starting work and report any issues to their supervisor . All scaffolds are also inspected every 7 days or as necessary when in use and the inspection recorded .
Operative was lifting a worktop off the back of his van when it slipped and bent his thumb back causing his tendon to tear

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: whilst taking the pins out of machine to fold it away <NAME> jumped to platform and slipped and fell on right knee

On the morning of the accident <NAME> <NAME> operatives were installing felt and battens on plot 19 roof . As the IP stepped down from the roof over the intermediate internal guardrail which was still in place onto the scaffold approximately 300mm below he went over on his right ankle . The site manager was notified of the accident and the IP was made comfortable by the first aider in order to assess his condition . The IP was then taken by his co-workers to hospital for further examination and an X-ray revealed that he had suffered a chipped bone in his leg . The scaffold board on to which the IP had stepped down from the roof was in the middle of the five board working platform and had a slight indent on the top face . Although the slight damage / defect would not however in itself deem the board to be defective the scaffold board was replaced .
Lifting scaffold material onto shoulder as normal when felt pain on shoulder. Loss of grip and mobility in shoulder.
working on metal deck roof with filon sheets , accidently stepped onto a filon sheet and fell through into building landing inside into passage

The DP was working from a Genie Boom lift removing sheeting from a temp haki scaffold roof which had been installed across No 8 Dock . He was working with a team of scaffolders (3) located in the dock bottom who recovered the cut sections of sheet as they dropped to the dock bottom. In the process of manoeuvring the MEWP he has become trapped on the underside of a scaffold beam . He was 'released' and taken to ground level where he was attended by medics . Sadly he was declared dead at the scene
DP was electrician working from ladder tying electrical cable at a height of approx 9ft, fell from ladder as ladder slipped sideways.

Contractor had completed repairs to flat roof and noticed an air conditioning unit had been left - he went back on the roof and as he went to throw it off it attached to his PPE and the weight of the unit took him with it .

During the process of relocating a mewp frame one of 4 support feet which had been temporarily bolted to the frame to prevent falling revolved on the retaining bolt and trapped the erectors left thumb.

A miscommunication/lapse in concentration during a lifting operation resulted in an unauthorised operation of the machine boom . The injured party suffered a crush injury to two fingers on his right hand as it was caught between the lifting hook and lifting magnet

Operative In Canteen, Hot Coffee knocked off table and spilt on ankle resulting in scald to right ankle resulting in some redness and blistering that makes it uncomfortable to put safety boots on. Christmas Holidays mean that Operative will be away from work for seven days.

Assisting colleagues in the raising of a shutter curtain to enable access to an area at the rear of the property . The individual went to take a hold of the curtain at the same time as others , but shortly after doing do , pulled away , complaining of a pain in his upper arm .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Putting up fencing around school to make area safe site ( carrying and erecting fencing ) , put foot in hole next to manhole and put full weight onto ankle causing torn ligaments on left ankle .

It is understood that  <NAME> <NAME> ( the IP ) had just completed loading his van following his undertaking of a plate load test ( heaviest item weighing no more than 10kg ) . He then bent over to pick up his gloves that were on the floor and twisted round to respond to a question from his client when he felt an extreme pain in his back and legs . The ambulance service were summoned to site and treated <NAME> <NAME> to relieve his pain diagnosing trapped nerves at that time . <NAME> <NAME> was subsequently advised to take painkillers and anti-inflammatories . He was absent from work for one day but remains on light duties for the time being and has been referred to our Occupational Health  service for support in returning to work in his full capacity .

DP was due to help me paint exterior linnings of dormer windows at the property. He was to meet me at the job to foot the ladder, however he arrived before I did and went up the ladder without me which he was not supposed to do. Unfortunately, I dont know exactly what happened as I was not there. I received a call to say he had had a fall and was in hospital, to which upon my arrival I was told he had passed away.
tool box will be give once return to work on bending and lifting
Screwdriver slipped whilst removing bin wheels and punctured palm of left hand
Felt  and battening a garage roof , when saw slipped and cut through thumb/tenden

The operative was breaking a concrete foundation with a hand held breaker and did not have his safety goggles on which were provided . A very small piece of concrete broke off and penetrated his eye .
DP Fell from 3rd floor window to concrete surface at basement level to rear of property, whilst carrying out repairs to sash window.
struck in left eye by nail

*TELEPHONE report- During installation of precast concrete wideslab unit for flooring the IP was struck on the foot by the precast concrete unit . This caused injury to toes . The IP was taken by ambulance to hospital . The IP 's toes were crushed and resulted in a fracture , could lead to possible amputation .
Employee was lifting a board off the back of our Scaffold lorry and as he lowered the board down to an employee on the ground, he fell down with the board, off the back of the lorry.

The FCU ring was located in the wrong place so wearing glasses the engineer drilled through the wall and went down the ladder to place the drill on the floor and removed his glasses - Began to reroute the cable and it flicked up and scratched his eye

Whilst manually manoeuvring a small trailer to be hitched to a transit van an injury was sustained to <NAME> <NAME> 's Achilles tendon

The fitting team were installing structural glazing on the first floor at <NAME> <NAME> as part of a extensive project . They were turning around the fourth glass panel . The employee was holding on to a corner when the pain in his back and leg occurred . To prevent similar incidents we will arrange refresher manual handling training .
An air handling unit had fallen onto a work colleague . I attempted ,with the help of one other ,to lift the unit of him .
DP suffered severe head injuries and died as a result of a fall from height apparently whilst painting.

IP was passing a carpenter operating a planning a door with an electric planner - it would appear the carpenter released the trigger and the machine was running down , when his right hand index finger touched the exposed blade of the plane . [NAME] Homes carried out investigation - Our Safety Advisors carried out an investigation , remedial suggestions / recommendation regarding designated cutting areas , signage and housekeeping have all been addressed .

The injured person was removing a timber beam using a small metal bar to loosen it from the brick , when doing so the person broke the brick and a piece (5cm ) chipped off and hit him in the right eye . He was not wearing eye protection .
Clearing Debris  turned & slipped  through floor opening being worked on .

Employee was marking up for remedial works to an abutment at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> . <NAME> went to move further down the line and had to duck and bend under an acrow prop . When employee went to straighten up he felt a sharp pain in left knee and was unable to put any weight on the leg when the knee was bent .
The IP was pushing a podium along when a one of the wheels has gone into a hole where a cover for a floor box would normally be . This caused the IP to fall and twist and land on his back .
Unwrapping 5.5m lengths of downpipe , packaging broken and hand swung back into a skip with force . Skip was behind him .

[NAME] [NAME] was drilling into a concrete soffit with a [NAME] hammer drill and he was wearing safety glasses whilst carrying out the drilling operation . He says that when he lowered his head to climb down from his podium some dust fell through the gap around his safety glasses and entered his left eye . He reported it to his supervisor and the site First aider. Sterile eye wash solution was used to irrigate his eye , then he was taken to [NAME] and [NAME] [NAME] for further medical attention . He returned to normal work operation on [Date]

The fencing contractors arrived on site to re-configure the pedestrian gate and main site entrance gates . The operatives carried out a general site induction prior to commencing works . The ground worker carried out a scan of the ground using a cable avoidance tool to identify any cables . This process identified 1 cable within the footpath running parallel to the site entrance . A 2nd cable was identified running into the site not in the area of the dig to the proposed new excavation . The operatives then proceeded to excavate the new post hole using a grafter and electric hilti heavy duty breaker and there was concrete in the hole , it was at this time that whilst breaking out the concrete the operative <NAME> struck the buried cable with the breaker . The IP <NAME> <NAME> suffered <NAME> eye to his right eye following incident .

<NAME> fell off of a step ladder whilst installing a conservatory at our customers house . We will continue to carry out risk assessments on site and regular talks to fitters about working safely at heights .

DP was working in a shrub bed, preparing to install a safety rail. During his work he has fallen off of the raised bed and injured himself when he landing on the pavement, subsequently died from his injuries.

Scaffolding operations were being carried out at the time . Operatives positioned themselves on different lifts of the scaffold structure and were lowering a scaffold tube from one to the other . During this activity the injured person had not properly taken the weight of the tube and it dropped on his foot . A toolbox talk has been given to emphasise the need for operatives to communicate confirmation that they have taken the weight of material from the operative passing it to them .
<NAME> <NAME> was fixing guttering when the leg on his ladder bent over ( he was using his own ladder , but mine was on site )

The IP had instructed a colleague to reverse a works vehicle (van ) which was parked on site . Whilst the vehicle was reversing the IP walked around the rear of the vehicle and was struck by the vehicle causing the IP to fall to the floor . Vehicles to be parked in designated areas and banksman to be used for al reversing activity
Cutting section down on basket tray and a piece of metal richochet and cut his eye

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

The employee was on his dinner break and decided to use the tramlines in the area where is was working prior . He had permission from the fit out company however not from <NAME> . He collided with another person and damaged his leg . He went back to work but found his leg was hurting so informed his supervision that he wanted to go home early as his leg was hurting . At this point it was assumed that it was only a bruised leg so the supervisor booked him off site and he went home . He went home and found his leg swelled up and he then went to the <NAME> <NAME> in <NAME> to have it inspected . It was discovered that he has a fractured fibula and he has now been put in plaster and is off work for 4 weeks until his appointment for an assessment . We have filled out a incident report in <NAME> 's office and the companies accident book however this was not really an accident caused undertaking a working activity . We have reviewed our RAMS to now include the use of recreational equipment on site where applicable .

The IP was installing chipboard flooring on top of floor joists that he had installed previously . Was fitting the last few rows of flooring at the time of sustaining the injury . At time of accident IP was standing on the scaffolding , lifting a sheet of flooring from the loading bay . It was one of the last sheets in the pack , therefore was lifting sheet from floor level . As he picked the sheet up , he felt something go in his back . After 15-20 minutes he could hardly move . A tool box talk will be given on manual handling , and method statement will be reviewed for this operation .

IP was pulling a small diameter street lighting cable through a duct . He twisted sideways and trapped a nerve in his back . He returned to work on the <NAME>  and then went off work again and returned on the  <NAME>  with a sick note . The IP has now been off work for more than 7 days .

Employee was asked to move some items from the site storage unit as the site was being demobilised as works had completed . The employee has a pre existing back condition and had not brought the matter to employers attention . Manual handling lifting operation caused inflammation of pre existing condition . A review of the business process has commenced to produce a formal record which will allow employees to note any physical condition which exists that should be brought to employers attention in advance of commencing any works . A written confirmation by all employees will be required . Business safety share developed and distributed to all employees on manual handling considerations and drawing their attention to company procedures pertaining to MH operations and restrictions .

This accident has n't been officially reported but we have endeavoured to contact our employee since we first heard about it . We successfully contacted our employee by phone today . The IP said he was using a  Stillson Pipe Wrench to tighten up a connection in a pipe and as he was putting pressure on to it it slipped and he dropped the wrench and jarred his back . He said that he had done this on the  <NAME>  but had n't reported it . He worked on the 11th & 12th <NAME>  and he said it was easing through the day but was very sore at nights . He said that he was going to see how it was resting over the 3 day weekend ( <NAME> , <NAME> & <NAME> ) . He felt worse over the weekend so went to the doctor on the <NAME> , the doctor said he had torn a muscle . The IPs first day of absense was the  <NAME> and the self medication form was filled in on the  <NAME> . The details of the accident cannot be verified as there were no witnesses and it was n't reported to the site or any of his colleagues so could have happened anywhere , at any time and on any day .

Landlord was carrying out repair work to roof using various substances . Failed to ensure that vapours from substances could not ingress into the building , which caused a severe asthma attack to be brought on . Paramedics called advised attendance at hospital released home on same day . Treated by doctor at home there after

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: I was returning to my office after the morning safety checks . I pulled open the heavy steel plated door , ducked my head to enter my office ( the opening is lower than my height ) and proceeded to trip on the 45mm concrete step ( 2 inch ) when entering . I stumbled forward but retained my balance and immediately sat down at my desk . I completed some paper work/emails and after approximately 15 to 20 minutes I stood up and felt a searing pain in my lower back area .

<NAME> <NAME> opened her front door and in the garden she has scaffold tube as [NAME] are repairing on the property and all properties on the street , <NAME> <NAME> came from her front door focusing on on her grandchild not looking at the path and hit her foot on the sole pad under the scaffold tube that was in the garden , she tumbled and didnt want to hit the ladders that were there and tumbled over again and hit her hand against her gate and broke her hand on her front gate , then realising when she fell the other was broken also , Her granddaughter picked her up and Telephoned an Ambulance , We have given the Householders as much of an area clear, thats why the Sole Pad was in the Garden and not on the Path, We will look into how we can prevent this happening again

When electrician feeding cables through to back box for a temporary supply his hands came into contact with an unknown substance , subsequently thought to be a DPC cream applied a week earlier , which resulted in a reaction to the skin of his hands and has since been diagnosed as dermatitis .

Injury occurred whilst holding steel rods in place for colleague to weld together . As welding wire struck steel it ricocheted off steel and struck [NAME] 's index finger on left hand , penetrating the skin .

The machine driver swung the lever around by accident & the bucket hit [NAME] 's knee . pushed cartilage and torn all ligaments in knee , operation has been booked for [Date] . This has been revised since further information received from worker on 14/05/13 - previous report sent in [Date]

The IP was returning across the site from using the toilet. he walked passed an area where scaffolding was erected and being dismantled . The scaffolding contractors where dismantling the scaffolding and throwing the scaffold poles from a height of 7m above the ground . The scaffolders mate was supposed to be positioned at the foot of the scaffolding to assist with the dismantling , collection and stacking of poles however he was positioned on the top lift of the scaffolding assisting another work colleague . As the IP walked passed the scaffolding to return to the workplace he was struck on the head by a 5/4 scaffold pole . The IP immediately fell to the ground . The main contractor of the site is [NAME] . The Injured person immediately received first aid from the project manager and then he was taken to the minor injury Unit at [NAME]. The IP was seen by a ENP at the hospital . The IP was wearing head protection at the time of the incident .

Whilst passing/handling a scaffolding board up to a colleague on the next lift , felt splinter go into hand ( right ) and through glove . Carried on working , did n't think anymore about it at the time . I thought splinter had come straight out . Over next day , hand started to swell and become more painful . As the swelling and pain got worse over the weekend , I went to hospital on <NAME>  <NAME>  , ended up having operation to remove splinter .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: Stepping off a 490mm platform and went over on ankle , has a reoccurring ankle injury .

I was a passenger in my partners vehicle being driven south in <NAME> <NAME> and just after passing the junction with <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> a overladen JCB fork lift exited the building site on the west side of <NAME> <NAME> . Due to the extremely high load he was carrying he would have had no forward vision at all . There was no banks man in attendance .My partner stopped his car and was as close to the kerb as possible , we were unable to mount He kerb due to the high kerb stones as the road was not complete . The JCB registration <NAME> completely cut the corner and drove into our vehicle hitting it first with its front tyre then with its rear tyre . The impact was sufficiently hard to rock the car side to side on each occasion.The driver drove off making no attempt to stop and I had to chase after him to get him to stop , he swore and at first accused us of driving into him then stated he could n't see us . He kept driving at me and said he was going to the site up the road ( location not known ).Police were called and attended as did the site manager for <NAME> <NAME> , police declined to report it as it was not a public road . That evening I developed lower back and neck pain which required medical treatment and my partner required medical treatment for his shoulder . Our insurance company have now informed me that the JCB was not insured . I am concerned that <NAME> <NAME> are allowing vehicles to be driven on residential roads uninsured and over ladedso driver was unable to see where he is going . I have photos of the vehicle if necessary .
Shifting kerbs and slabs and pulled tendon on arm
DP was struck by a reversing waste removal vehicle on site.

The operative attempted to lift a steel concreting pipe , whilst lifting he felt a pain in his lower back . He notified the operative who was working with him that he was in pain , his colleague guided him from the working area to the first aid room . A trained first aider attended to the injured person , however the injured person required a medical professional to assess his injury due to the pain , he was taken off site in an ambulance . He has attended hospital , the injury sustained is not known yet .Further manual handling training has been carried out on site with all relevant personnel .
whilst installing cable to new lighting point a coil of cable fell through a gap in the building structure to the floor below hitting a member of the public

The IP was using a pillar drill to bore holes in a stainless steel flange , the work piece was held in a clamp attached the the bed of the drill and the drill was fitted with an interlocked guard , it appears a length of swarf caught on the IP 's boiler suit cuff and pulled his hand against the drill chuck . The swarf cut the thumb of his right hand which was quickly cleaned and a plaster applied . The following day he attended hospital as he was in pain and was treated for a possible chipped bone .

IP was working from the scaffolding drilling hole into gable end wall as preparation to fit plugs into scrin prior to roughcasting . Further action : The quality of the drills bits will be checked . The team will be briefed and a report will be prepared on the findings of the inspection .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level

IP was taken to <NAME> hospital by site manager . Right knee was x-rayed , IP was informed he had a torn ligament .
DP was climbing down a ladder, I could hear the ladder shaking but could not see it and as I looked over the scaffold I saw him falling towards the ground on the right side of the ladder.
DP fell from a tower scaffold whilst working at height adjacent to a car park building.
DP was struck in chest by a grease gun nipple which failed under pressure whilst grease was being pumped into a hydraulic unit on crawler tracks for a piling rig.
DP Fell from ladder whilst carrying out roofing and pointing repairs to a single storey rear extension.

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The accident happened at approx . 13 :15 on [NAME] [Date] outside the property of 48 [NAME]  , [NAME] . [NAME] was getting the ladders down from the roof rack of his van . He came down the ladder which is fitted to the rear door of his van , then stood on the step of the van , but when he stepped down from the van to the roadside/pathway , he landed on the edge of the kerb , twisting his ankle . [NAME]  was on site with him ( witness ) who took him home , and his partner then took him to hospital .

Accident has been discussed with <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> - IP was erecting scaffold on a low level flat roof . 1st lift was erected at 1m high , guardrail was erected to the external faces of this lift . The lift was then boarded out with 2.13m long scaffold boards . Platform was compliant with SG4:10 . IP gained access to the lift by ladder . IP was erecting the next lift , walked to the front of the scaffold to check the level of a transom , when two scaffold boards became dislodged , IP fell through the boards and came to land on the roof some 1m below , striking R hand/thumb and L ankle . It is alleged that the scaffold boards were covered in slime , IP still chose to use these boards and turned them over as the underside was less affected , we are unable to confirm this claim . IP attended hospital , suspected fracture to thumb and swelling to L ankle , hand put in cast . IP was not signed off and returned to work . Attended hospital 12 days later , hand was put in another cast and L ankle was put in a cast . We believe the IP has a scaphoid fracture to R hand , actual injury to L ankle has not yet been fully diagnosed but understand the fall may have aggravated an existing unknown arthritic ankle condition which is now subject to further investigation via MRI scan . IP has not provided a sick note for his absence and was not flagged up as being absent from work , which has lead to us making this late report . Systems will be reviewed to ensure that this cannot happen again.work

The injured party was acting as a banksman for a Telehandler operator . He was walking at the side of the Machine and the wheel pinned his foot . He was wearing Good PPE and this did not injure his foot , however he stumbled and the operator ran over his lower leg in an attempt to release his trapped foot . An ambulance was called and he walked to the ambulance . Thus indicating he had not broken anything however his leg did receive several stitches . He was released from hospital after 4 hours and is recovering at his home . It is now at the point of seven days . He was wearing a high Visibility vest and had been working with the operator of the machine for over 30 years . Both operators were competent to perform all these tasks .

Ground maintenance Team leader was strimming in the external areas of the [Name] estate . While strimming some debris was ejected up and made contact with IP right eye . Although IP was wearing safety goggles the debris flicked up underneath them . No treatment or hospital visit was needed at the time of the incident . IP continued to work for the rest of day and the following two days ( <NAME> and <NAME> ) . However IP was not fit for work on the <NAME> <NAME>. It appears the debris had caused an infection in his eye and as such has been signed off by his GP. (yet to return to work ) The manager carried out an investigation and it was apparent that although IP was following both risks assessment and SSW the debris still flicked up under safety goggles . Review of eye protection has resulted in IP being provided with full facial mask to be worn over the goggles to prevent this accident reoccuring .

The injured person attempted to move a steel personnel door from its position on the floor to an upright position , in preparation for other operatives to aid him in moving it to a suitable storage location . Whilst doing this he pulled/tore his right bicep.

The IP was transporting a single sheet of <NAME> flooring measuring ( 1200mm by 450mm ) , as the IP attempted to put the <NAME> down onto the floor , he lost grip on the board resulting in the board slipping from his grip . The edge of the board struck the top of the IPs left foot above the area protected by the steel toe cap . The IP attended <NAME> <NAME> hospital and was diagnosed with soft tissue damage preventing him from returning to work for two weeks .Investigation of the incident revealed that the operative was not wearing any gloves when handling the board which increased the risk of the board slipping due to the smooth surface finish. The incident and the necessary precautions (use of gloves with textured finish when handling materials ) has been briefed to other site operatives

Operative was part of a gang clearing vegetation through the river <NAME>, the operation consist of walking through the river (Small watercourse with less than 300mm of water in). While cutting a blackthorn branch and using a cutting hook to cut the branch the blackthorn swung back once cut and the thorn hit the operative in the back of the thumb between the nail and knuckle. The operative was wearing hard wearing Kevlar waterproof gloves which have good grip and palm protection but have little back hand protection. Leather gloves were not opted for as they are not waterproof. The operative carried on working for the rest of the day and then visited the hospital in the evening. He also returned and worked the next day, but went home as his thumb was badly swollen and infected. He then went back to hospital where they done a x-ray of his knuckle to confirm whether the thorn had broken off in the joint, This did not show anything so an Ultra sound scan was carried out, they were still not sure. He was then put under general aesthetic where the knuckle was cut open and flushed out where they did find part of the thorn. The Operative was then signed of work for two weeks. For any works of this nature leather gloves will be issued with a number of spare so when the leather gloves are wet then new glove will be worn. we are also looking to find a better glove for the works which offers better all round protection and which are also waterproof.

Following this accident , the use of hearing protection will be included in future site inductions .

description: [NAME] was given a delivery of building materials to deliver to the above address in [NAME] on [NAME] , [NAME] . [NAME] contacted myself ( [NAME] ) by telephone to explain that the address was a building site that was fenced off by metal site fencing and know one was on site to accept the delivery . I Let [NAME] know i would call him back once i had made contact with the customer . I telephoned the customer but got no reply so informed [NAME] i would try again and get back to him . I short time latter i received a phone call from [NAME] (depot manager at our [Name] store ) to say he had spoken with the customer and [NAME], the customer had requested that we do what we could on site to make the delivery as he could not be there to help . On [NAME] re-laying this message to [NAME], [NAME] informed [NAME] that the access to the site was locked to stop him getting in , [NAME] advised again to do what he could . The first i knew of a problem/injury to [NAME] was when he arrived back at our depot at [NAME], [NAME]  he informed me that he had managed to get the fencing open as to compleate the delivery he needed access to the site , but whilst holding the fencing open during the delivery it had swung back and struck him in the face pushing him backwards and off ballance , as he stepped backwards he trod on one of the load spreading pads that he was using for his crane foot and injured his back . I made note in the company's accident book of all [NAME] told me and advised him in future not to move barrier fencing and to return the delivery to our depot if it 's not safe/possable to unload and gave i gave the book to [NAME] to confirm what i had written was correct .

During the loading of 11no . [NAME] floor tables from level 10 of [NAME] [NAME] by a tower crane (TC1 ) onto a trailer to return back to the supplier . The floor tables had been slung by site personnel on level 10 and was being lowered down towards the trailer when it was observed by the crane operator following the change to a slower gear that the 3 ton web slings suddenly move towards the centre of the load causing the floor tables to tip and fall from the two lifting slings , falling approximately 10m above the ground . The floor tables landed on the trailer with a loud bang narrowly missing [NAME]  who was standing on the trailer to the receive the load . It caused [NAME]  to fall from the trailer and it was also reported that a floor table struck a second slinger/signaller [NAME] causing him to also fall from the trailer causing his injuries.The injured personnel were attended to by the site first aiders and the project emergency procedure was implemented and the emergency services were called . On arrival a doctor , paramedics and ambulance crews treated the casualties at the scene before taking them to the local A &E department at [NAME] hospital . At the hospital the injured parties were examines and treat by the medical staff for their injuries then admitted into the hospital for further tests and further monitoring ( [NAME] was treated for chipped bone to her left hip and bad bruising ) . All lifting operations were suspended on site as an immediate safety precaution . The police and the fire services also attended the scene and following the evacuation of the casualties the incident area cordon off by the police and their investigation commenced . The HSE was also notified of the incident.The two injured personnel were release from hospital on the 18/03/16.On investigation and from initial findings the client and [NAME] have implemented of the following :•Monthly ‘Lifting Operation' meeting chaired by the client site management •Daily briefings which includes : o Who are the appointed slinger/signallers and which tower crane they are designated . oLoads for the day . oWeather forecast and wind speed/s . oAgreed communication between client and subcontractors• No standing on any vehicle bed or trailers to receive loads•Use of tag lines with all loads A full investigation into the cause of the incident to be carried out and all lesson learnt to be communicated to all relevant parties .

Over the weekend prior to the incident the main contractor ( <NAME> <NAME> ) imported some loose material to create a safer walkway around the site . This material was compacted however , the walkway was not diverted which meant that on <NAME> morning operatives had to access the actual work site via the old route which meant <NAME> had to walk from a new compacted access route to the old access route which required him to walk over some loose material.It was whilst walking over the loose material when <NAME> stumbled and sustained Cruciate Ligament damage ( as it was later diagnosed ) . <NAME> carried on with his work activity until midday when he approaced the site manager and <NAME> <NAME> safety advisor and informed them of the incident and showed them his knee which was swolen at this point . Both the site manager and safety advisor advised <NAME> to go to hospital to get it checked out which he did . As a precautionary measure the local hospital ( which was a drop in centre ) wanted to put <NAME> in a temporary cast but he refused this stating he had to drive home to <NAME> . <NAME> drove home and visited his local hospital ( <NAME> ) the folllwoing day where they put him in a support cast and told him to rest . The hospital informed <NAME> he had Cruciate Ligament damage .Since the incident the walkway has been diverted and now goes along the compacted material around the site . All <NAME> oepratives ahve been informed of the new access route and asked to notify site managhement of any identified hazards on site .

While carrying out his normal daily duties driving the 15ton lorry , <NAME> <NAME> was working on site at the <NAME> Homes location of <NAME> <NAME> . He was working along side a <NAME> 's folk lift truck driver at the time dealing with the delivery/collection of scaffolding equipment. <NAME> had climbed up onto the back of the lorry while the forklift truck driver was assisting with the equipment loaded on the back . <NAME> advised that he was assisting the equipment at the time but was continuously distracted by the folklift truck driver . Although against company policy , <NAME> should not of been on the back of the lorry , he described himself as not paying attention when accidentally turned the wrong way and stepped off the lorry .There were no issues that directly cause <NAME> to fall off the lorry . The weather conditions were dry , no equipment or persons caused him to fall . He admitted it was his own error and that it was him ,himself who was at fault though not following company procedures ,interfering while there was a forklift in use and accessing the back of the lorry itself.The forklift truck driver witnessed <NAME> failing from the rear of the lorry , but was put at ease as <NAME> advised he was OK and did not require any medical assistance. <NAME> continued to carry out his daily duties as normal that day without informing a line manager until seeing <NAME> <NAME> at 16 :10pm on <NAME> on the <NAME> <NAME> Gardens <NAME> at <NAME> . He advised our managing director , <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> of the incident the same day that it took place . <NAME> <NAME> spoke with <NAME> , who confirmed he was still fit to carry out his work and had no major issues .Following the end of <NAME> 's shift , <NAME> called <NAME> and said he was getting worse so he would be visiting <NAME> hospital.  <NAME> received a text message from <NAME> at 19:29pm & 22:08pm , stating he was still at hospital waiting for an X-Ray followed by an additional text at 22:57pm fro <NAME> stating " No definate fracture as they will not X-Ray " " Also they think my two fingers are broken so i will need to return back in the morning to get a second x-ray as they are too swolen" <NAME> then called in sick the following working day and advised he was a little sore from the event but advising <NAME> <NAME> that he would only require one days abcence and that he would be fit to return back to work on the <NAME>  <NAME> . On <NAME> 's return to work , an accident/incident report was completed during a meeting with <NAME> <NAME> and myself . He advised that he had visited the hospital since his fall and he presumes he has fractured his ribs and damaged the tissue in his finger . He confirmed he did not require any assistance / additional requirements and he was fully fit to return to work and carry out his role .Lee then worked and carried out all his normal duties on <NAME>  <NAME> & <NAME>  <NAME> . communication <NAME> then handed in a sick note for 7days on <NAME> due to presumed fractured ribs

The activity undertaken was resurfacing a section of road under a full road closure with access provided within the traffic management for local employees working for a manufacturing /distribution factory (  <NAME> ) . Work was undertaken at night . The section of road was lit by streetlights . The weather was mild with sporadic rain showers . Access was required within the closure but no access was required or permitted through the works site (area being resurfaced ).A member of the public needed access through the closure to commence night shift in <NAME> <NAME> . The member of public stopped at the entrance to the closure where he was greeted by a gatesman . The gatesman explained that the access was available through the closure to <NAME> <NAME> only and to proceed through the closure with care . The member of the public proceeded through the site at speed and drove into and mounted a pile of road chippings . The member of public exited his vehicle and discussed the incident with the traffic management team . The police and ambulance attended the scene . Following an internal investigation future traffic management sites will have designated coned areas for material and plant storage . Members of the public entering the closure for access will be provided with a card explaining the works and site speed limits . Site speed limits will be imposed with appropriate signage for all closures .
