The following report is from <NAME> <NAME> who was working at the property in question . <NAME> <NAME> is the owner of the property and his wife is <NAME> <NAME> . My name is <NAME> <NAME> and I am a director of the <NAME> <NAME> Services <NAME>.  <NAME> <NAME> is the plumber who was working with <NAME> <NAME> following is my account of the accident at <NAME> 's house at <NAME>road this morning.  <NAME>  - 9am I was asked to go with plumber to assist in investigating a possible leak in radiator pipes under the floor in the kitchen and utility rooms as the boiler was losing pressure , the plumber was n't convinced their was a leak in these areas as the boiler was visibly leaking when we where there so <NAME> took of the main front cover which showed large areas of rust and obvious signs of on going leaks , so this was the way the investigation from <NAME> was going to try to get to the root of the problem. <NAME> phoned <NAME> , when he came off the phone <NAME> immediately phoned <NAME> , after the call <NAME> said we have to go ahead and open up the areas where there could be a possible leak , but to to check under floor in main house first as this was more accessible through a hatch in the hall floor , <NAME> took me to the area in the hall and lifted back the underlay and carpet. I said ' I will go to van for screw gun' , <NAME> said ' I have something to unscrew hatch ' but I said 'it 's ok I will do it ' . i got screw gun and opened up hatch for <NAME> . i said I will head back to the other site for a transformer and circular saw which was required for lifting the other floors.As I drove away I noted the time as 10.01 as this was our usual T break time I arrived at site at <NAME> had my tea , picked up the required tools and headed back to <NAME>.Their was an ambulance in the drive approx 11 o'clock . I entered the house via the garage into utility I was met by <NAME> he said his wife had fell down through the hatch and to let  <NAME> know , I phoned <NAME> and explained the situation , after call I went into house I was shaken and very concerned for her . <NAME> introduced me by saying 'this is the builder here ' . I asked 'how serious is it ? ' and the reply from the medic was 'serious enough ' . <NAME> turned to me and said 'the underlay must have fell back over the open hatch , it 's done that before ' . At that point I put my tools back in the van and came back with my screw gun to screw back down the hatch . <NAME> wife had been moved to the ambulance when I came back in to house , I said to <NAME> 'i never realised your wife was in' . <NAME> said 'it 's not your fault I should have said to her , this is <NAME> fault if he had dealt with these problems at the time my wife would n't be going to hospital ' . I was screwing down the hatch at this point . <NAME> helped put back down the underlay and the carpet . I left at this point and spoke to  <NAME> about the situation . <NAME> <NAME>  <NAME>

* On <NAME>  , the operative was operating the chain driven roller shutter to access the rear yard ;* During the process , the operative rubbed their forearm against an existing steel rail local to the area of operation . No accident report was completed , no blood was drawn and there was no discomfort or at the time , or reason to raise any issue . The contracts manager was also on site and nothing was mentioned to him ;* The operative continued to attend work for the next two weeks without raising an issue , however is now alluding that during those two weeks , they felt they had a splinter ( which they suggest is from the above operation ) , which they continued to "pick at " of an evening and perhaps irritate ;* On <NAME> <NAME> , they attended  <NAME>  NHSwalk in centre with a swollen and infected wound . They were discharged without any medication or follow up action necessary ;* By <NAME>  , their arm and hand had completely swollen and they attended their GP. The GP referred them to A & E whom admitted the operative immediately for IV fed antibiotics for cellulitis. They were discharged from hospital on  <NAME> but had to finish the course of IV fed antibiotics at home through district care ;* They returned to work on <NAME> . Due to the circumstances and ambiguity of the above , we took advice form your RIDDOR helpline whom have confirmed to us that due to the operative 's suggestion of this being a "work related incident" , and even though the timeframes were so , that we should report this under RIDDOR .

description: Employee was asked by the supervisor to return to the yard to get beams that were required on the job . Employee wrongly climbed a ladder to take beams that were stored on the roof of a container . Whilst they took beams from the roof of the container they slipped on ice falling onto their side and onto an object on the same level . They continued to remove the beams , load them onto the lorry and take to the job they were required on . The employees side began to hurt as the day progressed and they attended A & E that evening . No xrays were ordered , analgesics were given and they were told to rest . All employees were reminded that nobody is to access the container roof for any items at any time .

The Technician involved dropped a spanner and whilst bending down to pick it up experienced some discomfort in his back . I was working with [NAME] and [NAME]  removing contents in to black waste sacks . We were also dismantling metal Dexion racking which is bolted together , whilst I was dismantling the racking I dropped a spanner and then bent down to pick it up , the next thing I knew I could not get back up , I had bent over from the hip , so I mean I could not straighten my back . I then called out to [NAME] and let him know that I had back pain , I managed to straighten my back after a little while , the pain disappeared and I continued to dismantle the racking , when I got to the bottom shelving where I had to bend over the pain returned . All of this happen over about an half an hour period which I estimate commenced at 10.30 . At about 11.00 when the back pain returned I left the working area , making my way up the basement stairs to the rear of the building , I left the working area un-assisted , I then tried to walk off the stiffness for no more than 30 minutes ( about 11.30 ) . [NAME] was already in the van doing paperwork and [NAME] was bringing waste out of the boiler room to the top of the stairs , at this point [NAME] called lunch break , as we had to segregate our transit route from the public and this was to be done after lunch . By this point ( about 11.45 ) the pain had increased and at this point I informed [NAME] that I had injured my back and recorded in incident in [NAME] daily dairy, at this point I phoned my GP for an appointment , the earliest appointment I could get was the [NAME] 22nd [NAME] . I volunteered to return to work after lunch for the rest of the day , however I did no more bending just transiting the light bags of waste to the van from the top of the stairs ( about 20 metres ) . At the end of the working day we came back to the yard and unloaded the van , I did not assist with the unloading of our van , after we had done this I was dropped off home . I found it extremely painful to get out of the van at my house , I told [NAME] I hoped to see him in the morning . On the  of <NAME> at approximately 13:30 ,  <NAME> <NAME> was working as part of drylining team when , he was instructed by <NAME> site manager <NAME> <NAME> to complete works on a riser cupboard block 4 ground floor ( for exact area please see attached drawing ) . While carrying out these duties the IP accidentally activated the quarter turn valve lever on the <NAME> hot water pipe. Exactly how this was activated is not known at this time as the IP did not include this information in his brief statement ( please see attached ) . The IP run out of the riser cupboard shouting in pain , operatives assisted the IP and called an ambulance over which was parked locally to the site . The IP received immediate treatment for his burns in the ambulance and taken to <NAME> <NAME> hospital . The IP was admitted for approximately 24 hours before being released . To date <NAME> the IP has not returned to work and is returning to the hospital for treatment weekly . An accident report has been completed by the principal contractor and sub-contractor teams involved. Conclusion The incident happened due to a lack of awareness of the possibility of burns from the M & E equipment and not being capped off and/or quarter turn valve lever M & E actions taken to prevent reoccurrence1 . Cap off all pressurised M & E systems and/or remove quarter turn valve lever as a matter of industry best practise . PC to ensure this is implemented into the M & E teams RAMS and provide suitable supervision process .2 . Incorporate suitable risk signage in these areas .3 . <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> to complete a safety bulletin and create awareness on all sites for all PC's. 4 . <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> to implement this risk into riser specific risk assessment .

<NAME> were employed to remove items of plant such as CHPs and small boilers . An activity that we are employed with on a daily basis . 3 members of the team were moving an item of plant using a pallet truck . Whilst they were moving the load down a purpose built scaffold ramp ( provided by the principal contractor ) one of the boards slightly raised which caused the steering wheel to turn , this imparted a tipping action on the pallet truck . The injured party was walking beside the load at the time and the pallet truck tipped onto his foot . His foot was released immediately . The employee was wearing foot protection but was taken to hospital almost immediately by his father (employee ) as he was complaining of pain . He arrived at <NAME> <NAME> hospital at 13.30hrs , was treated and arrived home at 14.00hrs . His treatment consisted of pain relief and was told to apply ice at home and keep his foot raised.The following day he spoke to <NAME> <NAME>  Operations director to say he would not be in . He then failed to return for a further week in breach of his contract of employment , as he should have made an attempt to either come in or contact one of the Directors to discuss his case . Our procedure would then to have put him on light duties on full pay and monitor the injury to ascertain whether a RIDDOR report was required . Upon his return on the <NAME> he was asked to complete the company sickness form and a return to work interview took place where we discussed the event and if anything could be learnt from it . At that point he was sent to his doctor for a fit note , as we needed some professional confirmation of his injury . The doctor commented on the fit note that he may benefit from 3 days light duties . A RIDDOR report was not raised at this point as his injury was not confirmed until that point.The action points that arose from our discussion and my accident investigation were that all operatives must be continually aware of the changes in their work environment however small , particularly when working alongside multiple trades who may continually affect changes to the working environment . We discussed the merits of strapping down a load to a pallet truck however in this case the truck would still tip . But the employee was reminded that if they felt that on any given day if they recognise that an extra control may mitigate the chance of injury or other damage occurring they should either apply that control of contact a line manager to seek further advice .As we paid the employee SSP for the week he made no contact he has raised a Personal injury claim seeking compensation for loss of earnings and injury . Section C item 2.2 of the claim states ' Are you aware of any rehabilitation needs that the claimant has arising out of the accident ? the solicitors have answered YES. Due to this statement we have to reinstate the light duties , as is our duty of care , as we are not medical professionals and as such becomes reportable under RIDDOR

IP was part of a 3 man team painting windows at ground and first floor level , he placed his ladder to paint first floor kitchen window ( 5s ) the path had slight slope on it and he placed his Rojax ladder stop under one foot of the ladder to level it and the ladder slid out when he climbed it.IP failed to secure the ladder , he did not request anyone to foot the ladder and he did not use the ladder leveller supplied by us will by interviewed on his return to work with regard to his actions which are contrary to normal work practices and instruction/information he has recieved in training

IP was part of a two man team who would follow joiners installing new entrance doors. once at the specific location both members of the team's job was to uplift the old existing timber door and associated timber frame etc, place on the back og a ford pick - up truck and transfer to a designated recycling area. during the manual handling process the IP felt a twinge to his rigth shoulder. the IP states that it did not stop him carrying out his normal working duties at that point but steadily got worse as the week progressed finally reporting the injury to a line manager on the [Date] - manager name morris roberts. during the accident investion it was noted that the i.p. has reported 6 occasions where an accident has occurred during the manual handling of items since [Date] it was also noted that he has attended manual handling traing, has had manual handling tool box talks and has a copy of safety instruction cards pertaining to manual handling. he is also aware of the contents of the ssow. on conclusion of the investigation a decision has been made to send the i.p. on a manual handling refresher course and has been reminded that good manual handling techniques/practices should be adopted on every occasion..

description: The injured person , <NAME> <NAME> , was climbing over a concrete skeletal beam ( approximately 1200mm in height ) using the foot irons fixed to the beam . As <NAME> dismounted from the bottom iron ( approximately 400mm from the floor level ) he placed his foot onto a scaffold tube that was fixed holding down a sheet of plyboard . This caused <NAME> to twist his foot causing him pain. <NAME> immediately reported the accident at the site office . It was decided due to the swelling of the ankle that <NAME> attend A & E . An x-ray confirmed no break to the bones , he was diagnosed with a sprain to the ankle .A full investigation is being undertaken . The following immediate actions have been implemented to date ; Installations of temporary handrails to enable safe use of iron steps . Relocation of hold down scaffold tubes , away from the access steps to the beams and any walkways . Reviewed location of any mateirals stored to ensure safe access to walkways and access points . Toolbox Talks held with all on site informing them of the changes to the RAMS , ensuring they are understood and signed by all operatives on site .

The IP was working from a purpose built scaffold platform of 1.8 metres height on the upper ground floor of block P , securing armoured cables within the electrical riser . At approximately 08.45 the IP needed to leave the platform to retrieve additional cable ties from his toolbox that was situated in the reception area on the ground floor . To access the ground floor , the IP descended a proprietary fixed ladder which provided access to the platform from the floor . There was a self closing gate situated at the top of the ladder to prevent falls from the platform and there were scaffold guardrails adjacent to the top of the ladder to prevent falls sideways when using the ladder . As the IP was in the process of descending that ladder he lost his footing slipped downwards , grabbing the mid rail of the platforms edge protection with his right hand in order to break his fall . This caused trauma to the right shoulder . He then slid down the ladder until reaching the floor . Preventative workshops on work at height and the safe use of ladders have been instigated following the incident .

The injured person ( IP ) was pushing/pulling a trolley cage loaded with ceiling tiles with another operative . The safe system of work detailed the use of a loading bay to use to remove the tiles from the trolley . The IP thought that it would be quicker to transport the load bodily down a staircase located approximately 20 metres away from the loading bay . The loading bay method had been used many times before the incident . When they got to the staircase , the second operative pointed out to the IP that the trolley was too heavy to lift down the stairs so they tried to turn the trolley cage around to return to the loading bay . At this point , the IP put his foot backwards on to the second step on the staircase to provide sufficient room to turn the trolley . As he did this , the trolley pushed him backwards down the metal stairs . The trolley full of ceiling tiles landed on the IP 's left leg . The other labourer quickly moved the tiles and trolley from the IP 's leg and called for help . An ambulance took the IP to Hospital , but he was not detained .

On [Date] at about 15:00 [NAME] scaffolding operatives were assisting [NAME] scaffolding's lorry driver to load bundled materials from the floor onto the bed of the lorry, (the lorry driver was operating the HIAB which is attached to the lorry ) the IP ( [NAME]  ) was about to attach the strops to the HIAB hook when the boom of the HIAB suddenly jerked and knocked the IP against an adjacent wall and subseqently to the ground . after checking whether the IP was ok the IP was instructed by [NAME] scaffolding foreman to rest and go and enter the accident into the main contractors accident book , The IP rested but declined to make the accident book entry . The days work shift ended soon after without the IP taking any further part in working activities . The IP returned to work as normal on [Name] and continued to attend work with the exception of 4 days ( spread intermittantly and on only one occassion did he attribute the time off to injury ) untill [Date] when he informed his contracts manager that he would not be at work for 1 week as he had problems relating to the accident , he was signed off work by his GP on this day for 1 week , he returned to his GP on the [Date] and was signed off for afurther 4 weeks .

On [Date], the Traffic Marshal Supervisor  was working adjacent to the security office of [NAME]  moving boxes containing K-guard components that weighed 19kgs ( this is clearly stated on the boxes ) on the ground floor slab . The Traffic Marshal Supervisor relocated approximately 5-6 boxes The Traffic Marshal Supervisor was working with a general operatiove while undertaking this task . The boxes were moved one at a time . The boxes were transferred approximately 3-5 metres.The boxes are documented as being transferred in a hurry , with the last box being thrown by the Traffic Marshal Supervisor , during this transfer The Traffic Marshal Supervisor realised mid-throw that the box would not fit in the intended area and attempted to stop the box’s trajectory by grabbing it. During this manoeuvre the Traffic Marshal Supervisor is reported to have experienced a sharp pain in his back .On experiencing discomfort The Traffic Marshal Supervisor sat down then laid down on the floor until the pain subsided.The Traffic Marshal Supervisor was unable to move for approximately 3-5 minutes . When he was able to move again , he went to the office to undertake some laminating . While in the office The Traffic Marshal Supervisor was approached and discussed his circumstance with The Induction Administrator at approximately 10.30 , The The Induction Administrator referred The Traffic Marshal Supervisor to [NAME]  who happened to be at [NAME]  that day.The Traffic Marshal Supervisor then left site to travel home 13.52 . All person to receive refresher briefing on correct manual handling techniques. A general ( e .g . in line with HSE guidance ) assessment of manual handling should be compiled.The manual handling assessment sheet should be communicated to all site operatives. A briefing on the immediate reporting of incidents is to be compiled and communicated to all personnel and operatives .

description: The IP stumbled/tripped on a prepared walkway , banging his knee as he fell , while walking into a temporary office during a shift as a security guard.The incident was not regarded by the IP as being significant at the time , no accident report was made by the IP and there were no witnesses to the event . After finishing work at the scheduled time the IP returned to his home address where his knee `ballooned up ' to such an extent that it was necessary for him to attend the local ( <NAME> <NAME> ) hospital that evening.The IP has a history of serious general health issues and despite the fact that there was no injury other than a swollen knee it was decided that as a precautionary measure he should remain in hospital and this situation remained until release on the morning of <NAME> 09 <NAME> report is being raised by virtue of the fact that the IP was detained in hospital for a period in excess of 24 hours and therefore constitutes a Major Injury as defined under RIDDOR 1995.It remains unclear whether the stay in hospital was the result of the incident , the result of an underlying health issue or a combination of both . The IP has been released from hospital and our occupational health service provided have been engaged in order to help find the best possible resolution for all concerned .

description: An incident occurred when an operative was carrying repair work on a sign post following storm damage. riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The injured party erected his step ladders in an area where these site manager had stored mobile tower components at ground level . He did not clear the area or request the area to be cleared prior to setting his step ladders to run new electrical cabling . Once the cable had been located in the ceiling void he descended the ladders and whilst stepping off the bottom rung of the ladder he stood on a mobile tower component and rolled his ankle . The injured casualty removed his safety boot from his injured right foot where swelling was noticeable . The first aider ([NAME] ) ensured that an ambulance was called immediate incase of a possible break . Myself and the site manger then moved the injured person to the site office where we applied a cold compress and elevated his ankle whilst waiting for the paramedic to arrive . Once the paramedic arrived approx 1 hour later he assessed the ankle and informed the injured party and myself that the most probable injury was a sprained/brused ankle , however would advise attending A & E for an X-Ray to ensure the diagnosis . The paramedic offered to take the injured person to A & E however this offer was declined as he chose to call a family member to take him in as he did not want to leave his vehicle on site . I later spoke with the injured parties employer who confirmed that the injury was in fact a sprain as diagnosed by the paramedic . All areas to be thoroughly inspected to ensure clear work areas prior to work activities being undertaken .

0n the [Date] [NAME] was inducted by [NAME] ( Principal Contractors ) to work for [NAME]  as a labourer supplied by  [NAME] . The induction was delivered in his native [Name], after which a toolbox talk on manual handling was also delivered in his native language . He signed the induction form and the toolbox talk and was put to work by [NAME], his foreman, to move materials from the delivery van to the required work areas . Some materials ( small ones ) were loaded onto a trolley and taken around the building via the loading bay , and other longer materials were fed through a window to a lay down area by the contractors office on the ground floor . The load in question was approximately 2.4m long ( a bundle of approximately 10 pieces of timber , weighing around 54kg ) . The foreman ,  [NAME] and his work partner were due to go on a break , so told [NAME] and his work partner, [NAME] to move the smaller stuff and leave the bigger stuff until they got back . [NAME] was inside the building and [NAME] was pasing wood through the window . He told [NAME] to wait for him so they could lift together , but [NAME] attempted to lift the load himself from the middle . In doing this he hurt his back . An ambulance was called and he was taken to the [NAME] where he was admitted and had numerous tests . The diagnosis was that this was a muscular injury and he was prescribed strong painkillers and physiotherapy .

Replacing glass in front door , Transcribed from discussion with IP I removed the new glass from his van , then removed the glazing cassette from the door , I placed the cassette on the floor to fix the glazing tape to the cassette as it was the easiest thing to do . While in a kneeling position I turned to the right to pick up the glazing cassette but as turning and going to pick it up I felt a sharp pain in my right side . I rang my supervisor asking if there was anyone close by to come and assist me . Following a discussion with the IP it was thought best in the future to use his work mate to place the cassette on to carry out the repair rather than in a kneeling position , that said it could have been any other type of low level job he was carrying out which could have resulted in the incident .

description: The information gatheredduring interviews with the above conducted on the 25th <NAME> <NAME> confirms the followingsequence of events . Operatives were working inside the confined space applying  Flexcrete844 by trowel to the reservoir soffit . Three mobile alloy towers were deployed inside thetank providing access to the soffit for <NAME> , <NAME> and <NAME> . <NAME> was preparing mixedFlexcrete 844 for the others to apply . At approximately 10:30 am <NAME> had finished hisapplication of Flexcrete844 and climbed down from the alloy tower and went to go aroundthe back of the tower when his left leg slipped on the tarpaulin positioned over thereservoir floor and gully to capture fallen materials . <NAME> foot slipped into the 150 mmdeep gully causing him to fall forward and as a result <NAME> left knee twisted and landedon the edge of the gully and the reservoir concrete floor . None of the team actually saw <NAME> fall but all confirm hearing call out in pain at the time he fell and that he reported hurting his knee . <NAME> was able to walk unaided from the tank and permit records showthat the team exited the tank at 10:50 am.The team re-entered the confined space 11:45 am and continued to work until 2 pm when <NAME> reported to <NAME> ( site supervisor ) that he could not continue to work as his knee was extremely painful . <NAME> tried to climb down the alloy tower unaided but was notable to put any weight on this left knee . <NAME> and <NAME> helped get <NAME> down from thealloy tower before assisting him to the access ladder within the tank . <NAME> was winchassisted out of the tank before being taken to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> for treatment .

Labourer <NAME> <NAME> was on site when an external plant hire company arrived on site to collect a piece of plant ( towable generator ) . <NAME> was first point of contact for the hire company representative and showed him where the item of plant was . <NAME> (uninstructed ) went to hook the towbar of the generator on to the external company 's vehicle . <NAME> had n't realised that the handbrake was still on and thus when he pulled to lift the generator it did not move and <NAME> felt a pull on a muscle in his lower back area . <NAME> called the site foreman ( <NAME> <NAME> ) to assist who called the company health & Safety Manager to report the incident . The health and Safety manager asked <NAME> to bring <NAME> to the head office to complete an accident report form and internal accident investigation form . From the internal accident investigation , the health & Safety Manager noted that <NAME> had a pre existing back problem and he felt the moving of this item had triggered a reoccurence of this and that he would now require to visit his GP to advise of the extent of the injury . The health and Safety manager advised <NAME> to go to visit his GP and advice the company of the outcome , as if off for more than 3 consecutive days , this injury would become a reportable injury to the health & Safety Manager . The health & Safety Manager also advised <NAME> that this injury had occured from <NAME> carrying out a task of which he should not have been involved in as the plant hire representative was the person who was trained to operate the piece of plant ( including delivery & collection ) and that although he had acted to assist the representative , the decision he had made had resulted in an injury to himself . <NAME> was also advised that if the collection of the item of plant was a two man job then the hire company should recognise this and provide two operatives to deliver and collect plant .

riskcat: Slip or trip on same level
description: The activity involved the construction of a geo-grid reinforced granular beam approx 3 m wide x 2 m deep x 50 m in length built 100 mm offset to an existing sheet pile wall.  Works were 50% complete at time. Steel road plates were being installed as temporary formwork to support the front face of the beam during construction.  The plates were secured at the toe by embedding into clay material at the bottom of the excavation and propped against the steel pile with timber connection hook at top of the plate a secondary rope support was also provided.  The plates were being lifted and placed into position using a tracked excavator and associated lifting accessories and held in position until secured. The placement of the geo-grid matress and granular fill material then proceeded in layers.  on completion of the fill the props were removed and the plate lifted out leaving the self supporting geo-grid beam.  At the time of the incident 2 no steel plates were being used one next to the other in preperation for placement of the geo-grid and granular material on the next section of beam.  During lifting of the second plate it came into contact with the first plate causing it to move and fall to the ground.the operative involved in the activity advised he was a safe distance away from the plate but moved further back as a precaution and tripped whilst doing so.  However, no injuries were sustained and micheal continued to work for the rest of the shift.  in addition, no damages were caused to any plant or equipment.immediate action taken - reviewed methodology and re-briefed all personnel involvedaction proposed to prevent recurrence - only one plate to be installed at any one time.  Props must be suitable and inspected before each entry.  previous plate must be securely propped before additional plates installed.  ensure all personnel stand clear of the load until it has been placed down into the excavation.

description: The IP's job is a spotter for over height / weight / length vehicles at the [NAME] river crossing . TheIP was walking on a made tarmac footpath and states he fell over . The IP has subsequently reported unfit for work due to aggravating a pre exiting back injury that occurred in a road traffic collision 3 years previous . The absence length takes him to the end of his contracted employment . Inspection of the footpath has shown no visible defects or pot holes that would lead to a fall . [NAME] was working in the front bedroom of the property , repairing a window . He removed the sash ( whilst still glazed ) in order to carry out repair to damaged friction hinges . Upon lifting sash out of position he aggravated a pre-existing back injury . [NAME] took pain killers shortly after and continued in work that day . [NAME] confirms work area was well lit and clear of obstructions . He was also wearing required PPE. [NAME] did not report injury to his supervisor until later that afternoon . Actions Taken to prevent recurrence - Manager to 1 ) Review , update risk assessment and method statement to ensure injured person was working to safe systems of work - if he was not clarify why he worked outside of the assessment to ascertain reason for accident 2 ) RAMS to be updated if required and communicated to staff 3 ) Provide toolbox talk / guidance on accident , risks and control measures to operatives 4 ) Ensure adequate supervision and monitoring of work activities 5 ) Assess further training needs 6 ) Manager to reinforce message of employees duties to report accidents / incidents immediately so that investigation can be conducted 7 ) Manager to communicate to employees the importance of reporting accidents / incidents and to be aware of RIDDOR report requirements . This report has been made late due to confusion in relation to employee reporting accident and manager being unaware that sickness was not specifically due to pre-existing back injury . At the time of the reported accident , [NAME]  informed a supervisor that he was ok to continue work and took pain killers ( his manager was off the day of the incident ) . He did however call in sick the following day informing his manager that it was due to back pains . The Manager did not ask at that time if it was work related and assumed it was pre-existing . As a result no accident investigation was conducted . This sickness was queried as part of the H & S audit process and during investigation it was noted as an over 7 days reportable incident .

The injured person had been carrying out the removal of existing ceiling joists and the installation of new ceiling joists on the previous day and upto the time of the injury on the second day . This involved the manual handling of the joists as a multiple person lift and the measuring and cutting of timber joists at ground level.The persons carrying out this task had dynamically assessed how theyy were going to be able to lift and lower the joists and had considered mechanical lifting aids before deciding that the most practicable and safest way of performing the task was to manually handle the joists.This had been carried out successfully on the first day without incident when removing the old joists , on the second day they were installing the new joists . They had installed 2 new joists when the injured person had bent down to measure and cut the third joist when he felt pain in his lower back . He then was attended to by the site first aider and taken home to seek medical advice .All manual handling activities that are carried out will be assessed prior to carrying out the task . Manual Handling Training for all staff is to be refreshed .Manual Handling risk assessment training is to be refreshed for all staff. Review of current SSoW for the task and amendments carried out and communicated where required .

A subcontract joiner was fitting a door set ; the door had been removed and the door frame was placed in position and was loosely fixed by 2 screws . As the joiner went to get his battery screwdriver the frame started to topple over and hit the shoulder/neck of an apprentice joiner who was walking past at the time . The injured party was checked over by the site first aider who found , apart from a small graze , no obvious injury . However , as he was experiencing discomfort he went to the hospital where he was assessed and was told to take some pain killers , it was suggested that it was possibly soft tissue damage .As the injured party was still experiencing discomfort he visited his GP (<NAME>) who signed him off work for 2 weeks .Following an investigation it was agreed that the risk assessment for the activity be revised to reflect the need for materials to be adequately fixed in position , with tools at hand to secure fully . This revision will be communicated by means of toolbox talks .

The employee was working on a geothermal drilling project on the site at  [NAME] . There has apparently been a piling mat install as we requested , but on the first day we thought that it was not sufficient as the machine made ruts on entering the site . The site is very small.The drilling crews went about the task to drill holes , but over the course of the next week or the ground conditions under foot became very sloppy , with [NAME] present all over the site . While the crews where working they where having to pull/twist their feet out of the clay . The crew where performing their routine manual handling tasks of drilling rods . The ground conditions under foot where not sufficient for walking and driving a telehandler on site . One employee obtained a back injury from the twisting and pulling of his feet out of the clay . Resulting in 9 days of work . We have since discussed this with the client and they have a mini digger on site to scrap back the clay to the suppose piling mat and a pump to pump away any water . The works are stopped until the site is safe to move around in and move our plant . One the [NAME] has been removed the site should be safe to work in again . We have extra staff on site to keep the situation under review .

description: The injured person <NAME> <NAME> ( IP ) was one of 5 people passing a roof truss from a completed 1st floor zone up to the top of the timber frame walls . The trusses were being laid flat on top of the wall panels in readiness to be fixed in to their final position . 3no . operatives were at the bottom of the truss with 2 further operatives on the scaffold above .The process was 80 % complete when the incident occurred . As the three operatives picked up the truss to lift it upwards the IP slipped and stumbled back on to a small pack of timber frame panels . His left leg went in between the studs in the panels and he dropped his end of the truss . His body weight forcing him to over extend his knee backwards.The IP sat down for a 5 minutes as there was a lot of pain in his leg . Another operative took the IP 's place and the task was completed . The IP continued to work installing insulation the the wall and other light duties . Two hours later the IP left site as the pain was n't going away . Whilst driving home the pain became increasingly worse and he decided to go to hospital to get an x-ray . The initial findings were inconclusive and an MRI scan was required . Results showed no fracture and IP was advised of a severe strain and to rest until the pain has gone away. A full review of the <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> assessment have subsequently been carried out . Toolbox talks have been given regarding manual handling . All operatives have been told to make sure the work area is clear and free of all material .

<NAME> <NAME> site fitters <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> attended site to carry out additional work to structural steelwork that had previously been fitted . A crane was on site to install hollocore flooring . While other trades were laying the flooring they found a fixed steel column had been designed incorrectly by the clients design team , and needed to be altered onsite . They could not cut the hollocore flooring as it was load bearing and decided the fixed steel column was to be altered instead.The site agent asked <NAME> <NAME> operatives <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> and <NAME> <NAME> if they could cut back the stanchion to accommodate the hollocore flooring. <NAME> , our senior fitter , said he would , once a safe working platform had been erected . Both operatives carried on with the works they had been sent to site to carry out.The site agent brought an excavator over to the stanchion . He then asked <NAME> <NAME> if he would get in the excavator bucket so he could be elevated to the cutting height and cut the stanchion with a 9 " angle <NAME> <NAME> refused to do this and told the site agent this is not the correct way to do this safely .The site agent repeatedly asked <NAME>  and <NAME> <NAME> to do this . Following the continued pressure , eventually <NAME> <NAME> said he would do it.The site agent operated the excavator and hoisted <NAME> <NAME> to the cutting height and got out the machine , leaving it unattended .Mr <NAME> started cutting the stanchion , approximately 15 minutes later the bucket tilted downsending <NAME> <NAME> out of the bucket , hanging on a block wall next to the stanchion . He then dropped approximately 4.00m to the floor.Both <NAME> <NAME> , and <NAME> <NAME> were informed by Managing <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> on their return to the company that this was unacceptable practice , and completely against company policy . <NAME> <NAME> was informed that he should seek medical advice if he felt unable to fulfil his duties , and inform one of the directors of any outcome . There will be a review on his return to work , and appropriate action will be taken . A further toolbox talk is due to be held this week with all site operatives on this incident and the unacceptable requests from site agents are to be referred back to management . In NO way are operatives to go against their <NAME> training and company health and safety procedures .

During installation of rear first floor replacement window , installer climbed ladder to access aperture for replacement window . As he reached working height of approx 3 metres , the foot of the ladder slipped backwards , because only one ladder spur had been fitted , and the patio slabs were wet . Risk Assessments for working at height and ladder work are also in place . An accident investigation has been completed . As a result , a tool box talk was held on <NAME>  to discuss the importance of working safely at height . Current methods , training , and risk assessments were discussed , and the importance of working to these practices was made clear . It is considered that no further action is required at this time in order to prevent similar incidents occuring .

description: I was employed as a night site manager by <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> at <NAME> <NAME> . The project involved fitting out of offices and a warehouse . Work was being done at night.On my first evening at work , [17th <NAME> 2013] , I inspected the site and made note of a number of issues . The most serious issue was a lack of lighting both in the offices where work was being done and around the site compound , which was pitch black after 10pm . Overall the site was very untidy and in my opinion unsafe .At approximately 01.00 that morning [Tues ] I was returning from site to the site office I was forced to walk through a narrow walkway between a skip and the site fencing . I tripped and fell heavily on the concrete foot of the <NAME> fencing , which was protruding into the walkway . I noted the accident in the site diary and asked for it to be recorded in the accident book . The next day I discovered this was not done , I decided I would write to my agency manager to express my concerns . I did this the following morning , <NAME> <NAME> , and was requested to approach the company directly regarding site safety issues.At 00.40 <NAME> a representative of the company came to site . I repeated my concerns with regards to the site set up . I told him that I had tripped and hurt myself in the pitch black and wanted the accident recorded . He refused and responded Well that s how it is , and if you dont like you can fuck offSince the accident the company have further refused to file a RIDDOR report . As of the night of <NAME> <NAME> no action has been taken to prevent similar incidents occurring .

description: IP was opening the main entry/exit gate to the depot . The gate is wide and heavy , split into 2 hinged halves which swing inwards to open . The gates are opened from the inside , the gates are accessed from the inside by using a separate pedestrian gate . IP unlocked the main gate and turned to pull the right hand side open by trailing it behind . The gate has a gap of approx 200mm between the bottom and the road surface at the start ( when closed ) . IP caught their left heel under under the gate as they walked foraward trailing the gate behind . The momentum of the gate made the trapping effect worse , jamming the thier left foot between the bottom of the gate and the road . IP sustained damaged to the achillies tendon on the left leg. Remedial Actions :1. Stop opening the gate by dragging behind person opening it .2 . Install signage warning of potential trappinf hazard .3 . Mark  road with hatched area to avoid while opening gate .4 . Install a mechanical open/close system to eliminate manual opening/closing .

description: On the morning of <NAME>  , between 7.10 am and 7.30am I slipped and fell at the above address , aggravating my sciatica . As a result my GP has signed me off as unfit for work for a period of two weeks .The circumstances of the accident were as follows : I was approaching the back door to my office at the rear of the house , accessing from the terrace area next to the pool house . I unlocked the door and stepped onto the threshold . The threshold was wet and it was dark . My foot slipped sideways off the threshold and I was pitched sideways . The sciatica is on my right side . I effectively did the splits as I fell but managed to stay off of the floor . I stayed at work for an hour and a half or so , organising people as they arrived and setting things up , I reported the accident to my line manager <NAME> and then left to go and see my GP.  My GP prescribed pain killers and 2 weeks off work . I have also sought treatment from a bone doctor. <NAME> <NAME>

The IP is employed as a gas installer , at the time of the accident he was involved in the removal of redundant heating cabinets from flats in the tower block , <NAME> <NAME> . These cabinets are the size of a small cupboard used to previously house heating boilers , they are made up of metal frames . There was a specific risk assessment drawn up for this task where manual handling was recognised as an issue and employees were instructed that the cabinet frames must be cut into small manageable sizes prior to carrying them to the lifts for removal from the blocks . The IP strained his shoulder carrying a section of this frame to the lift.The IP has had manual handling training and he has been referred to occupational health. The IP has not yet been formally interviewed by his manger to ascertain why he had not cut down the frame to a manageable size .

The Injured party ( IP ) was working with a number of colleagues to prepare wooden stop planks which were to be fitted into a canal , at a later date ; to form a temporary dam structure . In preparing these stop planks a small machine had been used to transport the planks into position ready for cutting to size in the workshop area . The machine operator was redirected to another task , whilst two team members continued to cut and prepare stop planks . Following manually lifting a number of these cut stop planks the IP felt his back stiffen up towards the end of the working day . The IP attended work on <NAME>  <NAME> but realized that he was still suffering from a stiff back and was n't fit for work . The IP stayed off work , returning on <NAME> <NAME> . The injury took place in our workshop area , which is dry , flat , well lit.The planks when cut to size are 5150mm x 230mm x 150mm <NAME> <NAME> to grade c24 with an approx . individual weight of 74.62Kg ( taken from TRADA timber stop plank calculator ) . The IP has received specific training in ' Safe lifting techniques ( with problem solving ) ' & and manual handling in general.The following actions have been taken in the first instance : - Ensure machine available to undertake all lifting of this size stop plank to remove chance of manual handling injury. - Check with engineering team on calculations in TRADA stop plank calculator the value for the individual plank weight is thought to not be correct for the type of timber used ( provide more accurate information for supervisor and team members ).- review the Manual handling assessment which is in place for this activity .

The power bar method has been used on numerous occasions without incident and is believed to the safety method for removing bolts. However alternative methods are being investigated.

While Lowering an electrical control panel from the rear of a transit van to a bogey below ( 1.5ft drop <NAME> was in the rear of the van and when lowering his end of the panel onto the bogey meant he had to bend and turn the panel before lowering down onto the bogey . This awkward back position while supporting the weight of the panel caused <NAME> to twist his back and could no longer perform his duties thereafter.This was first thing in the morning @ 07.10am and trying to un-load the panel to move it onto site to allow them to mount it within the boilerhouse . Electrician was loading van with materials before travelling to site . Several materials were loaded on the van including a cable drum complete with cable . This was a team lift and they were loading into the back of renault master ( transit size ) . They had to lift the drum approximately 400mm where upon it could be slid into the van . The injured person did not feel any issue at the time of the lift but when he travelled to site approximately 1.5hrs from the head office his back had stiffened up and he was unable to continue work . The individual has manual handling training but has had issues with his back in the past . We are intending to issue a toolbox talk and a briefing to all our staff regarding this incident and safe manual handling . There is a forklift truck available on site for the loading of materials that staff do not feel confortable about manually handling . At the time of the morning when the individual was loading the van there was no driver available for the forklift truck . We are arranging additional training to ensure we have sufficient driver coverage . All staff will be reminded in the toolbox talk that when there are materials requiring a forklift to load that this should be prearranged to ensure there is driver availability .

Injury occurred when entering microbiology plant room . The operative carried on working and no further symptoms were noticed until around 20:30hrs , when he felt pain in his mid-back region . The IP was apprentice joiner who was undertaking works with a chop saw , whist undertaking a cutting operation he was distracted and brought down the blade which made contact with his left thumb causing a small cut to the base of his nail . Following the incident the chop saw was visually checked and was found to be in good operating order with a good blade with sharp cutting edge and guard operating sufficiently .

Electrician was under floor wiring at front door . The IP glanced in and proceeded to go around the side of the hatch where she lost her balance resulting in her falling feet first into the foundation . The tenant scraped her lower stock and an ambulance was called due to the injured person being pregnant .

The premises are a private dwelling currently undergoing insurance subsidence repair by <NAME> . The toilet/bathroom in question , following agreement and knowledge of the householder , <NAME> <NAME> , whilst undergoing plasterwork and minor cracks work was being used to store equipment/materials . It was also agreed that the complete bathroom suite would be covered in protective protek , visqueen and hardboard . This in itself would prevent access or use of the toilet or other items . [Name] operatives left the room at 16 30 hours <NAME> and all was in order . ( There is dispute between the injured person and operatives whether she was told not to use this toilet ). About 0330 hours despite there being a commode in her room and another toilet in the premises <NAME> <NAME> chose to use the toilet in question . After toilet use she stood up and tripped over a cardboard box , fell and was injured bumping her right knee with reddening caused to her left forehead . She rang 111 and was advised to attend hospital . An ambulance attended and she was taken to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> where her knee was diagnosed as a soft tissue injury . ( of more concern was that she had high blood pressure ) . <NAME> <NAME> , following observations , discharged herself from hospital about 4pm on <NAME>  and has been told to rest and take painkillers. <NAME> has a history of physical problems , is disabled and under medication . She had a choice of a walking frame , crutches or sticks but didnt use anything during this toilet visit.All on site works have been suspended pending this accident investigation and a meeting with the <NAME> <NAME> which occurred earlier today . Hence this report has followed when witnesses have been spoken to in order to ascertain the facts of the accident . [Name] accident book reference <NAME>

The site operative (scaffold competent person ) was assisting to remove the front elevation scaffold . While waiting for others to finish their tasks he put his weight on a scaffold pole which he thought was a standard extending all the way to the ground . The pole in question was only an intermediate support for handrails and it was already whose fixings were already removed and could not carry the weight of the operative . The person involved tried to hold on to the pole but lost his balance . He slided on the first floor and then landed on his shoulder and back at ground floor . He sustained minor abrasions and reported pain on his right leg . He was taken to [NAME]  Hospital where he was examined and released on the same day .Following the accident , the operations stopped until it was determined what caused the accident . The removal of the scaffolding was completed two days later without any other occurrence . Members of staff were consulted and information was provided about the accident . Information was provided on how to ensure safety while working at height .

description: <NAME> stepped over some installed low level electrical ladder racking to get to the work area to continue installing 54mm diameter copper pipework when he accidently tripped on the ladder racking , falling forward and hitting his face on an adjacent gas pipe , marking his face and suffering some minor damage to his teeth with a grazed knee . The principle contractor has extended the handrail on the walkway to prevent future operative access and has introduced specific hazard notification on roof works in all future site inductions whilst introducing further signage at roof level .

Injured Person ( IP ) arrived on site and reversed lorry into gateway , being supervised by [NAME]  ( [NAME] employee ) . As the width of the opened double gates were only just wide enough for lorry to fit through the IP had dropped the sides of his lorry before reversing . When IP had reversed as far as possible there was n't room for him to get down the side to rear of vehicle and the pedestrian gate was locked . The IP said that he decided that the only way to get to rear of lorry to unload was to was to go up the front access ladder , walk across vehicle bed and down the rear access ladder . IP then went up the front ladder , over packs of slates and onto some stacked pallets . The IP said that the pallets were all different sizes and unstable . He said he stepped on to the top pallet which tipped up and he fell forwards off the pallets and onto the tarmac below , landing on right side of body , wrist and hitting his head .  [NAME] went to IP aid , called site agent who applied first aid and IP manager ( [NAME] ) was notified . IP was taken to [NAME] hospital  A & E by his manager and was discharged same day . According to IP statement weather was fine and dry but pallets were moist due to being outside in damp/wet conditions.IP manager has re-iterated to all drivers importance of adhering to company safe systems of work , site delivery instructions , and liaisoning with site personnel .

A 3T excavator , operated by <NAME> <NAME> was being manouevred around the end of the retaining wall . <NAME> was taking care to avoid striking the retaining wall on eone side and trees on to the rear. <NAME> was working in the same area and needed to walk past the excavator . <NAME> had the excavator in a position facing <NAME> , but <NAME> failed to get <NAME> 's attention , continuing to approach the excavator assuming <NAME> was aware of him. <NAME> started to slew the excavator , checking over his shoulder to avoid the wall . When <NAME> turned to face forward he began to move the excavator bucket ( 1.2m wide ) , into a space <NAME> had entered . The bucket struck <NAME> on his left side and pushed him against the concrete wall. <NAME> sustained injuries to his left arm and ribs . He was taken to <NAME> <NAME> 's hospital where he was X-rayed and released the same evening after it was estblished that he had no cuts or broken bones , but bruising to his left arm and ribs .

Our employee was fixing a head section of a set of bi-folding doors by drilling fixings up into aluminium. It was reported that the employee was wearing PPE (safety goggles), but a small fragment of swarf got behind them and entered his right eye. Eye wash was immediately used on the day. The issue got slightly worse the next day so the employee visited the local A & E for assessment and treatment. His eye is now perfectly OK. Additional training has now been given with regard to the importance of PPE. A meeting has been taken to confirm all our installers have wrap around safety goggles to protect their eyes and also random spot checks will take place on sites to ensure our installers are complying with our PPE requirements.

IP was using the falcon blast machine to carry out an asbestos clean within the boiler room area . The IP accidentally lost control of the lance/handle allowing the grit blast material to make contact with his left leg , just above the knee , resulting in an abrasion injury the to the skin .

description: The operative was carrying out soft etrip out works , incident occurred when operative was removing 2.4 x 1.2 piece of plywood with granite bonded to it , when taking down lost grip / footing , got pushed back into wall and sustained small cut to his chin.Operative went to site office where a plaster was applied to chin and was then asked if felt ok to continue working or alternatively could go home to rest .
he was passing trim down to lower level and it slipped from hands and cut his arm on the trim .

An unauthorised/untrained site operative was operating a three tonne capacity forward tipping dumper ( moving soil ) . The operative was thrown from the dumper when it overturned while executing a turning manoeuvre , the operative was not wearing a safety restraint at time of incident and jumped clear of the overturning dumper resulting in soft tissue damage . The operative in question was observed earlier operating the dumper by his manager and was reprimanded and instructed not to operate the dumper under any circumstances as there was more than adequate numbers of trained operatives on site . A short while later the operative involved mounted the dumper again and the incident occurred . The operative was transported to the local hospital ( <NAME> <NAME> ) where his injuries were assessed as soft tissue damage immediate action taken after a preliminary investigation was a toolbox talk was communicated to all sites concerned .supervisor to ensure a up to date training matrix is available on site , a list of trained/authorised operators displayed in site office .Supervisors to ensure only trained/authorised operatives are selected to carry out plant operations. Operator involved will be subjected to a internal disciplinary procedure

Our sub contractors had set up a walk way around a concrete delivery lorry on the public highway . the walk way consisted of herras fencing panels , as far as i am aware these were placed in heavy duty feet , tied back to the lorry and clipped together to ensure the did not fall over . As far as i am aware the wind blew hard against the fence and forced it out into the live carridgeway and into the path of an oncomming motorcycle .

The IP was conducting his normal duties as a road worker . His team were tasked to remove a bus shelter that had previously had an electric supply . The electricity supply had been disconnected by the electricity supplier prior to the work being allocated . The team commenced removing concrete from around the legs of the shelter when the IP reached into the hole to remove a piece of concrete debris . During this activity he claims to have received an electric shock , he remained in work for the remainder of the day but decided to see his GP the following day as he had muscular pains in his left arm and shoulder . The doctor signed him off for a period of one week . The matter has been reported back to the electricity supplier to determine if a supply cable was left in proximity of the shelter after the disconnect had taken place .

There is scaffolding erected over a public pathway with no provisions made to go around the scaffolding therefore pedestrians have no other option than to walk under the scaffolding . There was workmen doing repair work to roof . My eleven year old girl walked under the scaffolding and something fell and struck her in the face . Workmen acknowledged she had been struck by falling debris and apologised to my daughter and myself . Unable to contact scaffolding company to report incident . Reported to local authority on <NAME> who informed me as erected over public highway a permit is required and that they would go and inspect scaffolding to see if any safety breaches had been made . Local authority made inspection and informed me that it needed "double boarding " as there were indeed gaps that debris could fall through . Also informed that they did NOT actually have a permit for this scaffolding to be erected . Safety measures have still not been put in place so this still remains a danger to the public .

Worker was removing data trunking from a wall , using step ladder to access upper fixings . Reminded staff and contractors in the safe use of access equipment including scafold towers available on site .

Unloading steel from wagon with craneSteel & site wagon entered site to be unloaded . [NAME] & [NAME] Banksman banked wagon onto site , wagon stopped and parked up outside banksman shed . [NAME] [NAME] got out of vehicle . Steel was pre marked as to where the slings should be positioned to be lifted by the crane . [NAME]  was stood on the back of the vehicle towards the cabin end . The short slings had been positioned as per markings and the crane hooks had been attached to the slings .  [NAME] was waiting for tension to come on the front sling so he could detach the ratchet strap attached to the vehicle .The tension comes onto the back sling towards the rear of the vehicle , it begins to lift the steel from the back whilst the  [NAME] is stood at the cabin end of the vehicle . The strap is still slack at the cabin end of the vehicle . The steel was lifted , the angle that the steel was loaded onto the vehicle created tension on the vehicle ratchet strap at the cabin end causing it to snap and resultantly impact [NAME] in the stomach causing him to jump down of the vehicle before the steel hit him again in its balancing motion .
One of our site operatives was pointing to the inside of the building . The injured party took his safety glasses off to clean and looked up and some lime plaster fell into his right eye .

The injured person was striking a birdcage scaffold , passing down boards from the top lift and got a splinter in the palm of his right hand . The injured person was taken to <NAME> <NAME> hospital where they cut open his hand a bit , removed the splinter and gave him two stitches . The injured person returned to college .

Changing parts on lift car and using 2 spanners to undo a 6mm nut and bolt , a spanner slipped , causing hand to contact side of part , causing small graze on knuckle of right hand through safety gloves . He continued to work normally through the week without complaint or registering the incident . The incident happened on the <NAME> of <NAME> but as it was not reported at the time , we have no time of the incident , this incident was only notified on the <NAME> <NAME> to our company representative , but did mention this to the <NAME> <NAME> site <NAME> on the <NAME> of <NAME> , where he complained of swelling to his right hand.There is no record of this incident . He returned to site on the <NAME> to record the incident as an accident , after being treated for an abscess to his right hand . Steps to prevent similar incidents are to train staff to report all incidents however small or insignificant they may seem . Also to ensure that checks are daily with employees at end of shift that all is well
Coming down a step ladder from the roof . Stepped off the second rung of the step ladder onto a piece of chipboard . Foot went through chipboard up to knee height .

The ip was working in the kitchen and wearing ppe. he was kneeling down in a corner to do pipework. as he stood up he caught the back of his his gloved hand on the sharp brackets that were standing proud of the wall, cutting the back of his hand. it was noticed that the glove fabric to the rear of the hand was much thinner than the rest of the glove, which was rubberised. rather than look at ppe, the system of work has been altered such that brackets will be removed or taped prior to works where there is no radiator fitted. <NAME>

A scaffold type hand rail around the top of the north service trench gave way when lent on , resulting in the injured person fallining approx 2.7m into the bottom of the concrete trench . His fall was partially broken by a gas pipe , he landed on his back in the bottom of the trench and banged his head on the wall/floor .

Ip was working in the matwell area on the edge of the building under construction,at about 2.30pm the ip was struck on the side of his helmet by a connector attached to a rubber supply pipe which had been used for screeding.I understand that screeding operations had finished on the second floor of the building under construction an operative was either lowering or let the rubber supply pipe fall this has not been confirmed either way as the pipe came down it struck the ip as he was bending down to undertake his task. He was given assistance by the people around him at the time, the screeding company operative once he relized what had happened came down and spoke to the ip.
The employee opened a bottle of ( hydochloric ) acid - And was exposed to the fumes . Direct contact was ( not ) made with the substance .

The injured party ( IP ) was working on the roof of the building carrying out insulation and waterproofing works . Weather conditions at the time were fine . While carrying out the new roofing works , the IP selected a fixing , comprising of a metal screw and plastic sleeve , and attempted to remove the fixing from the tube in order to use a longer screw . The fixing was stuck fast in the plastic tube so rather than selecting an alternative fixing , the IP tried to remove the screw from the tube using an electric screw gun . To gain 'leverage ' the IP placed the screw point on his steel toe cap of his boot and bent over , held the plastic tube in one hand and the screw gun in the other . The IP stated that the screw gun was in reverse operation as he started to try and remove the screw , however the end point of the screw slipped backwards off the steel toe cap and to the top of his boot , as it slipped , the IP states that his finger slipped the screw gun into 'forward ' and he screwed the fixing through his boot and into his foot . The IP then 'reversed ' the screw out of his foot . The IP acknowledges that he was carrying out an unauthorised procedure and that he should not have attempted to do the process he did . The IP attended hospital and was given a tetnus injection and oral antibotics . It was declared that no bones had been broken and no veins or tendons had been hit. The screw had been driven into the web between the big toe and second toe. The screw did not penetrate through the foot .
